HEADLINE: Your Money;
I.R.S. Questions Gifts of Insurance

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
Financial advisers fear that a recent ruling by the Internal Revenue Service may place in jeopardy thousands of gifts of life insurance intended to benefit churches, synagogues, educational institutions, hospitals and other charities.
Technically, because it is a private-letter ruling (No. 9110016), it sets no legal precedent for other cases. Still, lawyers and accountants study the I.R.S.'s private-letter rulings to see what positions the service is likely to take, and now they are advising charitably inclined clients in many states to consider other ways of giving. 
 "They've knocked the guts out of one of the most popular techniques for middle-class donors," said Avery E. Neumark, a partner in Weber, Lipshie & Company, certified public accountants, and an adjunct professor at Fordham University. "This was something people took advantage of, and it was great. My clients are very concerned."
The insurance industry has promoted the idea. The current issue of Assets, a newsletter that many insurance agents send to their clients, says: "One excellent way to provide a very substantial benefit at a fraction of the cost is to give cash to a charity, which, in turn, uses the cash to pay life insurance premiums on the donor's life. For a fraction of the total benefit, you can provide a lasting, substantial gift to the charity. In addition, you will receive an income tax benefit along the way." But the I.R.S. ruling makes the strategy problematic.
Neil P. Myerberg, chief executive of planned giving and endowments for the UJA Federation in New York, said, "We haven't had anyone cancel" who gives the charity money to pay premiums on a policy, "but I'm not recommending this to anybody" at present. He is, however, working to persuade legislators to amend New York law to state explicitly that charities have "an insurable interest" in the donor, which would eliminate the I.R.S.'s problem. Many of his counterparts at other charities and in other states and making similar efforts.
Sam Radin, a lawyer who heads the National Madison Group in New York and is a member of the State Bar Association Committees on Charitable Organizations and Gift and Estate Taxes, has also appealed to Albany, arguing that charities, their middle- and upper-class supporters and the poor who are helped are all hurt by the ruling, which will bring in little additional tax revenue.
In the ruling, the I.R.S. said that because New York State law, like that of 35 other states, does not specifically say charities have an insurable interest, a donor who buys a policy and transfers it to a charity would be circumventing New York law. Therefore, the insurer could refuse to pay the proceeds to the charity, or, if it did, the executor of the estate could sue to recover them, the I.R.S. said. Therefore, it concluded, no income-tax or gift-tax charitable deduction may be allowed. The notion of insurable interest came into law in the 19th century, Mr. Radin noted, to prevent policy buyers from "wagering on the life of a stranger." No reputable charity does that, but the law is nevertheless being used against them.
The simplest solution for a New Yorker who wants to donate to a charity, Mr. Radin said, is to buy a policy issued in Connecticut, where the statute recognizes charities' insurable interest. Many New York brokers also hold Connecticut licenses, he noted, so the donor need not travel there. Other states that recognize charities' interest are Arizona, Delaware, Hawaii, Idaho, Kentucky, Maine, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Oregon, Texas and Wyoming.
People who find they no longer need policies for their original purpose and give them to charity need not worry, Mr. Radin noted, because "insurable interest is measured at the time of issue."
But people who have given a policy directly to charity should "try some damage control," Mr. Radin said. "One remedy is to put a provision in the will that directs the executor not to seek recovery of money paid to charity, and if monies are paid to him to give them to charity," he said. Or, it may be possible to rewrite the policy in one of the 14 states specifically recognizing charities' insurable interests.
Mr. Neumark, who serves as New York region president for the Orthodox Union, the umbrella organization for Orthodox synagogues throughout the country, said, "I advise my clients not to shy away from giving to charities, especially in these hard economic times when charities are most in need," but he is looking into other means of making significant, long-term gifts.
Charitable trusts are one avenue. Another possibility is regular gifts of zero-coupon bonds, he said. A current income-tax deduction can be taken, and if the charity has agreed to hold the bonds to maturity, a university chair, for example, or a special project with the donor's name on it could eventually be financed.

HEADLINE: Late Rally Steadies Credit Markets

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
A late rally stabilized the Treasury securities market yesterday after prices were slashed earlier by a flow of Government reports indicating that the economy was rebounding or at least bottoming out.
Before the market opened, for example, the Government reported that its index of leading economic indicators rose in April for the third consecutive month, while factory orders rose for the first time since October. 
 "The data showed an economy that was much stronger than the Street had expected and this triggered the selling from the opening," said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president and credit market specialist at Dean Witter Reynolds. "Bond investors in particular were concerned that the signs of a reviving economy would lessen chances for further easing by the Federal Reserve and it also reawakened the always-latent inflation fears."
What helped end the decline, Mr. Sullivan continued, was a strong demand for dollars in the foreign exchange market late in the day. Although the dollar had been volatile all week, the demand tended to enhance the value of Treasury securities. When the decline ended, some short covering as well as buying by bargain hunters also materalized, he added.
 
 Bellwether Bonds' Range

During the session, the price of the Treasury's bellwether long bonds, the 8 1/8 percent issue maturing in May 2021, ranged between an intraday high of 98 27/32 and a low of 98 5/32. Late in the day, the long bonds were being offered at 98 16/32, down 17/32, to yield 8.26 percent, compared with 8.21 percent the day before and 8.29 percent a week ago.
Among other closely watched Treasury debt issues traded in the secondary market, the 8 percent notes of May 2001 fell 9/32, to 99 21/32, for a yield of 8.05 percent. The new 7 5/8 percent notes of 1996 declined 8/ 32, to 99 23/32, for a yield of 7.69 percent; the new 6 3/4 percent notes of 1993 lost 5/32, at 100 4/32, for a yield of 6.68 percent.
At the short end of the Treasury market, the discount rate on 90-day bills jumped eight basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.53 percent; six-month bills rose four basis points, to 5.67 percent, and the one-year bills gained six basis points, to 5.81 percent.
The Federal Reserve added $1.5 billion of reserves to the banking system for the weekend. The addition was expected and had little if any effect on the key Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans. The funds traded most of the day at 5 3/4 percent, the Fed's perceived target level for this pivotal interest rate, but closed at 6 1/8 percent.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Platinum Up, Palladium Off; Moves Seen as Corrections

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Platinum futures prices rose modestly yesterday in a move widely viewed as correcting an overreaction to news that a Japanese car company had developed a platinum-free catalytic converter.
The futures price of palladium, the alternative metal for the converter, drifted lower after having soared on the same news. 
 Platinum futures settled $1.10 to $1.60 higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with the contract for delivery in June up $1.60 at $376.80 an ounce; palladium was $1.50 to $1.70 lower, with June at $96.35 an ounce.
Both moves were reversals from the previous session, in which platinum plunged and palladium soared on news that the Nissan Motor Company had developed a catalytic converter that substituted palladium and other elements for higher-priced platinum.
 
 40% of Platinum Use at Stake

Catalytic converters, which cleanse automobile exhaust of some harmful gases, account for about 40 percent of platinum consumption.
Analysts said Thursday's drop of more than $20 in platinum and gain of about $6 in palladium were overreactions to the Nissan news.
"Nissan still has a lot of testing to do," said Fred Demler, metals economist with Paine Webber Inc. in New York.
He said it was not clear whether the new converter could be used on all cars, whether it would work with United States gasolines or whether it would meet United States pollution-control requirements.
"Technological change tends to be evolutionary, not revolutionary," Mr. Demler said. "The market reacted Thursday on a revolutionary bias."
Platinum is unlikely to recover all of Thursday's losses in the near term, said Anne Orton, president of Barclays Metals Inc. in New York.
"This announcement has really knocked it down quite a bit," she said, "and I think it's going to have some trouble to get back up in the $390's again."
In precious-metal trading on the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold futures settled $1.70 lower across the board, with June at $361.40 an ounce. Silver was 4.7 to 4.8 cents lower, with July at $4.117 an ounce.
Energy futures fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange, pulled lower by a plunging gasoline market as traders sold the expiring June gasoline and heating oil contracts to escape delivery obligations.
Crude oil settled 19 to 20 cents lower, with July at $21.13 a barrel; heating oil was 0.22 to 0.89 cent lower, with June at 56.48 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.07 cent to 1.4 cents lower, with June at 66.91 cents a gallon; natural gas was 1.5 cents lower to 0.7 cent higher, with July at $1.333 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Grain and soybean futures advanced on the Chicago Board of Trade amid worries about Midwestern crop weather and ideas that the Bush Administration might announce a Soviet food aid package over the weekend.
Wheat futures settled 1 cent to 2 cents higher, with July at $2.87 a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 4 cents higher, with July at $2.45 3/4 a bushel; oats were unchanged to 3/4 cent higher, with July at $1.23 3/4 a bushel; soybeans were 1/2 cent lower to 6 3/4 cents higher, with July at $5.81 3/4 a bushel.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Surges on Optimism At Signs of U.S. Recovery

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar surged against foreign currencies yesterday as investors rode a wave of optimism over prospects for a rebound in the United States economy.
The dollar ended at 1.7425 German marks, up from 1.7190 at Thursday's close, and it rose to 138.35 Japanese yen from 137.80. 
 Traders were encouraged by Government data that suggested the economy would soon shake free from the grip of the 11-month recession.
Factory orders rose in April for the first time in six months, the Government said, and the index of leading indicators rose for the third month in a row.
"Those were the factors that convincingly changed the market," said Chuck Spence, manager of corporate foreign exchange trading for First Interstate Bank.
"It's too soon to say the U.S. economy has bottomed, but the evidence is beginning to tilt the scales in that direction," said Anne Parker Mills of Shearson Lehman Brothers.
Persistent speculation that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union may not be able to hold onto power also supported the dollar, dealers said.
"The market sentiment has changed," Mr. Spence said. "Earlier in the week, the market was bearish on the dollar and the United States economy, and civil unrest in the Soviet Union appeared to be calming."
He said the market was turned around by a string of positive economic indicators ending with the two reports yesterday; comments on Mr. Gorbachev from the departing Director of Central Intelligence, William Webster, and a stock market rally.
The Dow Jones industrial average added 113.59 points this week, or 3.9 percent, to close at a record 3,027.50 yesterday.
"We're now expecting a stronger economy than originally thought, with a turnaround by midyear," said John Krey, international economist at MCM Currency Watch. "The U.S. economy has already bottomed."
But other analysts were less confident about the dollar's direction.
"People should be nervous at these levels," said Varick Martin, manager of foreign exchange in North America for Manufacturers Hanover Trust.
Much of the dollar's gain stems from the mark's weakness, Mr. Martin said.
The British pound fell to $1.6975 from $1.7135. The dollar rose to 1.4855 Swiss francs, from 1.4640 on Thursday, and to 5.9075 French francs from 5.8305.

HEADLINE: Tighter U.S. Mortgage Rules Set

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
The Government said today that it was putting tighter lending standards into place for mortgages backed by the Federal Housing Administration. One lending group charged that the move would reduce home sales by as much as 200,000 annually.
The new rules will require people financing their purchases with F.H.A.-backed mortgages to pay higher closing costs and for the first time they will have to make annual payments for mortgage insurance. 
 "These new regulations could not have come at a worse time," said Warren Lasko, executive vice president of the Mortgage Bankers Association. "These changes will lock out thousands of families who will no longer be able to afford a home."
 
 'Hits Right at Middle America'
 He added that his group, which represents 2,300 mortgage lenders, would lobby Congress to overturn the new regulations. "This requirement hits right at middle America -- young, moderate-income families trying to insure some measure of economic stability for themselves by buying a home," he said.
The F.H.A. said the requirements, which take effect July 1, were required to shore up a mortgage program that is losing $200 million a year. It estimated that the more stringent requirements would prevent 20,000 potential buyers from purchasing homes.
However, housing groups contended that the new rules, which come as the housing industry is struggling to emerge from a two-year slump, go much further than intended by Congress. Mortgage bankers estimated that the new rules could reduce annual home sales by 100,000 to 200,000 annually, enough to abort a housing recovery and to make it more difficult for the overall economy to emerge from the recession.
Jack Kemp, Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, said when the Administration first proposed the requirements last year that they were necessary to "protect the taxpayer from bearing the costs of poor management" of the program.
A recent audit by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, estimated that the F.H.A.'s cumulative losses were approaching $7 billion, partly because the agency did not require sufficiently large down payments. With less of their own cash at risk, homeowners were more likely to default on their mortgages.
One of the new requirements taking effect July 1 will limit closing costs that can be financed in the mortgage to 57 percent. At present up to 100 percent of closing costs can be financed.
That would mean a home buyer taking out a $100,000 F.H.A. loan and facing closing costs of $2,500 would have to pay $1,000 of the closing costs out of pocket, rather than financing the full amount as part of the mortgage.
 
New Insurance Premium
 In addition, F.H.A. home buyers now will have to pay a new annual mortgage insurance premium of five-tenths of 1 percent. Previously, they had been required to pay only an up-front premium of 3.8 percent. On a $100,000 loan, the new premium would add $80 to the monthly payment.
The new rules also require that homeowners refinancing existing F.H.A. loans pay the new insurance premiums.
The mortgage program was set up by Congress in 1934 and provides for 800,000 new loans each year.

HEADLINE: Economic Index Posts 3d Advance In a Sign Recession May End Soon

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
Posting a third straight advance, the Government's main economic forecasting gauge signaled today that the 10-month-old recession would soon be over.
"The end is imminent," said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc. "We're going to have a summer recovery." 
 Although practically no analysts expect a vigorous recovery, those who say the recession will end by midyear have formed a steadily larger consensus in recent weeks. Few now say the recession will extend into the autumn and, in fact, historians may eventually determine that recovery is already under way.
 
Three Consecutive Increases
 The composite index of leading indicators climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Commerce Department reported today, following increases of seven-tenths of 1 percent in March and 1.2 percent in February.
In another positive economic report today, the Commerce Department said orders received by American factories rose in April for the first time in six months. The two reports helped propel the stock market to a record close, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 27.05, to 3,027.50. [Page 35.]
Three straight advances in the leading indicators have almost invariably signaled imminent recovery during the postwar period, the only exceptions being in 1954 and 1961, when the advances were not as strong and the expansion was delayed for one or two quarters.
The leading index has a far less reliable record in forecasting recessions, having predicted many that have failed to occur and giving little or no notice on others. Four straight declines surrounding the October 1987 stock market crash were not followed by recession, and last year the leading index had gains for both May and June, just before the recession began.
Further buoying hopes today, in addition to the figures on factory orders, was a report of a substantial jump in the industrial index compiled by Chicago purchasing managers. The factory orders were foreshadowed by last week's positive statistics on durable goods, a subgroup of that index.
In all, today's figures, "clearly fit with the impression of the recession coming to its end," asserted Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Currency traders were also caught up in the wave of optimism and pushed the dollar higher against foreign currencies.
The data today followed reports on Thursday that showed sales of new homes and personal incomes both rose for the third month in a row, even though consumer spending dipped.
 The rise in the leading index was broad-based and, unlike preceding months when the gains were concentrated in financial and psychological components, "you've got the real stuff this time," Mr. Harris said.
 Of the six advancing components, by far the biggest factor was an increase in new factory orders for consumer goods. The others, ranked by their contribution, were a decline in average weekly initial claims for state unemployment insurance, a rise in the proportion of companies getting slower deliveries from suppliers, higher stock prices, a longer average workweek and an increase in building permits.
 
 Some Negative Forces
 By far the most important of the negative forces was a decline in the University of Michigan's index of consumer expectations. The others were lower contracts and orders for plant and equipment, a decline in unfilled factory orders for durable goods and the tiniest of declines in the M-2 money supply -- less than one-hundredth of a percent. One or two of these, in fact, would probably have risen had it not been for a drop-off of aircraft orders, already heavily backlogged.
The 11th indicator, materials prices especially sensitive to shifts in the business cycle, was unchanged, the department reported.
Today's report also showed that factories' new orders for consumer goods did not decline as much as initially estimated in March and this was the main reason that the overall index for the month was revised to post a gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent instead of five-tenths of 1 percent.
 
 Other Indexes Agree
 Meanwhile, the department's index of coincident indicators fell three-tenths of 1 percent in April, the 10th straight monthly decline but the smallest since August. The index of lagging indicators dropped 1.6 percent, the biggest since November and December 1982, the final months of the 1981-82 recession.
The ratio of the coincident index to the lagging one -- regarded, like the leading index, as a predictor -- rose in April following seven straight declines.
A private forecasting index compiled by Safian Investment Research in White Plains rose six-tenths of a point in April, with 12 of its components up, 9 down and 2 unchanged. More importantly, Kenneth Safian declared, the components assessing the "real" economy posted their first monthly gain since May 1990 and the biggest since March 1987.
"This signals that the recession is over," Mr. Safian said.
The National Bureau of Economic Research, the private group that dates expansions and contractions, said today that its experimental recession index showed that there was only a 2 percent chance the economy would still be in recession in October. A month ago, it put the odds at 3 percent for September.

HEADLINE: Orders to Factories Up First Time in 6 Months

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
Orders received by American factories rose in April for the first time in six months, the Commerce Department said today.
The 1.8 percent gain in April orders, following a revised 2.9 percent drop in March orders, was slightly above the 1.5 percent gain forecast by Wall Street economists. The report provided a new piece of evidence that an economic recovery might be near. 
 The department said earlier today that its key forecasting gauge, the index of leading indicators, rose for a third straight month in April.
Both reports were in line with other economic reports released Thursday that showed personal incomes and new-home sales strengthened in April for a third consecutive month, although another report on Thursday showed consumer spending had fallen slightly in April.
The last time factory orders had risen was in October, when they were up 2.4 percent. Orders fell in each month from November through March as the recession sapped demand and cost thousands of manufacturing jobs in the nation's weakened industrial sector.
A key component of factory orders, durable goods, rose 3.0 percent in April after declining 4.6 percent in March. Durables include items like refrigerators and automobiles that are meant to last at least three years.
Military orders, a volatile category subject to wide monthly swings, rose 12.4 percent in April after declining 15.5 percent in March.
Excluding military orders, the "core rate" of factory orders rose 1.5 percent in April after declining 2.4 percent in March.
Manufacturers' inventories of all types of goods fell two-tenths of 1 percent in April after dropping six-tenths of 1 percent in March. The department noted that inventories have fallen in four of the last five months since hitting a peak last November.
Producers have been holding down stocks of unsold goods, which economists say will speed recovery when consumer spending eventually picks up enough to encourage companies to hire more workers and increase output.
The Bush Administration is forecasting a resumption of growth in the second half of the year.
The Commerce Department reported a week ago that durable goods orders rose 2.9 percent in April, with every major industry except transportation sharing in the increase. But that figure was revised upward to a 3.0 percent gain in today's report.
Transportation equipment orders fell 3.8 percent in April after falling by 4.8 percent in March. Within that category, orders for aircraft and missiles dropped by 29.3 percent, after declining by 6.1 percent in March, and more than offset a gain in motor vehicle orders.
Excluding transportation, factory orders rose 2.6 percent in April after a 2.6 percent fall in March.
Originally, overall factory orders were reported declining 2.8 percent in March but that was revised to a 2.9 percent fall.

HEADLINE: Goldome Closed and Split Between Rivals

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Goldome, New York State's largest savings institution, will be closed and divided between local competitors -- the First Empire Corporation of Buffalo and Keycorp of Albany, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced yesterday. The troubled Buffalo-based savings bank failed to attract the new investors it needed.
Branches of Goldome will open under their new names either Saturday or Monday with no interruption in service or change in deposit insurance coverage. 
 The F.D.I.C., which insures many savings banks as well as commercial banks, expects to lose about $930 million from closing Goldome, making it the sixth-most-costly failure in the agency's history. With $9.9 billion of assets, Goldome was the 13th-largest savings institution in the country. Ten commercial banks in New York are larger than Goldome.
Keycorp's subsidiary banks in Buffalo and Syracuse will acquire 31 branches with about $3.3 billion of deposits, while the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company, a unit of First Empire, will acquire 11 branches in Buffalo with $1.9 billion of deposits.
A Goldome savings and loan association in St. Petersburg, Fla., was seized by Federal regulators yesterday and will be operated by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Government agency handling failed savings and loans.
Customers of the Goldome Realty Corporation, which handles monthly payments for about $14 billion of mortgages around the country, will be shifted to a subsidiary of Keycorp, making it one of the nation's 10 largest mortgage servicing concerns.
"Keycorp and First Empire have been the most logical candidates to acquire Goldome because they are already so large in the western New York market," said Donald J. Kauth, a banking analyst at the First Albany Corporation. Earlier this year both Keycorp and First Empire raised additional capital, which allows them to make acquisitions without any signficant sacrifice of financial strength.
The sale ends a three-year struggle by Goldome's management to save a bank that started the 1980's as a financially sound and profitable Buffalo bank with about $3 billion of assets. Its strength was dissipated during the decade as it acquired weaker New York savings banks with regulators' approval and assistance, and expanded into new markets and new businesses.
Expenses rose more rapidly than profits during the phase of rapid expansion, and some acquisitions -- particularly the Florida savings and loan association -- produced unexpected losses. In addition to losses on some loans for multifamily housing developments, Goldome was hurt in 1989 by changes in accounting rules, which meant it could no longer count good will as part of its capital. The good will, which amounted to $532 million, represented the amount by which payments for acquisitions exceeded the worth of those companies.
The change in accounting rules, plus losses totaling $372 million in 1988 and 1989, left Goldome at the end of 1990 with a negative capital position of $452.4 million. Although the company was insolvent under accounting rules, banking regulators allowed it to stay in business while new management returned it to profitability and searched for fresh capital.
 
 Changing Approach

After Thomas A. Cooper, a former president of the BankAmerica Corporation, became chairman two years ago, Goldome cut non-interest expenses to $255 million in 1990 from $438 million in 1989, and began to concentrate on collecting deposits and making loans to middle-income consumers in the Buffalo area, where 35 percent of the households have an account with the bank.
As part of its effort to make a turnaround, Goldome sold 24 branches with $2.8 billion of deposits in the New York City area to the Manufactures Hanover Trust Company during late 1989 and earlier this year.
Because of the strong position of Goldome in the Buffalo area, and its return to profitability -- the company earned $37.5 million in 1990 -- Mr. Cooper said earlier this year that the company was "worth much more than is shown on its balance sheet."
 
 Search for Investors
 But Mr. Cooper's efforts to assemble a group of investors were unsuccessful, and other potential buyers, including GE Capital, decided against investing in the company. Investment bankers said many other banks were interested in Goldome, but none could compete with Keycorp and First Empire, which had the advantage of local branch networks that could be economically merged with Goldome's system.
Keycorp and First Empire, which agreed to add $195 million and $40 million of capital, respectively, to their banking units, face limited risk of loss because the F.D.I.C. agreed to take about $1.8 billion of loans and other assets from Goldome subsidiaries, as well as $400 million of weak loans from Goldome's Buffalo savings bank.
In addition, the two companies may return for three years any Goldome loans that turn bad. To attract the two buyers, the F.D.I.C. agreed to pay $163 million to Keycorp and $40 million to First Empire, a Keycorp official said.
Keycorp and First Empire previously collaborated in 1989 in the purchase of branches and deposits of the Empire of America Corporation, another Buffalo savings bank that ran into trouble during the 1980's, when it expanded outside its local market.

HEADLINE: S.I. Home Port Fight Shifts to Its Closing

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
The long fight over opening the Staten Island Home Port has now turned into a fight over its proposed closing.
Just two years after the naval port began operating, a Federal panel yesterday placed it on the Pentagon's list of military installations that might be shut down to save money.
Thirty-four other additions to the list were also announced in Washington by the panel, the Base Closure and Realignment Commission. The panel must still make a final recommendation, which will be subject to Congressional and Presidential approval. 
 The decision to add the Staten Island base to the list was praised by a coalition of dozens of environmental, antinuclear and peace groups and other critics in New York City that had waged a losing campaign to prevent the creation of the home port.
 
Concern Over Jobs
 But advocates of the home port argued that its elimination would cost thousands of jobs and hundreds of millions of dollars, when the recession-battered local economy can ill afford it.
The only warship now based at the port, the Aegis missile cruiser Normandy, was sent to the Persian Gulf and returned earlier this year.
The Staten Island Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, a supporter of the home port, contended that the opposition of Mayor David N. Dinkins was partly to blame for the possibility that the base would be closed. Mr. Dinkins's predecessor, Edward I. Koch, had lobbied in favor of the Navy's decision to build the $200 million port.
Mr. Molinari and the City Council President, Andrew J. Stein, said yesterday that they would try to persuade the commission to reconsider, while opponents said they would be working to insure that the base was closed.
Mayor Dinkins said he would regret any loss of jobs, but he suggested that there might be other ways to develop the Staten Island port. Asked about reports of possible cuts at Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn and Fort Totten in Queens, the Mayor said he opposed closing those bases.
After failing to stop the opening of the home port with lawsuits, petitions and demonstrations, critics of the base said they felt a special vindication that the Government itself was moving to close it. The opponents had contended that the port was a waste of money. They also said some ships using it would be likely to carry nuclear weapons and warned about a possible nuclear accident. The Navy never confirms whether a ship is armed with nuclear weapons.
 
Critics Hail 'Wonderful News'
 "It's wonderful news," said Lynda Rodolitz, a representative of the Coalition for a Nuclear-Free Harbor. "We've been fighting since 1983. I wouldn't say we gave up, but it was looking bad for a while."
The home port issue has cut across party lines in the city. Mr. Molinari is a Republican; Mr. Dinkins, Mr. Koch and Mr. Stein are Democrats.
Mr. Molinari expressed dismay that some local officials had opposed the base. "Nowhere else does that happen," he said. "Normally you get governors, mayors and congressmen pleading to keep bases open, but not here."
He argued that Federal officials were more likely to close a base that has substantial opposition than one with strong local support. When fully operational, he said, the home port would generate $400 million a year for the local economy, providing more than 1,000 jobs at the base and many more indirectly.
Construction recently began on 1,100 homes for Navy personnel, a $115 million project that will be canceled if the base is closed, Mr. Molinari said. Also facing cancellation is a $100 million expansion of a second pier. And Bayley Seton Hospital, a Catholic institution that serves the Navy and many local residents, would be jeopardized by losing the Federal subsidies it gets as an adjunct to the home port, he said.
Mr. Molinari also offered another defense of the home port. "New York City is part of the United States of America and wants to be protected the same degree as any other area, and that means sharing the responsibility," he said.
But Representative Ted Weiss, a Democrat from Manhattan and the first local Congressman to come out against the home port, said, "With the cold war in decline, the original strategic justification for building new home ports has disappeared." He said the economic benefits of the port had been exaggerated, and denounced it as "a pork-barrel project."
The home port, located near the Staten Island Ferry terminal at St. George, includes a 1,400-foot pier and a large building for servicing and repairing Navy ships. It was officially dedicated on May 3, 1989.

HEADLINE: Highway Project May Bring Boston to a Standstill

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 31

 BODY:
When Boston's Central Artery and Third Harbor Tunnel project was formally presented to the public eight years ago, the price tag for unsnarling one of the most congested, dangerous and unsightly stretches of interstate highway in the country was put at $2.2 billion.
That figure has since more than doubled, to $4.9 billion. But cost is just one of the concerns, now that the project has won final Federal approval. 
 In the 10 years of construction that lie ahead, dirt, noise and detours threaten to bring downtown Boston to a standstill. And despite an eight-year environmental review, there are protests that the project will violate the nation's Clean Air Act, the Environmental Protection Act and parkland protection laws.
And then there are rats. A similar project undertaken here in the 1950's forced thousands of them out of their underground tunnels onto city streets. That threat is back again.
Still, construction on the project, one of the largest urban highway projects ever attempted, is set to begin. Known as "The Big Dig," it will mean the elimination of an ugly, two-mile elevated section of Interstate 93, which will be rebuilt underground between the historic Faneuil Hall marketplace and the North End. It will also extend the Massachusetts Turnpike into a new third tunnel to be dug under Boston Harbor. All of this will involve moving 12 million cubic yards of dirt and installing 200,000 tons of steel and 4 million cubic yards of concrete.
 
150 Acres of Open Space
 If all goes according to plan, designers say, the artery-tunnel project should ultimately ease Boston's infamous congestion problems and in the process create 150 acres of open space above the tunnel and along the Charles River.
"The congestion is unbearable and irreversible without this project as proposed," said Richard L. Taylor, the state's Secretary of Transportation. "And the artery is in disrepair. There is no solution that does not involve significant public cost."
Construction on the harbor tunnel, the first phase of the project, is now expected to start this fall. Three buildings have already been torn down and bids are now being accepted for a $250 million contract for the tunnel. Construction for the artery will start next year.
Transportation officials say they are doing all they can to assure that disruption to the city will be minimal and that all environmental and design options are considered. All six lanes of the present highway will remain open throughout construction, as will the two tunnels connecting downtown to East Boston and Logan International Airport.
But public opposition, including five lawsuits, continues to nag at planners and could ultimately stall the already belabored project.
On Wednesday, the Conservation Law Foundation announced plans to sue the Federal Highway Administration, Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts and top state transportation officials. The foundation contends that unless huge mass transit improvements are required by the plan, the project will violate the nation's Clean Air Act, the Environmental Protection Act and parkland-protection laws.
Two other lawsuits, including one filed by the Sierra Club, challenge the project's plans to control the exhaust fumes from automobiles in the tunnels.
And the city of Cambridge and the Charles River Watershed Association, a non-profit public interest group, have filed notice of intent to sue over a plan for a 10-story spaghetti-loop interchange known as "Scheme Z." But that interchange design was scrapped today in meetings of planners and is expected to be replaced by a sleeker, more costly alternative.
The current artery, built in the 1950's, was designed to handle 75,000 vehicles a day. Last year, 190,000 vehicles a day spent hours inching past the Boston Garden and Faneuil Hall or trying to get around the city and to Logan Airport.
 
Roadway That Spells Accidents
 That kind of congestion, coupled with bottlenecks and entrance and exit ramps that force drivers to careen across two or more lanes in spaces of less than 300 feet, has spelled disaster. The accident rate on Boston's central artery is two times the national average. On one short stretch on the northern side of the city alone, there are more than 400 accidents a year, according to state officials.
The artery-tunnel planners also say the project is needed to revive the economy in Massachusetts, where recession has pushed the unemployment rate to 9.7 percent. At the height of construction, in 1994, the project is expected to create 15,000 jobs, 5,000 in construction alone. So far, about $165 million worth of design contracts have been awarded to more than 100 businesses, most of them based in Massachusetts, state officials say.
The roadways, which will be expanded from six to eight lanes, are also expected to pull up to 40,000 cars off Boston's congested downtown streets, which wander and twist in a pattern created during Colonial times by cows meandering to graze on the Boston Common.
 
U.S to Pay Most of Cost
 About 85 percent of the $5 billion project is to be paid for reimbursed by Federal coffers under the 1987 Surface Transportation Act, an arrangement secured by former House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. as a kind of retirement gift to his home town. To date, $1.4 billion has been allocated, according to state officials. President Bush included an additional $2.1 billion for the project in a proposal sent to Congress earlier this year.
But even with the sweet promises of jobs and clearer roadways, the project's path continues to be strewn with complaints from environmental and neighborhood groups who say the artery-tunnel project will do more harm than good. The rats, they say, are just part of the problem.
In 1959, during the construction of one of the other two tunnels, Callahan Tunnel, thousands of rats were forced out of sewers into city streets, report North End residents who say they witnessed the rampage.
This time around, the state will pay more than $2 million for an extensive rodent control program. A 24-hour rat hotline is also on order for residents who spot even a single rodent.
Many residents of Boston's North End, a strip of land wedged between the expressway and Boston Harbor, also say the construction will ruin their tiny businesses that rely on local patronage and tourism.
 
'Project Is Bad for Everybody'
 "This project is bad for everybody," said Salvatore Tecce, whose family owns an Italian restaurant on North Washington Street in the North End. When the first central artery was built in the 1950's, his father, Joseph Tecce, was forced to close his fruit stand as a result of construction havoc, he said.
"Who will want to come here to the North End?" Mr. Tecce said. "With all the dust and the debris, how are we going to survive?
"See that," he said, nodding to a plate of fettucini carbonara. "You'll be eating sand."
Frederick Langone, a former city councilor and one of the most vocal opponents of the project, said it will not only cost Massachusetts money that it does not have, but will attract additional cars into the already congested roadway.
"I was against the original artery 30 years ago and I am against the new one," Mr. Langone said. "There will always be gridlock on the artery even if you build two more tunnels."

HEADLINE: City Reviving Plan for Tolls At East River

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
New York City transportation officials are drafting a proposal to collect tolls on the four free East River bridges. The idea has often been rejected, but officials say it is more plausible now because of the budget crisis and the cost of repairing the dilapidated structures.
The officials say new systems to collect the tolls would mean that tolls would cause less congestion and pollution than in the past and point to a new Federal law that would increase the financial benefit. 
 Although concern over the long-neglected bridges has grown, the officials concede that there has been little change in the biggest obstacles to new tolls, opposition from residents of Brooklyn and Queens, who would expect to pay the lion's share.
The officials said they hoped to have a formal proposal for the tolls on the East River bridges -- and possibly for nine bridges across the Harlem River -- ready for consideration by Mayor David N. Dinkins by the end of the summer.
 
'Bill Is Coming Due'
 "We have never been more serious about placing tolls on the East River bridges than we are now," Transportation Commissioner Lucius J. Riccio said in an interview. "The bill is coming due for 40 to 50 years of deferring maintenance on our bridges, and given the current budget crisis, tolls are a sensible means of paying that bill."
Preliminary estimates of potential revenue from the East River and Harlem River bridges indicate that a $2.50 toll could generate $700 million a year, according to the city's Transportation Department. Some transportation officials said the tolls would initially be priced much lower, at maybe $1, but would be increased over time.
The department estimates that it needs an additional $600 million, on top of the $3.3 billion already allocated, to rehabilitate poor and fair bridges. Although the city has allocated $29 million a year for the next 10 years to clean and operate the bridges, the officials say an additional $16 million a year is needed to maintain them properly.
Although the toll proposal is extremely tentative and a formal agreement may be years away, some members of the Mayoral Management Advisory Task Force, who insisted on anonymity, said the panel was "extremely optimistic" that the plan would go forward. The Mayor has instructed the panel to formulate a plan for the tolls.
But placing tolls on the East River bridges is likely to face strong opposition from political leaders, who argue that the tolls would create even larger traffic jams around bridges and worsen air pollution. The tolls would also create barriers between the boroughs and end a tradition of cost-free access to Manhattan from Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx.
A spokeswoman for the City Council, Peg Breen, said Council leaders opposed the tolls because they felt there were alternatives to raising dedicated funds for bridge repair and maintenance. She said analysts were working on the alternatives.
"This was a stupid idea when it was first floated decades ago, and it hasn't improved with age," said Councilman Kenneth K. Fisher, Democrat of Brooklyn, whose district includes the Brooklyn, Manhattan and Williamsburg Bridges. "When it comes time for people from other boroughs to come into Manhattan, they will have to cross economic drawbridges, and the gates will be up."
If the tolls were imposed, they would most likely be for the Brooklyn, Manhattan, Williamsburg and Queensboro Bridges.
The mayoral panel has not decided about the nine Harlem River bridges or whether the tolls would be one-way into Manhattan or in both directions.
The executive director of the panel, Thomas W. Bergdall, said that although the group was very hopeful that tolls would be approved, major hurdles remained. Instituting the tolls would most likely require state and city legislation, perhaps working through an authority, Mr. Bergdall said. A comprehensive environmental study also has to be undertaken.
 
To Change Federal Subsidy
 The officials cited two developments as favoring tolls. The Bush Administration has proposed a transportation spending bill that would for the first time allow Federal money to pay for roads and bridges with tolls. Without the law, New York would stand to lose hundreds of millions of Federal dollars for bridges if it instituted the tolls.
The second development is the advent of automatic collection systems, which would let three times as many vehicles pass than is the case now. The machines pick up radio signals from electronic cards attached to windshields and deduct the tolls from prepaid accounts.
The officials also cited newspaper and other surveys indicating that most New Yorkers did not oppose placing moderate tolls in the East River bridges or an increase in the gasoline tax, if those revenues were used to maintain roads and bridges.
Mr. Riccio said that although he supported tolls on the East River bridges, he would prefer an increase in the state's gas tax. At 8 cents a gallon, New York has the lowest tax in the nation, Mr. Riccio said, and even a modest increase of 10 cents a gallon would generate $500 million statewide, money that could be spent on roads and bridges.
But such dedicated financing, either from tolls or a gas-tax increase, could take years to start, and many bridge-engineering experts doubt that the city can afford to continue to defer maintenance and repairs on its crumbling bridges. The experts say many bridges will have to be closed.

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
At Wellesley, Advice To Seek Creative Path

 BODY:
Madeleine L'Engle, the author of "A Wrinkle in Time" and other books praised for their unusual blend of fantasy, science and autobiography, advised graduating seniors at Wellesley College's 113th commencement exercises yesterday to be aware of the integration of characteristics necessary to become "great human beings."
Borrowing from Greek mythology she told them to "use fully the Apollo, the intellect, which is a great glory, and rejoice equally in Sophia, the wisdom which makes the intellect creative instead of destructive." Ms. L'Engle also advised the graduates to take charge of their lives through the choices they make. 
 Ms. L'Engle, a 1941 graduate of Smith College who was invited by the senior class to speak at commencement, has written 28 books, including "A Swiftly Tilting Planet," which won the 1978 American Book Award, and "A Wrinkle in Time," winner of the 1963 Newbery Award.
Wellesley's president, Nannerl O. Keohane, presented bachelor's degrees to 543 women, including 27 Davis Scholars, graduates of the Massachusetts college's continuing education program, which marked its 20th anniversary this year.
 
George Washington University
 On the 50th anniversary of his own graduation from medical school, the former United States Surgeon General, C. Everett Koop, urged graduates at the George Washington University Medical School to hold themselves to higher moral standards than those required by law.
"Sometimes society will call for death over life," he told the 150 graduates at the school's 170th commencement exercises yesterday. "Choose life."
He criticized Dr. Timothy E. Quill, the Rochester doctor who disclosed that he helped a cancer patient commit suicide by prescribing tranquilizers, for shirking his obligations as a healer. "She was not suffering," Dr. Koop said. "She just didn't want to die from her disease. I say, 'How sad for our profession.' " No charges were brought against Dr. Quill.
Dr. Koop, who was awarded an honorary degree for public service, earned his medical degree from Cornell University.
 
 Queens College
 Queens College awarded 3,200 bachelor's, master's and doctoral degrees at its 67th commencement ceremony held yesterday on the school's campus in Flushing. The college honored the 135 members of the class of 1941, the first class to graduate from the college. Members of the class, wearing gold robes, marched at the head of the academic procession.
Raymond C. Kurzweil, the inventor of the Kurzweil reading computer for the blind, was awarded an honorary doctorate of science degree. Mr. Kurzweil is the founder and chairman of Kurzweil Applied Intelligence Inc. and chairman of the Kurzweil Reading Machine division of Xerox.
 
 Fashion Institute Of Technology
 Mayor David N. Dinkins told 2,445 graduating students at the Fashion Institute of Technology yesterday, "New York remains the greatest city on earth, and you can make this city a more beautiful place."
Speaking at the school's 45th commencement at Radio City Music Hall, the Mayor added, "Your fresh ideas fuel the economy while adding an unmatched luster to this metropolis of steel and concrete." He stressed the diversity of New York City, which he said was reflected in the graduates of the school.
At the ceremony, William F. Passannante, who was the most senior member of the State Assembly until his retirement this year, received an honorary doctorate of humane letters.
George Simonton, the women's wear designer, received the Mortimer C. Ritter alumni award.
 
 Pratt Institute
 State Senator Roy M. Goodman of New York urged the 1,100 graduates of Pratt Institute yesterday to "depart from what is tried and true" at the institute's 102d commencement on the campus in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn.
"The artist's job is to experiment," said Mr. Goodman, Republican of Manhattan, "to imagine, to find new ideas and new ways to express those ideas. That means taking chances. It means that some artists will be self-absorbed and self-indulgent. Others will have an unhealthy preoccupation with what is bizarre or forbidden. Still others will create the works of genius. And civilization will advance a little bit more."
Senator Goodman was one of six people awarded honorary degrees.
Dennis Ray Barrie, director of the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati, who was acquitted of obscenity charges stemming from an exhibition of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe, received a standing ovation when he was awarded an honorary degree.
Other honorary degrees were given to Iris Cantor, a philanthropist and patron of the arts; the painter Pat Steir; Robert M. Wilson, an artist known for his innovation in theater and design, and Henry Luce 3d, president of the board of the New Museum of Contemporary Art.
 
 John Jay College
 John Jay College of Criminal Justice awarded 595 undergraduate degrees and 130 master's degrees at its 26th commencement exercises yesterday at Carnegie Hall. Dr. James P. Comer, associate dean of the Yale School of Medicine, gave the commencement address and was one of four people awarded honorary degrees. The others were Charlayne Hunter-Gault, national correspondent for "The MacNeil-Lehrer News Hour"; Carmen Jovet, a journalist and producer based in Puerto Rico; and Harry T. Edwards, Circuit Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. The Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, received the college's Presidential Medal for distinguished service to the college and to the people of New York City.

HEADLINE: AIDS-Like Virus Is Found At High Rate in U.S. Cattle

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
After four years of research, scientists from the Department of Agriculture have found that a virus similar in genetic structure to the AIDS virus is more common in cattle in United States than researchers had anticipated. The scientists say there is no evidence that the virus can infect people.
The virus, bovine immunodeficiency-like virus, or BIV, is spread through the blood and is a member of a family of slow-acting viruses that have been shown to reduce the activity of an animal's immune system. Such immune suppression, veterinarians said today, can open the way for other infections. The virus, which was first isolated in 1969, has been shown to cause illness in calves, a top scientist at the Department of Agriculture said today. Scientists say they believe that the virus causes immune suppression in adult cattle, but how powerful it is remains uncertain. 
 Researchers said much more needs to be found out about the virus to understand its importance to the $55 billion cattle and dairy industries.
"We will continue to do research on this virus because it will help create a body of information that may provide a way to reduce the costs of production," said Dr. Harry Mussman, the deputy assistant Secretary of Agriculture for science and education. "It is very important that the public understands that this is not the AIDS virus. We do not have the AIDS virus in cattle."
 
Millions Lost to Disease
 Dairy and cattle producers now lose hundreds of millions of dollars each year because sick animals must be culled from their herds. In addition, cattle and dairy farmers spend $300 million to $500 million for anti-bacterial agents, antibiotics and other drugs to treat sick animals. The Food and Drug Administration has sought in the last two years to crack down on the use of such drugs because some are known carcinogens and residues have been found in meat and milk, posing a threat to public health. It is uncertain what the findings about the bovine virus infections will mean for the agency's effort.
Until now, most agricultural experts have attributed the rise in veterinary drug use to modern husbandry practices in which greater numbers of animals are being confined in pens and dairy barns. Whether the cattle virus is also related to the increasing drug use by causing immune suppression in adult cattle has not yet been studied, scientists said.
"The short-term research conducted so far won't give us an answer," said Dr. Matthew A. Gonda, a molecular virologist and head of the Laboratory of Cell and Molecular Structure at the Frederick Cancer Research and Development Center in Frederick, Md. "We really have to go back and do more research, take fresh isolates of the virus and put it into more animals and see what happens."
Another important consequence of the research on the cattle virus could be the effect on American exports of semen, embryos, and breeding stock, a $68 million-a-year industry, according to the Department of Agriculture. European countries, the major purchasers of American genetic material, are scrupulous about avoiding the risk of contamination by animal infections.
The bovine immunodeficiency-like virus was first isolated in 1969 by Dr. Martin J. Van Der Maaten, a veterinarian at the Agriculture Department's National Animal Disease Center in Ames, Iowa, who found it in a cow's blood serum collected in Louisiana.
The virus did not receive intense scientific scrutiny until the mid-1980's, when Dr. Gonda began to study the cattle virus and determined that its genetic structure was similar to the human AIDS virus. Both viruses have eight genes, Dr. Gonda said today, and magnified by an electron microscope, they look remarkably alike.
Prompted by a petition from The Foundation on Economic Trends, a Washington-based public interest group concerned about the virus's effects on the farm economy and human health, Dr. Van Der Maaten and his colleagues in Iowa began a new study in 1987. The research had four goals: to determine how prevalent the virus was in cattle, see whether it could produce illness in people, determine if it could cause significant infections in the nation's 99 million dairy and beef cattle and find out how it was spread.
 
No Human Infection Found
 The early research shows that the virus is much more common in cattle than Dr. Van Der Maaten thought. He and his colleagues in Iowa have identified the virus in blood serum collected from cattle in Louisiana, Texas, Kansas and Iowa.
Dr. Cecelia A. Whetstone, a microbiologist at the National Animal Disease Center who was in charge of the studies on human health, said in an interview that the "potential for human infection from BIV is zero." Laboratory workers who handled the virus in concentrated form, animal caretakers exposed to the virus and two workers who accidentally pricked themselves with infected needles are regularly tested for antibodies to the virus. The tests showed none of the workers had been infected.
There is circumstantial evidence that the cattle virus may be causing production problems in some herds. Dr. Van Der Maaten noted that dairy herds he has examined that had more illness from common diseases also had more cows infected with the virus than herds that were performing well. "We need a sound statistical study nationwide to help us understand what this could mean," he said.
Dr. Van Der Maaten and his colleagues also determined that the virus is spread in cattle through blood. Farmers could prevent infections from spreading by taking greater precautions in how they handle their animals. Using the same needle to draw blood or administer veterinary drugs on 60 or 70 animals is one way to spread the virus in a herd, he said.
The Foundation on Economic Trends today filed a formal petition with the Department of Agriculture asking the Government to take immediate steps to quarantine infected cattle, and accelerate the pace of research.
Al Strating, a director in the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, the Agriculture Department division that orders quarantines, said the Government had no plans for a nationwide program to quarantine or cull infected cattle.

HEADLINE: U.N. CHIEF RATES IRAQI REPARATIONS

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 31

 BODY:
The United Nations Secretary General recommended today that the Baghdad Government pay up to 30 percent of its annual oil revenue as reparations for the invasion of Kuwait and the Persian Gulf war.
Iraq agreed to pay reparations out of current oil revenues as part of the terms of the gulf war cease-fire. But in a letter this month to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, Baghdad asked for a five-year moratorium on reparations payments to give it time to rebuild its shattered economy. That request is under study by the United Nations Compensation Fund, which received the Secretary General's recommendation and will determine what the actual payment level will be. 
 Iraq has not been permitted to resume oil exports since the end of the war, pending United Nations certification of its compliance with other sections of the cease-fire agreement.
A reparations figure of 20 to 30 percent of oil revenues had been widely expected, even though the United States had called for a ceiling of as much as 50 percent. It was assumed that the American figure was a negotiating stance to offset figures as low as 5 percent proposed by Security Council members sympathetic to Iraq like Cuba.
 
Ceiling Set by OPEC
 With a 30 percent cap and current oil market conditions, including the ceiling of 3.14 million barrels of Iraqi exports per day set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the most Iraq could be asked to pay in any year would be roughly equivalent to the $5 billion or so it spent annually buying foreign weapons before the gulf war.
In the words of the cease-fire agreement, Iraq is liable "for any direct loss or damage, including environmental damage and the depletion of natural resources, or injury to foreign government, national and corporations, as a result of unlawful invasion and occupation of Kuwait."
Iraq expects to reach its 1989 export level of 2.85 million barrels a day in 1993. At an adjusted price of $20.04 a barrel for Iraqi crude, export earnings could be expected to reach $21 billion in 1993, Mr. Perez de Cuellar said.
With imports absorbing about 48 percent of Iraq's oil export earnings and service on its $42 billion foreign debt consuming 22 percent more, reparations should not exceed 30 percent, the Secretary General said.

HEADLINE: 35 More Bases Considered for Closing

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
The politically charged effort to select military bases that will be closed or consolidated took a new turn today when a commission reviewing the issue nearly doubled the number of installations under consideration.
Three dozen additional military installations, including Fort Drum army base in Watertown, N.Y., and five new naval home ports championed by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, could be affected under the plan released today by the base closing commission. 
 The commission plan expands the list of 43 potential base closings that Mr. Cheney released in April, adding Wisconsin and Alaska, plus Guam and Puerto Rico to the 34 states that had been affected. New York, which was to have gained jobs through the expansion of the Staten Island Naval Home Port, and California would be the hardest hit under the new proposals, with six bases added each. Florida and Virginia are home to four of the affected bases each.
The commission's action caught some members of Congress by surprise and provoked fresh outcry from elected officials who represent the affected areas.
 
'Won't Rubber-Stamp'
 "I have said all along that we won't rubber-stamp the Defense Secretary's proposals," the commission chairman, James A. Courter, said in a statement today. "And I have cautioned everyone not to assume that their installation is safe just because it is not included in the Pentagon's report."
A spokesman for the commission cautioned against overreacting to the inclusions on the new list and said it should be treated as a "menu of options" designed only to give commissioners greater latitude in making the final decisions on which installations should be closed or consolidated.
The spokesman, Cary Walker, said the commission has not yet made a full evaluation of the military or economic merits of closing any of the additional bases.
Many of the new installations included on the list appeared to have been added at the insistence of local communities who pleaded their own cases by suggesting that bases in other states be closed instead.
 
Pointing at Others' Bases
 For example, Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado, told the commission at a recent hearing that Lowry Air Force Base in her district was being recommended for closing on Mr. Cheney's list as a way of saving Goodfellow Air Force Base in San Angelo, Tex.
"Many of the facilities listed by the commission today were recommended for study by individuals seeking to void their own base closure or realignment," said Representative Sherwood Boehlert, Republican of New York. "This kind of finger pointing is to be expected and is nothing new."
The commission, which was appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate, plays a central role in the base-closing process. Established by Congress to review and modify recommendations made by the Pentagon, the panel was also designed to absorb some of the political heat generated by the potential economic impact of base closings. Congress has often found it difficult to close bases without some outside impetus.
The commission has until July 1 to review the Pentagon proposal and send it to President Bush. The President must approve the commission report without changes by July 15 or return it to the panel with recommended alterations. Congress also cannot modify the report but can accept or reject it within 45 days. If either the President or Congress disapprove of the final report, there will be no base closings this year.
The seven-member Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission commission, led by Mr. Courter, a former Republican Representative for New Jersey, is made up of business executives and former secretaries of the Army and Navy. Since the Pentagon list was released, the commission has conducted several hearings in Washington and around the country, soliciting advice on Mr. Cheney's suggestions. The panel is scheduled to meet again Thursday to further whittle down the list of proposed closings.
 
Importance of Home Ports
 At an April news conference in which he released his recommendations, Mr. Cheney strongly defended the strategic home ports in Washington, New York, Texas, Alabama and Mississippi, four of which are still under construction.
The new naval home ports are considered to be state-of-the-art facilities that make more efficient use of Navy personnel and equipment because of the proximity of deep water harbors and of nearby naval air stations.
But the General Accounting Office, Congress's investigative arm, criticized the Navy's evaluation process and suggested that those ports might be candidates for reductions.
"We continue to believe that list is a good one, and we hope that the commission will agree," the Pentagon said in a written statement today.
Some members of Congress briefed on the new list today offered muted responses to the commission's action, pointing out that no final decisions have yet been made.
 
Anger About New Candidates
 "The fact that they put the shipyard back on the list for consideration is not really all that distressing," said Representative Dana Rohrabacher, the Republican from California who represents the Long Beach Naval Shipyard. "It's basically being done to lower the octave levels coming from Philadelphia."
But other members who were convinced they had dodged a bullet when Mr. Cheney's list was released were angrier today.
"The commission's options constitute a clear and present danger to our national security and to New York's economy," said Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Republican of New York, who questioned whether "political considerations and parochial interests are really at the heart of these ill-conceived proposals."
Mr. Courter said in his statement: "I want to emphasize that this is not a list of closures. Nor is it a list of recommended realignments. It sets forth a wide array of options."
Besides the 35 military installations, the Army Corps of Engineers was added as a candidate for reduction. Mr. Cheney said in April that the Department of the Army had recommended reduction of the corps, which has projects around the nation, but that the commission process was not the correct way to accomplish it.
The members of the base closing commission are Mr. Courter, William L. Ball 3d, former secretary of the Navy and president of the National Soft Drink Association, Retired Air Force Gen. Duane Cassidy, Arthur Levitt, former chairman of the American Stock Exchange Inc., James Smith 2, vice president of the Houston engineering firm Brown & Root and Robert D. Stuart Jr., a former ambassador to Norway who is chairman of the Quaker Oats Company.

HEADLINE: Peace, but Little Else, Crystallizes for Angola

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN

 BODY:
A quarter-century of bloodshed financed in large part by the United States, the Soviet Union, Cuba and South Africa preceded the handshake yesterday between Jose Eduardo dos Santos, the President of Angola, and Jonas Savimbi, the longtime leader of the Angolan rebels.
And with memories of a generation of violence still vivid in the minds of Angolans, the peace accord has laid to rest none of the questions about the country's future. 
 "It is not at all clear from this what government will emerge," said Michael Clough, senior fellow for African studies at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York. "If the people of Angola had their way, they would probably vote out Savimbi and dos Santos both."
Angola is one of Africa's richest countries in natural resources, including huge reserves of oil and diamonds. But that untapped wealth did little to ease the welter of ethnic, personal and ideological conflicts that fragmented both the struggle for independence -- which began in the 1960's and was won from Portugal in November 1975 -- and the nation after independence.
 
Independence as Byproduct
 Even independence was won not so much as a product of successful rebellion but as the fallout of a coup d'etat in Lisbon, which set Portugal on a course toward democratic government and led to its hasty pullout from Angola in 1975.
In the months after independence, Mr. dos Santos's party, the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, or M.P.L.A., which had received most of its arms and money from the Soviet Union and its allies, moved swiftly against its two principal rebel rivals.
One guerrilla organization was destroyed. The other, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita, which was led by Mr. Savimbi, retreated in disarray into the desolate southeast, despite the covert backing of South Africa and the United States.
In 1976, after the extent of American clandestine support for Mr. Savimbi was exposed in press reports and Congressional hearings, Congress enacted the Clark Amendment, barring further assistance to Unita. Only South Africa, on the pretext of insuring security in neighboring Namibia, which it controlled at the time, continued military actions against the Angolan Government. Soviet and Cuban aid to the dos Santos Government remained at a high level.
 
American Involvement Deepens
 American involvement in Angola deepened under President Ronald Reagan, who condoned cooperation with South African forces. In 1985, the Clark Amendment was repealed and the United States began supplying military aid to Mr. Savimbi.
In the 1980's, Unita and the South Africans made gains on the ground, only to lose them to counterattacking Cuban troops, who had been invited into Angola as a bulwark against South African forces stationed in Namibia.
The war dragged on, although Washington's appetite for underwriting Unita weakened after several independent authorities, including Human Rights Watch, a New York-Based agency, documented ritualistic killings and policies of forced labor and conscription under Mr. Savimbi.
Ultimately, the inability of either side to win a decisive victory had as much to do with yesterday's cease-fire agreement as did Namibia's independence from South Africa.
 
'Settlement From Exhaustion'
 "What finally happened is that the M.P.L.A. and Unita just basically ran out of options," said Mr. Clough. "It's a settlement from exhaustion. The Soviets were tired. The U.S. was tired. The South Africans are basically out. The analysis is, 'Nobody is going to pay us to keep fighting, so let's settle.' "
Last week, the final contingent of Cuban troops left Angola as part of the 1988 accord that assured independence for Namibia.
Despite Washington's support for Unita and its refusal to establish diplomatic relations with the Government in Luanda, the capital, Angola remained Washington's third-largest trading partner in sub-Saharan Africa.
Almost all of Angola's crude oil is exported to the United States, making up about 90 percent of the country's revenues. Other untapped and potentially vast mineral reserves offer still greater potential for exploitation, including uranium and copper.
Years of war have left Angola's roads, railways and rural electrical sytem in shambles. And while the country's economic potential remains considerable, its political future is still largely uncertain.
Some analysts, however, are optimistic about the country's future, while at the same time hinting that yesterday's handshake in Lisbon will not necessarily define Angola's political shape. In an article to be published next week in the Center for Strategic and International Studies Africa Notes, Sean McCormick, a specialist on Angola, writes that "the competition between the M.P.L.A. and Unita for support from the electorate over the next 15 to 18 months could be fractious, but the entry of new political forces into the fray suggests that the contest will be truly multiparty, rather than two party in nature."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The leading indicators posted their third straight advance, signaling that the 10-month-old recession will soon be over. The 0.6 percent rise followed increases of 0.7 percent in March and 1.2 percent in February. In the postwar period, three straight advances have almost invariably signaled an imminent recovery. [Page 1.] 
 Tighter lending standards for F.H.A.-backed mortgages will take effect July 1, the Government said. One lending group said the move would reduce home sales by up to 200,000 annually. [35.]
Orders received by American factories rose in April for the first time in six months, the Commerce Department said. The 1.8 percent gain followed a revised 2.9 percent drop in March. [38.]
In many frequent-flier programs, moving to first class is the most-used award. Consumer's World. [50.]

HEADLINE: Weicker Vetoes Budget Bill; Special Session is Expected

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 31

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. tonight rejected the Legislature's plan to resolve Connecticut's budget crisis through a huge expansion of the sales-tax system, calling it unfair to lower-income residents and destructive to the state's economy. It was the first time in 20 years that a Connecticut governor had vetoed a budget.
The decision, which lawmakers said all but guarantees a special legislative session after mandatory adjournment next Wednesday, was not unexpected. But it was closely watched for the tone that it would take in rejecting the budget and for the language that might suggest a direction for compromise. 
 In his two-page veto message and in his comments to reporters in his office after signing the veto at 9:50 P.M., Mr. Weicker repeatedly mentioned that some elements of the proposal could still be salvaged, though he declined to describe them specifically. The veto letter aimed almost all of its fire at the tax proposals in the legislative plan, rather than at the package of spending controls, which had been a major element in drawing support for passing the plan in the General Assembly.
"Many parts of the whole merit adoption," Mr. Weicker said. "But the sum total of the whole merits veto."
Mr. Weicker, who was inaugurated in January as Connecticut's first third-party independent governor since the Civil War, proposed a sweeping overhaul of the tax system in February and the introduction of a long-avoided income tax, only to see the plan rejected out of hand by lawmakers. They substituted -- and approved on Thursday -- a traditional tax package that would rely on the sales tax and the corporate-earnings tax, both of which would have been expanded.
In turning that plan down, Mr. Weicker said tonight that with the economy "in tatters," raising business taxes now would mean greater deficits and fewer jobs. Lawmakers had argued that the opposite was true, that by avoiding the income tax, consumers would have more money to help fuel the recovery.
 
Tensions Are High
 The last time that a Connecticut governor vetoed a budget bill was in 1971, when Gov. Thomas J. Meskill, a Republican, rejected the legislature's efforts. The further historical parallel that Governor Meskill's veto resulted in Connecticut's only other flirtation with the income tax has not been lost on lawmakers. After returning in a special session in June of that year, the legislature passed an income tax but repealed the law less than two months later amid a storm of public protest.
Tension is already high in the Capitol. The Senate, after giving final approval to the budget Thursday afternoon, refused to send it to Mr. Weicker immediately, as he had requested. Instead, the senators slogged through an entire calendar of business before ordering the documents transferred for Mr. Weicker's consideration about 9:30 P.M. Twenty minutes later the 349-page bill was dead.
Mr. Weicker previously identified four general principles that would have to be included in any budget, and his budget office issued a critique last week before the first vote on the legislature's plan saying that it fell short on all four.
A successful plan, Mr. Weicker said, would have to balance the budget and repair the revenue shortfall, which is about $900 million for the year that ends on June 30 and about $1.8 billion for the following year, in a preliminary spending plan of $8.6 billion.
Second, it could not rely on any "gimmicks," or "one-shot" revenues that would leave the state with a deficit next year.
Third, it would have to keep down the cost of borrowing to pay off the $900 million shortage in the current year.
Fourth, it would have to encourage economic development by cutting taxes paid by business.
