HEADLINE: Bush Is Feeling 'More Positive' On Kremlin Aid

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
President Bush said today after meeting a high-level Soviet economic delegation that he felt Moscow was really moving down the path of radical economic reform and therefore he was "feeling more positive" about the question of aiding President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Speaking after meeting for nearly an hour with the Soviet team headed by the Gorbachev adviser Yevgeny M. Primakov, Mr. Bush said: "I had the impression that they are undertaking what for them is, and what the world will see as, radical economic reform. When you've had a totally controlled economy, to try to move to a market economy, it's not easy. You need help along the way." 
 The President continued, "I liked what I heard."
American officials said that Mr. Bush let Mr. Primakov know that he would try to obtain associate membership in the International Monetary Fund for the Soviets, which would give them access to its expertise in reform economics.
Both the Reuters news agency and The Washington Post reported tonight that Mr. Primakov had asked the I.M.F. for as much as $250 billion in loans over the next five years to help the Soviet Union repair its battered economy and move to a free-market system.
A spokesman for the I.M.F. said he could not confirm the accounts.
The President, the officials said, also left Mr. Primakov with a strong hint that he is going to find a way to extend all or part of the $1.5 billion in bank credits to buy grain that the Soviet Union has been seeking. Mr. Bush also suggested sending a team of American oil executives to Moscow to work directly with the Soviets in exploiting their resources in exchange for hard currency.
Aides said the President would also announce by June 3 that he is waiving the Jackson-Vanik trade restrictions on the Soviets for another year, because of liberalized emigration policies. That will allow Moscow to continue to be eligible for American credit guarantees to finance Soviet imports from the United States and American investments in the Soviet Union.
The Administration is also committed to granting the Soviets the lowest possible tariffs into this country because of the passage in the Soviet Parliament of the law liberalizing travel. But the President declined to specify when he would grant that treatment, known as most-favored-nation status.
 
Criterion for a Summit Role
 But while the President signaled a willingess to move on those smaller steps, he left open his options on some of the bigger, politically charged decisions. Officials said that Mr. Primakov formally asked the President if he would support an invitation to Mr. Gorbachev to the meeting in London next month of the world's seven leading industrialized democracies.
Mr. Bush responded, officials said, that the key criterion for him was whether Mr. Gorbachev would come with a real, comprehensive free-market economic-reform plan in hand.
While the President indicated to Mr. Primakov that the ideas presented today were moving in the right direction, he also said they were not there yet. If Mr. Gorbachev produced such a plan, and going to the London summit meeting would help fulfill it, then Mr. Bush said he would likely lean in that direction. But simply to go to the summit meeting without a plan would raise a lot of unfulfilled expectations on both sides, he said.
The President and Mr. Primakov's delegation also discussed the concept known as the Grand Bargain, now being broached by some American and Soviet economists. That approach envisions that the Soviets would agree to institute free-market changes, democratic changes and political revisions, like halting aid to Cuba and harassment of the Baltics and reducing defense spending, in return for a long-term commitment of Western aid. American officials said they tried to dissuade the Soviets from such a notion.
"The Soviets are expressing a serious intention to work toward market reform, but they are still uncertain about how to do so," said the Undersecretary of State for Economic Affairs, Robert B. Zoellick, who took part in the talks this week with Mr. Primakov. "The idea of a Grand Bargain, though, is a political fantasy. For both sides to assume that the Soviets could commit in writing to such sweeping political and economic changes, in exchange for a commitment from the West of a big pile of money, is not realistic. The President's message was that we have to move step by step."
That view is not shared by some leading Congressmen. The House Majority Leader, Richard A. Gephardt, for instance, argued Thursday that "if rewards to the Soviets are only paid out for concrete results, I don't see how we lose."
Mr. Bush's public response today to the latest Soviet proposals were far more positive than the one offered on Thursday by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. But Administration officials said Mr. Bush, because he tends to see the relationship with the Soviet Union through his personal relationship with Mr. Gorbachev, wanted to try to put the best cast on things in order not to undermine the Soviet leader.
 
Lobbying for an Invitation
 Aides also said Mr. Bush was highly aware of the fact that key allies, like France and Germany, have been lobbying him to invite Mr. Gorbachev to London, and he does not want to be totally out of tune with them.
But asked whether he was now more inclined to invite Mr. Gorbachev to the economic summit meeting, as Germany, Italy and France are urging, the President said: "Well, that matter was obviously discussed. I've got a little homework to do now before I make comments on that. But I'm feeling more positive on a wide array of specific questions, and yet that isn't to suggest that there are not some big problems -- big problems out there."
The latest Soviet thinking was presented to Mr. Bush by Mr. Primakov, the member of Mr. Gorbachev's national security council responsible for economics; First Deputy Prime Minister Vladimir Shcherbakov and Grigory A. Yavlinsky, a private economist.
American officials said there were two clearly different proposals coming from the Soviet side: one from Mr. Primakov and Mr. Shcherbakov, which seemed to reflect Mr. Gorbachev's current economic thinking, and another more far-reaching proposal from Mr. Yavlinsky, which American officials say could represent where Mr. Gorbachev would be prepared to go if he felt he had at least some Western backing.
The Primakov plan for resolving the Soviet economic crisis, the officials said, referred to a lot of the right objectives from the American point of view -- lifting some price controls, converting the ruble to a hard currency, and selling some state-owned industries.
But the problem with the plan, American officials said, was that the means for achieving free-market changes in the near future included using greater centralized control to get goods to and from the markets rather than using the market alone.

HEADLINE: Connecticut's Nowhere Budget

 BODY:
Connecticut's General Assembly adopted a budget that was going nowhere, and the legislators knew it. Its no-income-tax budget, concocted by a coalition of Republicans and nervous Democrats, barely squeaked through the House. Given the certainty of Gov. Lowell Weicker's veto and the remote chances of overriding it, the Assembly has wasted its time -- and its public trust.
Connecticut faces a $2.8 billion deficit, equal to almost one-third of the total budget. New revenues are essential. Governor Weicker has proposed a 6 percent income tax; he would also slash the state sales tax and cut taxes on corporate profits. The Assembly clings to the notion that Connecticut can eke out another year of precarious solvency by keeping the sales tax at 8 percent -- the highest state sales tax in the nation -- and broadening it to include goods and services now exempt. 
 Reliance on a sales tax means wide swings in state revenue, up and down with the economy, which explains Hartford's current deep distress. An income tax is more stable and, above all, it's fairer. Sales taxes are notoriously regressive; the poor pay the same as the rich. Mr. Weicker's flat 6 percent tax is marginally progressive; it exempts the first $12,000 of income ($25,000 for couples).
A graduated tax would be better, but even the flat tax is fairer than the legislature's alternative. A new analysis by the Assembly's nonpartisan budget office says families earning less than $40,000 a year would fare better with an income tax than with the Assembly's plan. And the latest Hartford Courant poll, published this week, indicates that the public is catching on; it doesn't like the Assembly plan any better than Mr. Weicker's.
Armed with these facts -- that an income tax is fairer and that the alternative is no more popular -- perhaps the legislature can now rise to its responsibility and approve the Governor's more sensible approach.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Electricity Markup Penalizes Small Businesses

 BODY:
To the Editor:
For years, commercial landlords in New York City have resold electricity to small businesses, marking up the bill an average of 30 percent to 35 percent, in some cases more than 100 percent. This unfair practice affects thousands of small businesses, many in the garment and printing industries, and costs them more than $100 million a year in electricity overcharges. The leases often conceal the basis for these markups. 
 This is the only unregulated sale of electricity in New York; unlike other commercial or residential consumers, these small businesses cannot look to the Public Service Commission for protection. (State law has long prohibited electricity resale to residential tenants.) With electricity costs in New York already among the highest in the country, small businesses should not have to suffer additional charges by landlords who can mark up the bill with impunity.
Legislation introduced by Assemblyman Jerrold Nadler and State Senator Guy J. Velella would cap the electricity markups at 12 percent and require leases to disclose the basis for the charges. It would allow landlords to recover the costs of distributing electricity to their tenants, but provide some protection for the affected businesses. The city, small business associations and the P.S.C. strongly support the bill.
But similar legislation has been defeated in the past by lobbyists for landlords. They argue that landlords would simply recover the additional revenue by raising rents. That may be so, but at least it would be understandable to tenants and undisguised, and would not skew the economics between the utility and real estate markets. If commercial landlords want to enter the electricity business, they should get authority from the P.S.C. and do it out in the open.
Small businesses are entitled to the same protection in their use of electricity as other consumers. These added costs impose an unfair burden on many companies that are striving to maintain their place in a difficult economic climate. The NadlerVelella bill warrants immediate enactment.
 
WILLIAM F. SQUADRON
New York City Commissioner of Telecommunications and Energy
New York, May 15, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Born in the U.S.S.R.

BYLINE: By Terry Teachout; Terry Teachout is the author of "City Limits: Memories of a Small-Town Boy," which will be published this fall. He is at work on a biography of H. L. Mencken.

 BODY:

FROM LENIN TO LENNON
A Memoir of Russia in the Sixties.
By David Gurevich.
307 pp. San Diego:
Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $21.95.  
 When I was 12 years old, I talked my parents into subscribing to Soviet Life, a Life-style propaganda magazine published each month by the Soviet Government for the benefit of gullible American readers. Not that I was particularly gullible. Even at 12, I knew the Soviet Union was a land of brutal oppression. What I vainly sought in the slick pages of Soviet Life was the answer to a deceptively simple question: how did ordinary Soviet citizens get through the day in the land of Big Brother? For me, that was -- and is -- the essence of the Soviet enigma.
I picked up a copy of Soviet Life the other day, surprised to find that it was still in business and positively astonished by the first headline I spotted: "What Is a Free Economic Zone?" But glasnost and perestroika have done little to answer the question that intrigued me a quarter-century ago. The same, oddly enough, is true of the many emigre memoirs published in recent years. These books, fascinating in their own right, are the work of exceptional people: scholars and scientists, glamorous sopranos, fearless dissidents.
David Gurevich's "From Lenin to Lennon: A Memoir of Russia in the Sixties" is a different kind of book. Mr. Gurevich was no dissident, no child prodigy -- merely a bright young man with a knack for languages who endured the rigors of the Soviet system, grew to loathe them and then, by the accident of his Jewish birth, found a way of escape. Not coincidentally, his dryly witty account of everyday life in the workers' paradise is one of the most revealing books ever written about the Soviet Union.
Mr. Gurevich, now a playwright and novelist, grew up in Syzran, a seedy little town on the banks of the Volga River. Uninterested in politics, bored to tears by the Marxist-Leninist doctrine his teachers rammed down his throat, he yearned not for the large abstractions of liberty but for such commonplace things as a decent job, a few good books and records and, most important, a bit of privacy. ("There is no Russian word for this concept; it came to me from English, with a flash of recognition: Aha, that's what I've always liked.") But he kept running into politics at every turn, from Young Pioneer summer camp to elementary school: "At the age of eleven you discovered whether you had an appetite for power and the willingness to take and give orders; or, if you didn't mind being one of the sheep, then you learned to develop the skills necessary for ovine survival. You learned to nod, to raise your hand in a unanimous vote, to weather the endless boredom of meetings."
Instead of following the narrow path of party-line orthodoxy to a translating job at "Exportthis Importthat," Mr. Gurevich spent his free time getting drunk and reading subversive books like "The Gulag Archipelago," "Nineteen Eighty-Four" and "The Catcher in the Rye." He discovered 1960's America through bootlegged rock albums ("my Tocqueville to America") and Hollywood movies, which he "read" in ways inconceivable to ideologues of any persuasion: "Easy Rider's free and loose ways seemed like something concocted by the USIA for foreign consumption. We argued about it interminably in the wee hours around Moscow kitchen tables: it was easy to accept the reality of convertibles and swimming pools and other signs of economic prosperity; it was so much harder to accept the reality of so much freedom."
In the end, Mr. Gurevich found it impossible to make it as a nonpolitical man. Falsely accused by a student informer of being the leader of a nonexistent Zionist cell, he was blacklisted from working abroad as a translator, with predictable results: "The word 'Zionist' was not unfamiliar to me, but I certainly knew and cared more about Eric Clapton than Herzl or Zhabotinsky. Sometimes a search for cultural and ethnic identity starts with an informer's report. Now I was interested in Herzl." He left the Soviet Union under a Jewish quota in 1976, coming to America to grapple with the daily problems of life in a free society: "And if freedom sometimes seems like a burden, it's one worth carrying; as a destination, it's also worth all the stumbling on your way to it."
To read "From Lenin to Lennon" is to learn an important (and easily overlooked) lesson about life under a totalitarian regime: its most typical horrors are not the savage methods by which open rebellion is put down, but the day-to-day humiliations to which the average citizen is subjected in a society ruled by ideology run rampant. It is a lesson that the self-righteous prigs of the 90's, who measure all things against the blunt yardsticks of their preferred political orthodoxies, would do well to take to heart.

HEADLINE: Fashion: American Report;
The Magnificent Eight

BYLINE: BY CARRIE DONOVAN

 BODY:
WHEN THE NEW YORK FALL COLLECTIONS CAME TO A close this past April, the general feeling was that America's contribution to new fashion was somewhat less than visionary. There were some nice small changes -- the infusion of colorful tweeds and plaids, for example, and the sway of flippy, pleated skirts. (Hemlines, however, stayed above the knee.) But coming on the heels of the forward-looking shows in Paris, the American shows for the most part lacked the slight silhouette changes and the imaginative accessorizing that nudge fashion forward. It was especially disappointing that several of the newer talents who had brought excitement to the last season settled for doing the same stuff over again in winter fabrics.
The reluctance of so many American designers and manufacturers to go off into uncharted territories, though regrettable, was understandable. These collections had been produced amid the uncertainties of the Persian Gulf war. More important, the fact that the recession had already cut deeply into the retail and fashion industry and still showed no sign of receding made the status quo a safer route. Nevertheless, the majority of the new clothes were O.K. and, mercifully, from a store buyer's point of view, quite wearable. 
 But then there were the eight designers whose collections were both solid and studded with nuggets of newness. This small cluster transcended the general lie-low mood and gave American fashion a firm footing. Of these, two are without a doubt the country's top stars.
Geoffrey Beene's controlled creativity is of such a fine caliber that it has earned him a place among the world's elite designers. His new clothes maneuvered around the body in ways that were at once highly sophisticated and powerfully sexy. There were new variations on his shockingly bare, lacy slip dresses, his enveloping coats and his razor-sharp suits with jackets scissored off at asymmetrical angles.
Isaac Mizrahi's showings, usually held in a downtown loft, are rowdy romps reminiscent of the most exciting Paris events. They have become a mecca for fashion professionals, assorted celebrities, the social and theatrical avant-garde, visiting European designers and whatever fashion hangers-on and groupies can manage to sneak in. Mizrahi's models came flying down the long runway, unleashing a torrent of fascinating ideas, silhouettes and directions. The mix included Indian beadings, Western fringes, street trappings, Star of David pendants, biker leathers, Scottish tweeds, overblown trench coats, impeccable men's pants suits, schoolgirl jumpers and neat little outfits for Park Avenue matrons. Not only was the show a tour de force, but when the clothes were inspected on the showroom racks, devoid of their madcap accessories, their true wearability, even practical qualities, stood out.
After these two creative blasts, the other American offerings might well have seemed subdued, yet the collections of Donna Karan, Ralph Lauren, Louis Dell'Olio for the Anne Klein Company, Calvin Klein, Christian Francis Roth -- and, if you erase some of the misguided accessorizing at the actual show, Bill Blass -- played to their strengths.
As always, Ralph Lauren's clothes had a freshness that enlivened their studied, classy mien. He has moved his military might -- the spiffy way he has of sprucing up women's clothes with brassy touches, like gold buttons, braidings and epaulets -- to his sleek, active ski wear. These pieces will no doubt start a trend. Meanwhile, Lauren's town clothes of tweed or tartan showed a little flair at the hip of a suit jacket or the hemline of a dress. Everything looked proper but desirable.
Donna Karan has the ability to transform a variety of women into modern-day goddesses. Her ideal customers are confident, sexy and career-driven. Next fall, they will be molded into bodysuits of shining Lycra armor and powerful ensembles of soft black leather or luscious woolens deceptively shaded such faint hues as celadon green and pale peach.
Everything having to do with a Calvin Klein production is calm and sybaritic. The models, impossibly beautiful to begin with, were artfully made up to look natural yet as sexy as all get-out. Granted, Klein's debt to the work of Giorgio Armani is often evident, yet his simple, easy separates were polished to perfection and so carefully thought out that every sweater, jacket, coat or pair of pants had a throwaway elegance.
Christian Francis Roth is a newish American talent, and a promising one. Only 22 years old, he has the designing ability and the technical expertise to stay around for a long time. For fall he chose two narrow channels of inspiration -- hobo attire and Amish quilts -- to realize a small, charming collection of eccentric, witty clothes for women who collect such things.
Louis Dell'Olio drummed out just the right rat-a-tat line for the vast number of women who believe in and buy the Anne Klein Company's products. In the best American manufacturing tradition, it was a summation of the season's ideas: long-line zippered jackets, pleated or pencil skirts, hot colors, tweeds, plaids and deep-tone velours. And he didn't leave out the all-important all-black outfits or short puff-ball evening skirts and long slinky sequined ones. Dell'Olio had one idea, though, that gave pause for thought -- the all-in-one legging-shoe. When it needs refurbishing, do you send it to the dry cleaner or the shoe repair?
Bill Blass also did well by his customer, who is usually rich, snappy and American. He offered suits with longer jacket, unusual cashmere sweaters and superb coats. Everyone looks to Blass for evening attire, but he, along with the other designers, seemed stumped. Where to go after the little slip dress? Blass's attempts at evening separates fell short.
A footnote: after everyone else had shown, up popped Byron Lars. A former Californian, Lars had considered becoming an architect but after learning to sew in his senior year of high school developed a passion for designing fashion. His 30-piece collection was so fresh and naively chic that it reminded old hands of Kenzo's beginning years in Paris. Talent aside, the hurdles Lars will face in order to make it in the tough world of American fashion are staggering. One hopes he'll keep plunging ahead.
Despite these contributions, this round of American shows once again ceded the crown of creativity to Paris.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 31; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1662 words

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
Sex, Lies and the Trouble With Videotapes

BYLINE: By Jon Pareles

 BODY:
"Rape is not a serious crime," says Sut Jhally in the narration of his videotape "Dreamworlds: Desire/Sex/Power in Rock Video," "because, after all, she deserved it and she was asking for it. Hell, she must probably have enjoyed it."
Mr. Jhally, a communications professor at the University of Massachusetts, doesn't mean that. In fact, his videotape, which his department is selling for classroom use, offers a quiet yet vehement argument against that attitude and against the video images that, he believes, contribute to it. But I've wrenched his words out of context and given them lurid placement at the top of the column in order to imitate the professor's own methods. "Dreamworlds" uses the illusory logic of video; it tears images out of context, then proceeds as if juxtaposition equals logical connection. 
 Mr. Jhally reaches his conclusions within a zone of political correctness, decrying the victimization of women, reciting shocking rape statistics and using academese like "the gaze" and "gender and sexual power relationships." But his tactics and inferences -- first the raunchy pictures, then the scary statistics -- bear an uncanny resemblance to those of "Rising to the Challenge," the video sold by the Parents' Musical Resource Center of Arlington, Va., which pressured the record business into placing warning labels on potentially offensive albums.
MTV has made threatening legal noises because "Dreamworlds" includes an MTV station identification and shows an MTV logo on its promotional brochure, and usually anything that cracks MTV's corporate cool is fine with me. But watching "Dreamworlds" alongside the 1991 update of "Rising to the Challenge" makes it clear that academics are just as prone as fundamentalists to misunderstand rock video.
Just as Mr. Jhally offers "Dreamworlds" as an examination of "rock video" -- no qualifiers -- "Rising to the Challenge" asserts that its nasty bits represent a "cross section" of what is available in "most local record stores," even if most of its malefactors are admittedly obscure. "Rising to the Challenge" (no Freudian implications, I'm sure)was co-written by Jennifer Norwood, the center's former executive director, and Robert DeMoss, the youth-culture specialist of Focus on the Family, a fundamentalist Christian group.
The new version of "Rising to the Challenge," narrated by Art Linkletter, looks shopworn. Many of the groups the center was complaining about when it got started in 1985 (and still cites) have either cleaned up their acts or returned to obscurity. Lawsuits against Jello Biafra, Ozzy Osbourne and the 2 Live Crew have been largely unsuccessful. The section on "occultism" -- a bugbear of certain fundamentalists, who apparently don't believe that law-abiding Satanists are entitled to freedom of religion -- admits that "occult themes in music are declining" yet reports of Satanic crimes are increasing, which would seem to argue against any connection between art and life.
A new section on bigotry, which points out genuinely ugly things sung by Guns 'n' Roses and rapped by Audio Two, closes with statistics on bias incidents that took place before most of the albums mentioned were released, once again suggesting that the music reflects the culture instead of driving it. And after the inevitable juxtapositions of leather-clad rockers, scantily clad women in music videos, clothed strippers and bondage magazines, Mr. Linkletter says, "Hard-core pornography, records, albums, posters, fan magazines, concert stage, music videos -- it's sometimes hard to distinguish between the two." Two?
Best of all, the videotape concludes with survey results showing that teen-agers' values reflect "the ethnic and social class life style of their parents more than the universal teen culture." Perhaps the Parents' Music Resource Center should start working on the parents instead of the music.
While the center's ax has been ground to a nub, "Dreamworlds" has a veneer of academic respectability. Over creepy new-age music, the videotape shows what must be virtually every glimpse of revealing clothing and suggestive movement Mr. Jhally could tape from MTV. As the snippets flicker, Mr. Jhally argues that by objectifying women -- by showing them as nymphomaniacs who exist purely for men's pleasure and who mean yes even when they say no -- rock video contributes to attitudes that legitimize rape.
The professor has a good eye for the cliches used by many hard-rock bands. The high heels striding down the streetlighted sidewalk, the bikinis on the beach, the singers' heads framed by a pair of legs, the adoring women clinging to the singers, the leather and lace, the cleavage and rump close-ups -- all might as well be stock footage. (Of course, they're also staples of prime-time drama and tabloid news.)
"Dreamworlds" doesn't bother to track down the source of those images in movies, advertising and, especially, men's magazines. Nor does it distinguish between straight-faced sexist spectacle and over-the-top self-parody of acts like David Lee Roth, Aerosmith and Sam Kinison. And from the beginning, it misreads the lusty admiration shown by all those willing women -- they're not undiscriminating nymphomaniacs, they're star-struck fans of the band.
"Dreamworlds" also shows many female dancers. And, gosh, they're dressed in the same kinds of short skirts and low-cut tops seen at actual clubs on Saturday nights. In "Dreamworlds," people moving to the beat becomes another example of objectification; but for all but the must prudish observers, dancing simply demonstrates how the music can be used.
 "Dreamworlds" is deaf to the music of rock videos, and it pays no attention to lyrics. We're not told if a sequence of a man following a woman down a street, being pushed away but then sharing an embrace acts out a story line about a lovers' quarrel and reconciliation, and since "Dreamworlds" doesn't list sources, there's no way to check it out. But the scene is clearly not a documentary. Most rock songs aren't about real life; they're about love, lust, good times, frustrations, fantasies. "Dreamworlds" is valid in its suggestion that popular culture can mold fantasies, but songwriters also try to tap into what's already there; students were getting crushes on teachers long before Van Halen wrote "Hot for Teacher."
Does all "rock video," or even a majority of clips, conform to what "Dreamworlds" describes? Hardly. I watched sizable chunks of MTV and tallied about one in six video clips showing ornamental women dancing or sexy women paying fealty to bands. Even in the hard-rock "Headbanger's Ball" or "Yo! MTV Raps," where there are more pretty people, shots of female faces and bodies are squeezed in between much longer sequences of male band members performing the songs and, often, preening.
Surprise: many of the males are bimbos, too, with longer hair, more outlandish costumes and just as much makeup as the women. Why doesn't some professor analyze male roles in music video? It's a man's world on MTV, and sooner or later most of them take off their shirts. If MTV presents any kind of overarching world view, it's a vision of male camaraderie, where women are more often absent or marginalized -- a bad idea, obviously, and the males' loss -- than victimized. As in advertising and most other television fare, music video prizes attractiveness; unglamorous people of either sex are reduced to comic walk-ons.
Even if sex-object women appear infrequently, "Dreamworlds" might make its case if that were the only role women were allowed. Wrong again. While there's perhaps two minutes per hour of female bimbofication, along with such various non-bimbos as moms, teachers, old women and children, there are also full-length songs with women singing them -- lately, Amy Grant's "Baby Baby," in which she and her chosen beefcake act out a romantic weekend, and Paula Abdul's "Rush Rush," in which Ms. Abdul and Keanu Reeves try to remake scenes from "Rebel Without a Cause."
Mr. Jhally's narration says that rock video detracts from thinking about women as "real people with feelings, emotions, intellects, their own dreams and ambitions." (Like whom? The members of Poison?) Although Ms. Grant and Ms. Abdul try to be three-dimensional characters, that's a lot to ask of a three-minute video -- and more than television provides in the average cop show or sitcom.
Near the end of "Dreamworlds," after admitting that "explicit violence is a small part of the dreamworld," Mr. Jhally cheats most blatantly. "Dreamworlds" shows long stretches of the rape scene from "The Accused" and intercuts snippets of rock videos over its soundtrack. Suddenly, Billy Idol shaking his fists on stage in a cloud of smoke, looking silly, is equated with men cheering on a gang rape. "Removed from their normal context, the rock video images did not look too different from the horrendous images of the rape," he narrates, as if similarities in lighting technique are the same as similarities in content.
The greatest flaw in both "Rising to the Challenge" and "Dreamworlds" is the attempt to connect the perceived evils of popular music to the real world. Both narrations reject simple cause-and-effect mechanisms -- "We realize that a normal healthy teen will not commit suicide because of a song," Mr. Linkletter says -- only to go on into fuzzy zones about how music and video are "important" influences on "attitudes," while ignoring other likely factors. (How about correlating the scary statistics with teen-age unemployment?)
When a teen-ager sees some guy with waist-length two-tone hair, wearing leopard-print spandex and studded leather, standing in a spotlight holding a guitar, he or she can probably figure out that it's a performance, a show, a fantasy -- part of a privileged arena far away from daily life.
Given the evidence, I wish I could say the same about their elders.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Music-video images used in the educational videotapes "Dreamworlds: Desire/Sex/Power in Rock Video," above and left, and "Rising to the Challenge"--trying to connect the perceived evils of popular music to the real world.

LENGTH: 1810 words

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Sacramento

BYLINE: By TERRY TRUCCO; TERRY TRUCCO grew up near Sacramento.

 BODY:
For years the best thing that could be said about Sacramento was that it was centrally situated, a short drive from the ocean, the wine country and interesting places, like San Francisco, Lake Tahoe and Yosemite. But these days, California's sprawling state capital can consider itself interesting in its own right.
Sacramento's charms are subtle. It's a pretty enough place, with a nicely restored downtown area, a splendid collection of refurbished Victorian houses and enormous suburbs that extend for miles. The city is bound by two fish-filled rivers, the American and the Sacramento. And with more than 120 parks and acres of municipal golf courses, there's an abundance of cool greenery. 
 The setting isn't dramatic, however. And while winters are mild, summer temperatures can shoot past 100 and fade the flowers. (Fortunately, everything in town is air-conditioned, except the great outdoors.)
But Sacramento is rich in a commodity that's almost as rare and precious in California as water -- history. By 1850, when Los Angeles was still a dusty dot, Sacramento was booming, with an economy based on agriculture, manufacturing and shipping. It was also the supply center for the gold rush in the nearby Mother Lode. In 1854 Sacramento easily beat out the competition to become the permanent capital for the four-year-old State of California. The city was also the logical choice for the first western terminus of the transcontinental railroad, completed in 1869.
Sacramento discovered its impressive past, and its tourist potential, in the 1960's, when a historic but slum-riddled area was threatened by plans for a new freeway. Instead the district was declared a state park, and restored as a living museum of the Gold Rush era. Old Sacramento, with its gas lights, cobbled streets and frontier-style wood buildings, is now home to the California State Railroad Museum, the fine Sacramento History Museum, the Towe Ford Museum, with a display of over 150 vintage Fords, and more than 100 restaurants, theaters and shops.
Sacramento's turn-of-the-century State Capitol building was also transformed into a municipal treasure in 1982. Completely gutted and restored to its 1907 splendor, it has served as a model for other states eager to revive early capitols.
Along the way, Sacramento has grown less provincial, with a symphony orchestra and ballet company, several theater groups and a zoo known for its chimps. It has a fine selection of restaurants. (Reservations at the best-known ones are a must, particularly at lunch.) And though the Kings, Sacramento's franchise in the National Basketball Association, don't have a terrific record, home games at the new Arco Arena are enthusiastically attended. In short, Sacramento has become a city of the 90's -- clean, pleasant and a nice place to take the kids.
 
 Events
 Free summer concerts are offered in McClatchy Park, 33d Street and Fifth Avenue, (916) 321-1792, on selected Saturdays, June 22 to Sept. 7. Concerts begin at 11:30 A.M. with local bands and end late in the day with a featured act. Performers include the jazz trumpeter Freddie Hubbard (June 22), the Latin drummer Pancho Sanchez (July 20), the Duke Ellington Orchestra (Aug. 17) and the Les McCann Orchestra (Sept. 7). The 15-acre park is well shaded and popular with picnickers.
Sacramento's biggest event of this, or any, summer, is the California State Fair, 1600 Exposition Boulevard, (916) 924-2015. The fair, Aug. 16 to Sept. 2, will have a pavilion devoted to the food, art and culture of Spain. Open 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. Admission $6.
Jill Trenary, Peggy Fleming and Kristi Yamaguchi are among the skaters performing in World Tour Figure Skating, June 11, 8 P.M. at Arco Arena, 1 Sports Parkway, (916) 928-8499. Tickets $22.50, $35.
The boxers Loreto Garza and Edwin Rosario head an evening of fights, June 14, 6 P.M. at Arco Arena. Tickets $27, $42, $62, $100.
 
 Sightseeing
 If Sacramento issued a postage stamp, the California State Capitol, 10th Street and Capitol Mall, (916) 324-0333, would probably be on it. Dignified, with an enormous copper dome, the neo-classical building houses the Governor's offices, a museum and the flamboyantly decorated chambers of the State Assembly and State Senate. (Visitors can watch debates when each house is in session.) The meticulously restored building has crenelated ceilings, intricate mosaic floors, stained-glass windows and witty touches, like carved grizzly bears, the state mascot, on the wooden banisters. Open daily, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Free admission.
Until 1967, when Gov. Ronald Reagan requested newer lodgings, California's governors resided at the Governor's Mansion, 1526 H Street, (916) 323-3047, a 26-room Victorian mansion (and one of California's first homes with indoor plumbing). The eclectic furnishings include an old-fashioned claw-footed bathtub with red fingernail polish on its toenails. Open daily from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., with tours on the hour. Admission $2.
The California State Railroad Museum, corner of Second Street and I Street, (916) 445-4209, has more than two dozen vintage engines and cars, which visitors can inspect. Train rides are offered on weekends in the summer. Open daily, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission $5.
The Crocker Art Museum, 216 O Street, (916) 449-5423, houses an appealing, if uneven, collection of European, American and northern California art in a restored Victorian art gallery and mansion. (The richly wallpapered ballroom is magnificent.) The museum is best known for its fine European drawing collection; an exhibition of French drawings, including renderings by Jean Honore Fragonard and Jacques Louis David, will run through June 30. Also on view is "Artful Deception -- the Craft of the Forger," June 21 to Aug. 18. Visitors are invited to spot the fakes in a group of 28 paintings and sculptures. Open Tuesday to Sunday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Thursday until 9 P.M. Admission $2.50.
The 135-year-old Leland Stanford Mansion, 802 N Street, (916) 324-0575, the oldest house in Sacramento open to the public, is being restored. Visitors wishing to see how a major restoration is done can view this work in progress.
Stanford, founder of Stanford University, was president of the Central Pacific Railroad Corporation and a governor of California.
Open for tours most Tuesdays and Thursdays at 12:15 P.M., Saturdays at 12:15 P.M. and 1:30 P.M. Call to verify schedule. Free admission.
Sacramento's modern history began in 1839, when John Augustus Sutter arrived from Switzerland, built an adobe fort and named his land New Helvetia (New Switzerland). Sutter's Fort, 2701 L Street, (916) 445-4422, housed workers who tilled Sutter's fields.
The fort also provided free shelter and supplies for pioneers, including surviving members of the ill-fated Donner Party in 1846. June 15 is Living History Day, with re-enactments of events from 1846. Open daily 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission $2, special events $3.
<> <>
 
Where to Stay
 For years Sacramento was a city of big, styleless motels with overworked air-conditioners. These days it's possible to find something considerably more elegant.
The Sterling Hotel, 1300 H Street, (800) 365-7660 outside Sacramento and (916) 448-1300 in Sacramento, opened three years ago in a spotlessly restored Victorian mansion near the State Capitol. Guests ascend the imposing central staircase to the 12 rooms, which are mostly large, with high ceilings, handsome wood furniture and big, marble-tiled bathrooms with whirlpool baths. Rooms for two from $110 to $225.
Under the same ownership, the Driver Mansion Inn, 2019 21st Street, (800) 456-2019 outside Sacramento and (916) 455-5242 in Sacramento, is a nine-room bed and breakfast inn in a large white turn-of-the-century house. Rooms, from $75 to $225, blend antiques and traditional pieces from the 1920's and '30s. The largest have whirlpool baths.
Sacramento has several other bed and breakfast inns in handsome old houses. Aunt Abigail's, 2120 G Street, (916) 441 5007, has a spacious, light-filled sitting room and a window-lined dining room where guests breakfast on blueberry-filled french toast. Doubles from $70 to $115. The Bear Flag Inn, 2814 I Street, (916) 448-5417, has five rooms, from $75 to $125, in a 1910 California Arts and Crafts-style house.
The 502-room Hyatt Regency Sacramento, 1209 L Street, (800) 233-1234, opened three years ago and is a cut above most chain hotels. Directly across from the State Capitol, its window-lined piano lounge is a popular place to watch passers-by. Rooms, from $162, are huge, furnished in pastels (front rooms have wonderful views).
The 353-room Radisson Hotel, 500 Leisure Lane, (800) 333-3333, covers 18 acres in east Sacramento and has a lake where guests can rent a canoe or paddle boat. Doubles from $94.
Budget choice: The Vagabond Inn, 909 Third Street, (916) 446-1481, is near Old Sacramento and has a swimming pool. Doubles from $55.
 
 Where to Eat
 Since opening five years ago on a busy corner near Sutter's Fort, Biba, 2801 Capitol Avenue, (916) 455-2422, has been popular with legislators and locals. Biba Caggiano, author of several books on Italian cooking, chats with her customers, then disappears into the kitchen to oversee dishes like homemade ravioli stuffed with eggplant and duck with port and sweet cherries. Dinner for two with a modest bottle of wine about $70 plus tip.
With its thick green carpets, handsome wood furniture and candlelight, Mitchell's Terrace, 544 Pavillions Lane, (916) 920-3800), is probably the most romantic -- and expensive -- restaurant in town. The California-French offerings, which change monthly, can include roast loin of arctic moose with carmelized shallots. Dinner for two about $100.
Chanterelle, 1300 H Street, (916) 442-0451), is small and chic, with tables in three little rooms on the ground floor of the Sterling Hotel. Among the California-style specialties are quail with chestnuts and rosemary. Dinner for two about $80.
Caffe Donatello, 2627 Town & Country Place, (916) 973-1800, serves northern Italian dishes and crispy breads in an airy building with a cathedral ceiling in Town & Country Village. Individual pizzas are a specialty, with prosciutto, artichokes and mushrooms ($8.75) or mozzarella and Roma tomatoes ($6.95). Dinner for two about $50.
Paragary's Bar & Oven, 1401 28th Street, (916) 457-5737, and 2384 Fair Oaks Boulevard, (916) 485-7100), is lively and casual, known for brick-oven pizzas and huge plates of pasta salad. About $20 for two.
The Tower Cafe, 1518 Broadway, (916) 441-0222, is an arch 1990's version of the classic 1950's-style coffee shop. Open all day, the cafe is ideal for a hamburger ($6.95 for an All American Burger, with bacon and cheese) or meatless Earth Burger (made with nuts, $5.95).

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Times Square Signs;
Things That Go Blink in the Night

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
THEY say the neon signs will be even brighter on Broadway, as the Ramada Renaissance hotel rises over Duffy Square with blazing billboards. But there is some darkness around the edges.
"We feel the recession, but not nearly as much as the retail business or the real-estate market," said Richard Schaps, president of Van Wagner Communications of Manhattan, who estimates that his company handles 85 percent of the signs around Times Square. 
 "Five or six years ago, we had a waiting list," he said. "At this time, we have some space. But it's not wide open.
"Signage in Times Square is never part of an advertiser's original budget," Mr. Schaps said. "We are always looking for companies with additional promotional dollars outside their normal advertising budget. In these times, it's more difficult to scour up these additional dollars. At the same time, advertisers do know the advantages of having that name in front of the public 365 days a year, and the additional benefits of being photographed millions of times.
"It's the most expensive real estate in the world, if you figure it on a per-square-foot basis," he said. "It's much, much greater than any office or retail space in the world" -- which would mean well over $200.
Besides an increase in supply and a slackening demand, Mr. Schaps has noticed another trend: "We see a resurgence of American advertisers very much in the Times Square area. That is due to the fact that we have eight or nine new hotels and you're really seeing Times Square turn back into the entertainment mecca that it once was."
Of the two dozen or so giant signs in Times Square, more than a third currently advertise Japanese electronics and photographic concerns. But more than half advertise domestic products or services.
Other signs are on the way. In recent weeks, the Ramada Renaissance hotel has taken form, showing the facade on 47th Street on which three giant signs are to be hung, for Coca-Cola, Suntory whisky and Samsung electronics. (For now, the only sign is the workers' graffito: "The Moose Is Loose.")
At the base of the building will be an "enormous electronic cube, 20 feet off the ground, smack in the middle of Times Square," as described by the developer, Jeffrey Katz. At the top will be, again in his words, a "big, elliptical sign with concentric rings like the rings of Saturn and a 50-foot radio tower." Neither has been leased yet.
That is not all. There are to be two more signs projecting from the Broadway side, one shaped like an accordion, the other like a wedge. The architects are Mayers & Schiff Associates of Manhattan.
"What we're selling here is visibility," the developer said. "When movie-makers want to say, 'This is New York,' this is what they shoot."
Mr. Katz said he expected the Coke, Suntory and Samsung signs to be ready in time for the Thanksgiving Day parade. The hotel is not to open until next February.
The Ramada Renaissance tower may be the most conspicuous, but it is not alone.
Although Ian Bruce Eichner's One Broadway Place tower, at 45th Street, is missing its office tenants, shopping mall and movie theaters, it does have the new 34- by 65-foot "Qlinn" display, which sits on a setback overlooking Broadway. This is to be joined soon by a neon spectacular for Gold Star, a Korean electronics concern.
Qlinn (pronounced KEW-linn) is composed of 84,000 cubes, each of which has four visible faces: red, blue, white and green. As these rotate, they form distinct patterns, images and letters in dozens of colors.
Hiroji Hamanaka, the president of Qlinn New York, said advertisements, news, time, weather forecasts and general information would be displayed on the board 22 hours a day. The parent concern, Nihon Advanced Products Company, already operates such boards in Asia, Europe and South America, but the one in Times Square, Mr. Hamanaka said, is the biggest.
MCI Communications Corporation is operating a huge digital display between 46th and 47th Streets that constantly ticks off the number of dollars that "America Is Saving By Using MCI Instead of A.T.&T."
ANOTHER sign is also being added to One Times Square, the former Times Tower, between 42d and 43d Street, which is already caked with advertisements for New York Newsday, Pepsi, Minolta and Sony.
In addition, a spot on the Embassy Suites hotel, Broadway and 47th Street, has been leased to Warner Brothers.
Many of the new signs result from zoning rules adopted in the 1980's. These were meant to perpetuate the "nature of the signs that gave character to Times Square," while allowing a "wide choice" in design and placement, said Lauren Otis, chief urban designer for the City Planning Department.
The rules apply to all new developments on Broadway and Seventh Avenue, between 43d and 50th Street. In simplified form, they establish the following formulas:
* At ground level, there must be at least one illuminated sign for each establishment on Seventh Avenue or Broadway.
* There must be illuminated signs with 12 square feet of surface for each linear foot of frontage on Seventh Avenue or Broadway, as well as a portion of any intersecting side street. These must be installed between the height of 10 and 60 feet.
* There must be "super" signs -- illuminated and animated -- with 50 square feet of surface for each linear foot of frontage. These must be installed between the height of 10 and 120 feet.
The most conspicuously unblazing towers are 1585 Broadway, at 47th Street, and 750 Seventh Avenue, at 49th Street, both developed by Solomon Equities.
Although signs are required at both sites, the regulation does not take force until a certificate of occupancy is requested for more than half of the new building.
"For 1585, we have leases out that will bring the building up to 60 percent, so we're working on that signage right now," said Jean W. Solomon, president of Solomon Equities. At 750 Seventh Avenue, she said, leases are out for 40 percent of the building, so the question of signs is also "of concern."
"THE signage we're displaying we want to be in keeping with the first-class quality of the buildings and the tenants," Mrs. Solomon said. "While we could have gone out and leased to outside advertisers, we've decided to have the input of our tenants and to use certain signage for tenant identification in the building." She said there was also room for building identification. Some signs will be supported by the vertical "fins" that hang over the Broadway sidewalk. There would be super signs above the first setback.
At 750 Seventh Avenue, the signs would be behind glass, so there would be no framework on the exterior. In addition, the spire at the top of the tower would be illuminated.
Perhaps the only place beside the Solomon buildings where restraint is deliberately being exercised is on the Seventh Avenue facade of the Ramada Renaissance. That is to be a plain, dark glass wall with a single sign for the hotel.
"The hotel guest's experience is one of the Seventh Avenue exposure, with a discrete entrance," said Bruce W. McIntosh, regional vice president of Ramada International Hotels and Resorts, and general manager of the Times Square hotel. "They don't get the impression of being in a building with signs hung all over it."
The sign itself is at an oblique angle to the guest rooms, which are further protected from it by double panes of tinted glass. "This isn't a cheap motel sign or an 'Eat at Joe's' sign," Mr. Katz said. "You won't hear it or see it."

HEADLINE: Talking: Refinancing;
Shopping For a Deal For a Co-op

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
A GROWING number of New York City co-ops are scrambling to refinance their underlying mortgages and many are encountering unexpected -- but not insurmountable -- roadblocks.
 Sagging real estate values and difficulties with financially troubled sponsors are making lenders more conservative about the amount they will provide and the buildings they deem acceptable. As a result, boards are being forced to learn how to cope with new realities to get what they need. 
 The underlying mortgage on the building is separate from any loans shareholders in the co-op corporationmay have made to buy their apartments.
 Some co-ops, such as the 60-unit building at 878 West End Avenue, at 102d Street, are eager to refinance because they want to lower monthly payments by taking advantage of today's exceptionally low interest rates.
 Others are eager to get out of the mortgage loan placed on the building by the sponsor at the time of conversion. "Loans that looked so great at the beginning are now starting to hurt," said Marcie Waterman, a Manhattan laywer specializing in co-ops. She explained that many were structured to carry an artifically low rate for the early years in return for higher costs later.
 Still other buildings have no choice because individual unit sales are being affected. "Lenders have become reluctant to finance shares unless the building's underlying mortgage has at least two or three years to run," said Bernard G. Walpin, a lawyer on the Upper West Side who specializes in co-ops and has several clients facing such a predicament.
 And finally, more and more co-ops are reaching the end of the 5- or 10-year term on existing mortgages taken out in the heyday of conversions in the late 80's. Unlike a one-family house with a personal mortgage, a multifamily building is normally limited to a balloon mortgage that must be refinanced or renegotiated every 5 or 10 years even though monthly payments may be based on a 30-year amortization schedule.
 Strategies for getting a commitment on a new mortgage will initially hinge on whether the sponsor still owns some units. If the sponsor owns more than 30 percent it may be futile to shop around, say mortgage brokers. Many bankers are still refusing to deal with these buildings, fearing financial difficulties should the sponsor default.
"So you will have to stay with the original lender," said Daniel Cunningham, an associate with Harvey P. Katz & Associates, a mortgage broker that often handles co-ops.
 This may mean higher, not lower, interest charges. Mr. Cunningham insists it is so because the loan is considered riskier. But before rushing to pay such a premium, consider the approach of Bernard Liebman, a laywer in Rockville Centre, L.I., who has managed to get reduced interest charges even in these situations.
The original underlying mortgage of $1.1 million on a 50-unit building in Greenwich Village was coming due for refinancing this year, but 30 percent of the units were still owned by the sponsor. Mr. Liebman made a point of showing the lender how the shareholders were already struggling to meet rising maintenance costs caused by higher water and sewer charges and real estate taxes. Thus, he noted, it would not be in anyone's interest to place even more pressure on them.
AS a result, said Mr. Liebman, an agreement was reached to refinance the outstanding balance at a special low introductory rate of 7.5 percent for the first three years, rising to 10 percent for the remaining two years (the old loan had carried a fixed interest rate of 10.7 percent). In return, the co-op agreed to pay the lender the proceeds from its 4 percent flip tax levied on profits realized by individual shareholders when they sell their units. Further, by staying with the same lender, said Mr. Liebman, the co-op saved on closing costs.
 Mature co-ops -- those where all units are now privately owned or where less than 30 percent are still sponsor-controlled -- can still shop around for the best deal. But even these co-ops should be prepared to encounter more stringent limits on the amount the lender is willing to provide.
"One of our buildings that was offered $12.5 million in the late 1980's will be lucky to get $8 million today," said Ms. Waterman. As a result, boards should no longer automatically count on refinancing as a way to generate auxiliary funds for major capital improvement, say the experts.
 Boards should be prepared, too, for tougher and more detailed questions. For example, lenders may insist on a clause that gives them the right to mandate increases in maintenance costs if payments become delinquent, warned David A. Tane, a colleague of Ms. Waterman.
Other lenders, said Mr. Tane, are requiring co-ops to pledge assets from their operating or reserve accounts. Some lenders may also want financial information on individual shareholders -- "to see if they can pay increased charges if needed," he added. Further, even if the sponsor owns only a handful of units the lender may require details about that sponsor's financial condition, too.
 Closing costs must be monitored carefully, since some of the lenders' added requirements are raising such charges. Mr. Cunningham, the mortgage broker, has found that lenders are asking for an "environmental" report -- actully a euphemism for a professional inspection -- to determine whether a building has any asbestos. An updated engineering report may also be required. All this can add $5,000 or $6,000 to the tab.
 Care should also be taken to minimize the impact of the state's mortgage recording tax, which is now 2 percent for loan under $500,000 and 2.75 percent for loans of $500,000 or more. The tax can usually be eliminated, said Ms. Waterman, by having the old mortgage assigned to the new lender. If an additional sum over and above the original amount is being borrowed, the mortgage recording tax would be due only on the excess.
Another way to eliminate these taxes would be to borrow from the National Cooperative Bank. Formed by Congressional charter in 1978, it is exempt from all these levies. The bank has refinanced the underlying mortgages of some 130 buildings in New York City in the last three years, said Sheldon Gartenstein, vice president and regional manager. His office is at 101 East 52d Street.
Finally, boards should not overlook help that may be available to them from the managing agents of their buildings. Some management firms have specialists in mortgage finance who know the market and can suggest lenders willing to offer refinancings. Directors can then compare the terms of those lenders with what other lenders offer.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Foreclosure Stalls East Lyme Project

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
THE Bride Brook Nursing & Rehabilitation Center, under construction on two acres at Rocky Neck Corporate Park in East Lyme, is the only sign of life on the stalled 38-acre development.
Abandoned construction trailers with outdated building permits in the windows, and weeds bending to the wind, dot the landscape. But the $5 million, 62,000-square-foot health facility continues to rise at a brisk pace, headed for a fall opening. 
 "Speed and quality of work are high," said Kevin Morrissey, project manager for the builder, C. R. Klewin Construction Company of Norwich. "A lot of good men are out of work and we get the cream of the crop."
The center got town approval as part of a plan for 600,000 square feet of office, light-industrial and nursing-home space on 15 lots. It was proposed in 1987 by the E & F Company of Bridgeport, a 65-year-old construction and development concern that went bankrupt last year.
The buildings were to resemble mills and ship chandleries along winding, tree-lined streets in a New England village concept. But only four lots besides the nursing-home site were sold before the recession and bad investments by E & F forced foreclosure on the unsold 26 acres, and on E & F's only completed structure, a vacant office building. Two empty lots are for sale by the owner, Donald Brodeur of Old Saybrook, who said, "We'd consider anything."
 The 120-bed Bride Brook facility for subacute care, a type of licensed skilled nursing service, will receive reimbursement from Medicare, Medicaid, health maintenance organizations and private insurers. It is one of seven such facilities owned and operated by Mariner Health Care of Mystic.
 Mariner accepts patients over the age of 14 who are too well for a hospital but not well enough to go home. Fees vary, but they average a third to half the cost of a hospital stay, said Sandy Lawson, vice president of marketing. Jennifer Gallagher, vice president of development, said: "We are cost-effective because we don't have to support an emergency room or operating room."
 The building resembles a large seaside cottage. The architects, Design Group One of Hartford, used a mix of clapboard and shingles treated with bleaching oil for a natural exterior with white trim and balconies.
 Local realtors are not having much luck selling the park's remaining lots. They had been marketed at $125,000 an acre and are currently valued at about $90,000 to $100,000 with electricity and water lines in. Sewer lines will be operative in September.
 "We have to clear all offers with City Trust in Bridgeport or Fleet/Norstar in Providence, the banks that hold the property," said James Moore, former vice president of E & F. Current zoning permits professional offices, light-industrial use, warehousing and garden centers. Dutton Realtors of Mystic, Dunham Realtors of Lyme and MCR Property Management of New Haven are among those handling the open listing.
 Structured Technologies Corporation, contractors of engineering software for the Navy, was scheduled to rent E & F's office building but backed out over a dispute about construction and a setback in its own finances. Andrew Macy, co-president with Pat Haftaris of S.T.C., said: "we are now talking to Fleet/Norstar about moving in. We feel that the park and the community will bounce back."
 E & F began developing the project, which is off Exit 72 of I-95 before the effects of the 1987 stock market crash took hold. It got into trouble when its construction division started funding the development division in real estate deals that turned sour.
LAST month the park's prospects were darkened further by the announcement by the Department of Defense that it may move substantial portions of its naval installations out of the New London-Groton area. "The whole southeastern Connecticut region would be seriously affected," said David Mills, vice-president of Schnip Development Corporation in Norwich, a major regional company. Most area businesses depend on the Navy.
 When Electric Boat was awarded a Navy contract on May 5 to build a Sea Wolf submarine at the Groton plant, the news was greeted with joy. But a few days later the Newport News Shipping & Dry Dock Company in Virginia sued in Federal District Court, alleging improper bidding. Judge Robert G. Doumar issued an injunction stopping work on the sub and set a July 11 court date.
 "We are confident that the Sea Wolf will be awarded to Electric Boat," said William Moore, executive director of the New London Chamber of Commerce, who has been attending Congressional hearings in Washington as an advocate of preserving the region's defense industries. "But we are seeing the decommissioning of the U.S.S. Fulton submarine with 1,500 naval personnel and the relocation of a possible 3,000 Navy people out of the area."
 Another Department of Defense proposal would downsize the Navy Underwater Sound Systems Center in New London from 1,500 civilians to 400 by moving most of them to Newport, R.I. The center is the Navy's principal research and testing arm for submarine warfare and surface ship sonar systems.
 According to S.G. Payne, the center's public affairs officer, "the proposal is a cost-containment measure."
"It will go to President Bush in a package around July 1 for his approval or disapproval," he said, "after which the package goes to Congress for a vote. No item-by-item deals."
 "Taking people from here and putting them in Newport is no savings," said David Cini, First Selectman of East Lyme. "We think it will take the Navy 25 years to break even."
 A drain of engineers and scientists is as worrisome to the region as the economic ramifications, and alternatives for the future are being sought by the Southeastern Economic Development Coalition of business and community leaders of all New London County towns, meeting regularly since last fall.
"We expect to complete a guide for action by the end of this year," said Richard Erickson, director of the Southeastern Regional Planning Agency in Norwich.
 Neil Runzel, communications officer for Electric Boat and an East Lyme resident, believes that "we will get Sea Wolf, but we can't live on one submarine a year -- we must find another source of income."

HEADLINE: Postings: City Hall Forum;
The Co-op/Condo Troubles

 BODY:
Eighteen months after serious financial problems began to emerge in recently converted New York City co-ops and condominiums, the fallout has spread across all five of the city's boroughs. Accordingly, the five borough presidents are for the first time sponsoring a public forum on what they call "The Co-op/Condo Financial Crisis" at City Hall. It is scheduled for Wednesday evening, from 6:30 to 9 P.M., in the Board of Estimate chamber.
Among the speakers will be Frederick K. Mehlman, the assistant attorney general in charge of New York state's Real Estate Finance Bureau, which regulates co-op and condominium conversions, and Stuart Saft, a Manhattan real estate lawyer who has respresented several co-op boards seeking to work out problems with their sponsors and avoid foreclosure on their buildings by lenders. Borough Presidents Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, Claire Shulman of Queens and Howard Golden of Brooklyn have promised to attend, while Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx and Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island will either attend or send representatives, according to a spokesman for Ms. Schulman, who first proposed the joint forum. 
 Mr. Mehlman's office, which requires disclosure of the financial condition of co-ops and condominiums, has reported that sponsors have fallen behind in their obligations at more than 200 buildings. Those sponsors were in default on maintenance payments, loan payments and taxes. Many of them retain large numbers of rent-regulated apartments, whose tenants elected not to buy them in noneviction conversion plans, and whose rents are less than is necessary to cover monthly maintenance charges. The officials said the forum was designed to provide information on the legal rights of co-op and condominium owners, as well as tenants, and strategies for financial workouts.

HEADLINE: Postings: Sonny Mae Program;
Wider Mortgage Eligibility

 BODY:
The State of New York Mortgage Agency -- known as Sonny Mae -- makes home mortgages with below market rates available to first-time homebuyers who aren't too rich and whose dream houses are not too costly. Under new income and cost guidelines established last month, threshold standards have been raised, making it easier for more people to qualify for the program.
Although income and home cost limits vary by region of the state, the income maximum for households to qualify for the mortgages has been raised $4,200, on average, statewide, to just under $50,000. Housing cost limits for one-family properties were raised by an average of $11,900 for all regions, and now range from about $120,000 in much of upstate to $176,000 on Long Island. 
 Sonny Mae sells tax-free state bonds to make the mortgages, which are issued through participating lenders. The agency, which has issued $2.4 billion in mortgages to 41,000 families in the last eight years, currently charges 8.4 percent for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage, about one percentage point below market rate.
In New York City, the new income limit is $42,520 and the cost limit for a one-family house is $159,000. But there are ways around the limits, for those who move into an economically blighted area. In these so-called target areas, city residents can earn up to $50,520 and buy a house costing $193,600, while Long Islanders may have incomes to $65,400 and pay $201,300 for a house. The Sonny Mae information line is (800) 382-HOME.

HEADLINE: HOBOKEN JOURNAL;
Night Life With 'Music Coming Out of Every Doorway'

BYLINE: By CHRISTINA JOHNSON

DATELINE: HOBOKEN

 BODY:
IT used to be that some young New Jerseyans would hang out in Hoboken only if they didn't have the cash to get through the tunnel.
But now all kinds are coming to carouse on Washington Street, the main boulevard. They can be seen lined up at the bank machines: young women in wobbly white heels, musicians in spray-painted combat boots and college students in sneakers. They watch where the young men in tasseled penny loafers are going and then bolt in the other direction. 
 The rapid gentrification that squeezed artists out of their lofts, split up ethnic neighborhoods and let in the young professionals has charged Hoboken night life with purpose. People who wear suits to bars have replaced the police as the thing to avoid.
"The yuppies provided everyone with a common enemy," said Robin Shamburg, a 22-year-old writer who has been frequenting Hoboken night spots since she had fake identification at 14.
"All kinds of people from different political and social stratas started hanging out together," she said, "people who normally wouldn't have been caught dead in the same bars."
Ms. Shamburg and her friends from neighboring towns hang out and roll cigarettes in a narrow bar called Boo-Boo's on Newark Street, next to a former sailors' hangout, the Clam Broth House. One habitue describedBoo-Boo's decor, which includes little drink umbrellas stuck in the ceiling and Christmas lights tangled up on the walls, as a "Gilligan's Island boutique." When there isn't a blues band playing, there's reggae or house music on the jukebox.
Late on a recent Friday night, people in their 20's, in jeans, boots and motorcycle jackets, were sitting on the rickety chairs at Boo-Boo's, waving friends over to their wobbly tables. If they hadn't gone to high school with the cashier at the door, they paid $2 to get in, which is $2 more than most bars charge. Susan Shaftan, the manager, who wears a smock, black sneakers and a crystal around her neck as she works the crowd, said there was a cover charge to keep the number of customers under control.
All night long, bits of the crowd at Boo-Boo's cross the street to Red Heads on Hudson Street, a good place for beer in long-necked bottles and free Cheese Doodles. It's locally famous as the place run by a former showgirl for lonely sailors.
But there are others who prefer the bars on the opposite side of town. Peter Keane, a 39-year-old owner of a Harley-Davidson Sportster and a self-described "crisis specialist," says he avoids yuppies in Hoboken, whom he calls "insidious and annoying." He says he goes where they wouldn't go.
 
A Place for 'Intelligent Conversations'
 "Fabian's," Mr. Keane said, "is the best place to hang out and have some intelligent conversations." There the other night, he said, he had a drink with a lawyer who gave up his practice to be a delivery boy.
Rich young professionals, Ms. Shamburg said, can be credited for contributing something to Hoboken pub culture. "Hoboken didn't know 'happy hour' before yuppies came along," she said.
In those twilight hours when caffeinated breezes from the Maxwell House plant waft through town and beer is only a dollar, the sidewalks can be teeming with people doing the pub crawl. More than one observer has noticed unusually large numbers of college-age men at the bars.
Shayna Felts, who works in the student center at the Stevens Institute of Technology, at Sixth Street, said she had a clue as to why.
"There are five men to every woman at Stevens," said the 24-year-old Ms. Felts, a computer science graduate student there. "They say we have attitude, but it's no big deal. Nine out of ten of them are dorks."
This could be part of the reason why there are so many friendly young men in places like Good & Plenti, where waitresses and female patrons are encouraged to dance on the bar, and Stinky Sullivan's, a place that stands out in this city because it doesn't have a pool table. They also go to Shooters, a large dance club with lots of mirrors, which has been nicknamed the Hair Bar for the women's unusually large coiffures.
This is not to be confused with the new-wave club called Down Under, which is nicknamed the Cop Bar. It is across the street from the police headquarters.
Off the beaten path on Jefferson Street, a gay club called Excalibur caters to a mostly male crowd. Upstairs, where they have summer barbecues, and downstairs on the dance floor the crowd seemed relaxed and friendly.
When people head off the dance floor and go to the bar, they find more than liquor in the glasses. In neat bundles are neon orange business cards, and on the back blank lines with the words "name, address and phone number." A glass of pencils is within reach.
No matter how they have changed bar-hopping, Hoboken's new residents have had little effect on the music scene. People still come from as far as Philadelphia to hear all kinds of bands on the cutting edge.
"You walk downtown on a Saturday night, and it's like you're walking down the boardwalk at Asbury Park," said Jim Testa, the music columnist for Gold Coast, a local weekly. "There's music coming out of every doorway."
If a pub or pizzeria can squeeze in a band, it will. On a recent Friday night, a blues band called Haley and the Hand Jives performed in the corner of Red Heads. The lead singer sang behind a mirrored column, so she was the only one who saw her perform.
On Washington Street at the Brass Rail, a bistro known for its raspberry beer, Tim Cafaro's band was jazzing it up at the bustling bar. At a swanky restaurant called Frankie and Johnnie's On the Waterfront, at 14th Street and Garden, a pianist and his baby grand sat right next to the tables.
The most talked-about music scene, though, is in the alternative rock category. There's a club called Live Tonight!, where the bartender stuffs his ears with cocktail napkins, and then there's the city's pride, Maxwell's.
"It's a landmark," Mayme Jurkat said of Maxwell's. "It's a place where young musicians can get a hearing; it's very much an institution." Ms. Jurkat is the director of Hoboken Advantage Inc., a nonprofit economic development company.
Emilio China is the 21-year-old lead singer of a Hoboken band that plays the local clubs. The band is called Sweet Lizard Illtet, and Mr. China described its sound as "somewhere between hip-hop, hard core, and funk industrial rock." Last month the band was offered a recording contract, he said.
 
Influences on the Music
 Mr. China, who wears mismatched sneakers and multicolored braids in the chunks of hair he hasn't shaved off, said Hoboken's changing demographics had affected the music heard around town. "It's a standard rock-youth, big-hair, heavy-metal thing," he said, but "mixed up with the New York club scene." He said the Latin and black street music sounds popular in the local neighborhoods could be heard in the music.
Residents of Hoboken don't mind visitors, but prefer them to take the PATH train or the bus. A look at Washington Street shows why: cars are double and triple parked. Once, the $5 ticket was no big deal, but at the turn of the year the fine shot up to $31.
"My sister lived here for two years," said Patti Moorehead of Montclair, who was eating at East L.A., a trendy Mexican restaurant. "She finally came home because she couldn't find a parking space."
