LENGTH: 794 words

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Antioch;
Cross-Cultural Program Looks at 2 Areas in U.S.

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
John Sims says he be lieves in a hands-on approach to African-American cultures, especially when those cultures are in the United States and readily available to students. So for last six weeks, Mr. Sims, assistant to the dean of the faculty at Antioch College in Yellow Springs, Ohio, has led six Antioch students into direct encounters with two distinct black communities in the southeastern United States -- the Gullahs of South Carolina's Sea Islands and the townspeople of Keysville, in rural eastern Georgia.
"If you want to talk about the African-American experience you have to look to the roots of that experience in the Southeast," Mr. Sims explained on the group's return from the Martin Luther King Center for Nonviolent Social Change in Atlanta, the last leg of the field trip, which ends tomorrow. 
 "The Gullahs, which were isolated from the mainland for many years, have retained many Africanisms," Mr. Simms said. "Keysville, by contrast, offers students the opportunity to live with, learn from and work in a contemporary rural African-American community that is going through political, economic and social change."
 
 Retaining Sense of Family
 Renee Davis, a third-year communications and visual arts major from Washington, said she was surprised to find that "there are a lot of communities that retain Africanisms as a survival mechanism." Keysville, she noted, has retained a strong sense of family and community involvement. "They are meeting their problems, the same problems we face in a lot of urban areas, with different strategies."
The students' field work, combined with community service and anthropology, history, cross-cultural studies and environmental courses, constitutes the Cross-Cultural Field Program, the domestic component to the multicultural curriculum being developed at Antioch. The curriculum will require all undergraduates to be proficient in a foreign language and to study another culture first hand, either in foreign countries or in the United States.
Mr. Sims said the program challenged students to think "that cross-cultural studies don't always happen somewhere 'out there'; they also happen here."
Antioch students are already required to hold paying or volunteer jobs for six academic quarters. Both programs, Mr. Sims said, show Antioch's commitment to "experiential learning -- learning by doing."
Mr. Sims, a 1990 Antioch graduate in mathematics, said he was inspired to create the program when he was an undergraduate studying in Europe. "I was amazed at the level of attention the Europeans gave to African-American culture and at the low level of such attention in the United States."
 
'Diversity Exists'
 "I wanted students to understand that diversity exists in African-American experience along many lines -- culture and language, for example -- and that there are also some shared experiences and knowledge," Mr. Sims said. "And I wanted them to recognize that we are all Americans. White students, too, should understand that part of their experience as Americans is the black experience."
In preparation for the field work, students took three weeks of seminars and lectures at Antioch and became involved in the African-American Cultural Week celebration that Mr. Sims started. "The idea is that if we are going to talk about race relations in the South, we must talk about them in Yellow Springs, Ohio," Mr. Sims said.
The bulk of the field work was done among the Gullah community and in Keysville, where 80 percent of the 400 residents are black.
The community work centered on Keysville, where students helped in the local library and tutoring children, Mr. Sims said.
"Part of Antioch's history is the belief that social action is important," Mr. Sims said. "And I believe that institutions of higher learning have a responsibility to deal with social ills and should not be disenchanted with or divorce themselves from those problems."
The group's itinerary also included stops at the Avery Center for African-American Culture in Charleston, S.C.; the Highlander Center near Knoxville, Tenn., an important meeting place and training ground for leaders of the civil rights and union movements, and the King Center in Atlanta.
The students will spend the rest of the quarter, which ends on June 22, preparing papers and oral presentations on specific topics studied in the field.
The lessons of the program extend far beyond the specific subjects studied, said a first-year student, Sharane Antonette, a cross-cultural studies major from Baltimore . "We need to learn all the things we can about other cultures, their ideas, the way they approach problems, and see what works," Ms. Antonette said. "We didn't save Keysville; Keysville saved us."

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
Disneyland As Antidote For Poverty

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW

 BODY:
After winning $100 in a lottery, a homeless young California family splurges on a day at Disneyland. While there, the father (Philip Seymour Hoffman) decides to prolong the experience by staying on in the theme park after closing time. He and his wife and their daughter camp on Tom Sawyer's Island, and the couple have a romantic interlude in the Swiss Family Robinson treehouse. As might be expected, the reckless idyll ends disastrously. But within months the family has become fabled among other homeless people as the ones who lived at Disneyland.
This is the fanciful but grim beginning of Jane Anderson's "Food and Shelter," at the Vineyard Theater. At the outset Ms. Anderson sets her polarities: the magical though manufactured kingdom against the dreariness of those whose only residence is a car and whose life is otherwise circumscribed by food stamps and soup kitchens. If the playwright had been able to sustain the initial feelings aroused by her work, this might have been a disturbing portrait of what it means to be down and falling out in recession-struck America. 
 For all its flashes of quirky humor and its realistic depiction of everyday frustration and anguish, "Food and Shelter" wanders over the landscape. The play shifts in and out of Disneyland and loses its best intention on the road to social commentary.
With the family split after the overnight adventure, the mother and daughter embark on a desperate struggle for borderline survival -- and to overcome the red tape and recalcitrance of those who are supposed to be offering them help. Unable to work because she has no place to leave the child, the mother waits impatiently for word from her prodigal husband.
Despite one's natural sympathy for the mother's predicament, she soon becomes irritating as she moves helplessly from one unwelcome place to another. Although some of the encounters make their point, scenes are repetitive. A curious reversal takes place. We feel an annoyance with the woman even as she faces obstacles. Kelly Coffield's single-edged performance as the mother does not enhance the situation, although admittedly the playwright has not given her an interesting character with which to work. As the daughter, T-F Walker seems overly quarrelsome.
In an evident attempt to inject imagination into the script, Ms. Anderson creates a fantasy friend for the girl, who is suddenly enabled to read and to see through mailboxes. The flirtation with magical powers leads to a few comical moments, but it is ultimately as fleeting as the family life itself. While Ann Sheffield's design is elaborate -- a mock Matterhorn towers over the first act -- it also means unwieldy changing of scenery. Andre Ernotte's staging is unable to conceal the episodic nature of the narrative.
Not until the father returns after months of abandonment does the play regain its dramatic stride. With the enthusiasm of someone who has been reborn on the road, Mr. Hoffman tells shaggy tales about riding the rails and discovering untarnished beaches. At one point he describes two Beverly Hills professional men who once a year pretend to be homeless, traveling with hoboes while keeping their credit cards sewn in their clothing for a quick return to prosperity.
These and other stories -- and Mr. Hoffman's vibrant performance -- make one think that the playwright may have concentrated attention on the less rewarding half of the family, or at least that she should have been more equitable in her split-focus vision of people "living on the outside of regular life."
 
FOOD AND SHELTER
 
By Jane Anderson; directed by Andre Ernotte; scenic design by Ann Sheffield; lighting, Donald Holder; costumes, Muriel Stockdale; sound and music, Aural Fixation; production stage manager, Crystal Huntington; production manager, Mark Lorenzen. Presented by the Vineyard Theater, Douglas Aibel, artistic director-theater; Barbara Zinn Krieger, executive director; Jon Nakagawa, managing director. At 108 East 15th Street.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Protecting Limited Partners . . .

BYLINE: By Alison Leigh Cowan

 BODY:
Limited partners are the Rodney Dangerfields of the investor community. They get less information on properties they own than shareholders of most public companies. They rarely have annual meetings and thus have few opportunities to compare notes. And their interests are rarely protected by a board of directors.
"Limited partnership is just another name for a totalitarian state," said Barry Vinocur, editor of Stanger's Partnership Watch, in Shrewsbury, N.J. "There is no such thing as shareholder democracy in limited partnerships." 
 In good times, limited partners have few complaints. Indeed, since 1970, they have poured close to $150 billion into various partnerships, half of which financed real estate deals. But now, with so many partnerships in trouble because of lower real estate values, the loss of tax benefits or an ailing general partner, it seems only natural that limited partners have begun to organize to improve their clout.
One would-be Pied Piper for limited partners is Eggert Dagbjartsson, a 29-year-old senior vice president of the Equity Resources Group in Cambridge, Mass., who goes by the name of Dagson for short. Equity Resources buys illiquid partnership units that others are desperate to sell for anywhere from 45 to 70 cents on the dollar.
Since its inception 11 years ago, it has put about $30 million of its own limited partners' money to work. And though it has avoided many of the biggest disasters, the frail condition of many partnerships has persuaded the firm to take a hands-on or adversarial role in about 30 of its 500 deals.
That is where Mr. Dagson fits in. A strapping, fresh-faced blond who joined Equity Resources in 1985 after dropping out of Harvard College, Mr. Dagson appears to have a knack for finance and law despite a lack of formal training.
A native of Iceland who did not know English when he came to the States as an exchange student in 1977, Mr. Dagson is now fluent in English, as well as French, Swedish and Icelandic, and has a smattering of Japanese, a vestige of his East Asian studies in college. Unfailingly polite in a rough-and-tumble business, he rarely loses his cool beyond the occasional "yak manure," uttered in response to objectionable comments.
Unlike some "work out" experts, Mr. Dagson insists that his firm is merely protecting its own interests and is generally uninterested in charging fees for its work beyond the sums it solicits from limited partners to cover its expenses.
Though many of the deals are pending, Equity Resources has had some success. For instance, it was instrumental in keeping two apartment complexes managed by Southmark out of a 1987 restructuring that proved disastrous for investors who were included. These days, much of Mr. Dagson's attention is focused on deals where VMS Realty Partners, a troubled Chicago real estate firm, or its affiliates are general partners.
To settle its debts and stay out of bankruptcy, VMS is seeking to sell some of its prize properties despite the soft real estate market, a move Mr. Dagson opposes. "The story here is that you've got limited partners fighting back," said Mr. Dagson. "We don't want to see a property sold today in a recession simply because VMS is short of cash."
Other limited partners generally appreciate having Equity Resources around. "Their reputation is very good," said Robert Sonnenblick, a partner in the Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation, an investment bank that specializes in commercial real estate and a limited partner in a VMS deal.
VMS officials, who have gone so far as to force Mr. Dagson to fly to Chicago to pick up monthly financial statements, did not return phone calls left last week at their Chicago office seeking comment.
But others who have clashed with Equity Resources are not always complimentary. "They're gadflies," said Ronald Schy, a Chicago lawyer who represents thousands of limited partners who have lost money in VMS deals in a class-action lawsuit in United States District Court in Chicago.
He and other lawyers complain that Equity Resources is too willing to egg on the limited partners to withhold their consent on certain transactions until the general partners agree to concessions. The lawyers also contend many investors do not understand that by acquiring many of its positions at estate sales and auctions, Equity Resources may have different economic incentives than the typical limited partner.
They blame Equity Resources, for instance, for organizing the limited partners who ultimately scared off the buyer VMS had lined up for the Raleigh-Spring Forest Apartments in Raleigh, N.C. "They killed the sale, the partnership went bankrupt and the limiteds got no money," Mr. Schy said.
For his part, Mr. Dagson argues that the firm occasionally has helped general partners sell their plans to limited partners. And in adversarial cases, he says, other limited partners must take his firm's side for it to have any influence because Equity Resources has only small, minority positions.
But in the VMS case, the firm may have used inappropriate tactics to make its case. Equity Resources has urged the limited partners of some of the more valuable VMS properties to question the proposed settlement of the class-action lawsuit that Mr. Schy has negotiated because it could give VMS the right to sell certain properties without their consent.
VMS's lawyers convinced the judge in the case, James B. Zagel, that Equity Resources had sent misleading materials to other limited partners to marshal support for its point of view, and last month the judge ordered Equity Resources to submit all future mass mailings to the court for review. Equity Resources, which says the order violates its constitutional right to communicate freely with its partners, is studying whether to appeal.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Why Swiss Bank Shunned Gold

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
When the Swiss Bank Corporation's private banking group did its projections for financial markets in the second quarter, it predicted that the price of gold would rise to $370 an ounce by the end of June, an increase of 3.6 percent.
This was one of the better returns projected as the group looked at financial markets around the world and forecast outlooks for stocks, bonds and short-term interest rates on cash. But when it came to allocating clients' money among these numerous markets, the bank did not buy gold. 
 This was the second quarter in a row that Swiss Bank had taken the position that gold would rally but then did not buy it for clients' portfolios.
Why? For Swiss Bank's customers, gold was perceived as too risky. Or as Malcolm A. Clinger Jr., vice president and chief investment officer of the Swiss Bank Corporation, said, "It is a volatile world, and we would rather pull back when the confidence is not as high as we would like."
This non-allocation of gold shows how optimistic forecasts for individual markets can be turned upside-down when they are adjusted for the investment goals of the client or the money manager. In fact, the Swiss Bank's recommended mix of investments changes quite dramatically with just a small shift in the assumptions about a client's bias toward or away from risk.
In the bank's outlook for the current quarter, the best performing stock market will be Spain, with a projected rise of 10.8 percent. Australia is expected to be second, with a 7.86 rise; Switzerland third, 7.53 percent; Hong Kong fourth, 6.78 percent; Singapore fifth, 5.98 percent, and the United States sixth, 5.27 percent.
But when allocating clients' money among the world's financial markets, the bank recommends putting most of the cash in the United States.
The main reason, according to Mr. Clinger, is that the Swiss Bank portfolios are based on the dollar, and the bank wants to avoid the risk of a rising dollar, which can eat sharply into capital gains when dollars are invested in non-United States markets, as was the case in the first quarter of the year.
Another attraction of the United States is its bond market, which the bank expects to be the second-best performer of the 10 bond markets it follows. But in cash returns, the United States is last on the list with the lowest short-term interest rates.
In Swiss Bank's classifications, the most risk-adverse investors, many of whom are Latin Americans, are in the fixed-income portfolio category and have 87.5 percent of their investments in the United States. Of this amount, 75 percent is in bonds and the rest is in cash. The next largest country allocation is Canada, where clients are advised to have 5 percent of their total portfolios in Canadian bonds.
The growth portfolio, for investors who are most tolerant of risk, is more heavily invested overseas. Only 59 percent of the entire portfolio is in the United States. Of this allocation, 70 percent is in the stock market and 30 percent is in cash. This leaves these investments more open to the risk of currency fluctuations. But Swiss Bank will move to hedge against these losses if the dollar begins to move sharply above its current levels. The dollar closed Friday at 1.7425 marks to the dollar and the Swiss Bank projection has it rising to 1.75 by the end of June.
The rest of the growth portfolio is distributed among other stock markets around the world, including 8.5 percent in Switzerland, 7 percent in Japan, 6.5 percent in Spain, 3.5 percent in France and in Singapore, and 3 percent in Hong Kong.
Japan gets a higher allocation than Spain, Singapore and France, although these stock markets are projected to provide a higher return. Mr. Clinger said the allocation is higher because he has more confidence in the Japanese market projection than those for the other markets. In addition, the Tokyo stock market offers a wider variety of stocks and greater liquidity for the investor who needs to get in or out of the market quickly.
For a growth-oriented portfolio with less tolerance of risk, the lineup changes significantly. The portion allocated to the United States rises to 70 percent. Of this, 40 percent is in the stock market, 45 percent in bonds and 15 percent in cash.
The rest is distributed more conservatively among other countries' bond and stock markets. Instead of 7 percent in Japan, the allocation is 4 percent. But the amount in Hong Kong is raised slightly to 3.5 percent because the Hong Kong dollar is pegged to the American dollar and this lessens currency risk.
The income-oriented portfolio cuts the risk even more, putting 80 percent of the money in the United States with 55 percent in bonds, 20 percent in cash and only 25 percent in stocks.
Most of the investors who are willing to take the least risk, Mr. Clinger said, are non-United States citizens who "are very sensitive to losing any capital." The investors willing to take the most risk, however, tend to be Americans "who are knowledgeable about global markets and are long-term investors."

HEADLINE: Technology;
Separating Plastic Wheat and Chaff

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

DATELINE: PISCATAWAY, N.J.

 BODY:
Plastic bottles rush along a conveyor belt here at Rutgers University's Center for Plastic Recycling Research. They are a diverse mix: clear, green, translucent, opaque; some are intact, some partially crushed.
As they whiz along at 150 to 200 feet per second, they pass between light sources and sensors. Blasts of compressed air blow the bottles off the line into the appropriate bins. The line is sorting the containers by chemical type and color, with a goal of producing materials with more value than the mixed varieties used to make things like plastic lumber. 
 Finding a way to sort mixed materials quickly and accurately may be the key to making plastics recycling practical. Unlike aluminum cans, which are of uniform composition, plastics come in a variety of colors and chemical formulations, called resins.
The chemical industry is eager to demonstrate that plastics are recyclable, because legislation restricting or taxing plastic products is pending in most states.
Two industry giants, the Du Pont Company and Waste Management Inc., have formed a joint venture, the Plastic Recycling Alliance, to demonstrate that soda bottles made of polyethylene terephthalate and milk bottles made of high-density polyethylene can be commercially recycled.
But at one recent conference on plastics, Jane Witheridge, Waste Management's vice president for recycling, said the project "is not working for us." Because manufacturers have been unwilling to take back many types of plastic, recycling is "not now economically sustainable," she said.
 Officials of the Council for Solid Waste Solution, a plastic industry trade association concentrating on recycling, said sorting is the main problem. "The people who buy recycled plastics require a quality sort," said Jean Statler, a council official. "If they are buying blue bottles, they want blue, not orange or red. The markets are there if the materials are sorted by color."
Now, most sorting is done by hand. Workers stand next to a conveyor and try to identify the different types of plastic and toss them into the right bins. Color is simple; beyond that, it can be difficult.
For example, most clear bottles are made of polyethylene terephthalate, generally known as PET. But some of the clear containers -- a small percentage -- are made of polyvinyl chloride. The only way to tell the difference is to look at the code number on the bottom of the bottle. PET is 1; PVC is 3.
The problem is that PVC can contaminate PET. PVC melts at a lower temperature than PET, so when the PET is processed, the PVC burns, mixing black particles in the clear plastic. "One PVC bottle in a bale can spoil the whole load," said Jose R. Fernandes, a project manager at the Rutgers center.
That is why the first detector on the line looks for PVC. Unlike PET, each molecule of PVC contains a chlorine atom. This causes it to fluoresce, or glow, when subjected to X-ray radiation.
The detector emits a low-powered X-ray beam at the bottles passing by. If it detects a glow (invisible to the human eye), a valve opens and a blast of air with a pressure of 80 pounds per square inch blows the bottle off the line and into a bin.
Optical detectors continue the separation. Light shining through clear bottles activates the air blast. A more intense light detects transparent green, and one that is still more intense separates translucent milk bottles. Other types, mostly opaque colored bottles, run off the end of the line into a container.
Mr. Fernandes and his colleagues have been debugging the line for nine months. One problem concerns the random orientation of the bottles on the line. Looking through the handle of a bottle, a detector might falsely conclude it is transparent. The answer was to add a detector on top of the line, as well as alongside it.
Another problem involves labels and dissimilar materials. Encountering a heavily printed paper label or a solidly colored base on a soda bottle, the detectors might conclude the bottle is opaque. So the detectors have now been programmed to act on the most intense transmission of light through a container. Thus, the transparent part of a bottle, not other sections, would trigger the air blast.
Once they are separated by resin and color, the bottles are ready to be recycled. Paper labels, polypropylene labels and aluminum caps, as well as residual soda and milk are contaminants to plastic and must be removed.
The bottles are chopped into flakes about one-quarter-inch square) and washed with hot water and industrial detergent. This cleans off the milk and soda and reduces the paper to a fine pulp that is carried off with the wash water and filtered out.
An electrostatic precipitator pulls out most of the aluminum shreds. The plastic and remaining metal are poured onto a rotating drum and subject to 12,000 volts of static electric charge. The metal, being a good conductor of electricity, falls off the drum. The plastic, a poor conductor, sticks until the charge is canceled.
The plastic flakes are run through a cone-shaped piece of equipment where swirling water separates the lighter, high-density polyethylene from the heavier PET. The flakes are dried and loaded in large cardboard boxes for shipment to plastics users.
The current system represents first-generation technology, Mr. Fernandes said. Under development is another system that would group all the detectors in one location. As a bottle came past the detection station, the identification would be loaded into a computer's memory, which would assign a gate where each bottle would be blown off. Knowing the rate of movement of the conveyor, computer-managed relays then would activate the air blast when the bottle reached the appropriate gate.
Other detectors could be added as well. Since each type of resin has its own infrared "fingerprint," infrared detectors could separate different types of plastic.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Market Message: From Bust to Boom?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
The recession seems to be ending. But the overwhelming consensus is that the recovery will not amount to much. There is talk of a "double dip" downturn, and few expect strong growth.
The stock market, however, seems to have a different opinion, That contrary notion, of coming strength in the economy, is conveyed not just by the fact that the Dow Jones industrial average last week rose 113.59 points, to 3,027.50, setting a record and closing above 3,000 for the first time since April 17. It may also be significant that it is no longer the recession-resistant consumer stocks, like Procter & Gamble and Philip Morris, that are leading the charge.
 Of the 30 stocks in the Dow, four are now at least 10 percent higher than they were when the average first closed over 3,000. All are big, grimy, cyclical stocks: Du Pont, Goodyear, General Motors and Bethlehem Steel. International Paper and Union Carbide have risen almost as much. If those moves are to make sense, then this economy needs than a weak recovery.
 The bond market's refusal to rally may also be sending a signal of surprising economic strength,. The Federal Reserve has pushed short-term interest rates dopwn sharply, and American investors have taken the hint. Sales of mutural funds are booming.
 And yet, as Fred Leiner, an economist at Continental Bank, points out, long-term interest rates have been stalled for six months, making minor moves but essentially going sideways. "I'm concerned by some similarities with late 1986," he said. "We see money pouring into bond funds, yet the bond market is unable to move higher. Those similarities suggest the market may move lower from these levels."
 In late 1986 and early 1987, he recalled, the bond market stalled while stocks leaped. Then bond prices crashed in the spring, and stock prices followed the fall.
 This year, there are certainly plenty of reasons to doubt that the economy can rebound strongly. The debt overhang that helped to bring on this recession has not disappeared, and the Government's efforts to fight the recession have been limited by the severe fiscal problems brought on by the profligacy of the 1980's. It is hard to imagine a new boom in commercial construction.
 Moreover, the evidence that the recession is ending, while persuasive to a lot of stock traders, is still limited,. The leading indicators have risen for three consecutive months, and factory orders turned up in April. Consumers tell pollsters the present is bad, but the future will be better, and they seem to translate those beliefs into cautious spending, not a panicky increase in savings. Stock market analysts note that secondary stocks, which were leaders in the winter rally, are lagging as summer begins, Their particiaption would make this rally a more impressive one.
 But for all that, it is a fact that the economy usually finds a way to surprise the seers. A strong recovery this year would certianly qualify as a surprise. Perhaps, just perhaps, that is the current message of the markets.

HEADLINE: Why 'Green Taxes' Won't Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Sandra Postel indulges in wishful thinking ("The Greening of America's Taxes," Forum, May 19) when she says that new corporate taxes -- "green taxes" -- on industries that hurt the environment could fight pollution and help the economy at the same time. 
 She cites the figure of $130 billion in annual tax revenue. That's quite a bit of "green," but estimating tax revenue isn't that easy. The recession has made a mockery of state sales tax revenue estimates, and at the Federal level, the volatility of corporate profits has befuddled revenue estimators. She suggests replacing a portion of the income tax to correspond with these green tax estimates, but practically speaking, green taxes are more likely to be collected on top of income taxes, not in place of them.
Another weakness of these "green" taxes is that no one knows who will be paying them. A basic principle of sound fiscal policy is that when a new tax is passed, taxpayers should know who is going to pay it. Green taxes do not meet that test.
Finally, there is the problem of identifying whose activities do not harm the environment. Will sheep farmers be taxed on the methane their sheep introduce into the atmosphere? What about the noise pollution caused by automobiles and airplanes? Tax policy cannot be the vehicle to achieve every societal goal. Restructuring our Federal tax system is not the answer to environmental problems.
 
DAN WITT
Washington, May 23
 
The author is executive director of the Tax Foundation in Washington. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Angolan Revelers Celebrate the End of Civil War

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUANDA, Angola, June 1

 BODY:
Thousands of Angolans danced and cheered in the streets early this morning in rousing imprompu celebrations marking the formal end of this country's 16-year civil war.
I was too early to tell how well the cease-fire was being observed, Western diplomatic sources and relief workers said today, but so far there were no reports of renewed fighting. 
 Although the cease-fire was initialed Friday night in Lisbon, the Luanda Government had delayed a series of events here to commemorate the occasion until today to coincide with the return of Angola's president, Jose Eduardo dos Santos.
But people began lining the main avenues of this war-ravaged port city Friday evening, and by midnight the streets were crowded with revelers shouting "We've got peace! We've got bread!" -- an expression of hope that with the end of war will again come prosperity. Angola is one of the most richly endowed countries in Africa, but its economy has been devastated.
"I've been waiting all my life for this," said Dolce Henriques, a 23-year-old student as she danced around Kinaxixe Park. "Look at this," she said, pointing at the crowd, "this is what peace is about. We're free."
Bursts of automatic weapons fire could also be heard throughout the night. Firing weapons is a risky practice that often punctuates festivals here and a reminder that much of the civilian population is heavily armed.
"This is probably one of the most armed countries on earth," said Susan Hurlich, an American anthropologist doing research here. A Western relief worker added, "Nobody is really going to feel safe here until they get rid of the guns -- and there's nothing in the cease-fire about that."
The peace agreement came after more than a year of arduous negotiations in which Portugal, which was Angola's colonial master, and the United States and the Soviet Union, which backed the opposing factions, played a key role in encouraging the two sides to end a war that has taken 300,000 lives and produced no winners.
Later this month, a United Nations force of 600 men is expected to arrive here to monitor the cease-fire. At the same time, a joint political and military commission will form a single 40,000-member army and prepare for internationally supervised elections in the second half of 1992.
A de facto cease-fire has been in effect since May 15, and the two sides have largely complied with it, African and Western diplomats said today. Scattered and inexplicable incidents of violence have continued, however.
 Last Wednesday, a bomb exploded in the main market in Huambo, a provincial capital in the central highlands, killing 8 and wounding 20. The next day on Huambo's outskirts, a truck carrying civilians hit a land mine, killing 17 and wounding 30.
The last full-blown fighting between the two sides took place in the eastern city of Luena in early May, Western relief officials said, when the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita, besieged the area and the Government sent reinforcements in an effort to oust the rebels. The Angolan news service has also reported rebel incursions in Bia, Huambo and Kwanza Sul provinces in the west, but most of the incidents occurred before May 15.
The celebrations here were notable not only for their high spirits, but also for the virtual absence of any visible Unita presence. A senior Unita delegation is expected to arrive here later today, Government officials said, but the rebels are not likely to take part in any of the commemorative events in this capital of 1.3 million.
In Washington, a spokesman for Unita said the rebel leader, Jonas Savimbi, would make his first trip to the capital in at least 15 years, sometime in July. For most of the bloody civil war, rebel forces have been headquartered in Jamba, a town in the southeast.
Also conspicuous by their absence are the Cuban forces, at one point numbering 50,000. The Cuban Government hurriedly withdrew its remaining forces a week ago, a month before their scheduled departure, saying they had accomplished their mission.

HEADLINE: Paying for 'Eternal Vigilance'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I would like to add a comment to Prof. Seymour Melman's article ("When the Pentagon Walks Away," Forum, April 21, ) suggesting a conversion process rather than a total shutdown of outmoded military bases. 
 Brookley Air Force Base, Mobile, Ala., was the only Air Force base offering air, land and sea transportation access in the continental United States yet President Johnson ordered it closed down because Alabama and Mobile had voted overwhelmingly for Barry Goldwater. The economic result was disastrous, and took years to recover from, but this was pure politics: Brookley's work was moved to another base and continues today.
Professor Melman seeks to alleviate only the economic impact of our military restructuring, without full consideration of our geopolitical future. America is the guardian of the free world and we are so entwined with other nations that we have to maintain a credible and efficient military stance. Unfortunately, our citizens seem to regard military security as somewhat akin to police, fire and health services, calling on their instant response when they need them, ignoring them when they do not. This leads to "crisis management" when we should install the commercially accepted system of "risk management," as in fire, casualty and life insurance solutions. The "premium cost" would be whatever military budget was necessary to cover the risk.
It is projected that within a few years, as many as 15 nations will possess intercontinental ballistic missile capabilities. Since we are basically reactors to military threats, we need capable forces with adequate standby reserve forces. This is what our forefathers meant by "Eternal vigilance is the price of liberty."
 
HERBERT S. LOCKETT
Mobile, Ala., May 3

HEADLINE: China's South Is Finally Getting Some Respect

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CANTON

 BODY:
Ask a northerner about the people here in southern China and he would probably say they are oily, conniving, uneducated and nouveau riche and would do anything for money. But he might add that he would love to move down here.
This part of southern China used to be scorned as a land of rustic peasants, far from the sophisticated and cultured centers in the north. But these days, thanks to Guangdong Province's blossoming wealth, it is gaining grudging respect, as people on opposite ends of the Chinese map are re-examining their place on the nation's ladder of status. 
 "Southerners were poor, we worked in the sun and our skin was dark, whereas northerners stayed inside and their skin was light," said a Cantonese film maker in Guangdong Province. "But all those attitudes are changing now."
China's center of gravity, the backdrop for people's dreams, the place where they want their children to live, has moved south. It used to be that the north of the country was what mattered: Manchuria, in the northeast, had heavy industry; Beijing was the seat of power; and Shanghai was a center of industry, culture and education. But in the last few years, Guangdong, abutting Hong Kong, has come to be regarded as the richest and most advanced province in the country.
 
Fastest Growth Rate in China

"Northerners all want life styles like people in the south," said a Beijing entrepreneur who has traveled to Guangdong.
Part of it is luck, as Guangdong benefits from Hong Kong investment, as well as from easy access to Hong Kong television and radio programs, fashions and lifestyle. A flood of people cross the border in both directions, and Guangdong for a decade has had among the fastest growth rates in all of China. An entrepreneurial spirit has developed that is not unlike Hong Kong's, and these days Guangdong's cities -- especially Canton and Shenzhen -- radiate a siren's call of modernity and easy money.
Countless hairdressers throughout the country are named "Guangzhou hairdressers" (referring to the Chinese name for Canton) or "Shenzhen hair stylists," because there is a common perception that those cities have the most modern fashions and styles. Television commercials for consumer products often show people raving about the product in a Cantonese accent, because it is thought that the Cantonese are more discerning and choosy than other Chinese.
Indeed, the Cantonese are aware of their new place in the nation, and often refer to people living in the interior as "savages." They say they have always been more outward-looking and receptive than northerners to new customs brought in from outside China. In fact, the first Chinese immigrants to the United States were from Guangdong.
 
More Envy Than Scorn

At the same time that provincial leaders from China's interior complain about Beijing's favoritism toward Guangdong, they send business delegations here to learn from local managers. In the past, university graduates overwhelmingly preferred job assignments in Beijing; these days some prefer jobs in the south, especially Shenzhen, because the money and opportunities are greater.
Northerners still say southern people -- and they mean Guangdong, rather than its impoverished neighbor, Guangxi -- are shrewd, wily and untrustworthy. But their voices contain perhaps more envy than scorn.
Even the Cantonese language, a cacaphony of sounds, is assuming new attributes, as Guangdong travelers to the north get better service in hotels when they speak Chinese with a Cantonese accent. On some occasions they are mistaken for Hong Kong visitors.
"The Cantonese language has been elevated," said an official in the Guangdong city of Shenzhen. "People associate the Cantonese dialect with wealth, so that if you speak Cantonese, even if it's not native, then it's easier to get things done."

HEADLINE: No-Tax Vows and the Party Line Put Albany Republicans in a Bind

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 1

 BODY:
When Joseph R. Holland ran for State Senate last year, the Rockland County Republican printed brochures declaring, "Joe Holland knows how to say no to new taxes and spending." His radio advertisements boasted that as an Assemblyman he had "voted against over $1 billion in new taxes pushed by the Governor and the legislative bosses."
Now, as a freshman Senator, Mr. Holland faces the prospect of voting for a $51.9 billion state budget negotiated by his own legislative boss -- Ralph J. Marino, the Senate majority leader -- that includes more than $1.8 billion in new taxes, fees and other revenue measures. 
 Like Mr. Holland, many members of the Republican majority in the Senate are torn between competing loyalties -- one to their campaign promises and one to their party's leadership. Both have been important to the Republicans' electoral success, and many members said they feared the political consequences of sacrificing one for the other.
"I campaigned against taxes and I'm a fiscal conservative," Mr. Holland said. "It's going to choke me if I have to vote for this thing."
If Mr. Holland has to gulp hard and swallow when the Senate votes on the revenue bill, he will find himself in good company. Last year, President Bush broke his pledge of no new taxes by signing a budget raising taxes by $140 billion over five years.
 
A Mathematics Problem
 "There are a lot of Republicans who are voting for tax increases who have campaigned on some platform of no tax increases," said Eddie Mahe Jr., a Republican political consultant in Washington. "The box they got themselves into is that they made the pledge when the economy was going up and now the bill is coming due when the economy is going down. But none of them, as far as I know, said, 'No new taxes, except . . .' "
The problem facing Mr. Holland and other Republican legislators in New York who campaigned against taxes is rooted in the mathematics of the Senate. There are only 35 Republicans, and 31 votes are needed for a majority in the 61-member Senate. Unless Mr. Marino concludes that he can depend on Democratic senators to vote for the revenue bill, almost all of his members will have to vote "aye."
That vote in support of new taxes is a particular political risk for local and state legislators whose actions are often more closely tracked by their constituents, who are quick to register their displeasure at the next election.
The revenue measure was negotiated by Mr. Marino and the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, as an alternative to the plan Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed to close a budget gap estimated at $6.5 billion. Mr. Marino and Mr. Miller met with members of their houses today to review elements of the plan, and said votes could be scheduled Sunday or Monday.
A spokesman for Mr. Marino, John E. McArdle, said that even if the Republicans had more than enough votes to pass the bill, the majority leader might ask all his members to vote for it. "Right now we're assuming all our members will vote yes," he said. "As a conference, we're all in this together."
 
Help From Campaign Fund
 Mr. Holland fully understands the meaning of party unity. To a certain degree, he owes his election to a pair of campaign committees controlled by Mr. Marino. The Senate Republican Campaign Committee and the Fund for a Republican Majority spent $460,000 on Mr. Holland's campaign, according to financial reports. That was far more than Mr. Holland raised for himself and more than the committees spent on any other candidate.
"First of all, I owe the constituency," Mr. Holland said. "But these other things do enter your thinking."
Mr. Holland's thinking also is affected by the knowledge that the budget agreement announced this week by Mr. Marino and Mr. Miller would restore funds for a number of Rockland County programs that would have been cut by the Governor.
The measures include funds for the Nathan Kline Institute, a state psychiatric research center that Mr. Cuomo had proposed closing, a $350,000 study of a major highway expansion and $260,000 for a program for the elderly at Rockland Community College.
Another argument that may persuade Mr. Holland and many of his Republican colleagues is that the tax increases included in the compromise bill are preferable to those proposed by Mr. Cuomo and initially by the Assembly Democrats. The bill does not include the personal-income-tax increase proposed by Mr. Miller or the gasoline-tax increase pushed by the Governor.
 
'I'd Love to Keep My Word'
 The Republicans failed in their efforts to minimize tax increases by financing part of the budget with $1 billion in nonrecurring revenue measures, a plan that was rejected by Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Miller as fiscally irresponsible. But Mr. Marino ultimately decided that his members could live with a compromise plan that includes canceling a scheduled cut in income-tax rates, a heavy increase in taxes paid by producers and importers of petroleum, a new tax on natural gas, and the extension of the sales tax to products including noncustom computer software, shipping and telephone answering services.
"It's the best deal we could hope for given the fact that we were outnumbered two to one in the process and nobody would support our proposals," Mr. McArdle said.
Mr. Holland said he had not decided how he would vote on the tax bill, but planned to discuss his quandary with Mr. Marino. "I'm certainly going to go to him and explain that I ran on a no-tax-increase platform," he said. "I'd love to keep my word."
The tax dilemma is particularly thorny for the four freshman senators who left positions in the Assembly minority to join the Senate majority -- William J. Larkin Jr. of New Windsor, Stephen M. Saland of Poughkeepsie, William R. Sears of Woodgate, and Mr. Holland. Each campaigned vigorously against tax increases, pointing to their antitax votes in the Assembly.
In the Assembly, where the Democrats hold a 95-to-55 majority, Republican votes are rarely needed to pass legislation, leaving Republican members free to cast protest votes against taxing and spending measures. On Friday, for instance, the Assembly Republicans voted unanimously against a series of spending bills.
 
Help From Democrats?
 Republican senators said there was little question that Mr. Marino could deliver the votes needed to pass the budget. But some said they hoped the majority leader might be able to free some members to vote no if Democratic senators provide a cushion by voting for the revenue package.
Senator Kemp Hannon, Republican of Garden City, L.I., said, "I think it would be safe to assume there would be plenty of volunteers" to vote against the plan.
Last year, the Senate Democrats voted unanimously against a revenue bill that included $1.8 billion in new taxes and fees.
The Senate minority leader, Manfred Ohrenstein, a Manhattan Democrat, said he recognized that if Democrats voted for the compromise revenue plan, they might be freeing Republicans to vote no and later to trumpet those votes in campaigns. But given the outcome of last year's campaigns, when some Republican incumbents who had voted for tax measures were able to successfully portray themselves as tax opponents, Mr. Ohrenstein questioned whether the electorate really paid attention to budget votes.
"Have the Republicans gotten away with it?" he asked. "I feel to a degree they have."
Mr. Mahe, the consultant, said the problem facing the Democrats had less to do with a lack of voter vigilance than with Republican success in painting Democrats as big taxers and spenders.
"It shouldn't be a problem for the Republicans in their next elections, because polls show the public tends to trust them more on management and taxes," he said. "Even though they have broken their word, there are few Democrats who can take advantage of the issue."

HEADLINE: Patients and Profits/A special report.;
When Healers Are Entrepreneurs: A Debate Over Costs and Ethics

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR with ERIK ECKHOLM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
In 1984, Atlanta had one magnetic resonance imaging machine. Now it has at least 30. Most are owned by doctors, and not just any doctors: they are often the same ones who send their patients for imaging scans, at $600 to $1,000 a visit.
Nobody disputes that magnetic resonance imaging, or M.R.I., is an invaluable diagnostic tool that allows doctors to visualize abnormalities in the brain, spine, knees and other parts of the body. But the rapid proliferation of doctors' investments in M.R.I. clinics and in clinical laboratories, outpatient surgery centers and other health-care businesses has set off one of the most passionate ethical debates in medicine today.
 
More Than 10% Are Involved
 Critics, who are seeking to outlaw doctor referrals to services in which they have invested, charge that the practice is a blatant conflict of interest that encourages costly overuse of procedures. Defenders say it serves patients by speeding the availability of new technology. 
 Studies by the Government and private groups have found that more than 10 percent of the nation's doctors have invested in businesses to which they refer patients. In Florida, where state officials worried about excess costs are urgently studying the matter, the proportion of doctors making such investments has reached one-third.
The studies also find that doctors who share ownership of laboratories and other health-care businesses order more services than other physicians. Critics say many of those extra procedures are medically unnecessary. With the nation's health-care bill soaring, many experts say, it is time to ban the spreading practice known in the health-care industry as "self-referral."
 
'Patient as Economic Commodity'
 "You don't have to be an Einstein to see that the more patients you refer, the larger your profits will be," said Dr. Arnold S. Relman, editor of The New England Journal of Medicine and a crusader against what he sees as a dangerous new business ethic in American medicine. "When you earn money by referring to a facility where you are an investor, you're just using your patient as an economic commodity."
Concerned about the spread of self-referrals, Congress in 1989 passed a law to restrict some of them. Starting Jan. 1, the Government will prohibit doctors from referring Medicare or Medicaid patients to clinical laboratories in which the doctors have a financial interest. Now Congress and several states, including New York, Florida and California, are considering similar prohibitions on referrals to other doctor-owned ventures as well.
 
'The Entrepreneurial System'
 But defenders of the physician investments, including the American Medical Association, insist that they are proper and even beneficial. "It really does bring new things to the market," said Dr. Howard B. Krone, an Atlanta orthopedist, who has bought shares in two magnetic resonance imaging centers here, one near each of his offices. "If there's a profit involved, that's fine. It's the entrepreneurial system."
Proposals to ban ownership of M.R.I. centers or other businesses by referring physicians are "hogwash," he said, adding, "The doctors I know in Atlanta aren't abusing this."
 
The Atlanta Market
Doctors Share In $60 Million
 Physician investment in health-care businesses grew rapidly in the 1980's as the medical marketplace became more commercial and more competitive. Federal cost-control policies inadvertently encouraged such investments. Medicare's payment of flat fees for hospital stays, for example, gave hospitals an incentive to discharge patients faster, creating more demand for outpatient services. And as doctors' fees were newly limited, many doctors looked to investments to supplement their income.
Such investments have proceeded fastest in the Sun Belt, where patient populations have boomed, the entrepreneurial spirit is strong and regulation of medical investment is often not stringent. Data on the practice are most complete in Florida, where doctors now own or have invested in two-thirds of the state's outpatient surgery centers and three-fourths of its diagnostic imaging centers, according to a study by the state's Health Care Cost Containment Board.
The quick spread of imaging centers in Atlanta is typical.
 
Crucial Diagnostic Tool
 Magnetic resonance imaging, which did not become widely available until the late 1980's, uses magnetic and radio waves to provide sharp images of soft tissue and has become a crucial tool for diagnosing problems in the brain, spinal column, knees and other joints. The machines cost $1 million to $2 million each.
About 2,000 magnetic resonance scanners are now operating nationwide. Doctors hail M.R.I. as a marvel of technology; the procedure is cheaper and safer than surgery that might otherwise be required to determine the extent of an injury. And it can save money in other ways -- for example, by ruling out the need for months of worker's compensation payments to an employee feigning injury.
But the procedure can easily be overused. Many experts say costly magnetic resonance scans are often used to acquire information that is marginal or can be gained more cheaply by other techniques, or to rule out slight risks as a defense against potential lawsuits.
The number of scans is climbing, creating a huge new market. Here in Atlanta alone, experts say, M.R.I. fees this year will total at least $60 million, up from $4 million in 1985. Physicians share ownership of more than half of the area's magnetic resonance imaging machines, including many in freestanding centers and even some run by public hospitals.
 
Free-Enterprise Spirit
 Dr. Maurice Jove, an orthopedic surgeon here, said Atlanta doctors were imbued with the free-enterprise spirit. "The cowboys and Indians want to make a lot of money," he said, in explaining why so many doctors had invested in the new machines. "Why should large corporations be the only ones entitled to make money in medicine?"
Dr. Jove helped put together a partnership of doctors that leases an M.R.I. machine to the DeKalb Medical Center, a 525-bed public hospital in Atlanta's eastern suburbs.
Wherever the new machines were purchased, profits depended on their heavy use, and that required a steady flow of referrals from neurologists, neurosurgeons, orthopedic surgeons and other doctors. There could be no surer way to guarantee the supply of patients than to bring referring doctors into the business.
At the same time, many doctors, whose ability to refer patients was increasingly recognized as a valuable commodity, began to ask why they should not get a piece of the new business. Direct kickbacks for the referral of Medicare or Medicaid patients are forbidden under Federal law. But doctors may legally profit from part ownership of a business to which they refer patients, provided they do not receive any payment or other remuneration in return for the referrals.
 
Why Not Take a Profit?
 "Originally, I was sending my patients all the way across town to get M.R.I. scans," said Dr. Krone, the Atlanta orthopedist. "Then I started to think, Why shouldn't there be a financial benefit if it could be done honorably?"
Dr. Krone joined the partnership at DeKalb Medical Center, which opened its diagnostic imaging center in 1989.
Officials of the DeKalb Medical Center say they invited local physicians to join in the new diagnostic center to avoid a situation in which two machines would exist side by side, one owned by the hospital and one owned by doctors who controlled the patient referrals.
 
Duplication in a Suburb
 Such potentially wasteful duplication was not avoided in the south Atlanta suburb of Riverdale, where three machines are operating in an area of less than one square mile. One center, Atlanta Magnetic Imaging-South, opened in 1987 and is owned by Health Images Inc., an Atlanta-based company that operates centers nationwide.
Two more opened last year: one owned by a hospital, the Southern Regional Medical Center, and right next door in a small trailer-like building, Tara Magnetic Imaging, owned by a group of local doctors.
One result of the proliferation of machines is fierce competition for patients. Health Images, which runs two M.R.I. centers in Atlanta and 26 others around the country, says that more and more doctors who formerly referred patients to its sites are now channeling patients to centers in which they have invested.
Robert D. Carl 3d, founder and president of Health Images, a publicly traded company, said: "The laws of supply and demand don't operate when physicians refer patients to their own facilities. It's a captive market."
These fetters on a free market may also help explain why the fees for magnetic resonance imaging have remained so high despite the growing number of machines.
 
The Financial Schemes
Investors Tied To Referrals

Physician investments often take the form of limited partnerships. Doctors are asked to make relatively small investments with the prospect of high returns, in many cases over 50 percent a year. Critics say the high returns show that the arrangements are intended more to secure doctors (and their patients) than to raise capital.
One limited partnership, Premier Imaging Associates, opened an M.R.I. center on the north side of Atlanta in July 1990. In a prospectus filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission as required for certain limited partnerships, Premier said, "Management hopes to develop a large base of practitioners who will be inclined to refer their patients to an M.R.I. facility in which they have a financial interest."
Premier estimated that investors would get back more than twice the amount of their original investment by December 1992. The firm is well on the way to achieving that goal, investors report.
An imaging center in Texas projected even bigger profits: a return of $6,190 in the first year for each $500 of cash invested.
 
Nailing Down Referrals
 Dr. Robert E. Windsor, an orthopedic specialist at Sunbelt Spine and Sports Medicine, an Atlanta group practice, described his investments in four local imaging centers.
The general partners in those businesses "approached us and suggested that we invest in their centers because they wanted to solidify referral patterns," Dr. Windsor said, adding that 60 percent of his patients who need M.R.I. scans go to the four centers in which he has invested.
Dr. Windsor said that when doctors invested in a limited partnership here, they expected to get back profits equal to their initial investment in the first two years. Already, he said, he has recovered his $1,750 investment in Premier Imaging, opened last summer.
Premier was formed by Andrew M. Zeldin, a 34-year-old former real-estate developer, and Dr. Jonathan S. Gallen, a 35-year-old anesthesiologist. "If the doctor has an ownership interest in a facility, he has an incentive to support it," Dr. Gallen said. "He may profit from it at the end of the year."
Dr. Gallen said that 75 percent to 80 percent of the patients sent to Premier Imaging came from doctors who had invested in the business. But he added that 10 to 15 percent of the physician-investors have never sent a patient to Premier. This, he said, showed that "patients are referred on the basis of need, not greed."
 
No Government-Insured Patients
 Premier, like a number of the new centers, does not take patients under Medicare or Medicaid, the Federal health programs for the elderly and the poor. Such patients can be referred to other imaging centers. Premier's reason for excluding them was explained in its prospectus: this policy was adopted to insure that the firm and its owners would not violate any Federal "proscriptions against self-referrals."
The investment arrangement at DeKalb Medical Center on Atlanta's east side likewise suggests that securing a steady flow of patient referrals was a prime reason for getting doctors to invest. There, a partnership of 59 doctors (26 general partners and 33 limited partners) leases the imaging machine to the hospital.
The 1988 partnership agreement specified that the limited partners must be doctors on the medical staff of DeKalb Medical Center -- in other words, investors who could bring in patients. Since then, as concern rose about possible Federal regulations on self-referral, the agreement has been amended to allow others to invest, said Dr. Russell W. Wallace Jr., a neurologist who is a general partner.
 
Return Rises With the Number
 Another provision of the agreement could also encourage a high rate of referrals. Not only the return to the physician investors, but also the rate of return for each scan, rises with the total number of scans performed. Under the arrangement, if 1,200 imaging procedures are performed in a year, the hospital pays the investors 15 percent of all revenues, in addition to a base rental fee. And if more than 1,700 procedures are performed, as they were last year, the investors receive 30 percent of the revenues from all scans.
This arrangement could create a financial incentive for use of the procedure. But several partners said in interviews that they were unaware of this provision or that the additional money involved was so negligible that it would not influence their decisions.
In the mid-1980's, the heady early years of magnetic resonance imaging, the link between physician investment and the referral of patients was often explicit. Mr. Carl, the president of Health Images Inc., which opened Atlanta's first M.R.I. center in October 1984, said, "Banks and other lenders required us to have physician investors." Banks making loans for the new centers wanted doctors to have a stake in them in order to guarantee the flow of patients, and revenues, in what was then an untested market, said Mr. Carl and other officers of his company.
He and his company originally took doctors as partners in several imaging centers. But they later decided to buy out the doctors after they found physicians demanding "bigger and bigger cash distributions," Mr. Carl said.
 
The Ethics Issue
Would Cures Cause Harm?

The American Medical Assocation defends a doctor's right to invest in health-care operations, saying doctors are often the first to see the need for new medical technology or services in their community. Kirk B. Johnson, general counsel of the A.M.A., acknowledged that "there plainly are abuses going on." But he said it would be wrong for the Government to impose a complete ban on physician investment in businesses to which they refer patients.
Such a ban would be particularly harmful in rural areas, where physician investment may be the only way to raise capital for new health-care ventures, he said.
Some medical groups, including the American College of Radiology and the American College of Surgeons, have called on the medical association to repudiate self-referral. Radiologists have a personal stake: Many are losing business as neurologists, orthopedists and others invest in the imaging field and, in some cases, even take over the lucrative task of interpreting the images.
Defenders of self-referral, while admitting the potential for abuse, argue that the situation is not fundamentally different from other areas of medical practice in which a doctor's integrity and judgment are the bulwark against wrongs.
"To say this is a conflict of interest is like saying that every time a surgeon operates he's doing it for his own benefit," said Dr. Wallace.
 Critics like Dr. Relman, while agreeing that the potential for abuse exists throughout medical practice, say there is a more clear-cut ethical problem when doctors earn money from referrals than when they are paid for personally providing care.
"The whole climate in medicine is becoming more commercial and competitive," Dr. Relman said. "It's putting doctors in situations that force them to behave like entrepreneurs to survive."

GRAPHIC: Photos: "If there's a profit involved, that's fine," said Dr. Howard B. Krone, an Atlanta orthpedist, "it's the entrepreneurial system." Dr. Krone has shares in two magnetic imaging centers near his office; Atlanta has at least 30 magnetic resonance imaging machines and most are owned by doctors. Dr. Robert E. Windsor, an orthopedic specialist at Sunbelt Spine and Sports Medicine, a group practice in Atlanta, has investments in four local imaging centers. (Photographs by Alan Weiner for The New York Times) (pg. 30)

HEADLINE: New York City to Resume Listing Health Violations by Restaurants

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
New York City's listing of restaurants with health hazards and other sanitary-code violations -- a program suspended three years ago when a bribery-extortion scandal engulfed half the inspection force -- is being resumed with a virtually new staff of inspectors and an array of safeguards against corruption.
The new listings, dubbed "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly," will be issued by the Health Department for publication every two weeks and will include three categories of restaurants: those that have passed recent inspections, those ordered closed for operating without a valid permit and those closed for serious health hazards. 
 To minimize potential corruption, the department plans to rotate inspectors so they will not make repeated visits to restaurants, require inspectors to bring in evidence of health hazards and explain closing orders in detail, and have supervisors double-check "approved" restaurants within 24 hours.
"There are checks and balances, and it's a more cumbersome system now," said Pamela T. Miller, the deputy health commissioner for environmental health services, who set up the new system. "Nothing is foolproof, but this is as close as we're going to get."
 
Publication Halted
 The New York Times and other newspapers had printed the listings since 1971, but discontinued their publication in March 1988 after an undercover investigation led to charges against 28 health inspectors. They were accused of extorting hundreds of thousands of dollars from 300 restaurants by threatening to close them or cite them for sanitary violations.
Eventually, nearly 40 inspectors were convicted in the case, and health officials acknowledged that to protect their undercover investigation, they had allowed listings they knew to be inaccurate and incomplete to be published for more than a year.
When The Times suspended publication of the incomplete and erroneous lists, Max Frankel, the executive editor, said that if the city ever resumed issuing the lists, The Times "will not publish them until it is satisfied of their accuracy and honesty." Mr. Frankel said yesterday that The Times would examine the new procedures.
The city's system of publicizing the results of health inspections at 15,000 restaurants and other food outlets in New York is intended to protect the public from health hazards and to encourage restaurant dining, a major contributor to the local economy.
Armed with the city health code, inspectors may fault a restaurant for any of hundreds of violations, including evidence of vermin, improper food storage, improper handling of food and unsanitary personal habits by cooks and food servers.
Over the years, low salaries, poor morale, inadequate training and strict performance quotas fostered widespread corruption.
After the scandal broke in 1988, the city continued inspections to investigate complaints against specific restaurants, but suspended regular annual inspections until last summer.
Ms. Miller, who became deputy commissioner last February, said that the resumption of fair inspections and accurate listings was one of her highest priorities.
More than 90 percent of the department's 50 inspectors are new since the scandals of 1988, she said, and the entire staff has been given extensive training. She said the inspectors would visit 2,000 food service establishments every month.
 
Good, Bad and Ugly
 In releasing its first restaurant inspection results in three years yesterday, the Health Department said the biweekly listings would be issued in three categories.
One, the "good" list, would be of restaurants that passed a recent inspection with no condition needing correction. This category would include only restaurants subjected to an unannounced periodic inspection, not those that were the focus of a complaint or visited in a re-inspection.
A second category, the "bad" list, would be of restaurants ordered closed for operating without a valid Health Department permit. These might include restaurants that have tried to reopen prematurely after losing a permit, or those that have begun business without a permit.
A third category, the "ugly" list, would be of restaurants ordered closed because of immediate health hazards, such as sewage backups in food-preparation areas, lack of running water or proper refrigeration or the refusal of the restaurant to discard unsafe food.
Less serious code violations, like the presence of vermin or dirty food-preparation areas, Ms. Miller said, would prompt fines and orders to correct the deficiencies; if a restaurant does not clear violations in two later inspections, it may be closed.
To minimize possible corruption, Ms. Miller said, inspectors will be rotated periodically to new supervisors, and weekly to new restaurants and other businesses requiring inspections.
In addition, every restaurant placed on the "good" list will be re-inspected by a supervisor within 24 hours, Ms. Miller said. Those placed on the "bad" list will have their permit status checked with department records.
And an inspector who places a restaurant on the "ugly" list for serious health hazards will have to provide supervisors with samples of bad food or other evidence of the violations being cited, and will be required to immediately explain his decision in detail to a supervisor, who will also interview the restaurant's owner.

HEADLINE: Europeans Want Gorbachev at Talks

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, June 1

 BODY:
Although Britain and the United States say they have not yet made up their minds, there is growing pressure from Europe to invite the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to London next month when the leaders of the Group of Seven industrial democracies gather for an economic summit meeting.
In recent days, France and Germany have joined Italy in publicly endorsing Mr. Gorbachev's attendance in London, if not as a formal participant in the summit conference, at least to take part in separate discussions on the Soviet economy with Group of Seven members. 
 In addition, Jacques Attali, who is a former aide of President Francois Mitterrand and now the head of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, issued his own invitation Friday to Mr. Gorbachev, asking him to attend a "working session" at the bank's London headquarters in July.
Although he did not specify any dates, the invitation is presumably intended to insure that Mr. Gorbachev is at least in London sometime around July 15, when the two-day conference is scheduled to convene.
 
Symbolic Importance
 European officials say they believe it is symbolically important to have Mr. Gorbachev meet with the Group of Seven leaders, to show support for his efforts at domestic and economic change, as well as to map a plan for supporting the Soviet economy. In the last few weeks, aides to Mr. Gorbachev have made it clear the Soviet leader very much wants to meet with Western leaders in London.
Among the Group of Seven, only Britain and the United States so far have refused to say whether they want Mr. Gorbachev at the meeting, where presumably he would press for vast amounts of economic aid at a time when some in London and Washington are still wary of his commitment to economic reforms.
On Friday, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d issued a statement that seemed to tie Mr. Gorbachev's attendance in London to the reforms. "If President Gorbachev were to attend the economic summit," he said, "it is important that it be done in a way that would help promote the reform program in the Soviet Union and move the Soviet Union toward a free market economy."
At the same time, President Bush said Friday that he felt more positive about helping the Soviet Union, after discussing Soviet economic reforms in Washington with Yevgeny M. Primakov, a Soviet envoy.
In London, the British Government continues to adhere closely to Washington's position, in both its public and private statements. Despite pressure from Europe to tender an invitation to Mr. Gorbachev, a spokesman at 10 Downing Street would only say today that the question "is being considered."
"As the chairman and host of the G-7 summit," the spokesman said, "we are obviously consulting with other members and we are looking for a consensus." He said he did not expect a decision on the invitation question "until we get a little closer to the summit itself."
Among others, former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher may be putting some private pressure on her successor, John Major, to invite Mr. Gorbachev to London. While Mrs. Thatcher made no public statements about the matter when she met with Mr. Gorbachev during a private visit to Moscow this week, she said last year, before she was forced to resign as Prime Minister, that she was in favor of inviting Mr. Gorbachev to attend the London conference.
On Thursday, after a two-day French-German meeting in Lille, President Mitterrand and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said they wanted Mr. Gorbachev in London next month to meet with the leaders of the Western world.
 
France Wants Him There
 "I desire the presence of Mr. Gorbachev in London," Mr. Mitterrand said. He suggested that Mr. Gorbachev should not attend the actual two-day conference itself but rather should be there "only for consultations on subjects which are common to him and to us."
When pressed by reporters whether an invitation would imply a Western commitment to offer aid to the Soviet Union, Mr. Mitterrand replied: "I hope so, but the amount will depend on the conversation."
Until joined by France and Germany, Italy had taken the lead in pressing for an invitation, to emphasize Western support for Soviet economic reforms.
"We must decide quickly and act quickly at the London G-7," said Gianni De Michelis, the Italian Foreign Minister. "If we don't decide, we will be giving a signal of nonconfidence to private industry, which could just write off the Soviet Union as a target for investment."
