HEADLINE: Vote in a 'Melting Pot' of Los Angeles May Mirror the Future of California

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 1

 BODY:
The ethnic politics of the future are germinating here in a race for a State Assembly seat from a crowded immigrant neighborhood that some politicians call the new Ellis Island.
Fifteen candidates, some representing tiny immigrant constituencies, are maneuvering for votes in the 46th District in central Los Angeles, but as in the state at large, the heavily registered white voters are expected to determine the outcome. 
 Political analysts say this immigrant point of entry, where nearly 50 languages can be heard among the schoolchildren, offers a lesson in the gap between population numbers and political power.
"I contend that, like it or not, my district is what all of California is going to look like by the year 2025, if not before," said Michael Roos, the incumbent, whose resignation touched off this special election, scheduled for Tuesday.
 
Diversity of Candidates
 "It seems like every faction in the community has fielded a candidate," said Mr. Roos, a Democrat. "The gays have a candidate, the Jews have a candidate, the Filipinos have a candidate, the Latinos have a candidate, the Koreans have a candidate, the Japanese have a candidate."
But while the district has a population of more than 360,000 people, mostly immigrants and their children, it has only 63,000 registered voters, and fewer than 15,000 of them are expected to vote. Whites, though they account for only 15 percent of the residents, make up at least 60 percent of the electorate in this district.
Thus, political analysts predict that even though California's exploding Hispanic and Asian populations are expected to put minority groups in the majority by the turn of the century, their political power will continue to lag behind their numbers for some time.
"Every time I read an article about how something dramatic is going to change, I want to laugh," said James Hayes, a political consultant who said he was advising 12 of the candidates here. He pointed out that even though the state's minority population is growing rapidly, the electorate remains overwhelmingly white. Although minorities already make up 43 percent of the state's population, 80 percent of the voters in last November's election were white.
But as in the state at large, the white population of the 46th District is aging, while the mostly Hispanic immigrant population, many of whom are not yet citizens, is young and growing.
One Democratic candidate, John Emerson, the Chief Deputy City Attorney, said, "This is a district with one of the highest percentages of children living in it, whereas when the votes are tallied, more than 45 percent of those voting are over 65 years of age."
Another candidate, Michael Cacciotti, a Democrat who is a former aide to Mr. Roos, said this demographic picture was vivid as he campaigned from door to door. "I can see the dying population of Anglos and Europeans, by themselves or with their spouse, in their 80's and 90's," he said. "In another room, 20 kids are running down the hallway where Latino families have moved in."
With three white candidates and one homosexual candidate expected by most political experts to divide the white votes, some minority candidates are taking heart from predictions that the seat could be won with no more than 2,000 votes.
Victory seems possible if there were bloc voting by the 1,800 registered ethnic Japanese, the 1,200 Chinese, the 2,500 Koreans, the 300 Vietnamese, the 9,000 Mexican and Central Americans, the 4,000 Filipinos, the 1,000 Armenians or the 1,500 blacks.
 
Political Consultant's Advice
 But Mr. Hayes said he had counseled his clients that the route to victory in California's emerging multi-cultural politics was an appeal to a broad base beyond an ethnic constituency. He noted that several black and Japanese politicians have had success without strong racial or ethnic power bases. City Councilman Michael Woo won his seat in a district that is only 5 percent Asian, and Mayor Tom Bradley, who is black, has served for 17 years in a city where the black population now stands at 13 percent.
Although none of the 46th District's minority candidates may win, they are preparing the politics of the future in a community that includes what a demographic expert, Leo Estrada, termed "staging areas" for immigrant arrivals similar to New York's Lower East Side early in the century.
Like that neighborhood, he said, this is a district that offers low-cost housing and low-paying jobs, from which the various immigrant groups will eventually move on.
The 46th District runs from the affluent Silver Lake community in the north to a high-crime area along Pico Boulevard in the south, and includes most of Koreatown and slivers of Chinatown and the Armenian community of East Hollywood, as well as a Little Salvador and a miniature Manila.
Most strikingly, said Mr. Estrada, the ethnic groups here commingle more intensely than in almost any other place in the country, with nationalities shifting from building to building along a street.
"I know a place along Rampart Street that turned from white to Mexican to Filipino all within about a year and a half," said Mr. Estrada, who is a professor at the University of California at Los Angeles. "You'll find some villages re-emerging in the form of an apartment building in which a half to two-thirds of all apartments are being rented by people from the same village back home."
Crowded along a few blocks of Santa Monica Boulevard are the Panderia Salvadorena, Taslikian's Armenian Pastry, Lutong Bahay Filipino Food, Spicy B.B.Q. Thai and Chinese Food and the Tavlian Middle Eastern, Greek and Italian Grocery.
Sri Lankan Tamils and Mixtec Indians from Mexico's Oaxaca Province share shady neighborhoods with Sufi and Vietnamese Buddhist temples.
At the Hoover Street Elementary School, students speak Thai, Spanish, Portuguese, Filipino, Laotian, Korean, Khmer, Italian, Hindi, Hawaiian, Vietnamese, Amharic, Cantonese and other Chinese dialects. Only 30 percent speak English well.
At the Hobart Boulevard Elementary School, said Mr. Cacciotti, "P.T.A. meetings are like a three-ring circus."
"The principal gets up there and talks and most of the people can't understand him," he said. "Then one vice principal gets up and talks Spanish. Then the other gets up and talks Korean."
As with the state and the city at large, demographers say, new immigrants are lured here by the climate, the economy, the geographical location and the presence of others from their countries who came before them.
"In the 70's and 80's, everyone in the world that was going to get killed got out and came to L.A.," said a demographer who asked that his name not be used because he is a consultant to several of the candidates.
"They had these little tiny communities that were already here," he said. "Then climate, location, size, infrastructure and rents as a percentage of income -- if you were to create all that somewhere on the globe it would show up here in the 46th Assembly District."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The 46th State Assembly District in Los Angeles has been called the new Ellis Island because of the diversity of its immigrant population. A group waited at a bus stop in the district's Koreatown section. (Bart Bartholomew for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Top Ethiopia Rebel Talks of Democracy

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 1

 BODY:
The guerrilla leader who heads the new interim government here returned to Ethiopia today and promised to work for democracy and free enterprise.
The official, Meles Zenawi, arrived before dawn aboard a charter flight from London. His arrival was without public ceremony, and foreign diplomats who had contacts with the rebels said Mr. Meles had chosen the low-key entrance because he realized that his forces from Tigre Province, in the north, were widely distrusted by the ethnic Amhara group that dominates Addis Ababa. 
 Since Mr. Meles's forces overwhelmed the Government on Tuesday, they have forcibly suppressed a series of hostile demonstrations by civilians in the capital, resulting in at least 10 dead.
Mr. Meles's first public appearance was an afternoon meeting with the foreign diplomatic corps and a few members of the press, in which he attempted to dispel any notion that his Tigre People's Liberation Front remained committed to installing the Albanian-style Communist system it espoused several years ago.
"We're talking about a democratic and peaceful transition," he said. "We are not going for vendettas, retribution or kangaroo courts."
 
Some Free-Market Solutions
 He also said he favored dismantling state controls over agriculture and generally favored free-market remedies for Ethiopia's dire poverty.
Mr. Meles emphasized that the first priority of the interim administration was to establish order.
Longer-term policies, he said, will have to be set by a provisional government organized after leaders of his group and the two other major guerrilla armies meet by July 1. And he added that national elections would come "in a year or two," rather than immediately.
Mr. Meles responded carefully when questioned about the sensitive issue of independence for the Red Sea province of Eritrea, in the nation's far north. This has long been the aim of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, with which the Tigreans are loosely aligned.
He said he favored a referendum on Eritrean independence, but in deference to popular sentiment in the capital, which is strongly in favor of keeping the nation united, Mr. Meles told the diplomats that their portfolios still included Eritrea.
Questioned about the widespread impression that his forces only entered the capital after receiving permission from Washington, he replied that they were prepared to take Addis Ababa with or without American consent.
"We would not let any country invite us into our own capital," he said.
 
Eritrea a Touchy Subject
 A senior Middle Eastern diplomat said Mr. Meles "made a good impression," but the envoy warned that Ethiopia would again become consumed by civil war if the Eritrean rebels pressed for independence. "Eritrean independence is not acceptable here," the envoy said.
The Eritrean guerrillas, who represent the oldest and strongest fighting force in the country, already control all of their province and have formed their own provisional government in the capital, Asmara. Moreover, their command of Assab and Massawa, the nation's two principal ports, gives them tremendous leverage over the Tigreans in Addis Ababa.
Eritreans developed an independent identity because they were dominated for centuries by the Ottoman Empire, and later by the Egyptians, British and Italians. But a large number of Amharas, who have traditionally formed Ethiopia's governing elite, reject such aspirations as the illegitimate legacy of colonialism.
Later today, the Italian Ambassador, Sergio Angeletti, asked for a meeting with Mr. Meles to discuss the interim Government's first diplomatic imbroglio.
Tigrean fighters have surrounded the Italian Embassy since Friday night, after it became known that the former acting President, Lieut. Gen. Tesfaye Gibre-Kidan, and six other senior officials of the old government had taken refuge there. The Tigreans are demanding that the former officials surrender.

HEADLINE: Bush Assails 'Quota Bill' at West Point Graduation

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST POINT, N.Y., June 1

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he wanted to "destroy the racial mistrust that threatens our national well-being as much as violence or drugs or poverty" and called for support for his civil rights bill, saying it would avert employment quotas.
"We must think of ourselves not as colors or numbers," he said at the 193d commencement of the United States Military Academy here, "but as Americans, as bearers of sacred values." 
 Mr. Bush presented diplomas to each of the 915 graduates of the academy, which he hailed as an institution where people are measured by "merit, heart and will -- not creed or sex or color or national origin."
He attacked the competing civil rights bill, backed by the House Democratic leadership, as a "quota bill, regardless of how its authors dress it up." A provision declaring quotas illegal was added to the bill last week, but Mr. Bush said, "You can't put a sign on a pig and say it's a horse."
 
Bush's Veto Threat
 The Democratic bill, designed to overrule a series of 1989 Supreme Court decisions that made it harder for victims of job discrimination to sue and collect damages, is expected to be passed next week by the House. Supporters hope, and the White House apparently fears, that they can muster the two-thirds majority that would be necessary to override a threatened Presidential veto.
Mr. Bush, who has been hammering against the bill in recent days, said, "It invites people to litigate, not cooperate, and this is no way in our country to promote harmony."
"And so, let us cast off now the politics of division," he said. "Let's build a society in which people respect each other, work with, not against each other, and strive to illuminate the American character."
The audience of cadets and their families gave him a polite hearing, without the heckling or demonstrations that met him recently at Hampton and Yale Universities.
The crowd gave his civil rights message modest applause at only two points, when he said his bill would "not force employers to choose between using quotas or the risk of costly litigation," a charge he has made against the Democratic bill, and when he said his Administration "will strike at discrimination wherever it exists."
The speech today was the fifth of six commencement addresses this spring in which Mr. Bush has sought to define his Administration's position on major topics, ranging from China policy to "politically correct" speech.
Today's topic, Mr. Bush's view of race relations in America, had been planned for several weeks. But it gained relevance when House leaders put off a vote on the civil rights bill. They had hoped to vote on it this week. Now they plan a vote on Tuesday.
The bill is very similar to the one Mr. Bush vetoed last year. But a few changes, including the anti-quota section, and alterations in the makeup of the House since last year's election, have given sponsors serious hopes of mustering the critical two-thirds majority.
Today Mr. Bush also made a point of noting that the academy was graduating both its thousandth black and its thousandth woman, Michael Mayweather of St. Louis and Kimberly J. Ashton of Williston, N.D.
Fifty-four of the graduates who tossed their caps in the air at Michie Stadium after being commissioned as second lieutenants in the Army this morning are black. Eighty-six are women. The academy also said that 38 were Hispanic-Americans, 30 were Asian-Americans and 3 were native Americans.
In his speech, Mr. Bush contended that today's civil rights leaders had forgotten the message of their predecessors of the 1960's when the goal was "equality of opportunity and equality under the law." When Mr. Bush was running unsuccessfully for the Senate in Texas in 1964, he attacked the landmark Civil Rights Act of that year. But in 1968, as a member of the House, he cast a vote for that year's Fair Housing Act, a measure that few Southern Republicans favored.
 
Goal of 'a Fair Chance'
 "Government's responsibility," he said today, "is to enhance, not redistribute, opportunity, to insure that all people get a fair chance to achieve their dreams.
"Today some talk not of opportunity but of redistributing rights. They would pit one group against another, encourage people to think of others as competitors, not colleagues. That's not the way to achieve justice and equality here in America. We need to adopt a more unifying, moral and noble approach."
He said his Administration's commitment to equality involved not only the civil rights bill but a "comprehensive attack on the problems facing disadvantaged Americans." That plan included its efforts to promote innovation in education, individual ownership of public housing and economic enterprise zones he said.
He said his anti-crime program was also essential "because no American is free if imprisoned by the fear of crime."
"These policies," he said, "give power back to the people and they move us toward achieving the goal of equal opportunity. They do not -- cannot -- insure racial success."

HEADLINE: Soviet Jews Would Be Settled In Co-op City, State Plan Says

BYLINE: By ROBERT E. TOMASSON

 BODY:
A year after an attempt to relocate Soviet Jewish emigres at the Starrett City housing complex in Brooklyn collapsed amid accusations of discrimination, a more ambitious plan to settle up to 250 emigre families at Co-op City in the Bronx has been approved by New York State.
The proposal to bring emigre families to Starrett City was doomed, officials said, because the Brooklyn complex has a waiting list of about 8,000 families and its owners could not overcome the implication that white foreigners would be receiving preferential treatment over minority applicants in renting the apartments. 
 But at Co-op City, instead of a waiting list, there is a list of more than 500 units available for sale.
And to further avoid the appearance of singling out one group for special treatment in the government-subsidized complex, applications for the apartments and for subsidized loans to purchase them have been opened to all immigrant groups that have sponsoring organizations.
"What we have done here in effect is to create an affirmative-action program for immigrants," said Angelo Aponte, Commissioner of the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the state agency that oversees both Co-op City and Starrett City, and which approved the Co-op City plan.
Under an agreement signed last week by the state, the Riverbay Corporation, which runs Co-op City, and the Metropolitan New York Coordinating Council on Jewish Poverty, Soviet Jews would purchase mostly two- and three-bedroom apartments for an average of $10,000 each with interest-free loans from the Hebrew Free Loan Society, a 99-year-old philanthropic group.
 
15,372 Apartments
 David Cohen, the executive director of the Council on Jewish Poverty, a 19-year-old social-service organization, said that final agreement had not yet been reached on the financing, but that a decision was expected in two weeks. Without such funds, the agreement could collapse, he said.
Housing advocates who opposed the Starrett plan took a wait-and-see attitude on the Co-op proposal.
Under the terms of the agreement, newspaper ads will run this weekend offering apartments for sale to all comers. Managers of Co-op City, one of the largest apartment complexes in the nation with 15,372 apartments in 35 high-rises, expressed confidence that they could absorb hundreds of buyers in addition to those sponsored by the Council on Jewish Poverty.
The ads are believed to be the first ever run for units at the complex, said Al Zezula, a spokesman for the Co-op management. "It has always been word of mouth, but wham -- suddenly, like everybody else, there are vacancies," he said.
Besides Soviet Jews, assistance will be available to other immigrant groups under the loan program administered by the Hebrew Free Loan Society, which provides loans to needy people who require temporary assistance. The society is nonsectarian, but as a matter of tradition the vast majority of its services are provided to Jews, said its executive director, Arnold Teitelbaum.
 
30 Families a Month
 Under the terms of the agreement, which was reached after more than a year of often emotional debate among Co-op City residents, purchases would be arranged for 30 emigre families a month for three months, after which the program would be reassessed.
Last week, the board of the Riverbay Corporation voted 10 to 1 to approve the plan. One factor that overcame doubts about granting any one group special status was the specter of the vacancies that cut into everyone's equity in the complex.
"The Russian emigres are mostly professional people, and their presence will be a terrific shot in the arm for Co-op City and the Bronx," said Representative Eliot L. Engel, a 20-year resident of Co-op City and grandson of four Russian emigres, whose Congressional district includes the complex.
A chief architect of Co-op City was Herman J. Jessor, known for the amenities of his designs such as entrance foyers, eat-in kitchens with windows and large rooms that are the main selling points of the Bronx apartments. Mr. Jessor, who died in April 1990 at age 95, was himself a Russian immigrant who came to the United States when he was 12.

HEADLINE: Prison Unrest Shakes Elmira's Peace

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOUTHPORT, N.Y. June 1

 BODY:
The two state prisons in the Elmira area have provided jobs for residents for generations, a local historian says, but until recently they never thought of it as a prison town.
Instead Elmira identified itself with another resident -- Mark Twain, who spent summers here for 20 years. 
 Then the state decided six months ago to move its toughest and most jailwise inmates into the area's second prison, and then last week some of those prisoners staged a daylong rebellion that has shaken and angered residents and maybe changed the way Elmira looks at itself.
"I think it's changed the concept of Elmira for many people," said the town's retired historian, Thomas Byrne. "I never thought of it until now as a prison town."
 
'Pressures Are So Great'
 Officials said today that 50 of the 52 inmates involved in the incident had been transferred from Elmira to maximum-security prisons.
As far back as the Civil War, when 12,000 Confederate soldiers were interned at Elmira Prison Camp, inmates have been part of the population here. And until Southport Corrections Facility was made into a "maxi maxi" security prison for the state's worst inmates six months ago, Richard Gunderman, who has been a correction officer for 15 years, had the kind of job he hoped his son might pursue.
Standing last Friday within a stone's throw of Southport Corrections Facility, where he had earlier in the week spent nearly 27 hours without sleep as the inmates took over the prison and held three of his colleagues hostage, Officer Gunderman said he had told his son not to go through with his plan to apply for a guard's job.
"The pressures are so great here that I just go home and break down," said Officer Gunderman, 44 years old. "There's no release. I just want to go home and sit alone."
Southport opened in October 1988 as a maximum security prison intended to hold 750 inmates. It joined Elmira Correctional Facility, which opened in 1876 as a reformatory for boys, but later became a maximum security prison for adults.
Assemblyman George Winner Jr. led the fight to bring the second prison to Chemung County, whose economy had been rocked by a series of plant closings, including America La France, which had manufactured fire engines here for 150 years.
In the mid-1980's Chemung County had the highest unemployment rate in New York and ranked sixth nationally on the list of economically depressed areas, said Larry Bowman, president of the county Chamber of Commerce.
Given the local economic problems and the longtime acceptance of the older prison, there was little opposition to Southport. But last November, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced that Southport would be converted into the state's first all-solitary-confinement prison for nearly 800 of the state's worst inmates.
State officials said Elmira Correctional Facility has an annual payroll of $25 million and Southport one of $13 million. But their economic impact is estimated at triple those figures, counting the ripple effect of those salaries.
Mr. Winner, a Republican from Elmira and a 13-year veteran of the Assembly, said the state was able to force through the conversion to "maxi maxi" on the county without the agreement of legislators or county officials.
"They quieted the system down statewide by the removal of the most dangerous and the most disturbed inmates and made a nightmare out of Southport," Mr. Winner said. "The community is satisfied that there is no realistic risk that there is going to be a massive escape, but the community is concerned about the safety of its relatives and friends who work there."
This week's takeover prompted many guards and their families to reconsider the pressures that have increased -- at work and at home -- since Southport was converted.
"He got more sensitive to everything and was snapping a lot," said one guard's wife who spoke on condition of anonymity. She blamed her husband's moodiness on the longer hours -- sometimes 16 hours a day -- that he had been forced to work because of the transfer of 49 of the prison's 255 guards as part of statewide cutbacks.
"We have been a community with a prison for so long that I think for the most part it's been viewed as just another place where people go to work every day," said Mr. Bowman of the Chamber Commerce. "But the disturbance at Southport was a startling and graphic reminder that the prison jobs don't really compare to work in many other places."

HEADLINE: Today's Threat to Peace Is the Guy Down the Street

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SOON after word reached Washington that Rajiv Gandhi had been assassinated in India, President Bush remarked: "I just don't know what the world is coming to." That was a startling comment, coming from a man who only weeks earlier was proclaiming the birth of a new world order in the wake of the gulf war. In a way, though, there was no contradiction. The world is coming to a new order, but it is not the one that President Bush envisaged -- or one that he will have much ability to shape.
The main principle President Bush invoked to justify his opposition to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait was that unless international boundaries between sovereign nation states are respected, the alternative is chaos. But the sort of threat posed by Saddam Hussein -- one nation state simply devouring its neighbor -- is increasingly obsolete in world politics today. 
 Instead, what are becoming increasingly common are challenges to the sovereignty and sanctity of nation states from within -- from ethnic, tribal and religious groups dissatisfied with the shape or the content of their nations and ready to use any sort of violence to bring about change.
So it is not the gulf war, but events that have taken place since that really characterize the dominant trend and challenge in the post-cold war world -- the Kurdish drive to split off from Iraq, the assassination of Mr. Gandhi by opponents amid ethnic strife in India, the takover of Ethiopia by secessionist rebels from Eritrea and others seeking to replace Ethiopia's traditional tribal elite. Indeed, it is the same from Yugoslavia to Quebec and from the Soviet Union to South Africa: the predominant threat to stability is conflict within nations and not between them.
"The gulf war is the wave of the past," remarked Michael Mandelbaum, director of East-West studies at the Council on Foreign Relations. "India, Ethiopia, Yugoslavia and the breakup of the Soviet Union are the wave of the future.
"Most nation states arose as a result of the breakup of great empires following World War I and World War II," he said. "But the third great cataclysm of this century, the end of the cold war, is shaping up to be a story not so much about the unmaking of empires and the birth of nation states, but the unmaking of nation states that were born earlier in the century."
It is not surprising that the end of the cold war has been accompanied by the fragmentation of some nation states. The cold war not only held together by force such artificial nation states as Yugoslavia; it also enabled regimes in many weak states, such as Ethiopia and Iraq, to strengthen and sustain themselves far longer than they might have otherwise. They accomplished this by getting economic help and diplomatic backing from superpowers eager to bid for their support in the grand contest between East and West.
But those days are over, and life promises to be much more complicated not only for many weak nation states but for the superpowers as well. Generally speaking, the sorts of threats to international stability that the United States is likely to face now -- those coming from within states that are imploding -- will not easily be treated by classic great-power diplomacy. Nor will these threats offer the moral clarity that was available when there was a clear-cut villain or an "Evil Empire" challenging America. They also may not be responsive to brute force.
The NATO allies more or less acknowledged the changed environment last week, when they announced that they were revamping their forces from a massive dam designed to resist a Soviet invasion across Europe, to smaller mobile units better able to put out brush fires ignited by small states or tensions between European ethnic and regional groups.
Standard international relations texts -- including all the classic balance-of-power theories from Clausewitz to Kissinger -- will have to be revised somewhat, to teach statesmen how to improvise for these new challenges. For example, when the United States wanted to get a new Security Council resolution that would dispatch a United Nations police force to protect Kurds wanting to return home, and to replace the American troops, the Soviets and Chinese balked. They said they were afraid that if the United Nations could intervene to protect the Kurds in Iraq, it might later be asked to do the same for the Baltic peoples or those of Tibet. In the end, a murky compromise was cobbled together.
"What I am struck by," said Stanley Hoffmann, a professor of government at Harvard, "is the fact that the world order, or whatever there is of it, is still very much based on state sovereignty, and that is quite inadequate, and indeed dangerous when you consider that many of the most destabilizing troubles are likely to come from within states -- either because of ethnic strife or terrifying repressive measures that governments, like South Africa or the Soviet Union, might take that invite external intervention."
Mr. Hoffmann added: "There is very little in our repertoire of ideas that helps us to cope with such internal disorders. Each time statesmen have opened this Pandora's box of what goes on inside states, they have closed it in horror."
Washington also has less influence in these internal conflicts because in most cases they are going to be decided by small arms, an assassin's bullet or backwoods deals between peoples with whom America has little contact or understanding. If the Soviet republic of Georgia declares its independence tomorrow, with whom will Washington deal?
Moreover, the United States is not only less capable of intervening, but less interested in doing so. In the post-cold war world, when America no longer feels impelled to compete with the Soviet Union for every corner of the globe, it is far less urgent to many people who rules in Ethiopia, or whether it is one country or three.
But in another sense the United States has also acquired new leverage to influence some of these internal contests. This is because America's triumph in the cold war was not a territorial victory but a victory for a set of political and economic principles: democracy and the free market.
Many third-world countries that, in the first flush of independence, rejected capitalism for socialism, have now concluded that the free market is the wave of the future -- a future for which America is both the gatekeeper and the model.
It is precisely this economic leverage that the United States has over the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev -- whether to grant him everything from food credits to access to international lending agencies -- that enables Washington to press him to open his society more, to give more freedom to the republics and different ethnic groups and to loosen the reins of central economic control.
Call it diplomacy by the Federalist Papers. It is being used in Ethiopia too, where the once-Marxist rebels have gone from preaching Communism to pragmatism. The Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, Herman J. Cohen, who has been helping to mediate in the Ethiopian civil war, bluntly told Ethiopia's new leaders: "No democracy, no cooperation."
But such diplomacy by moral and economic suasion has its limits, as last week's anti-American protests in Ethiopia demonstrated. There is no more violent cocktail than ethnic and tribal hatreds combined with uneven economic growth. In an era when there is far more economic advice than resources to implement it, and far more ethnic passions than traditions of pluralism to contain them, there are going to be far more new world disorders than new world orders.

HEADLINE: The Region;
New York's City Workers: Freeloaders or Scapegoats?

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
WHEN Mayor David N. Dinkins outlined his worse-case solution to the city's $3.5 billion budget deficit, he said he was looking to three sources to help ease the crisis: the state, the Municipal Assistance Corporation and the city's labor unions.
With the state's budget more or less in hand and the assistance corporation back on the sidelines, rebuffed by rating agencies when it tried to help, the focus is on the unions. But many people inside and out of the government worry that the unions feel such a deep sense of entitlement that they will be unwilling to contribute in the way that the Mayor clearly hopes. 
 The pressure on them is enormous. The Mayor has asked his legal counsel to prepare legislation that if passed by the state, would enable him to impose furloughs. The business community, emboldened by the panoply of higher taxes it now faces, is urging him to force the municipal unions, which encompass 310,000 members, to sacrifice more.
In a letter to the Mayor last month, the New York City Partnership, a business lobbying group, asked him to impose a wage freeze on city workers for at least the next fiscal year, beginning next month. It also complained about benefits for city employees that it considers inordinate: three weeks of vacation for new employees and 12 days of paid vacation compared with 9 or 10 in the private sector. If the number of vacation days was reduced by two, the group said, the city could save more than $100 million.
Whether it is fair or not, the image of city workers sitting at their desks pushing pencils while raking in handsome salaries and fringe benefits is not an uncommon one. That impression is only heightened by the 30-second sound bites on the evening news in which municipal union leaders frequently come across as blustering and intransigent, seemingly oblivious to the possibility that the public might think the unions should feel some obligation to give some of their wages and benefits back.
 
The Unions' Arguments
 Despite these impressions, the unions have a number of arguments to support their stance. City employees suffered heavily during the last fiscal crisis. Not only did they put almost a third of their pension fund at risk by buying city bonds, but their work force was reduced by about 25 percent and their inflation-adjusted wages fell by about one-sixth, according to the Citizens Budget Commission.
During the 80's, of course, many of the unions got wage increases that helped make up the difference. But even with those increases, the average wage of a nonuniformed union worker has not kept pace with inflation. From 1975 through 1991, inflation was 155 percent, while the average wage rose 130 percent, according to Program Planners Inc., a labor consulting firm. The uniformed workers -- police, firemen, corrections and sanitation staff -- merely stayed level with inflation.
Work conditions for city employees also leave something to be desired. A survey of the city administration that was conducted by a private-sector group in 1989 found workplace overcrowding and lack of ventilation so serious that it concluded, "We have seen many situations which would suggest that an expert review of safety conditions would be beneficial."
Given the difficult conditions that many city workers work in, it is not surprising that union leaders feel their members are more than entitled to what they earn and find the notion that they are under a moral obligation to give something back almost bizarre.
"Why would you ask the teachers -- the classroom teachers -- to subsidize education for children?" said Sandra Feldman, head of the 106,000-member United Federation of Teachers, in a recent televised interview.
Even some who have been highly critical of the city's financial situation do not consider the unions' attitude to be the problem. "I don't think the unions are any more or any less wrapped up in the concept of entitlement than any other group," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission.
Stanley Hill, executive director of District 37 of the American Federation of State County and Municipal Unions, said he and his 140,000 members recognize that the city has problems and are more than willing to talk with the administration about ways to save money. It was his union's suggestion that the city suspend all nonessential payments, a city official confirmed. City Hall finally took that step four months later.
James F. Hanley, the acting commissioner of the Mayor's Office of Labor Relations, said that while union leaders sound supportive, "the few times we've scheduled meetings they have not been fruitful."
In a recent report, the Citizens Budget Commission argued that the goal should be a smaller, better-paid, more efficient city work force. If the city replaced only half the workers who left every year of their own accord, the commission said, it could reduce the work force by 20 percent by the mid-90's, annually saving $2.8 billion.
But unless that work force changes how it operates, poorer service would seem inevitable. This emphasis on productivity leads the commission to propose that everything be put on the negotiating table: restrictive work rules as well as wasteful management practices.
The question is whether both sides are going to continue debating the merits of givebacks and deferrals, or whether they will eventually discuss a more fundamental issue: how the city and its work force can deliver services more effectively.

HEADLINE: The World;
Is Iran's Urge to Prosper Overtaking Its Islamic Zeal?

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT was the Persian version of George Bush's new world order, a crystallizing moment that set forth a guiding postwar vision of the world as seen through the eyes of Iran's leadership. Last week, when 250 Western, Asian and Arab oil officials met in the ancient imperial city of Isfahan, they heard a clear message of Iran's pragmatic approach to its neighbors: When it comes to the economy, the revolution is over.
If there had been any doubt that economics, not revolutionary fervor, is now the driving force behind Iran's domestic and foreign policy, it was dispelled when Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati bluntly told the group that "a new order" is emerging in the world in which "economic considerations overshadow political priorities." If the conference participants had closed their eyes, they might have thought they were listening to the late Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi. 
 Iran's main problem is that its per capita income is half what it was in the time of the Shah. Even though the drop in oil prices and the devastation left by eight years of war with Iraq account for much of the decline, many ordinary Iranians blame the revolution.
The new approach is a radical departure from the early days of the revolution, when the regime nationalized the banks, forced foreign companies to close and stressed self-sufficiency in agriculture and industry. Now the Government encourages foreign investment and accepts foreign loans, and foreigners are allowed to own up to 49 percent of joint projects and administer the projects themselves. In the last year, the Government has introduced a more realistic exchange rate, sold off shares in many Government-owned companies, moved to eradicate price controls, and increased imports. It even recently started a global campaign to lure Iranian businessmen -- and their capital -- back from exile.
The driving force behind the policy is Iran's President, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, who, as an heir to his family's pistachio-growing and exporting empire, is versed in the ways of the bazaar. Although Mr. Rafsanjani campaigned for the presidency two years ago on a prosperity ticket, it was the war to drive Iraq from Kuwait that substituted Iraq for Iran as the regional pariah and positioned the Iranian leader to portray his country as a reliable and trustworthy partner.
His attempt at old-fashioned state-building dovetails with Iran's determination to play a key role in any future security arrangements in the region; to that end, Iran has moved to re-establish ties with the same regimes it once vowed to throw into history's dustbin. Since the restoration of relations with Saudi Arabia -- at a time when American troops were still there -- the two countries have agreed on a common oil strategy. Iranian pilgrims will attend the hajj in Mecca for the first time since 1987, when Iranian-led demonstrations set off riots that left 400 people dead. Egypt and Iran have arranged for diplomatic representation in each others' capitals. And Iran and Kuwait, which has traditionally been suspicious of Teheran's motives, recently signed a contract for Iranian technicians to extinguish 60 of the oil well fires set by retreating Iraqi troops.
Perhaps the best proof of Iran's new sense of limits was its resistance to what must have been a powerful temptation to take revenge on Saddam Hussein in the aftermath of Iraq's military defeat. There was no Iranian intervention, not even a big demonstration, after the Iraqi regime attacked the holy Shiite Muslim cities of Karbala and Najaf during the short-lived Iraqi civil war. There have been pinprick attacks across the border, but these seem to be nothing more than reminders to Mr. Hussein that he must watch his eastern flank.
The Persian Gulf states seem to feel that they have little to lose in trying to moderate the policies of Iran by embracing it, particularly since Teheran poses no military threat these days. As the country with the longest coastline on the gulf, Iran feels it is destined to play a role in securing the region around those waters, and the gulf Arabs would now prefer to include Iran in security arrangements, rather than have non-gulf regimes like Egypt and Syria station troops on their soil.
For Washington, Iran is still not a country to be trusted. The Bush Administration remains convinced that Teheran holds the key to the release of six American hostages held by pro-Iranian Shiite groups in Lebanon, the main obstacle to normalizing relations. And the State Department's annual report on patterns of terrorism, released in April, concludes that although the number of incidents of Iranian state-supported terrorism dropped last year, the country's intelligence services have assassinated dissidents and used embassies abroad to finance terrorist groups.
The Iranians botched a golden opportunity to curry favor with Washington when they mishandled American overtures to help the one million Iraqi Kurds who had taken refuge in Iran. Iranians harassed American relief workers, charged foreign relief companies exorbitant fees to land their aircraft and accused the United States of sending them second-hand blankets and clothes. The country's chief spoiler is Ahmed Khomeini, the son of the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini; he announced that the American pilots should have been shot after they landed, and he has invoked his father's name in explaining why Iran can never have relations with the Untied States.
The young Khomeini has only a limited constituency, but no Iranian would dare directly attack the son of the late Imam. So his words serve to remind analysts in Washington that whatever movement there has been toward a "new order," for some Iranian leaders the revolution is still alive -- if not as active as it used to be.

HEADLINE: Inattention to Its Neighbors' Fears Could Compound India's Problems

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: NEW DELHI

 BODY:
THE domestic problems facing India in the wake of Rajiv Gandhi's assassination are enormous: social disorder, political instability and violence, an economic crisis and the uncertainty of the monsoon rains, on which food crops depend. But whoever wins the national elections now rescheduled for mid-June is also going to have to pay careful attention to India's relationships with its neighbors -- particularly Pakistan -- or New Delhi will only compound its domestic woes.
India's turmoil at home is, in many ways, a reflection of the ethnic conflicts tearing at hopes for peace in this and other regions. If New Delhi doesn't mend its prickly relationships with many of its neighbors -- a result of overbearing behavior indulged in for decades -- the tensions could stand in the way of getting needed help from the developed world, and cooperation from its most powerful neighbor and adversary, Pakistan. 
 Over the last two years, the most serious threat to India's domestic integrity has been posed by the secessionist movement that has exploded over the Kashmir Valley, a disputed territory populated mostly by Muslims that straddles the India-Pakistan border.
Alarms have gone off in Washington more than once over this dispute, because India and Pakistan are not only perennially locked in confrontation but are also thought to be capable of turning their antagonism into nuclear war.
Since 1947, the two nations have fought three wars, all of them to one degree or another involving Kashmir. And since the last war, in 1971, India has set off a nuclear explosion and has successfully tested several missile delivery systems. For its part, Pakistan is now barred from receiving American aid because President Bush cannot certify that Islamabad is not developing nuclear arms.
If the ethnic conflict in Kashmir is a threat to India's national integrity, it is also inextricably linked to tensions with Pakistan because Islamabad, almost without trying, has been able to fan the flames of revolt in the valley. No cause is more popular in Pakistan than "free Kashmir," though Islamabad is silent on whether such freedom should also apply to its part of the territory.
To compound the problem India faces, New Delhi can no longer simply cut a deal with Pakistan over the territory without the involvement of the Kashmiris themselves; they are determined to bring this issue back to the United Nations, where resolutions calling for self-determination have been pending for more than 40 years. Members of the British Parliament from the Labor Party have now taken up the issue of Kashmiri rights. New Delhi, however, has never allowed a plebiscite.
In Kashmir, as in the Punjab, human rights violations by Indian military, paramilitary and police forces are beginning to draw the sustained attention of international human rights organizations, creating a new and less obliging environment in the West and Japan for "the world's most populous democracy."
 
A Reputation as a Bully
 And in such a world, less sympathetic to India, new light will inevitably be shed on India's years as South Asia's bully -- an issue that has been put into momentary eclipse by the turmoil at home.
Under the last two Prime Ministers of the Nehru dynasty -- Jawaharlal Nehru's daughter Indira Gandhi and her son Rajiv -- New Delhi played havoc with the stability of its much smaller neighbors. Militants from Sri Lanka and Bangladesh were trained and armed here. The small Kingdom of Sikkim was undermined and destroyed by Indian agents. Nepal suffered a crippling economic boycott and Bhutan has had to put up with a large contingent of Indian troops, ostensibly in the country to train the minuscule Bhutanese army.
For decades after the British left in 1947-48, India made the regional rules. If a desperate Bangladesh wanted to convene an international conference on rivers and floods, for example, India said it was a bilateral matter. Now, international organizations and European nations, in particular France, have begun to ignore those limitations and have taken the plight of Bangladesh to the world over the heads of New Delhi's neo-imperialists.
The United States, on the other hand, has always seemed predisposed to allow India a free hand. Sri Lankans say they got a clear message that Washington was not prepared to challenge India's policies in the region, even when Indian aircraft violated Sri Lankan airspace with impunity to drop supplies in rebel areas.
When a mercenary Sri Lankan Tamil band tried to invade the Indian Ocean nation of Maldives in 1988, India rushed in troops and was rewarded by a public pat on the back by Washington. A tremor went through Pakistan, Nepal and Bangladesh.
All around the region, the interrupted elections soon to be completed in India are of immense importance. For about 18 months, with the Congress Party of Rajiv Gandhi in opposition or behind the scenes instead of in the halls of power, the region has enjoyed a breathing space -- except, perhaps, for Pakistan, which had its own internal turmoil to contend with, in addition to its worries about the course of the insurrection in Kashmir.
But one hope for a lessening of tensions in the region is that Pakistan now has a pragmatic Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, who is determined to go down in history as the man who modernized his country economically while allowing it to come to terms with its Islamic soul.
Mr. Sharif made his first official trip to India to attend Mr. Gandhi's funeral. He made the most of it, meeting the leader of every major Indian political party, and thus all the potential prime ministers of the country. Islamabad's challenge to India to end hostilities in Kashmir (while giving the people of Kashmir a fair deal) and join hands in developing two of the world's poorest countries is a new one.
This new proposal may flummox the hawks in India's foreign policy establishment. But it could also provide the first chance in decades to talk about something other than war.

HEADLINE: Clash Of '91;
Higher Education Feels the Heat

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
IN laying out his plan to propel American schools into the 21st century, President Bush barely mentioned colleges or universities. But that doesn't mean everything is all right on the nation's campuses. In the absence of any strategy for coupling an improvement in higher education with the reform of elementary and secondary schools, there is plenty of evidence, much of it provided by the Administration itself, that there is a fundamental rethinking about what colleges do and how they ought to do it.
The splendid seclusion of the university has been shattered by a barrage of criticism, both from within and outside. Nothing seems settled anymore -- not the tradition of learning, nor the system of admissions on merit. 
 Should college be the liberal education based on the Great Books that Allan Bloom stubbornly supports, or, as envisioned by a new generation of administrators represented by Marguerite Ross Barnett, president of the University of Houston, should it be the scientific crucible that will help the nation's economy in the next century?
Much of the friction arises from the contrast between the romanticized, ivy-covered vision of what college once represented, and the raw, boisterous and disruptive experience it is today. Once provinces of white male privilege, the universities now more accurately reflect society, with all its tensions, conflicts and outbursts of bad blood.
In this year of war, many campuses were rocked not by political agitation as in the 1960's but by nagging doubts about the nature and worth of a college education.
The turmoil has made the campus less a retreat from reality than an immersion in it. The average tenure of a public college president is now less than four years. The overwhelming majority of faculty members retire before reaching the mandatory age of 70. And students have grown increasingly discontent. Diversity has bred divisions and alliances by minority grouping. And there is no escape from complex politics on campus, the forum for the debate over "political correctness" and whether it stifles free speech.
 
A 'Loss of Confidence'
 The academic year just ending has seen an outpouring of critiques of higher education -- the way it does business and its relationship with government.
"Such criticism reflects a profound skepticism and a loss of confidence," said Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching and a former United States Commissioner of Education. "People are no longer willing to grant colleges and universities the unchallenged right to stand above public judgment."
Stanford University is accused of padding Federal research expense accounts with inappropriate charges like cedar closets and sailing yachts. The elite members of the Ivy League, charged with antitrust violations, have agreed not to collaborate on student aid. Lamar Alexander, the new Secretary of Education, is questioning the standards used by private regional agencies that accredit colleges and universities.
But perhaps a stronger clue to the Bush Administration's thinking about higher education is its plan, disclosed last week, to revise its student financial aid program to heavily favor students from poor families over those in the middle class.
The plan calls for restructuring the largest student grant program -- the so-called Pell grants -- which provides $5.3 billion in aid to 3.4 million students. The maximum amount of a grant would rise from $2,400 to $3,700 but eligibility standards would be tightened so that 400,000 fewer grants would be awarded each year for all families earning less than the $35,000 cutoff. Generally, students from families with the lowest incomes would receive most of the grants, with the amount of each grant depending on income and the cost of tuition.
The plan underscores a division over whether Federal policy on student aid should favor middle-class students, who have a range of college options, or the poorest students, who often have little choice but to attend a community college or public university.
Mr. Alexander said he wants to concentrate aid on the lower-income students, "where it will do the most," and leave middle-income students to borrow more money to pay tuition or to lower their expectations and forgo private universities for less expensive state and community colleges.
For years the number of high school graduates heading for college has been flagging. At the same time, the number of minority students in the high schools has increased. By the year 2000, a third of all elementary and high school students are expected to come from minority groups, making this pool of students even more important to the future of post-secondary education.
Most colleges realize that to survive they will need to attract and keep this new type of student, who often comes with greater educational and economic needs than the typical students of years past.
Congressional leaders opposed to the new financial aid plan call it an attempt to turn higher education into a poverty program, and many educators, including Robert H. Atwell, president of the American Council on Education, said it moves in the wrong direction because middle-income families need more help, not less.
Some recent developments point to a changing perception of colleges and universities -- from institutions beyond reproach to aggressive enterprises to be regulated and watched. The result seems to be a re-examination of the longstanding partnership between the Federal Government and higher education.
Unlike other countries, the United States has never directly supported a system of national universities; the financing of higher education is generally left to the states and to private interests. But the benefits of a first-class system -- originally thought to consist of trained ministers, capable political leaders and responsible citizen-voters -- were so desirable that indirect support has always been deemed warranted.
During the Civil War, the Federal Government provided land for the first public colleges. During World War II, the Government first employed universities for scientific research. The post-war period also brought the G.I. Bill of Rights, which put millions of veterans in school.
Neither Government nor the universities are eager to classify the relationship a partnership, preferring the semblance of independence, but the reliance is substantial. Federal assistance -- including appropriations, grants and contracts -- has grown from less than $39 million at the beginning of World War II to $13 billion today.
The first cracks in this solidarity may have appeared during the anti-war protests of the 1960's, but they found a special voice in the mid-1980's with the attacks by William J. Bennett, then the Secretary of Education. Mr. Bennett lampooned Harvard, Stanford and other prestigious universities for caving in to the demands of students who wanted to ditch traditional studies for what were, in his opinion, faddish courses.
Mr. Bennett's remarks seemed to signal an open season on colleges. Critics emerged, like Prof. Allan Bloom of the University of Chicago, whose book "The Closing of the American Mind" chronicled the fall of higher education.
While the prestigious private universities took much of the heat during this time, state universities grew larger, stronger and more sophisticated. They also were becoming increasingly expensive as tuition had to be raised to pay for their expansion. The spiral seemed to break this year as some of the largest and most respected public university systems, including those in California and Massachusetts, were forced to scale back substantially.
Congress, meanwhile, seems to be getting impatient with higher education. Recent legislation requires colleges and universities to report campus crime, graduation rates of athletes and, in the wake of the Stanford research cost allegations, Congress is likely to impose a new, stricter system of compensating universities for the research they do.
Even though the actions of his department and the Administration seem to be taking away some of the schools' automomy and imposing a more rigid view of how colleges should be run, Mr. Alexander, a former governor of Tennessee and more recently the president of the University of Tennessee, says he is concerned about such intrusion. Sounding more like a university administrator than a voice of the Administration he has been with for just two months, Mr. Alexander said he would rather see the relationship between higher education and the Federal Government kept at arm's length.
"It's beginning to look a lot like meddling," Mr. Alexander said. "And that's not a good trend."

HEADLINE: Poverty, Not Politics, Drives Cubans Out Now

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, June 1

 BODY:
When his only income dried up, money from the sale of secondhand clothes sent to him by relatives in the United States, Juan Alfredo Molenillo Grenup decided that he had had enough of spartan life in Cuba and set out in desperation on a raft for Florida.
Three days later, after being picked up by boaters off the Florida Keys, Mr. Molenillo had arrived, joining more than 600 other Cubans who have escaped their country on makeshift vessels this year in the largest wave of refugees from the island since the Mariel boatlift in 1980. 
 But while many of the hundreds of thousands of Cubans who fled after Fidel Castro's Communist revolution in 1959 spoke of political motives for their flight, today's boat people talk of a stark austerity they say has begun to make life unbearable for many.
Though they still complain of a lack of freedoms in Cuba, today's boat people dwell with grim detail on an existence without necessities, from underwear to soap and medicines, that has taken hold since the collapse of Communist partners in Europe.
Andrew Zimbalist, an expert on the Cuban economy at Smith College in Northampton, Mass., said the country's per capita income had shrunk by 5 to 7 percent in 1990, adding, "We are looking at a similar decline for this year."
In recent months, as Mr. Castro's Government has tightened the nation's belt as part of an adjustment program, refugees say that even supplying a healthy diet has become a struggle for most Cuban families.
"For three months, we had eaten no meat," said Mr. Molenillo, a 36-year-old laid-off welder, interviewed along with half a dozen other recent arrivals at a detention center of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Miami, where they waited for their papers to be processed. "Without food, there was nothing to do but leave."
"In March, I traveled to Oriente, and people there told me they had been washing themselves with plain water because there was no soap," he said, referring to Cuba's eastern province. "I told them it had been three months since we have seen socks in Havana. We laughed and cried together."
In the past Cuba's Coast Guard aggressively patrolled the island's waters against escapees. But recent refugees report that Cuba's efforts to prevent flight by small boats, rafts and inner tubes has all but ended.
"There are so many people putting out to sea nowadays that the one or two patrols they have cannot really hope to stop them," said Mr. Molenillo, who left a wife and two children behind when he fled the island. "In any event, they don't seem to have much gas."
Economists say supplies of petroleum products from the Soviet Union have fallen sharply and deliveries have become irregular in the last year, largely a consequence of that country's own growing economic disorder.
The skin still wrinkled and peeling on his face from the exposure to the sun, Julio Lazar Rodriguez Siscard, 24, who drove a bus in Havana until his route was suspended, also spoke of hardships.
"Just basic products, clothes, you can't get anymore," said Mr. Rodriguez, who left Cuba on a raft, arriving in Key West with two brothers and three friends three days later.
Like several other refugees, Mr. Rodriguez castigated the "system" in Cuba, but spoke mainly of poverty and frustrated material desires. "What can I do with that?" he asked dismissively of the 350-peso monthly salary he said he was paid until he was laid off. "Find the bare necessities if I am lucky, nothing more."
Mr. Rodriguez's salary was considerably better than the average of about 195 pesos a month, or about $175. But with store shelves empty and almost all staple foods rationed, even many with relatively high wages have begun to look for ways out of the country.
"Our system is not something with a future," said Jorge Luis Torres Morales, a 25-year-old employee of a Havana food processing plant who arrived by small boat in May. "I made 350 pesos a month. That is not bad compared to some, but even if you work five years, you have nothing to show for it. A simple pair of pants, if you can find them, costs 50 pesos."

HEADLINE: Compromise Clears Way for Virginia Power Plant

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
The National Park Service and two electrical power companies announced Friday an unusual environmental compromise that will help clear the way for construction of a coal-fired power plant in Virginia, provided that an existing plant reduces air pollution that is threatening the Shenandoah National Park.
Park Service officials and Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., along with power company officials, hailed the compromise as a "significant new pollution-reduction agreement" that would protect the environment and still permit industrial development. 
 But Representative Henry A. Waxman, the California Democrat whose House Subcommitee on Health and Environment monitors pollution issues, called the compromise "an outrageous paper sham." He said it was vaguely written without any enforcement teeth and asserted that the Park Service had been forced to accept it by White House officials more concerned with company profits than the environment.
An environmental group that has opposed the plant, the Southern Environmental Law Center of Charlottesville, Va., questioned whether the agreement was broad enough. Center officials warned that they would challenge the compromise in court if it proved to have shortcomings.
 
Park Service Took Tough Stand
 The agreement, reached with the Virginia Power company and the Old Dominion Electric Cooperative, provides that the utilities may construct a new coal-fired generating plant in south-central Virginia so long as there is a reduction in pollution flowing from an old plant situated north of Shenandoah Park in West Virginia. The reduction is to be 1.1 times greater at the old plant than emissions from the new plant, and discussion may be reopened if Park Service officials conclude that the reduction is not achieved.
The agreement came about after the Park Service took an aggressive anti-pollution step and decided to actively oppose construction of the $1.2 billion electric plant rather than simply express concerns about pollution.
Park officials argued that the plant would add to industrial and urban pollution that is slowly killing the northern Virginia park that stretches 85 miles along the Blue Ridge Mountains and is famed for its cliff-hugging Skyline Drive. They said the pollution, much of from sulfur dioxide emissions from coal-fired power plants that falls to the earth as acid rain, was poisoning trout streams, searing trees and shrubs, clouding vistas and endangering the health of park visitors.
 An agency of the Interior Department, the Park Service had previously expressed concern about air pollution in a number of its parks, including Shenandoah, the Great Smokies on the Tennessee-North Carolina border and the Grand Canyon. But until it opposed the Virginia plant, it had avoided taking a stand that could affect the pace of industrial development, leaving such portentous action to the Environmental Protection Agency.
 
White House Pressure Denied
 The agreement is the kind encouraged by the Clean Air Act and the Bush Administration on the theory that trade-offs in pollution emissions achieve both environmental and economic goals. Spokesmen for the Interior Department and the power company said the White House kept close watch on the negotiations that led to the agreement. But they denied that there was any undue pressure on the Park Service to reach a compromise so that the power companies could avoid costly construction delays.
"The agreement resulted from negotiations, not pressure," said Carl F. Baab of Virginia Power.
Power company officials said they hoped work could start on the plant shortly. But they expressed concern over delays, should the agreement with the Park Service be challenged in court.
David W. Carr Jr., a lawyer for the Southern Environmental Law Center, said his organization would study the details of the agreement over the weekend and then determine whether there would be a challenge.

HEADLINE: North Korea to Earth: Coming Back

 BODY:
North and South Korea are now both set to assume full United Nations membership this fall, following Pyongyang's reluctant decision to submit its own separate application. That's a welcome sign in one of the last corners of the cold war. By responding promptly, the U.S. can help encourage a wider thaw.
The North's move is a pragmatic response to the South's courtship of Moscow and Beijing. It offers Washington an excellent chance to upgrade its own discussions with Pyongyang. They have a lot to talk about, from de-nuclearizing the peninsula to ending Pyongyang's dangerous isolation. 
 Koreans long for reunification. Their 46-year division interrupts more than a millennium of shared history. But the two Governments differ over what a united Korea would look like. Each naturally sees its own society as the model.
Seoul has tried to move Pyongyang closer to its own positions by reaching out to the Soviet Union and China, long North Korea's main allies. Moscow and Beijing both want South Korean investment. Seoul and Moscow now have diplomatic ties. China's economic relations with the South have blossomed; diplomatic relations may follow.
The Soviets and Chinese insist that better relations with Seoul have not come at the expense of the North. But the improved ties made it unlikely that Seoul's U.N. application would be vetoed. Pyongyang has now bowed to this new diplomatic reality.
South Korea correctly notes that separate U.N. seats did not prevent reunification of the two Germanys. That precedent of Communist collapse brings no joy to North Korea's orthodox Stalinist rulers. It's in America's interest to assuage Pyongyang's bitterness and help make its policy shift a source of new momentum for regional detente.
North Korea's nuclear program remains a source of justifiable worry. Pyongyang has signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, but has long resisted full international inspections, demanding that the U.S. first withdraw its own nuclear weapons from South Korea and renounce any intention to use them against the North. Last week, Pyongyang offered to begin talking about inspections.
North Korea has no right to demand concessions in return for what it is already obliged to do. But the U.S. can assure South Korea's security just as well with offshore nuclear weapons. And anything that would subject North Korea's nuclear installations to inspection would actually enhance South Korean security. Why not test Pyongyang's good faith by withdrawing a few U.S. nuclear weapons from Korean soil?
By applying for U.N. membership, Pyongyang has taken a clear step away from self-isolation. That step, however reluctant, warrants a constructive U.S. response.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Idea Gunslingers . . .

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Bush Administration bureaucrats are not enthusiastic about grand plans for big Western bucks to aid Soviet reforms. They say they need more details. There's a surprise.
 The bureaucrats -- diplomats, political appointees or civil servants -- are pessimistic about the Soviet capacity to reform. Aren't we all? 
 They are also doubtful that the U.S. and others can produce the necessary money. Nothing like a good doubt when it comes to cash.
 The last time the national security bureaucracy transcended doubts and pessimism about big ideas was in 1947. Then, in the flash of weeks, State Department bureaucrats fashioned the Truman Doctrine to contain Communism and the Marshall Plan to provide aid to Western Europe.
 Now, almost 45 years later, and with the threat to peace coming from Soviet weakness and not Soviet strength, the bureaucrats mostly wring their hands. Now, when aides say President Bush may well be interested in a new big idea to ward off chaos once again, Administration experts want to wait and see.
 Into this vacuum leaped two intellectual entrepreneurs: Grigory Yavlinsky, a Soviet economist and former Minister of the Russian Republic; and Graham Allison, a Harvard political scientist and former dean of its Kennedy School. They had an idea -- that the West and Moscow share a vital interest in promoting political pluralism and market reforms in the Soviet Union, and that they need a common plan to encourage quick and hard decisions in Moscow.
 The two principal framers of this scheme are actually a pair of idea gunslingers, the type the bureaucracy loves to squash or assign to policy planning staffs.
 Grigory Yavlinsky, acclaimed for his Western-style economic skills, sounds like the next-generation Russian politician, a man with plans he would like to implement himself. He is preparing himself to talk to people, not bureaucrats. Asked last week about Soviet investment policy, he answered: "In order to invest it is necessary to have money, and we have neither money nor pockets."
 Graham Allison is part scholar and part salesman. Not content with just having an idea, he always wants to sell it. He can open Democratic and Republican doors. That makes him a good counterpart for Mr. Yavlinsky, who seems to be representing both Mikhail Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin.
 For a month now the Allison-Yavlinsky duo and their impressive binational brain trust have been germinating a plan. It starts with the premise that a complete fragmentation of the Soviet Union and the reversion of its parts to authoritarianism could have catastrophic consequences: several Soviet republics with nuclear arms, locked in power struggles with each other and their neighbors. Refugees flooding into Eastern Europe, unsettling those fragile countries.
 Many Pentagon and White House officials downplay these alarms. Fortunately, State Department and C.I.A. bureaucrats take the risks most seriously. But the experts and their bosses preoccupy themselves with smaller decisions like whether to provide $1.5 billion in new food export credits or whether to invite Mr. Gorbachev to the West's economic summit talks.
 The Allison-Yavlinsky team sees these issues as sideshows. To them, nothing less than a great vision and a comprehensive joint blueprint can help a dying yet dangerous empire make the transition to democracy and free enterprise. To them, Moscow will not make tough choices without the prospect of help along the way. And they are right.
 They are also hardheaded and practical to advance their vision in stages, with Western aid dependent at each stage on Soviet performance. No performance, no money. (They should also insist on replacing Communist functionaries with reformers.) They have not officially revealed the price tag, but expect between $15 billion and $30 billion yearly, mostly for consumer goods and infrastructure, over five years.
 That is a small coin to implant freedoms, diminish Soviet military spending (one of the conditions) and forestall the potential costs of chaos on the Eurasian continent.
 Bureaucrats in Washington and Moscow will tarry on the sidelines of such great threats and opportunities. At such moments, great leaders will ignore them and embrace the intellectual gunslingers.

HEADLINE: Strong City Council, Strong Smell

 BODY:
Councilman Robert Dryfoos has now stepped aside as chairman of two influential New York City Council committees pending an investigation of his financial affairs. His troubles suggest two urgent tasks for the Council.
One is to devise ethical safeguards to match the Council's enhanced powers over the budget and real estate development. An intriguing first step has been taken by Council Speaker Peter Vallone with his proposal to require financial background checks for members being considered to head committees. 
 The other task is for all members of the Council running in this fall's special election to join the city's new campaign financing system.
The voluntary system, expressly designed to minimize conflicts of interest, offers public matching funds to candidates who accept strict limits on private fund-raising and enhanced public disclosure. More than 200 challengers for the 51 seats on next year's expanded Council have signed up.
Astoundingly, however, only 16 of the Council's 35 incumbents have agreed to participate. Among them is Mr. Vallone. But as the roster on the right shows, others whose leadership duties could attract special-interest money are conspicuously absent.
Council members who don't sign up will escape the law's disclosure and auditing provisions, thereby depriving voters of crucial information about who's bankrolling Council campaigns and buying influence with city government.
Participation in the system does not guarantee integrity. It didn't deter Mr. Dryfoos, for example, from establishing a special fund, ostensibly to cover office expenses, and then using it for personal purposes. But the system is a giant improvement over lax state rules. The next step toward Council credibility is to extend the deadline for joining the program -- and for Mr. Vallone to make clear that participation is a prerequisite for leadership jobs.
