HEADLINE: U.S. AND SOVIETS BRIDGE GAP ON CONVENTIONAL WEAPONS AND PLAN FOR SUMMIT SOON;
Soviets' Real Issue: Aid

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
In clearing away the last obstacles to the treaty reducing nonnuclear forces in Europe, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union has today sent another strong signal that he wants to focus on what for him is a real life or death issue: economic assistance from the West.
The increasingly desperate requirements of the Soviet leader for Western economic help bring with them both opportunities and demands for the Bush Administration. The opportunities are for Washington to squeeze the Soviets for as many concessions on arms control as possible, while at the same time pressing Mr. Gorbachev to undertake economic reforms far more sweeping than he is now prepared to consider. 
 But there are also limits on how far Mr. Bush can push the Soviet leader, because the Administration is committed to his political survival at home, and also, the European allies are likely to press Washington not to shove Mr. Gorbachev over a cliff.
In his meeting with a group of Soviet citizens in the Kazahk Republic on Thursday, Mr. Gorbachev all but confirmed his vulnerable predicament, saying: "Some people state that the results of our foreign policy activity mean a strategic defeat. It is being asked now why the President is engaged in the foreign policy so much? We need favorable conditions now that we have embarked on profound reforms."
Mr. Gorbachev added that arms control agreements that meet Soviet military doctrines are necessary to "reduce the military spending, and make our economy, overburdened with military affairs, turn to human interests."
 
Focus Shifts to Strategic Arms
 What he might have added was that without completing agreement on the conventional arms treaty on essentially American terms, there was a slimmer chance of talking to Mr. Bush at a summit meeting, where the Soviet leader could intensify his appeal for Western economic aid.
But if Mr. Gorbachev becomes more desperate, the cautious Mr. Bush will find himself under more pressure to make stronger demands on Moscow.
For instance, now that the conventional arms treaty is out of the way Mr. Gorbachev seems eager to remove the other obstacle to a summit -- the uncompleted strategic arms reduction treaty, known as Start. So, too, does Mr. Bush. As a result, the Soviet leader might be ready to show a little more flexibility on the last remaining technical issues holding up the treaty.
But in the view of many arms control experts, the real problem in the Start talks is not the Soviets but the Americans. These experts say that because of internal differences, officials in the Administrationcannot agree on what positions to adopt in the endgame of negotiations.
Indeed, many Western diplomats complain that the White House has consistantly evinced a great deal of ambivalence about the Start treaty and that the President, caught between conflicting advice, is now going to have to finally make up his mind about where he stands on the treaty and to fight the necessary beauracratic fights to get it done. Is he ready?
"The Soviets interestingly enough are saying that we need a Start agreement," a senior Administration official said. "They have been complaining that we've lost religion on Start."
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that negotiators would now resume work immediately on a "much more intensive basis than before" to try to settle the remaining Start issues, so this treaty slashing nuclear superpower nuclear arsenals by one-third can also be signed at a summit in June or July.
But Administration officials added that if it appeared that they could not resolve the remaining differences, there still might be a Bush-Gorbachev meeting, but probably a much shorter, lower-key affair.
The same two-way pressures also apply in the economic realm. A Soviet delegation -- led by Yevgeny Primakov, one of Mr. Gorbachev's chief economic advisers, and Grigory A. Yavlinsky, a private economist -- spent the last week in Washington getting the reaction of the President, his aides and the International Monetary Fund to some of Mr. Gorbachev's latest ideas for reforming the Soviet economy.
 
$30 Billion Mentioned
 Although Mr. Primakov did not ask Mr. Bush for money, Reuters reported that he had told officials of the I.M.F. that Moscow would need between $30 billion and $50 billion in foreign finance a year over the next five to six years if its economic reform program is to succeed.
Senior Administration officials literally scoffed at such numbers, for two reasons. First, there is no way the West would ever be able to come up with such levels of assistance, but more important, it is absurd, they say, to even talk about any figures until the Soviets have a clear-cut, workable reform plan in hand. The problem with Mr. Primakov's mission was that it revealed that the Soviet leadership, while it is now talking about moving to a free market, still wants to do it initially through central planning and control.
Mr. Yavlinsky, who has been working with a team of Harvard-based economists on a more sweeping reform program, right now has only a tenuous connection with Mr. Gorbachev. One of the messages that the President sent back to Moscow with Mr. Primakov was that Mr. Yavlinsky's approach is the right one and that the more he and economists like him are brought into the Kremlin, the more credibility Soviet reform proposals will have.
But what if on the next visit Mr. Yavlinsky arrives as Mr. Gorbachev's chief economist? That is when things could get very interesting for Mr. Bush, who will have to decide how far he is ready to go in aiding the Soviets, how far he feels the American taxpayers are ready to go and what the implications will be for the Western alliance if he wants to go slow and key allies, such as Germany and France, want to push faster?
As Jeffrey Sachs, one of the Harvard economists advising Mr. Yavlinsky said, the President has said there will be no help without Soviet reforms first, "but he has not spelled out what help there will be if there are Soviet reforms."
Already the Democrats are joining this issue, with House majority leader, Richard Gephardt, asking last week whether it would not in the long run be a lot cheaper for the American taxpayer to spend a few billion dollars a year to prompt the Soviets to make specific economic and political reforms that will make them a more open, democratic and less dangerous adversary?
Already, in an effort to deflect such pressures and to shape the coming debate, Administration officials are letting their limits be known.
"If you are talking about a grand bargain in which on one day they say we're going to do X things and we hand them a suitcase of money, that's impossible," a senior Administration official said. "If we're talking about something that's almost like an arms control process, in which we're doing confidence building measures, giving Western assistance in return for genuine reforms, that we can sell to our taxpayers, we're not dismissing that."

HEADLINE: Business Diary/May 26-31

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Akers Rattles a Few Cages at Buttoned-Down I.B.M. 

Rarely does the International Business Machines Corporation reveal its inner workings to the world. But last week it did when the contents of a tough speech given to a group of managers by John Akers, I.B.M.'s chairman, leaked out. It was an accident, the company said. Initially, investors did not like what they saw. I.B.M.'s stock dipped to $104.25 from $105.12 while the market rallied to new highs. Later, investors had a change of heart. The speech showed Mr. Akers struggling to do exactly what Wall Street wants: toughen up the company's country-club culture. According to the notes of the speech, Mr. Akers said I.B.M. had "too many people standing around the water cooler." Mr. Akers also said he would tolerate no further loss of market share. By the end of the week, the tough talk sank in. Big Blue's stock closed on Friday at $106.12. The only question now is whether the accidental release happened on purpose.
 
A Fast Train for Texas?
 
Japan's bullet trains cruise at 150 miles per hour and France's TGV -- for Train a Grande Vitess -- was clocked at 320 m.p.h. American coaches lumber along at less than 100 m.p.h. That may change. Last week, the Texas High-Speed Rail Authority voted to award GEC Alshom of Paris -- the builder of the TGV -- and the Morrison Knudsen Corporation of Boise, Idaho, a construction company, a contract to build a 200 m.p.h. rail line between Dallas and Houston by 1998. San Antonio would be added later, creating a 620-mile triangle. There is one catch: The consortium has to raise its own money to build the system, at a hefty estimated cost of $5.7 billion. So far, the companies have just $167 million in capital. Will they be able to raise the rest? "There is a feeling of confidence that the TGV consortium can pull it together," said Steven Polunsky the Texas High Speed Rail Authority.
 
Macy's Inexplicable Strategy
 
R. H. Macy & Company has big plans. The retailing chain figures if it opens 11 new stores over the next five years it can increase sales from $2.2 billion last year to $3.6 billion. That is a gain of 41.6 percent. It also wants to invest in technology and a new advertising campaign. Very aggressive actions in such a sluggish market. The trouble is, Macy's has little cash -- less than at any time since a leveraged buyout took it private in 1986. And it has a storeroom full of debt, $3.4 billion. It is losing money too -- $100.9 million last quarter -- as sales slide and margins thin. This has the analysts scratching their heads about Macy's plans. They are concerned about opening new stores "I am concerned about Macy's acceleration of store openings at a time when it is so important to gain existing-store productivity." said Walter F. Loeb an independent analysts in New York. The big store's creditors are getting nervous.
 
A Disney Bails Out L.A. Gear
 
L.A. Gear Inc., the athletic footwear maker, grew quickly by spotting fads on the playground. But now it's stumbling badly. It lost $12.5 million in the first quarter on sales of $171 million on top of losing $9.1 million in the final quarter last year. L.A. Gear's creditors, jittery from the losses, cut its credit line to $300 million from $360 million. The company needed cash. Last week it got it. Roy E. Disney, said he would buy 30 percent of the sneaker company for $100 million. The deal is the first for Trefoil Capital Investors, a $450 million investment fund formed by Mr. Disney's firm, Shamrock Capital Advisers Inc. of Burbank, Calif., to rescue ailing companies. In exchange for the money, Mr. Disney gets control of the compay's operating plan.
 
Ameritech Spruces Up
 
The Ameritech Corporation, based in Chicago, provides local telephone service in five Midwestern states. Pretty ho-hum, as businesses go, but a good provider of cash. Last week the company decided to dump its dowdy image and said it would buy Cybertel for $512 million from JMB Reality of Chicago and its partners. Cybertel is one of two companies providing cellular telephone service in St. Louis. Analysts think Ameritech cut a good deal. It will pay $195 for each "pop" -- slang for a cellular customer. Prices have been as high as $350. Best of all, Cybertel has only 40,000 customers, plenty of room for growth. That gives Ameritech's image an overhaul.
 
A Challenge to T.W.A.
 
To pare down some of its $2.7 billion in debt, Trans World Airlines Inc., sold its routes to London to American Airlines for $445 million. Last week the sale was put in doubt. The city of St. Louis, T.W.A.'s hub and its unions asked the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeal to reverse the sale. The challenge is moot, T.W.A.'s lawyers said. The deal is already done.
 
T.W.A. negotiated a deal to buy back some of its debt from Connecticut National Bank at 77.5 cents on the dollar. The bank was threatening threatening to reposses 10 airplanes and 62 engines.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Resistance to Favoring China
 
ast week, President Bush told the graduating class at Yale University that he would renew China's trade privileges for another year. But he added a disclaimer. He was trying to "chart a course through a world of lesser evils," he said. Maybe so, but getting Congress to agree that China is a "lesser evil," will not be easy. Three measures have already been introduced to revoke China's most-favored-nation status, which grants its goods low tariffs. China has not changed policies since 1989 when it cracked down on political activity, the bills' authors say. To mollify Congress, Mr. Bush said exports of supercomputers, missiles and nuclear technology would be restricted. Not enough to stop a fight in Congress. "The issue is joined," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York. Mr. Bush may lose the fight.
 
A Reward for Egypt
 
uring the gulf war, Egypt's crippled economy lost billions of dollars. But now it is being rewarded for having joined the fight against Iraq. The United States and other Western creditors agreed last week to forgive $20.2 billion of Egypt's Government debt -- almost half of Egypt's $50 billion in debt. Welcome relief for this struggling nation. But what will follow forgiveness? Most economist say more borrowing.
 
Primakov on a Mission
 
Yevgeny M. Primakov, the wily Soviet envoy who tried (and failed) to get Saddam Hussein to quit the war, saw President Bush last week. He said he thinks Washington will come up with $1.5 billion in credits so the Soviet Union can buy grain. The Administration is not so sure. It wants to see a reform plan for the Soviet economy it can believe in. So far it has not. The last plan called for more (not less) central control. Precisely the wrong direction. The latest plan, Mr. Primakov said, will do the opposite. But it is not quite finished. The Administration wants to see more before it gives the nod.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Good News, With a Caveat
 
There was optimism but it was tinctured with a dash of gloom. Sales of existing homes were up 3.4 percent for April, the third increase in a row according to the National Association of Realtors. The Commerce Department confirmed the good news. Sales of new homes climbed 1.2 percent in April. These figures indicate the housing slump may have reached its final days. But the Mortgage Bankers Association cast some doubt. It said 4.95 percent of the nation's homeowners were at least 30 days late on their mortgage payments in the first quarter, a sign that tough times remain. The delinquencies rate was 4.71 percent in the fourth quarter. Before the recession hit, the rate was 4.41 percent. Rising delinquencies mean future foreclosures -- bad news for the nation's home lenders. "The economy is staging a recovery," said Richard Peach, deputy chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association. "But we don't expect it to be terribly strong."
 
The Factory-Orders Omen
 
Factory orders rose 1.8 percent in April, according to the Commerce Department, the first increase in six months. Spending increased for both durable and nondurable goods. It was a better showing than most analysts had expected and followed declines of 2.9 percent in March and 0.6 percent in February. The new figures, released last week, show that inventories are shrinking and companies are ordering new goods. The Federal Reserve Chairman, Alan Greenspan, last month said an increase in factory orders would indicate that the economy is turning around. But economists caution the lag can be long between a pickup in orders and employment growth.

The G.N.P. Inches Back
 
The gross national product fell by 2.6 percent in the first quarter, the Commerce Department said last week. Everybody already knew that. But they did not know that the G.N.P. was down two-tenths of 1 percent less than the department's original estimate. The recession may be deep, but it's no Grand Canyon. Even better, the Commerce Department reported that corporate profits in the first quarter fell less than in the two preceding quarters. They were down three-tenths of 1 percent following declines of 1.9 percent and 3.9. The recession may have reached its nadir.

Hope From Consumers
 
Consumer spirits remain up, but they are not as buoyant as before. "We got dancing in the streets when the war was over," said Fabien Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center. "That is giving way to a somewhat more sober assessment." Nothing to worry about -- so far. Confidence, which is measured by a survey of current attitudes and future expectations is still in what analysts call the "hopeful range." That means consumers are willing to spend.

 CORRECTION:

Macy's sales in its most recent fiscal year were approximately $7 billion and the company's strategy is to increase those sales by $3.6 billion over the next five years.

HEADLINE: FILM;
Love and Hate in Black and White

BYLINE: By SAMUEL G. FREEDMAN; Samuel G. Freedman, the author of "Small Victories: The Real World of a Teacher, Her Students and Their High School," is writing a book about a black church in Brooklyn.

 BODY:
"Jungle Fever," Spike Lee's new film, opens with a still photograph of Yusuf K. Hawkins, the black teen-ager killed by a white mob in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn two summers ago. But if the screen had remained blank, the memory of that murder would have suffused "Jungle Fever" just as palpably, for it explores the nexus of race, sex and place that in one instance cost a 16-year-old innocent his life and in a broader historical scheme has tormented America for centuries. After touching these issues to both serious and comic effect in his earlier work, Mr. Lee with this latest film has driven to their core.
Hawkins was not shot, after all, because he crossed the line into a white neighborhood; he was shot because he was mistaken for being the companion of a local girl who was considered a pariah for dating blacks and Hispanics. And in the art Mr. Lee has forged from reality, the threatening prospect of interracial intimacy is embodied by Flipper Purify (Wesley Snipes), a married architect, and Angie Tucci (Annabella Sciorra), the temporary secretary who becomes his lover. 
 What begins as a standard-issue office affair, with late nights over Chinese take-out leading to desktop consummation, evolves by its racial nature into an affront to two families and two communities, Flipper's Harlem and Angie's Bensonhurst. When the pair begin living together midway through the film, it is less as willing mates than fellow traitors, and when they uncouple toward the end, Flipper says, "I give up. It's not worth it. I don't love you and I doubt seriously you ever loved me . . . . Love-can-overcome-everything . . . is only in Walt Disney movies, and I've always hated Disney movies."
Those words come as much from Mr. Lee as from the character. Even before "Jungle Fever" had its world premiere last month at the Cannes International Film Festival, he had said its purpose was to inspect and thereby demolish the sexual stereotypes of the black man as stud nonpareil and the white woman as beauty incarnate. But as he acknowledged in a recent interview -- in anticipation of the film's opening this Friday -- his concerns extend beyond the affair to its volatile, even violent consequences.
"I hate this whole Hollywood process of breaking down a movie to one sentence," he said. "My films don't deal with one theme. They interweave many different things. You have to think. I'm not saying interracial relationships are impossible. Flipper and Angie are not meant to represent every interracial couple in the world. They are meant to represent two people who got together because of sexual mythology instead of love. Then they stay together because they're pushed together. They're outcasts. And since their relationship isn't based on love, when things get tough, they can't weather the storm."
The sexual politics of race (or the racial politics of sex) has been a recurrent issue throughout Mr. Lee's career. "School Daze," his 1988 satire on an all-black college similar to his own alma mater, Morehouse, turned the friction centered on color into a pointed burlesque. The college's women divided into two camps, the dark "Jigaboos" and the fair "Wannabees," who taunted each other in one scene with the epithets "pickaninny," "Barbie doll," "tar baby" and "high-yellow heifer." The anti-apartheid activist who was the film's hero selected a dark girlfriend at least partly to establish his black nationalist credentials.
For exposing that color seam to white audiences, and so contravening the ideal of black unity, Mr. Lee received no small criticism from African-Americans. Not that it dissuaded him from raising the matter again and again. In "Do the Right Thing," the white owner of a pizzeria (Danny Aiello) treated a much younger black woman (Joie Lee) with affection that hovered ambiguously between paternalism and lechery. A black pianist's white girlfriend was the object of ridicule by his fellow musicians in "Mo' Better Blues." And Malcolm X, the subject of Mr. Lee's next film, spoke frequently about issues of color and appearance, whether castigating blacks for straightening their hair or wishing aloud he could drain the white blood from his veins, coming as it had from the rape of his maternal grandmother.
"You might call those sketches," Mr. Lee said of the scenes in his earlier films. "I really started thinking about 'Jungle Fever' while we were doing 'Mo' Better Blues.' I thought it was time to go back to the No. 1 problem in America -- racism -- but to try to broaden the canvas from 'Do the Right Thing.' That was about race alone. This is about race, sex, class, drugs -- and that's a more combustible mixture."
It is also about history. Ossie Davis, playing a retired minister who is Flipper's father, gives a speech that recalls the rape of black slaves by white masters and alludes to the case of Emmett Till, a 15-year-old black lynched for whistling at a white woman in Mississippi. "It really has to do with sexual inadequacy," Mr. Lee said, speaking of such violence. "If you look at the cases of black men who got lynched, they usually got castrated, too. There's something about black men being with white women that threatens white men. And that's why Yusuf Hawkins was killed."
It was in the fall of 1989, in the months immediately after the shooting, that Mr. Lee began making notes for "Jungle Fever." In his usual method, he transferred the best ideas from a legal pad to index cards, then arranged the cards into a sequence of scenes. Only then did he begin to write dialogue, guided not only by the skeletal plot but by his desire to tailor parts for Mr. Snipes, Mr. Davis, John Turturro and others.
Shaping issues of class as well as race, Mr. Lee made Flipper the white-collar half of the film's central couple. He lives in a restored brownstone on Striver's Row in Harlem, with The New York Times on the doorstep and a Romare Bearden collage on the wall. His wife works as a buyer at Bloomingdale's and their young daughter dresses for success in a Spelman College sweatshirt.
Angie, by contrast, is a child of the working class, visiting Manhattan only on assignment from a temporary agency. With her mother dead, she is expected by Old World custom to cook dinner for her father and brothers, preferably early enough so they can turn on the Mets game and heckle Darryl Strawberry. Angie's longtime boyfriend, Paulie Carbone (Mr. Turturro), shares her longing for a future outside the neighborhood, yet settles for running the family luncheonette.
The film unfolds largely through parallel scenes -- Flipper and Angie each confiding their affair to a close friend; the couple going on dates to the Harlem restaurant Sylvia's, where they have trouble being served because of her presence, and to the San Gennaro festival in Little Italy; Flipper being kicked out by his wife and Angie beaten by her father after friends betray their secret. And if there is one set piece that rises above the rest, however powerful and well observed audiences may find them, it is the conversation among Flipper's wife, Drew (Lonette McKee), and her friends after his eviction.
The screenplay sets the scene this way: "What we have here is a WAKE. A MOURNING for another SISTER who has been WRONGED. Drew. . .and her girlfriends sit in the living room, laughing, crying and discussing the state of THE BLACK MAN." Mr. Lee's camera then gives public exposition to private candor.
"Most of them are homos, drug addicts or in jail," a woman named Nilda says of single black men. "And the good ones know" they are, "so they see 10 women at a time, leaving babies all over the place." To which Drew rejoins: "Even though my marriage is wrecked, I still believe there are good black men out there. The problem is a lot of these good men just might be working class. A bus driver, garbage man or whatnot. There is nothing wrong with them."
A few moments later, the topic turns to white women. "It's ridiculous the way they act around the brothers," Drew says. "These white bitches think he's the best thing since sliced bread. This sacred thing that their daddies tried to keep them from all their life and when they get a chance, they gonna get some."
Mr. Lee devoted nearly three days to rehearsing the scene and an entire day to filming it, using two cameras at all times. Sam Pollard, the film's editor, culled two hours of usable dialogue, much of it ad-libbed at Mr. Lee's urging. "I can't write dialogue." he said, "as good as they're gonna say it."
For the actresses, the performance ventured deeply into their personal lives. Ms. McKee, the daughter of a black father and a white mother, was embraced only by her black relatives and yet has been spared certain racial indignities by virtue of her fair skin.
"There was a lot of truth in that scene," she said. "For nearly 500 years, we've been enslaved and told that white women are superior, that everything white is superior to anything black. How would a black woman compete with a white girl? We've been brainwashed for so long."
So intense and rending was the scene that it created several off-screen friendships between the actresses. And when Ms. McKee saw the finished film for the first time several weeks ago, she said the emotions felt as fresh as ever.
"I carry heavy baggage," she said, "and when I saw the scene I wept. It was just heart-wrenching for me. Because there's so much reality in that film. And I live it every day."
The mirror images of the black women in Drew's living room are the white men in Paulie's luncheonette. For them, too, color is a concept freighted with pain and irony. The customer quickest to bellow his bigotry listens to the rap group Public Enemy. The regular who reviles Angie for seeing Flipper curses the women who will not date him because, as a swarthy Sicilian, he is too dark. Paulie interrupts a customer's anti-black diatribe to recall the lynching of five Italian immigrants in Louisiana earlier in the century.
"There has to be a reason there's so much conflict with blacks and Italians," Mr. Lee mused. "Maybe it's because we're not that far apart. Sicily's not that far from Africa. Somewhere down the line, Hannibal or somebody. . . ." He let the sentence trail off, then continued: "New York has a lot of ethnic groups. Now we know there's conflict with blacks and Jews, with blacks and Koreans. But the violence is always between blacks and Italians."
Despite that atmosphere of lethal antagonism, Mr. Lee has shown the ability to write Italian characters as complex and varied as his black creations. And that artistic even-handedness has brought an integral tension and poignance to films like "Jungle Fever," based on confrontation.
Sal, the pizzeria owner, dominated "Do the Right Thing" with his mixture of pride, temper, tenderness and hate. In the aftermath of the Hawkins murder, Bensonhurst was often depicted as a monochromatic realm of racists. Mr. Lee in "Jungle Fever," however, has peopled the neighborhood with a far more complete range of humanity, from the gentle and yearning Paulie to the thuggish Vinny, whom the director modeled on Joseph Fama, the man convicted of murder in the Hawkins case.
Mr. Lee's familiarity and facility with such characters derives at least partly from his childhood. His family lived in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn when the neighborhood was largely Italian, and his closest friend on the block was Louie Tucci, his teammate for stickball in the schoolyard of P.S. 29. Louie's surname, of course, belongs to Angie in "Jungle Fever," and elements of his personality appear in Paulie. At the same time, Mr. Lee learned in Cobble Hill the limits of acceptance when he tried to join an all-white Cub Scout troop that operated from a nearby church. He was refused membership because, he was informed, he was not Roman Catholic.
Still, Mr. Lee said, he does not view the Italian and black communities in "Jungle Fever" as equally culpable, morally equivalent. Flipper's father may insult his child for crossing the racial line, but he will not exile or attack him. Even Drew Purify, it develops, is the child of a mixed marriage, who was accepted and raised in the black hemisphere of her bifurcated world.
"It's very rare," Mr. Lee said, "for a black family to disown a member for marrying someone white. This is not to say we view these couplings with open arms. But when you're oppressed, when you're at the bottom of a socio-economic system, you have a different perspective."
 
DRUGS IN HIS 'JUNGLE'
 While "Jungle Fever" is largely the story of an interracial affair and its aftershocks, the film also includes Spike Lee's first reckoning on film with the drug epidemic. Some critics took him to task for not portraying drug abuse in "Do the Right Thing," but Mr. Lee maintained that the inclusion of such material in "Jungle Fever" is not at all reactive.
"This was the film to deal with drugs in," Mr. Lee said. "In 'Do the Right Thing' it would've been a bogus subplot. And in 'Mo' Better Blues' it would've been a movie we've seen before -- the genius musician ruined by drugs. This time it could be organic to the story."
Drug abuse is personified in "Jungle Fever" by Gator Purify (Samuel L. Jackson), a crack addict who is the son of the Good Reverend Doctor (Ossie Davis) and his wife, Lucinda (Ruby Dee, in photograph with Mr. Jackson), and the older brother of Flipper, the successful architect portrayed by Wesley Snipes. At one point, after Gator has stolen the family television set, Flipper tracks him to a vast crack den called the Taj Mahal. So central did the issue of drugs become to "Jungle Fever" that Mr. Lee chose to end the film with Flipper's wordless cry of anguish when, as he walks his daughter to school, an addict offers to perform oral sex for $2.
"Which is more important," the director asked, "whether a black man should love a white woman, or what drugs are doing to the black community?"

HEADLINE: SOUND;
American Speakers -- Loud and Clear

BYLINE: By HANS FANTEL

 BODY:
While many American products have trouble competing overseas, American loudspeakers get an eager welcome. This week, at the Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago, a large number of buyers from abroad are expected to bolster an otherwise sluggish business.
"Our company has always maintained a global outlook," says Sidney Harman of Harman International, which makes speakers under well-known brand names like Infinity and JBL. "But lately, the export side of our business exceeds domestic sales." 
 Mr. Harman has a special reason to be pleased at this reversal of a trend. As Undersecretary of Commerce in the Carter Administration, he witnessed the drastic decline of America's share in the world market for home electronics. According to the economist Robert Kuttner, that share fell from 70 percent to 5 percent over the last few decades.
American loudspeakers, however, survived and are now flourishing once more. This renaissance is not confined to prominent brands. Inventiveness by newcomers is also being recognized in the world market. For example, Linaeum of Portland, Ore., a new company, is attracting attention with speakers based on a radically offbeat invention by a musician-engineer, Paul Paddock. In 1989, its first year, more than half of Linaeum's output went abroad.
Of course, the United States has no monopoly in the field. Britain, in particular, is known for producing excellent loudspeakers, and several German companies -- notably MB Quart -- have earned praise from audiophiles. But American speaker manufacturers hold the lead.
Much of this has to do with a technical assurance rooted in a long tradition. The modern high-quality loudspeaker is largely an American development dating to the 1950's, when engineers like Henry Kloss, Roy Allison and Paul Klipsch -- all still active -- created some of the first full-range speakers for the home. Before that, people relied on scaled-down versions of movie theater speakers.
Neither in bulk nor in timbre were those speakers suitably domesticated. They loomed in the living room like outsize armoires. Moreover, their trumpetlike tweeters -- originally meant to project movie dialogue to the far corners of a theater -- tended to be sonically overwhelming rather than musically pleasing.
It was Roy Allison's invention of the dome-shaped tweeter and Henry Kloss's design of the acoustic suspension enclosure that finally made it possible to package high-fidelity sound in relatively small boxes, thereby setting new quality standards for home audio. During the 60's, American companies like Acoustic Research, Advent and Allison Acoustics refined these principles, making American loudspeakers household items almost everywhere.
It is paradoxical that even in Japan -- the leading producer of audio equipment -- American speakers outsell Japanese products. For despite intense efforts, Japanese engineers have not been able to come up with loudspeakers that deal convincingly with symphonic music.
Given the unmatched competence of Japanese engineering in so many other aspects of audio, the consistent deficiency of their speakers in regard to orchestral sound has caused much puzzlement. It has been suggested that Japanese engineers, accustomed to the high-pitched plucking and piping of Oriental music, may lack esthetic sympathy and the proper feel for the more massive orchestral textures underlying the Western symphonic tradition. Such ethnically based theories may perk the interest of anthropologists; they certainly lie beyond the realm of engineering.
The high regard in which American speakers are held does not mean they all sound alike. Each model has its distinctive tonal character. Yet there are common attributes. As a group, they tend toward deeper and fuller sonorities than speakers made elsewhere. There is a sense of tonal coherence and blending rather than the analytic unraveling of distinct sonic strands. Especially pronounced in brands like Boston Acoustics, a/d/s/ and B.I.C., these qualities are highly flattering to the massed strings that form the basis of orchestral sound. Of course, this characteristic is shared only by speakers designed mainly to reproduce classical music, not to put a hard edge on the sounds of rock.
In at least one notable case, American dominance in this field has reversed the pattern of foreign companies' acquiring American manufacturing plants. Jensen International, a Chicago company that makes speakers under the names of Advent, Acoustic Research and NHT, is reaching across the Atlantic. "European sales are a growing part of our business," says Robert Shaw, the company's chief executive officer, "so we decided to move production closer to the market. Already we have plants in Italy and France and are now about to open up a new factory in what used to be East Germany."
Loudspeakers are only a drop in the total economic bucket. But moves like this, Mr. Shaw believes, are "the beginning of a rebirth" -- at least for certain specialized branches of American industry.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 4, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The Sound column in the Arts and Leisure section on June 2 misattributed the invention of the acoustic suspension speaker and the dome tweeter. A reader's letter, sent two weeks after the column appeared, pointed out that both were invented by Edgar Villchur. (This correction was improperly delayed through an oversight.)

HEADLINE: Using Lessons of Xerox to Run Education Dept.

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 30

 BODY:
David T. Kearns, lately chairman of Xerox, now Deputy Secretary of Education, is shuttling these days between his Government-issue office and the no-frills Holiday Inn across the street. Gone are his corporate jet, $1.3 million salary and undisputed authority as head of one of the country's largest corporations.
But Mr. Kearns's biggest challenge will not be learning to live with diminished perquisites and power and a tenth of his former salary. He faces the formidable task of proving that a businessman using business practices can marshal a Government bureaucracy to help American schools. 
 In his years at Xerox, which he joined in 1971 and headed for nearly a decade, Mr. Kearns (it rhymes with learns) did what many thought was impossible: He rescued a company reeling from Japanese competition. He led a sweeping reorganization that not only changed manufacturing and design processes but also transformed Xerox's bureaucracy and labor-management relations.
Many of the techniques he used at Xerox, he said, can be transferred to government and education. "The idea of putting decisions down at the level where people do the work," he said, offering one example. "Look at where the money is spent: in the school or the bureaucracy? Look at the huge bureaucracy we built in business that ended up not having a lot to do."
Mr. Kearns is not simply pontificating about how to run schools more efficiently. For the past several years, he has toured the country giving speeches and meeting with educators to convey the same message he outlined in a 1988 book published by a research organization: that the United States must catch up with the educational performance of competitors like Japan.
 
'Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig'
 Company rules required him to relinquish the title of chief executive officer at the age of 60 last August, although he stayed on as chairman. So he was willing to listen to Lamar Alexander, who became Education Secretary in March, who coaxed him to take the No. 2 position at the Education Department.
The resulting team, educators say, is the strongest ever at the 12-year-old department, and has helped make it a popular place to be in Washington. "It's like having Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig on the same team," said Denis P. Doyle, a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute who was co-author with Mr. Kearns of the book, "Winning the Brain Race: A Bold Plan to Make Our Schools Competitive."
President Bush has put the business ideals of competition and markets at the core of his strategy to improve American education. Mr. Kearns said his task is to promote the President's new education strategy while running the day-to-day operations of the Education Department and building relations with the business community.
But even those who wish him well warn that Mr. Kearns is stepping into a very different world.
"In a place like Xerox, the boss is the boss unless something goes really wrong," said Marc Tucker, president of the Center on Education and the Economy, a Rochester research institution on school improvement. "In Washington, if you wait long enough, there will be another boss, with another set of priorities."
Mr. Kearns's friends are cheering for him, but are also protective. "I think he's entering a jungle," said J. Richard Munro, the chairman of the executive committee of Time Warner Inc. and a longtime neighbor of Mr. Kearns's in New Canaan, Conn. "He has no affectation, no presumptuousness, no nonsense and no politics. Those kind of guys -- I'm not sure they make it in D.C."
 
Needed: Coaxing, Not Ordering
 Some of these very qualities, however, may help him allay the suspicions of bureaucrats who are secure in their jobs and may need more coaxing than ordering to follow his lead.
"He's easy to underestimate partly because he is so accessible," said Mr. Tucker, who has enlisted Xerox employees to help reorganize the Rochester school bureaucracy. "But he clearly has the capacity to lead, to somehow help others in the organization to share his values and his aspirations."
Mr. Doyle said Mr. Kearns's unpretentiousness helped endear him to employees at Xerox. "He drives a Jeep, carries his own bags and buys suits off the rack from Jos. A. Banks," he said.
Nevertheless, anyone who makes it to the top of a major corporation is probably not a pushover. Friends describe Mr. Kearns as tightly wound, a man whose refreshing lack of imperiousness does not hide his determination, competitiveness and drive.
Mr. Kearns pleads guilty. "People tease me about not being patient," he said. "I am impatient. You've got to walk a fine line. A certain amount of impatience is good because it stirs you to do things."
At Xerox, Mr. Kearns preached and practiced a more participatory management style, in which workers had a voice in forming policy.
By contrast, few of the 4,800 Government employees Mr. Kearns will manage had any voice in shaping the new education strategy, which was the work of a small cadre of outside advisers and top aides to Mr. Alexander.
 
Can Toe the President's Line
 Mr. Kearns said that everyone had been too polite to hint of any disagreement, but that he was certain he would encounter it and was optimistic he could win people over. He also said he accepted that he was not the boss and could toe the President's line.
In his book, Mr. Kearns called on the Federal Government to finance fully the Head Start preschool and Chapter One remedial education programs for poor children. He advocated sharp increases in Federal money for research on education. He wanted to restrict educational choice -- the idea that money can follow students to whatever school they choose -- to public schools, while Mr. Bush wants to extend it to private schools.
Mr. Kearns said he and Mr. Doyle had been revising the book to reflect their new view that choice should be extended to private schools, a conclusion he reached before his appointment, he said, because he was frustrated that public schools had not changed fast enough.
The immensity of the task before him is keeping him at the office late and prompting calls from his wife.
"The other day I called her at 10 P.M. and she said, 'You're not 30 anymore,' " he said, smiling. "It's invigorating, frankly."

GRAPHIC: Photo: David T. Kearns, former chairman of Xerox and now Deputy Secretary of Education, faces the task of proving that a businessman using business practices can marshal a Government bureaucracy to help schools. (Lisa Berg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Bush Resumes Hyperspeed; Is He Up to It?

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
GEORGE BUSH, the Eveready President, just keeps going and going and going.
Despite a thyroid condition that left him thinner, wan and tired, Mr. Bush has recently seemed for all the world like the mechanical bunny with the bass drum on the battery commercials. 
 Boom. Boom. Boom.
He pops up on the golf course at Kennebunkport, Me., playing 63 holes of golf over the Memorial Day weekend -- laughing with delight as he scatters startled aides and reporters with his speeding golf cart, giving a rambling news conference on the 18th hole.
Boom. Boom. Boom.
The President is on the telephone, dialing up Mikhail Gorbachev, Brian Mulroney of Canada, John Major of Britain, Yitzhak Shamir of Israel and the Emir of Kuwait.
Boom. . . well, you get the idea.
The Commander-in-Chief jets off to Colorado for the afternoon, speaks at the Air Force Academy commencement, shakes hands with all 980 graduates, hugs and kisses the women in their ranks, announces a much-delayed arms control initiative for the Middle East.
All of this activity was just part of a week that saw Mr. Bush travel thousands of miles aboard his Air Force Boeing 747 to deliver three other commencement speeches -- at Yale, West Point and the F.B.I. Academy -- and make pronouncements on civil rights and trade with China.
Though somewhat diminished by his illness and the drugs he is taking to combat it, Mr. Bush has, if anything, stepped up the pace of his Presidency-on-the-run, full of high-level diplomacy, high-speed travel and high-stakes conflicts with Capitol Hill.
Is all of this merely sound and activity, or is there substance behind it? And, in his condition, is George Bush really up to it?
Clearly Mr. Bush is involved as deeply as ever in the business of governing, the trait that more than any other sets him apart from Ronald Reagan. Some of his speeches last week, and in the weeks since his heart flutter and thyroid problem were first diagnosed, contained major initiatives. A case in point was his decision, announced at Yale University on Memorial Day, to extend China's "most favored nation" trading privileges for another year despite his misgivings about Beijing's human rights record.
Many of these events were scheduled well before Mr. Bush's illness was diagnosed. But Mr. Bush and his aides are anxious to demonstrate that this President is not going to let a little thyroid problem get him down.
So the speeches are still being delivered. And Mr. Bush still misspeaks, as he did on Wednesday, closing his speech at the Air Force Academy with, "Congratulations. And Godspleed."
But now, such a blooper at the podium, a confused answer to a reporter's question or another energetic Presidential golf match makes people begin wondering if Mr. Bush is exhibiting the ups-and-downs that can accompany his thyroid problem, caused by a condition known as Graves' Disease.
By Mr. Bush's own admission, and that of his doctor, Burton Lee, the drugs he has been taking slowed down his mental functions at first, at least temporarily, and may have been to blame for his worn appearance and confused answers at a recent news conference in the Rose Garden.
The President has visibly bounced back since then, gaining back about 5 of the 13 pounds he lost, and he has angrily rejected any suggestion that the thyroid condition can be blamed -- or credited, depending on your point of view -- for decisions made during the gulf war or since then.
Mr. Bush's ailments have been examined minutely by both the press and his own physicians. Last week, even the Bushes' dog, Millie, was under scrutiny to determine whether her case of canine lupus could have been caused by some environmental factor, like iodine in the First Pup's drinking bowl, that may in turn have contributed to the President's illness and that of his wife, Barbara, who last year was also treated for Graves' Disease.
Presidential aides say they have not added events simply to prove that Mr. Bush is fit. But in the White House these days, there is more than ever a sense of an Administration racing against the clock. The President and his aides are hurrying to decide what to about Moscow's requests for financial aid before the Soviet economy collapses further. Administration officials are fighting to stop Congress from passing a civil rights bill that Mr. Bush will feel compelled to veto, for the second year in a row.
They are scrambling to prevent lawmakers from attaching conditions to the President's extension of China's trading privileges for another year. And they are speeding to push their objectives in the Middle East before what Mr. Bush likes to call "a window of opportunity" slams shut.
And even while the United States is trying to paint itself an exit from northern Iraq and solve Arab-Israeli disputes in the sloppy peace that ended the gulf war, Mr. Bush raised the ante on Wednesday by proposing an arms control initiative for the Middle East during his speech at the Air Force Academy.
Under this plan, the countries of the Middle East would abandon their decades-old arms race and agree to ban ballistic missiles, stop the production and acquisition of material for making nuclear bombs and eliminate chemical and biological weapons. The five major arms producers -- the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China -- would agree not to sell "especially destabilizing" weapons to the Middle East.
How strongly Mr. Bush plans to pursue this plan was immediately called into doubt by his own treatment of it -- two short paragraphs that were slipped into the speech at the last minute.
White House aides made a point of saying that the United States would continue to supply what they consider their allies' legitimate defense needs. The proposal was characterized as a call for "an exercise in collective restraint."
In this area, at least, the White House may be racing against a political deadline -- the 1992 election. With Democrats in Congress already questioning Mr. Bush's post-war record in the Middle East, some Administration officials said the plan was in some measure a defensive action.
The President, meanwhile, is racing into summer, not as a leisure break, but as an extention of his peripatetic spring. Already on his schedule are more commencement speeches, a trip to California, a meeting in London with six other heads of state, a visit to Greece and Turkey and the increasing likelihood of a summit meeting in Moscow. That is not to mention three weeks in August in Maine, where, of course, he'll relax, intensely, no doubt.

HEADLINE: Global Executive Becomes Global Writer

BYLINE: By CAROL STRICKLAND

 BODY:
IN business, Chapter 11 means bankruptcy. In a new novel about the world of business, by chapter 11 an assassin wielding kung-fu knives has assaulted the company controller and demolished his North Shore house, and an audit of the company's deficits has occasioned five murders.
"A Whisper of Treason" is no ordinary business novel, just as its author, Sandy London, is no ordinary executive. 
 Ms. London is seeing the book, her first novel, released this month as a Fawcett paperback, and she is director of international operations at Cybex in Ronkokoma, a manufacturer of physical therapy, sports medicine and fitness equipment. Cybex is a division of Lumex Inc. of Bay Shore, which has $90 million a year in sales.
Ms. London, who has lived in Northport for 12 years, drew on her professional background as well as her imagination for the book. She heads a staff of 15 that sells equipment in more than 40 countries.
"Because of what I do for business," she said, "I have an opportunity to go places and meet people. "They say to write about what you know."
 
Scribbling on Trips

When Ms. London traveled on business to Italy, Austria or Switzerland -- all locales in the novel, along with many scenes on Long Island and New York City -- she scribbled notes.
She used "elements of different people, different conversations and different situations I've been in," she said. But "I didn't take any incident specifically and graft it onto the book."
One character, the Viper, can kill by merely shaking hands with a victim. "I don't handle violence real well," Ms. London said of real life.
Her international experience helped in another way. "Plane trips are great for doing the creative side of drafting a novel," Ms. London said. On 14-hour flights to Tokyo, while other executives plotted corporate maneuvers, Ms. London plotted different intrigues, her suspense thriller. She also wrote at night and on weekends, completing the novel in 1986.
Her agent sold the manuscript in 1989. "I was ecstatic," Ms. London said. "You couldn't peel me off the ceiling. Then came the contract, then working with an editor, then seeing it in the bookstores. It's been one high after another."
Although major publishing is new to Ms. London, "I've written ever since I was a child," she said. When I was in grammar school, I wrote novels for the amusement of my friends. I had my first short story accepted for publication when I was 10."
While growing up in rural California, she wrote westerns. "I was very much a tomboy," she said. By her mid-teens, under the influence of James Bond movies, she switched to "spy novel stuff." She conceded that she had difficulty describing exotic locales when she was just a Fresno County schoolgirl.
When she graduated from Willamette University in Salem, Ore., in 1972, "people didn't consider writing a viable economic alternative," Ms. London recalled. She started in a 9-to-5 job and became an international specialist "by accident," because of her fluency in Spanish.
"Whomever I worked with, I ended up in the international side of their business," Ms. London said. "I finally decided I didn't want to be told what to do. I wanted to make the decisions. In order to do that, I had to get a master's degree. So I did.
 "I wasn't a real writer. I was a dabbler."
Her husband urged her to market her work, and she demurred until he pointed out: " 'You have a master's degree in business, for crying out loud. You can sell what you write, just like you sell anything else.' "
"I really started taking my writing seriously when I moved to Long Island," Ms. London said. After taking an adult-education course at Northport High School, she helped found a writers' workshop. She has completed two additional novels and is working on another.
All the books deal with international intrigue. "I really like the mental challenge," she said. "It's like putting together a gigantic jigsaw puzzle when you don't have the top of the box."
Her most satisfying moments are when the characters come alive. "When your pen takes off and the character runs with it and you didn't intend the scene to happen that way," she said, "that's when you know you've really created a strong character that has some substance."
 One difference between "A Whisper of Treason" and many other suspense thrillers is that a strong female protagonist shares the spotlight with a male hero. "That element is missing in most novels of this genre," Ms. London said. "Some authors' women characters are very cardboard. They don't come through as human beings. I wanted to create a work with a suspenseful plot built around characters that mattered to the reader."
After the easing of the cold war, Ms. London incorporated an Iraqi as villain in her novel "long before Saddam moved on Kuwait."
"I just guessed right," she added.
Ms. London, who is 40 years old, said: "I have a splintered personality. Like most modern women, I'm doing more than one thing. I'm a wife, I'm a mother. I work full time at a very demanding job, and I write.
"I'm pulled in about eight different directions. Every once in a while, I feel like I'm pushed against a wall, and something has to give. I obviously can't give up my husband, my child, the mortgage or my job. That leaves either my sanity or the writing, and, if I give up the writing, I will lose my sanity."
After celebrating Mother's Day with her family, Ms. London flew to Italy on business.
"There are a lot of women who have multiple roles, and somehow manage to fulfill all of them," Ms. London said. "I don't regret a minute of it."

(Michael Shavel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Growing Produce and Community Pride

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
LAND preservation is Louis McCagg's chief concern. Two years ago he founded the nonprofit Westchester Land Trust, based in Bedford, which has worked successfully to protect large open tracts from development. But another thing the group has done is help communities transform small empty sites into community gardens.
"The concept of the community garden fits right in with our goal of preserving open land in the county," said Mr. McCagg, suggesting that empty lots in dense urban areas represented even more valuable land. 
 "We figure a quarter-acre of open land in Yonkers is as valuable as 10 acres in Bedford," he said. "Our first venture was setting up two gardens in Yonkers last year with the help of the Yonkers Department of Parks and Recreation and the Yonkers Rotary Club. It was so successful that we were inspired to help establish as many as 10 community gardens by this spring's planting season. And we're right on target."
Three more gardens have been added to Yonkers, and similar gardens are being dug in Mount Kisco, Greenburgh, New Rochelle, Ossining and Peekskill.
Ralph Crosby, a landscape architect in Yonkers who works as a volunteer with the program, coordinating the garden program, said the Land Trust acts as a catalyst.
"We start working with municipal parks departments and local neighborhood groups and businesses to find an appropriate site, and then we supply them with technical assistance, which includes preparing the soil, fertilizer and fencing," he said. "We also help them get sponsorship from businesses, civic groups, government agencies or foundations who will underwrite the project."
Mr. McCagg, who describes himself as "a product of the 60's," said civil rights work led him to a career in the inner cities. "It was there I saw what happened when an abandoned lot was turned into a garden," Mr. McCagg said. "It became an oasis. People cherished the garden. It gave them a feeling of neighborhood. Even vandalism to the area declined."
The Land Trust is financed through private donations and a few government grants, and is staffed mostly by volunteers. "We're a lean organization," Mr. McCagg said. "We have only three people on the payroll."
Mr. Crosby said he spends several hours a week at his volunteer work. "In my practice, I've seen some terrible abuses of land," he said. "A community garden is a win-win project. Not only will it do the obvious -- beautify the neighborhood and bring people together -- but it gives the people who work it the deep pleasure and satisfaction that comes from growing some of your own food."
An average 400-square-foot community garden plot can yield the equivalent of $500 worth of fresh produce over a growing season, said Paul Winkeller, a consultant with the Land Trust.
 
Transfer of Duties>
 Once the garden is established, Mr. Crosby said, daily management is turned over to a community group like a tenants association or a club for the elderly.
Gerard J. Byrne, the Commissioner of Parks and Recreation for Greenburgh, said 15 garden plots were laid out in April adjacent to three Montrose Housing Authority high-rise apartment buildings and were flourishing.
Mark Brown, who heads the Tenants Association at the apartment complex, said, "We could have had twice the number of gardens, the demand is so great." Mr. Brown, who is retired, said the gardeners come from all walks of life and engage in "a friendly competition," but also help each other.
"Retired fellows like myself water the whole thing when we water our own plots," he said. "There has been very little vandalism. What I can't use I'll give away, but there is one stipulation: The people I give the vegetables to have to pick them."
 
'A Terrific Experience'
 "The tenants are really excited about the Farm, which is the name of the garden project," Mr. Byrne said. "We have two of them in Greenburgh now. The other we call the Garden, and that's located near Woodlands High School." Mr. Byrne's assistant, Karen Watts-Cabe, is the coordinator in charge of both projects.
"The Land Trust worked with us and gave us the technical assistance we needed to get started," Ms. Watts-Cabe said. "Now we're on our own and it is really a terrific experience."
Each garden is fenced and is 15 by 20 feet, but "all of them are different," Ms. Watts-Cabe said. "Some gardeners plant circular beds; others use straight rows. And a variety of vegetables -- from beets to zucchini to garlic -- are being grown."
Another Montrose gardener is Evangeline Kelly, a child-care worker who was raised in North Carolina. "I work at night," she said, "but every morning when I come home, I can't help myself -- I stop and work in my garden. Then I go out in the evening as well. My husband is a great cook and when we harvest our fresh vegetables I can some and we freeze some for the winter."
All the gardeners exchange ideas, she said. "The more seasoned gardeners help the ones who are just beginning. For example, on the farm in North Carolina, we always hoed a row and piled the soil on top of the row and that's how we planted beans. And that way if a hard rain comes along, your beans don't get washed away. I showed that technique to a couple of gardeners who are using it now in their plots."
 
Two Lots Donated
 In Ossining, Patricia Knapp, head of the Ossining Chamber of Commerce, said two empty parcels of land in the heart of the village off Main Street were being transformed into community gardens.
"We got started when Mr. McCagg wrote to me about the feasibility of starting community gardens in Ossining," Ms. Knapp recalled. "I met with him, and the project sounded so appealing that I presented the idea to the village. And they thought it was so good that they offered to donate the empty lots."
Individual Chamber of Commerce members are financing the project. "Everyone, including the gardens' immediate neighbors, is enthusiastic," Ms. Knapp said. "We figure we'll probably have room for two dozen individual gardens, which, being in the center of town, will have high visibility."
 
Growing Pride, Too
 In Yonkers, the Commissioner of Parks and Recreation, Sal DeSantis, said community gardens in densely populated areas had proved their value. "We've seen numerous benefits, both social and economic, coming out of our community garden projects," he said. "Among them is the development of community pride. And people becoming more self-sufficient. We've had community gardens in Yonkers for a number of years, but now we have the Land Trust as a silent partner. They are a good resource for technical assistance and provide us with supplies and materials that we couldn't afford otherwise."
Those interested in starting neighborhood community gardens or working as volunteers with the Land Trust can reach Mr. McCagg at 241-6346.
