HEADLINE: FASTBALLS FROM THE EDGE

BYLINE: By Bruce Buschel; Bruce Buschel, a New York journalist, writes frequently about sports.

 BODY:
WHEN ROGER CLEMENS TOES the mound, you can't take your eyes off him. Standing erect, he exhales deeply as his empty right hand falls politely to his side. Like a chubby-cheeked choirboy lifting an open hymnal, he raises the black Wilson mitt on his left hand to a resting place in front of his solemn game face. After a gentle rock backward, he reaches into his glove, as if to remove a bookmark, grasps the ball and, with a grimace and a grunt, commences the same windup that he had rehearsed before a full-length mirror after every Little League game.
Clemens is a 6-foot-4-inch time machine, a throwback to an era when uniforms were baggy and throwing hard was everything, when the guy hurtling thunderbolts down from the mound was Cy Young or Walter Johnson or Bob Feller. His high hard ones rip across the ages, punching holes in fancy hitting theories and computerized strategies. In 1986, he struck out 20 batters in a single game, a major-league record. Grab a bat and feel the heat. Crowd the plate and he'll brush you back easy as spit. If the opposing pitcher plunks one of his mates, Clemens'll nail the next batter he faces. He even has a good old-fashioned monicker: the Rocket. 
 In the first inning on this crisp New England afternoon, three Indians come up, three Indians sit down. No ball leaves the infield. It will be a long and frustrating day for the batters from Cleveland, a club with two rookie starters who have never faced a pitcher of this caliber.
The 28-year-old Clemens is off to a dazzling start this season, already racking up six victories and 30 consecutive scoreless innings, striking out five times as many hitters as he walks. At this rate, by season's end he will have compiled 25 victories, struck out 200-plus batters for the sixth time, posted an earned run average in the neighborhood of 2.00.
Springtime, when pitchers are perennially ahead of hitters, always produces a few fast starters, but when the weather heats up, bats do likewise. Timing improves, pitchers' patterns are revealed. None of this applies to Clemens. He does not have slumps; barring injuries, he has only good stretches and dominating stretches. Last season, from early August until early September, he went 8-0 with an 0.80 e.r.a.: in 67 innings, he gave up six runs and six walks, registering 65 strikeouts.
Six Indians up, six Indians down. Already, Fenway Park is abuzz with talk of a no-hitter. It would be Clemens's first. In Section 21, the seats behind home plate, a kid, all of 10, in a tattered Red Sox cap with a red B, turns to his father and says, with all the wisdom of youth: "It's no fair, Dad, he throws too hard. They can't hit him."
 IT'S THAT SIMPLE AND THAT COMPLICATED. When Clemens throws his 97-m.p.h. fastball, a batter has 38/100 of a second to find it and hit it. Batters have nowhere to practice such an act. Most major-league fastballs are in the range of 85 m.p.h.
As if the super-octane gas weren't potent enough, Clemens pumps four different high grades. He will move a right-handed hitter away from the plate with a couple of fastballs that rush toward him, then deliver one that tails away, low and unreachable. When he holds the ball with his index and middle fingers across the seams, an underspin is produced that causes the ball to rise. (Physicists argue that this is a gravitational impossibility. Batters know only that it's a tough pitch to hit.) When Clemens grips the ball along the red stitching, the ball becomes "heavy" and sinks as it approaches the plate. After he makes the hitter "climb the ladder," sending successive pitches higher in the strike zone, the "seamer" comes as a complete surprise.
The rare hitter who manages to time the hard stuff may see the "89 slider," a pitch that veers away from a righty at a slightly slower pace. Or the old reliable curve, humpbacked and unexpected. And finally, Clemens has perfected a new pitch this season, the forkball, a nasty number that drops out of the strike zone entirely, but not before looking suspiciously like a fastball.
Baseball has a few pitchers who can match Clemens's speed, but none with his accuracy. Indeed, only a handful of pitchers in the history of the game have been able to throw the variety of pitches Clemens possesses with his pinpoint control.
"You can't watch for the fastball any more," reports Joe Carter, the Toronto Blue Jay slugger who has returned to the American League after a season in the National League. "I had to update my file on Roger -- everything he throws now can be a strike."
Control has always been Clemens's forte. In high school, where wildness is the norm, he walked only 24 batters while striking out 112 in 108 innings. In his two years at the University of Texas, there were 56 bases on balls and 241 whiffs in 275 innings. With conditioning and confidence, the power has increased over the years but the control has remained the same: last season, in 228 innings, he fanned 209 and walked 54.
"I could always throw strikes in the dark," says Clemens with his Texas twang. "It's a God-given thing."
Clemens has hit a silver dollar from 60 feet, 6 inches. During a game, 9 out of 10 pitches go exactly where he means them to go. His catcher, Tony Pena, says he simply sets up a target and waits for the thump. If the ball does not hit the padded pocket of his mitt just so, Pena's hand is numb for three innings.
 TWELVE INDIANS UP, 12 INDIANS DOWN. Cleveland is having no luck with the cross-seamer. Last week, against the fastball-hitting Toronto Blue Jays, nearly half of Clemens's pitches were forkballs, sliders and curves. Today, he picks up the speed.
 If anyone thought Clemens's concentration would be corrupted by his newly minted contract or the fallout from his explosion in last season's American League playoffs, they don't know him. He is inspired by tumult; he loves to disappoint his detractors.
And there are plenty of them. After carrying the Red Sox to a division title last fall, Clemens became unhinged during Boston's disastrous playoff loss to Oakland. He got into a series of verbal, even violent, imbroglios with a Boston photographer, sundry Oakland A's, umpires, his own manager and an innocent, if unyielding, clubhouse door, which he smashed with his pitching hand on the eve of the American League Championship. Ejected from the final game of the series for cursing, he ran through one umpire in order to threaten another with off-season retaliation. The Rocket had exploded. Indelible remains the memory of that lip-readable frenzy that caused one of the Red Sox owners, John Harrington -- not to mention millions of startled fans -- to question the mental stability of the star hurler.
Then, only three months later, Clemens was arrested for aggravated assault on a policeman. The officer had been in the process of arresting his older brother Randy Clemens for causing a disturbance in a crowded Houston saloon called Bayou Mama's Swamp Bar. The brawl was front-page news in Boston: Good Ol' Boy in Bad New Scrap.
How did the conservative Red Sox organization react to all the controversy? By awarding Clemens a four-year contract, averaging $5.3 million per season, making him the highest-paid player in baseball history (basketball and football history, too). Befuddled fans, especially in recession-plagued New England, questioned the mental stability of Red Sox management.
 THE WAY CLEMENS IS pitching today, it's easy to forgive his transgressions. After all, what's a freakout and a felony and five million bucks compared with the promise of a pennant? In the bottom of the third inning, the Red Sox had scored their first run on two Cleveland errors. Clemens watches Pena cross the plate on the monitor in the clubhouse, where he has gone to change into a fresh jersey and to confer with Bill Fischer, his pitching coach since his second season.
 "No one knows how [expletive] hard this guy works," Fischer, a grizzled ex-marine, says later. "Every [expletive] day, he works on his fastball, slider, curve, forkball, his mechanics, his pick-off move. He runs and he studies and he's [expletive] obsessed with being a great pitcher."
Fischer pitched for five teams during a nine-year major-league career distinguished by one record: 84 1/3 consecutive innings without a walk. You take a man who has spent his entire adult life around leathernecks and ballplayers and you are hard-pressed to hear an expletive-free sentence.
 "There's something the public doesn't understand about pitchers -- they're freaks. Roger Clemens is a [expletive] freak. Every great pitcher I ever known is a [expletive] freak. Any time you can throw a ball 90-plus m.p.h. over the plate whenever you want, you're a [expletive] freak of nature. There was Gibson and Palmer and Seaver and Ryan, and now there's Roger Clemens. He's the big bully on the block. He says he's the best, and he backs it up. That kills people. His only problem is that he works too [expletive] hard, and he overpitches sometimes. That's my job -- some guys you gotta calm down, some guys you gotta kick."
The pitching coach has his work cut out for him this year. After Clemens, the Red Sox staff is a collection of kids, castoffs and free agents acquired by the front office during a winter of irrepressible largess. Matt Young has a three-year contract that will give him $6.35 million. He has never won more than 12 games in one season in the majors. Danny Darwin signed for four years and $11.8 million. Darwin, 35, has never won more than nine games in a single year as a starter. Over all, the Red Sox agreed to pay six players a total of $66.2 million for 20 years, an average of $3.3 million a year.
In this great baseball bazaar, Roger Clemens may turn out to be one high-priced bargain.
"The marketplace is crazy," says the Red Sox's affable general manager, Lou Gorman. "The Red Sox payroll seven years ago was $6.7 million. The payroll this year is $34 million. You have no choice. I believe that if the escalation of salaries continues, there are going to be some clubs in bankruptcy."
The Red Sox are not one of those teams. Despite the fourth-highest payroll in baseball, there is little fear of red ink. Local television will bring in about $25 million a year until 1995. Fenway Park sells itself. The fans are crazy loyal.
Of course, the biggest news of the signing binge was Clemens's $5,380,250 per season. Based on last year's stats, this will break down to $256,202 per victory, $25,742 per strikeout. The numbers addle the brain until one considers that Ted Danson, the star of the long-running television hit "Cheers," earns comparable money per laugh and pickup line. And he only pretends he pitched for the Red Sox.
"If Clemens walked away, I believe the fans of New England would have hanged me from the centerfield flagpole," says Gorman, quickly adding, "in effigy. We had no choice. Leverage controls any negotiation. Clemens had total leverage. Look, we couldn't afford not to sign Clemens. We made the best deal we could, although no one would agree. Personally, I think we got off easy."
Before the signing, Clemens's arm was inspected by three specialists. Nobody probed his psyche. Gorman doesn't put much stock in that psychiatry stuff.
"I never thought about Roger seeing anyone," the general manager says. "He's just a very intense competitor who blew up last year. Off the field, his personal habits are good. He's a good family man. He never has more than one beer. He's a health nut. If I worry about anything, I worry about him running around the streets of Boston and getting hit by a car."
If not for $5,000, Clemens might be running through the mean streets of Manhattan. When he was a 19-year-old prospect at San Jacinto Junior College, the Mets tried to sign him. They drafted him in the 12th round and sent two officials to Texas to recruit him. The pair trapped him in a parking lot after a game and offered him $30,000. Roger wanted $5,000 more.
The vice president of the Mets nixed the deal. His name was Lou Gorman. Ten years and several zeroes later, he didn't let it happen again.
 IN THE FIFTH INNING, AS the 14th straight Indian is retired, the no-hitter talk takes on new earnestness. A number of fans invoke the name of Nolan Ryan, the 44-year-old Texas Ranger who will pitch his seventh no-hitter a couple of weeks later.
 As a teen-ager, Roger Clemens walked around with a photograph of Nolan Ryan in mid-pitch. He studied the still, intuiting that flawless mechanics were the key to both dominion and longevity on the mound. As a 10th grader, after his family had moved to Houston from Dayton, Ohio, he'd sneak off to the Astrodome to watch his local hero, then pitching for the Astros. When Ryan faced Tom Seaver, it was a masters' class in Advanced Power Pitching. Clemens's style is now a hybrid of those two classicists. Never more than acquaintances, Clemens and Ryan are separated by a generation, conflicting schedules and the 40 miles between two small Texas towns -- Clemens's Katy and Ryan's Alvin. Clemens jokes that if Ryan would only act his age, there might be a line or two in the record book left for him.
With two outs in the fifth inning, dreams of a no-no bounce up the middle, just beyond the reach of rookie shortstop Tim Naehring. Clemens hastily mops his brow with the tip of his glove, then glowers at the runner on first.
 According to John Marzano, the Red Sox's backup catcher and Clemens's best buddy on the team, the pitcher gets indignant when a runner reaches first; if said runner should find his way safely to second, Clemens gets downright livid. For Clemens, pitching is an angry meditation. Every hitter is an enemy, every game a mission. So fierce is his intensity that it irks fellow professionals. Willie Wilson, of the Oakland A's, once complained: "Who does he think he is? He struts around out there like 'Hey, man, I'm God. I'm Roger God Clemens, and nobody's going to hit me.' "
Clemens is a 230-pound workhorse who prances upon the mound on Clydesdale thighs that have been developed by running three seven-minute miles every day for over a decade. "I don't jog -- I run!" he proclaims. In the off-season, he ties tires to a harness and pulls them across the parking lot of his alma mater, Spring Woods High School in Houston. During the season, no matter the city in which he awakes, Clemens runs in the streets every morning, wearing a black Los Angeles Raiders cap turned backward, revealing short, spiky hair into which he has scupltured thin parallel lines.
For half the year, he lives in a self-imposed exile from fun. No carousing, no late-night revelry. He brings this purposefulness to the mound. With athletes like Rickey Henderson or Michael Jordan, you see their exuberance, their delight in sharing their delight. Clemens keeps his pleasures to himself -- the joy is in the work and the work is solitary.
Few teammates pretend to know Clemens. While they gratefully acknowledge his leadership and his accomplishments -- and are in awe of his combative nature -- few are friends. When one taped the words "Possessed Rebel" on Clemens's locker, it was both compliment and dig. The pitcher took a fancy to the image. Possessed? You bet. A rebel? In every sense -- the soul of an insurgent and family roots that stretch back to Robert E. Lee.
"That's where my fire comes from," says Clemens. "I've always been doubted, and I've always responded. That's what keeps me going, keeps me focused. If someone says I can't do something, I gotta show him he's wrong."
The fire is further fueled by the special burdens of performing for the Boston Red Sox. To say the Bosox are a secular religion in New England is neither blasphemy nor hyperbole. "Pope Dies -- Sox Still Alive!" was a newscast teaser in 1978. Clemens is the last best chance for the Red Sox to exorcise the demons that have denied them a world championship for three score and 12 seasons. Of this obligation, he is well aware and unafraid. In fact, he welcomes the responsibilities. He approaches the world like Atlas.
"I think about it all the time," he says. "How could I forget? People tell me their grandfather's sick, and he has to see the Red Sox win before he dies. The media's always writing about the monkey on our backs for 73 years. I was there in 1986 when we lost to the Mets -- I know about the curse. These people in Boston deserve a championship. My teammates deserve it, the ones on the field and the ones who aren't here any more. There are a lot of people counting on me. Believe me, it's on my mind all the time."
 BILL CLEMENS WAS not a responsible man. He was selfish and abusive and gone by the time his son Roger was 5 months old. The truck driver couldn't handle the pressures of supporting a wife and five children. Bill Clemens's interest in athletics involved a bottle of beer and a television set. He would not have understood, much less approved, what would become his youngest son Roger's obsession.
Roger spoke to his father only once, on the telephone, gave the old man hell, told him never to come around again. Roger was 10 years old. His stepfather had died the year before. In very different ways, Clemens lost two fathers in the first decade of his life. He was the only one of the five Clemens kids who refused to attend his father's funeral.
"I never knew my blood father until he passed away," Clemens says. "I'm sure he saw me pitch in the College World Series. Friends close to the family told me he watched me on television. He didn't pass until the end of that season, and seeing me might have contributed to his passing. I know if I were in his shoes, and I saw my boy do what I did, well, it would hurt, hurt real bad."
The finale of the 1983 College World Series was the game his natural father saw. Texas versus Alabama. In the ninth inning, protecting a one-run lead, Clemens gave up a leadoff double to Dave Magadan, currently the Mets first baseman. The Texas coach walked to the mound. "I ain't coming out," said the pitcher resolutely. "I want this one." And he got it. Celebration followed. As Clemens emerged from the pileup of Longhorns, too near an ESPN microphone, he raised his clenched fist to the heavens and shouted: "You tested me, you [expletive]! Don't test me!"
These are no small games Roger Clemens is playing.
"Roger was always more intense than the rest of us," recalls Mark Vennerholm, who has gone from catching the Rocket in Little League to designing rockets for Texas Instruments. "He was not an outstanding athlete, but you couldn't convince Roger of that. He was a bulldog, more motivated than anyone I've ever known. He was working on this long-term plan. And he was only 10 years old!"
 TO END THE SEVENTH inning, on a two-two count, Clemens suddenly drops sidearm and delivers a heater that immobilizes the hitter at the plate. His release point, on which batters time their swing, has just changed. It is a new Rocket wrinkle. A few of his teammates smile as they jog off the field.
 "On days when Roger pitches," says Red Sox utility man Steve Lyons, "some guys on the other team decide to rest their sore hamstrings or come down with stomachaches. Good timing, eh?"
Though hard to fathom, Clemens is still improving. Over the last five years, his 100 victories and 2.71 e.r.a. are the best in the majors. His statistics last year rival those of the great seasons of the modern era. He went 21-6, with an e.r.a. of 1.93, nearly a full two runs less than the league average. All this pitching in Fenway, a hitters' haven, without benefit of great defense or stalwart bullpen. "Clemens and Lemons," a local phrase last year, may have been an unkind characterization of the pitching staff, but the Red Sox were less than a .500 team without their ace on the mound. Had he not missed a crucial span in September with a sore shoulder -- the Sox folded like napkins in his absence -- he might have won his second Most Valuable Player Award and his third Cy Young Award.
Clemens went into the playoffs against the highly touted Oakland A's with a sore shoulder and fragile psyche. He was worn down by the demands of the long season, by the ghosts of failures past.
On the last day of the regular season, after unsuccessfully lobbying for a longer celebration before the news media were permitted into the locker room, he threw a tantrum and punched the door with his pitching hand. Despite his pitching well in the first game against Oakland, the A's were victorious. In the second game, his ragging of both umpires and opponents got so vicious that Clemens had to be restrained by his own manager, with whom he ended up in a shouting match. (Clemens denies both the bench jockeying and discord.) Moments before he was to start in the fourth game, his team down 0-3 in the best-of-seven series, Clemens rammed his shoulder into a photographer, Jim Davis of The Boston Herald, who was leaning against the backstop screen. (Clemens contends it was a light brush.)
"He went out of his way to hit me," Davis says. "I tried to think of the worst thing I could possibly say when he came back on the field. Remembering that he was 0 and 7 against Dave Stewart, when he ran by, I yelled, '0 and 8, pal! 0 and 8!' "
Since Dave Stewart became the ace of the Oakland staff five years ago, Clemens has not beaten him, lost to him four times last season alone. There is bad blood between the two best pitchers in the American League. Stewart resents all the accolades and awards Clemens has won. Clemens resents Stewart's three trips to the World Series, not to mention his fielders, hitters and bullpen. "What makes Dave Stewart so good," he says flatly, "is that he has eight guys behind him that could be on the All-Star team. I wish the writers would give him a Cy Young Award so I wouldn't have to listen to him anymore."
The hex has a hold on Clemens. When he squared off against Stewart for the fourth game of the championship series last October, he wore an unfamiliar Fu Manchu mustache and war-paint eyeblack. He was facing not only his old nemesis, but also the bitter prospect of being swept by a team whose showboating style he abhors.
He was not sharp that afternoon in Oakland. His fastball was not popping, his slider was missing. After walking second baseman Willie Randolph on a close call in the second inning, Clemens stomped around the mound cursing. Home plate umpire Terry Cooney shouted at him to shut up and pitch. Clemens shouted back at Cooney: "I'm not [expletive] talkin' to you. Get back behind the [expletive] plate and call the game." The next thing Clemens knew, Cooney had ejected him -- without warning and with questionable provocation. Baseball's unwritten rule allows players to use obscenity as long as it's not directed at an umpire personally.
When Clemens realized he had been tossed, he went wild. Racing across the infield grass toward home plate, where his manager was quarreling with several umpires, Clemens rushed at Cooney. Pushing umpire Jim Evans out of the way, the raging pitcher was finally restrained by teammates a few feet shy of his target. Unable to reach Cooney, he settled for terrorizing him. "I'm going to find out where you live and come after you this winter!" he yelled.
Clemens was suspended for five games this season and fined $10,000. He fought the decision, appealing twice, losing twice, and ended up missing one start in late April.
"I don't dispute bumping an umpire," he says now, "and I'm at fault for cursing a couple of times and threatening Cooney, but all that happened after the ejection. The ejection is the nucleus of the thing, and the umpire was falsifying all over the place. The decision was unjust."
Clemens feels persecuted by umpires, forgetting that throughout last season he had unleashed many a four-lettered tirade at various men behind the mask. Back in July, umpire Jim Evans had said, "If he's constantly having trouble with umpires, maybe he should look in the mirror and ask himself if maybe he's the problem." Clemens assumes no accountability, sees no cause and effect at work.
Similarly, Clemens believes the Boston news media are out to get him. Though his clippings are 99 percent positive, he remembers every negative story, as well as the byline above it. He thinks members of the press use him to sell papers and, in the process, cause him undeserved grief. And when Clemens feels bushwhacked, he strikes back. "Someone's gonna get hurt if they write about my family," he said a few years ago. "Whether it's physical or whatever, I'd take action -- severe action." Over the years, his relations with reporters have ranged from the embargo of 1989, when he refused all interviews, to this season of attempted accommodation, when he talks mostly after games in which he has pitched, and only about pitching.
 IN THE EIGHTH INNING, with a 4-0 lead, Clemens is on cruise control. Pitching with a lead makes him all the more effective; he does not have to worry about a single mistake costing him the game.
 The incident in which he was arrested in Houston last winter served only to corroborate Clemens's view of a world populated by hostile people. Clemens, along with his older brother Randy and two friends, had gone to Bayou Mama's after seeing an Andrew Dice Clay concert. They planned to meet some other friends at the saloon. A fracas broke out at the crowded bar, and Clemens saw his brother being arrested by an off-duty policeman who doubled as a bouncer.
Clemens went to his brother's aid. He says he tapped the cop on the shoulder, introduced himself, hoping that his name would turn things around, and tried to talk the officer out of making the arrest. The officer claims Clemens grabbed him from behind and crushed him in a headlock. A group of fellow officers subdued the Clemens brothers, arrested them for aggravated assault and took them to jail. The felony offense has since been downgraded to a misdemeanor charge for hindering an arrest. A hearing has been scheduled for next month. Maintaining his innocence, Clemens will not plea-bargain.
He sees the incident as a turning point in his life, when the dark side of fame and fortune was revealed to him, when the general public joined umpires and news media in turning against him.
"When I walk into a place like that," he says in pained tones, "everybody knows I'm there, so somebody has a chip on his shoulder or thinks I'm a tough guy. I never thought my life was gonna change. I never thought money would come back at me because of my name. Now I got people coming at me everywhere."
 To protect his wife, Debbie, his two young sons and himself from the perils of superstardom, he is building a 13,000-square-foot house on a three-acre plot just outside of Houston, complete with office, pitcher's mound, track, gym, weight room and 14-seat theater. The contractor is his wife's stepfather. The family is looking for a 100-acre ranch nearby, where his mother and brother Rick can live. When the compound is complete, his off-seasons will be filled with kith and kin. Father and sons will ride horses and watch movies and play catch in the spacious backyard.
"I don't know whether it's a phobia or what," he has said, "but I have a hard time dealing with a lot of people I don't know around me. Sometimes I'm with my family and the crowd gets too aggressive. If my family should get hurt by these people, then I'm either going to hurt somebody or go berserk."
Clemens has the Cleveland game well in hand. He has scattered three feckless singles and walked none. His fastball is still in the upper 90's and dead on. The Red Sox are on the verge of 4-0 victory.
Fenway fans are standing now, in noisy anticipation of the last out. Clemens looks in for the signal, blocks out the cheering throngs. He hears only his inner voice and the faint sparks of the plaque-maker sharpening his tools in Cooperstown.

LENGTH: 890 words

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
An Italian Table With Many Partisans

BYLINE: By JOANNE STARKEY

 BODY:
CAN more than 1,000 Long Island restaurantgoers be wrong? The recent Zagat Suburban New York City Restaurant Survey tabulating diners' responses ranks Navona in Great Neck as the Island's No. 1 Italian restaurant.
Recent visits confirm that much of its food is scrumptious. But there were also enough duds on the menu, including a few overly dry, dull entrees, to question the lofty rating. Navona does, however, make my Italian Top-5 list. 
 Navona is a small, elegant white-tablecloth storefront place. Yet, its mammoth mirrors create a feeling of spaciousness. Huge paintings of the restaurant's namesake, the Piazza Navona in Rome, share the walls with those mirrors.
While no one would ever accuse Navona of having bargain-basement prices, the restaurant makes it easy for diners on budgets to hold the line. Complimentary miniwedges of pizza one evening and bruschetta, garlicky toast piled high with fresh tomatoes, on another could substitute for appetizers. For those who feel a meal is incomplete without an opener, fried zucchini at $4.50, is an economical and delicious choice. A doily-covered platter is heaped with enough crispy wisps for the whole table.
At meal's end, there is a generous plate of gratis biscotti, the trendy Italian almond cookies. One night, they were joined by an even sweeter treat, chocolate-dipped strawberries. Therefore, it is possible to skip dessert, but I would not recommend it.
Navona delights with sensational homemade sweets including a feather-light chocolate cake, a luxuriant Napoleon, a crackly topped creme brulee and, best of all, crisp-crusted fruit tarts. Tiramisu, however, had a runny custardlike texture rather than the creamy one expected.
Star beginnings are the bacon-infused pasta e fagioli, the robust peasant soup; glistening seafood salad loaded with tender goodies, velvety polenta under a mantle of melted Gorgonzola cheese and scampi Ischitani bathed in white wine and masses of garlic. The sole loser among the starters was hot antipasto gypsy style, featuring a sharp tomato sauce playing host to sausage, chicken and mushy potatoes and peas.
Three pasta specials that shimmered were angel hair covered with a chunky tomato sauce and crowned with lobster medallions; pappardelle, wide noodles, enrobed in a bosky brown sauce loaded with porcini and shiitake mushrooms, and large pasta pillows stuffed with ricotta and spinach under a creamy pink sauce.
The salad sensation is the Charlotte. Three supersize radicchio leaves contain greens, roasted red peppers, onions, tomatoes and asparagus, all chopped, making a luscious meld. Asparagus spears nestled in endive spokes encircle the creation. It costs a whopping $8.50, but is large enough to share and outshines lesser lights.
At entree time, swim straight for the fish. The three top main courses sampled all had fins. A hefty swordfish steak smothered with shiitake mushrooms, elegantly simple Dover sole and red snapper topped with julienned peppers, onions and tomatoes, then steamed in foil, were lightly and splendidly turned out. They were far better than the arid, routine chicken scarpariello and broiled veal chop. Even less rewarding were the veal scallops a la Napoletana. Their tomato-mushroom sauce was tasty, but the meat was tough and dry.
More successful meat choices were the rack of lamb, rosy rare, thinly sliced and fanned on the plate, and a veal chop special. The chop, still on the bone, was pounded, breaded, crisply fried Milanese style, then mounded with cold crunchy salad.
Vegetable accompaniments nearly redeemed some of the drearier entrees. A souffle of cauliflower, carrot and broccoli purees and wedges of roasted fennel were perfect partners.
The mostly Italian wine list has a sprinkling of French and California choices. Although prices soar into the hundreds, 14 of the more than 60 selections are $14 to $20. One is a light subtle 1985 Villa Doria barbaresco riserva at $18.

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Long Beach, Calif.;
A Cambodian Centerpiece

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN

 BODY:
AN office-retail building with a roof designed to suggest a Cambodian temple is the centerpiece of efforts by Asian immigrants and this city's officials to revitalize a depressed commercial district.
Susan Shick, the city's Director of Community Development, said the $2 million, 22,000-square-foot UCC Plaza will be a "catalyst" for the redevelopment of the Anaheim Street area, a watershed of several immigrant neighborhoods. 
 The two-story building is a makeover of an existing 15,000-square-foot theater. Manny Perez, a local architect, enlarged and remodeled the building. The street level is for stores, the second floor for offices. The building, which was 75 percent leased when it opened in April, stands amid an aging retail strip where Hispanic businesses alternate with immigrant Asian concerns.
There are 45,000 Cambodians in this port city 20 miles south of downtown Los Angeles, one of the largest concentrations of Cambodians outside their native land. "The Cambodian community would like to become self-sufficient," said Than Pok, executive director of United Cambodian Community, the nonprofit developer. To sustain the community's growth, he said, the organization looked for a place "right in the middle" of where the Cambodians lived.
The notion of an office building in a working-class neighborhood was a tough sell to lenders, particularly at a time of recession and high office vacancy rates, said Mr. Pok. As a result, the financing for UCC Plaza is nearly as elaborate as the building's pagoda-like roof.
Mr. Pok's group bought the site for $121,000 in cash and the Local Initiative Support Corporation, a national nonprofit organization based in New York, contributed $30,000 in predevelopment costs, including architectural fees. The organization, which provides loans and technical assistance for community-sponsored housing and commercial projects, also provided $250,000 in equity.
A local lender, Queen City Bank, agreed to a $1.6 million construction loan andSecurity Pacific National Bank made a commitment to provide a $1.5 million mortgage to the project upon completion; the arrangement removes the difficulty of finding a second lender to pay off the construction loan, at a time when most lenders are shunning new projects.
Finally, the City of Long Beach tapped its Federal Community Development Block Grant funds for $172,000 for traffic improvement. The city also paid the project's development fees. Despite the help, Mr. Pok said, the project still needs $300,000 to cover cost overruns.

HEADLINE: Medical Waste Law Draws Criticism

BYLINE: By LEO H. CARNEY

 BODY:
A TWO-YEAR-OLD state law that strictly regulates the handling, disposal and tracking of the medical waste generated by thousands of hospitals, laboratories, doctors and others is being widely criticized.
State environmental officials say enforcement of the law has been hampered by insufficient funds and staff. Hospitals say the law is in conflict with a Federal statute, adding to the morass of costly regulations that the hospitals are already required to comply with. 
 Doctors say the law has been administered with too heavy a hand. Environmentalists say the law was never a priority for protecting the state's coastal areas.
 
No. 10 on List
 "If we had a list of 10 critical environmental concerns, and medical waste was on that list, it would be No. 10," said D. W. Bennett, the executive director of the American Littoral Society, an environmental group based in Sandy Hook.
Even the critics agree on the need to regulate the treatment of medical waste, but they are troubled by provisions of the current state law.
In 1988, when reports that used syringes and vials of blood had washed ashore prompted beach closings in New Jersey and New York, Congress and the Legislatures in both states began to take steps to address the problem.
Congress passed the 1988 Medical Waste Tracking Act, which set regulations on medical waste. It also provided New Jersey with $1.2 million for the creation of its own law. The Federal law expires June 24, and its reauthorization is working its way through Congress.
 
A Yearly Fee
 The New Jersey law, the Comprehensive Regulated Medical Waste Management Act, was signed by Gov. Thomas H. Kean in March 1989. It covers the handling, disposal and tracking of the refuse produced from the diagnosis and treatment of humans and animals as well as from embalming, medical research and blood banks.
Sites and practititioners who produce medical waste must register with the state and pay a yearly fee to cover the cost of administering and enforcing the law.
John R. Hagerty, a spokesman for the State Department of Environmental Protection, which, with the Department of Health, administers the state law, said the Federal law's revision or continuation would "probably have a negligible affect" on the state measure. He defended the state law as "one of the best in the country."
R. Scott Brubaker, chief of the Bureau of Inspections and Investigations in the Department of Environmental Protection, said the enforcement of the state law had been hampered by staff shortages in the last two years because of a state hiring freeze. As a result, with only two to seven medical waste investigators assigned to the entire state, roughly 10 percent of the 15,000 medical waste producers have been inspected since the law took effect, according to figures provided by Mr. Brubaker.
State investigators said that one in five of the generators inspected so far had been violating the law, either through failure to register or noncompliance with the rules for packaging, labeling, storing and transporting the waste, all of which fall on the individual generator.
 
Fees Reduced for Doctors
 Robert M. Confer, chief of the Bureau of Special Waste Planning in the Department of Environmental Protection, said the law called for registration fees that would have provided an operating budget of about $6 million a year for administering and enforcing the law.
But he and Mr. Brubaker noted that a 1990 amendment to the law had reduced the fees charged to mostly small generators, like doctors and dentists, thereby reducing the agency's medical waste budget by 40 to 50 percent annually. Fees generally range from $100 to $1,000 a year, depending on volume, whereas they had originally been proposed at $528.50 to $1,000.
In addition, Mr. Brubaker said the agency had received a special exemption from the Governor's office last month to hire more investigators with a current $600,000 grant from the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. The combination of the hiring freeze and the cut in fees "has caused us to revise our anticipated monitoring and compliance schedules, and I don't think we can make a commitment to regular inspections down the road," Mr. Brubaker said.
Mr. Confer said this meant that medical waste generators would be inspected only once every four and a half to five years, instead of every 12 to 18 months, as his bureau had originally envisioned. So far, he said, 12,700 generators have been registered.
 
Many Failed to Register
 A fiscal statement issued in February by the Assembly said $4.5 million a year was being raised by the fees.
But, Mr. Confer said, the $4 million or so that has been collected has come in since the law took effect, because many generators had failed to register during the first year of the law and the bureau was only now beginning to receive payments.
Mr. Confer and Mr. Brubaker added that although it was originally thought that there were 10,000 businesses and institutions that would fall under the state law when it was enacted, it is now believed that the number will be 15,000 to 16,000 or more when the registration is completed.
Of the 1,500 inspections made so far, Mr. Brubaker said, about 300 were charged with civil violations of the law, either by not registering or not following the prescribed procedure for packaging, labeling, storing and transporting.
Christopher Florenz, a spokesman for Robert J. Del Tufo, the State Attorney General, said there had been only two criminal charges filed by the Attorney General's office during the course of the two-year-old law. Three businesses have been referred from the Department of Environmental Protection to the Attorney General's Office of Administrative Hearings, he said, but have not yet been scheduled.
 
'Laws Are Overkill'
 Diana Stager, a vice president of the New Jersey Hospital Association in Princeton, said that she, like other critics, agreed with "the need for careful control of medical waste."
"But these two laws are overkill," she said.
Ms. Stager and the association have been pushing the state environmental agency for changes in the definition of medical waste, she said, "so that things like blood-soaked bandages are included but blood-stained ones are not, and so that things like the diapers of newborns are excluded."
 "These things aren't infectious or dangerous," she said.
Hospitals have borne the brunt of Federal enforcement efforts so far. Earlier this year, five hospitals in Bergen County were charged with violating a total of more than 30 counts of the Federal law. The Federal environmental agency is seeking fines of more than $1 million against them, but administrative hearings have not yet been scheduled on the charges, said Herman Phillips, a spokesman for the agency's regional office in New York.
 
Group Pressing State
 Physicians have been critical of the state agency's implementation and enforcement of the law. Joseph Lucci, director of medical and insurance affairs for the Medical Society of New Jersey, a 10,000-member group based in Lawrenceville, said the organization's environmental health committee voted this month to press the state environmental agency for "more on the educational end and exactly what is expected of our physician members under this law."
The agency, Mr. Lucci said, originally indicated that it would properly educate and notify physicians of the new law in 1989. But, he said, "as far as we know that has not been done, and we've received complaints from our members that they never received a first mailing from the D.E.P."
"Instead of education, the enforcement came first with this law," Mr. Lucci said.
The medical society, he noted, was instrumental in getting the proposed minimum fee registration of $528.50 reduced to $100. Last March, Mr. Lucci said, the society requested and received a three-month amnesty period from the Department of Environmental Protection for physicians who had not registered since 1989. The amnesty period ends June 30.

 
'Strictly for Esthetic Reasons'
 Mr. Confer of the state environmental agency said the amnesty had been extended to all categories of generators, not just physicians.
Daisy Mather, the coordinator of medical waste tracking for the Federal agency's regional office, said, "Doctors and dentists seem to not really want to be interested in this program because they feel it causes them to go out of their way to deal with all these requirements."
But Miss Mather agreed that the Federal law was too hastily promulgated and was primarily written in response to the public and political outcry in 1988 over the medical waste's washing up on beaches.
"Most of the regulations were strictly for esthetic reasons," she said.
She added that the current law "is costing us a lot, is providing us with a lot of information on the kinds of medical waste and who is generating them in what quantities." But, she said, "the law also is showing us that there really is very little health risk to the waste except to workers who are directly and regularly exposed to it."
Her view was supported by Mr. Bennett of the Littoral Society, who said the beach incidents were "few and far between to begin with, and I don't know of any medical waste that has washed up lately." The waste, he said, has "very little environmental impact, but it is an esthetic and economic problem -- look what it did to tourism."
The State Division of Travel and Tourism said that a large decline in tourism revenue in 1988 and 1989 was partly a result of the reports of beach closings attributed to medical waste.
 
Risk Called 'Very Low'
 Mr. Bennett's views on negligible environmental and health risks of medical waste are supported by several Federal agencies, including the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, which says the risk of contracting blood-borne diseases from discarded medical waste is "very low."
And a report issued last February by Congress's Office of Technology Assessment noted that only 15 percent of all hospital wastes were infectious. Most were sterilized or incubated on the site by hospitals, the report said.
The report further stated that Congress should move "beyond the current approach to medical waste management and define a more comprehensive approach."
 Representative Frank Pallone Jr., Democrat of Long Branch, was a sponsor of the original Federal law and is one of the legislators seeking to revise it. Russell McGerk, Mr. Pallone's legislative director, acknowledged that perhaps the 1988 law had been written too hastily in response to the public furor over the beach incidents. There are "discrepancies" between the Federal and state laws, Mr. McGerk said, "and the generator can be in total compliance with one while violating the other."
Also, "we have found that the hospitals are being too strictly regulated," he said. "Beach washups, for instance, don't necessarily have anything to do with hospitals."
James M. Staples, a spokesman for the Department of Environmental Protection, said it had been found that most syringes, for example, were disposed of in sewer systems by diabetics or drug addicts.
Mr. McGerk said: "Some of the things now regulated under the law may not be considered infectious waste. It has been found to be benign."

HEADLINE: Computerized Ordering Helps Bookstores Thrive

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
While some publishers are singing the blues at the convention of the American Booksellers Association, which ends tomorrow after four days at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, many book retailers are singing an upbeat tune.
At a time when most businesses are tightening their belts, bookstores, especially the independents, are proliferating, and many are prospering -- although many booksellers say they are worried about rising book prices. 
 All across the country, more bookstores are using computers to track sales and keep inventories lean. They are also ordering through an expanding network of national and regional distributors that can deliver books much faster than publishers. This allows bookstores to stock fewer copies of each book and more overall titles. As a result, publishers must rethink the size of their printings, no longer able to rely on bookstores to buy large amounts of popular titles out of fear of running out before they can order again.
"What used to be mom and pop bookstores may still be run by mom and pop, but now they are sophisticated business people," said Bruce Harris, an executive vice president of Random House.
 
 Emphasis on Service
 Seven or eight years ago, independent booksellers feared being run out of business by the chain stores, with their high volume and lower prices. Today, almost no one thinks the chains pose a long-term threat. Some chains are even emulating the independents' emphasis on service and breadth of stock.
For example, the 1,270-store Waldenbooks chain, cheered by the success of its Brentano operation and its Waldenbooks & More superstores, is thinking about devoting less space to non-book products, even in its mall stores -- the high-traffic locations that have stressed low price and rapid turnover, rather than selection. (Book sales in mall stores were sluggish in the first quarter because mall traffic was down generally.)
"A year ago, we changed the mix in our Waldenbooks & More from 40 percent non-books to 10 percent, and sales have increased substantially," said Charles R. Cumello, the president of Waldenbooks Inc., a unit of the K Mart Corporation.
 
More Selection, Higher Sales
 A similar pattern is discernible in the independent stores, including the smaller independents. "It's been their experience that the broader your selection, the more books you sell," said Bernard Rath, the executive director of the American Booksellers Association, whose members operate more than 7,000 stores.
About a quarter of the association's members now order books through one of two dozen computer systems, and the percentage is rising rapidly. Most such systems enable stores to record sales, check inventories and reorder electronically from the wholesalers.
As a result, booksellers do not have to tie up capital by stocking too many copies of the same book. The wholesalers can usually deliver from one to hundreds of books within 48 hours, and sometimes the next day. Booksellers can also quickly return books that are not selling for credit or for different titles. Most booksellers still place their initial orders with publishers, but reorder from wholesalers, who charge only slightly more than the publishers do.
"When I first went on the road as a sales rep in the 1970's," Mr. Rath said, "I'd make a sales call in September and booksellers would buy enough books to last through December because they'd not likely see me again for some time. These days, with the quick turnaround by wholesalers, booksellers only need to order a week's worth of books at a time."
 
An Owner's Personality
 One publisher, speaking on condition of anonymity, lamented that the independent booksellers might soon come to resemble the chains, whose buying decisions rely heavily on authors' past sales performances or on the performances of books with similar themes. But others doubt such a trend, saying independent bookstores still tend to reflect the personalities of their owners: Some specialize in literature, others in mysteries, biographies, or children's books.
Whether independent or part of a chain, bookstores continue to multiply, even though profits average a modest 3-to-5 percent of sales after salaries. Late last year, Audits and Surveys, a marketing concern, reported that the number of bookstores grew by 76 percent in the last decade, to 17,620, trailing only fast-food restaurants, which grew 78 percent, among the fastest-growing specialty stores.
Bookstore sales have increased in each of the last five years, from $4.9 billion in 1986 to an estimated $7.9 billion this year, according to the Commerce Department, and they are expected to continue growing. The American Booksellers Association estimates that retail sales will increase 8.2 percent this year over last.
"Our first quarter of this year is 7.4 percent ahead of the first quarter in 1990," Mr. Rath said. This performance, he added, was achieved in a quarter notable for a weak overall economy and for "people watching the gulf war on television for a couple of weeks, rather than buying books."

Douglas Lay uses a computer at Endicott Booksellers in Manhattan, where he is manager. (Jim Estrin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Media Business: Advertising;
Cigarette Companies Avoid Aggressive Publicity Efforts

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
NOWADAYS, the nation's leading cigarette companies are letting their advertising speak for itself -- though not entirely by choice.
It is increasingly common for marketers like Philip Morris USA, R. J. Reynolds Tobacco and the American Tobacco Company to play down, or forgo, the extensive, expensive publicity and public relations programs that were once key elements of introducing brands or advertising campaigns for existing brands. 
 Seemingly part of the past are such splashy, high-profile programs as the one Reynolds undertook in June 1989 to promote its return to Times Square with a giant billboard for Camel cigarettes. The hoopla included press kits, T-shirts, a press reception and a ceremony at which company executives pretended to turn on the gaudy neon sign for the first time.
The $40 billion industry is now immersed in one of its most intensive advertising pushes ever, spending hundreds of millions of dollars on dozens of brands. Yet publicity and public relations efforts have virtually vanished. That change is significant because it runs counter to a strong trend among most other consumer-product marketers to blitz consumers and the press with publicity and public-relations barrages.
"It's a reflection of the atmosphere we operate in," said Maura Payne, director of external communications for R. J. Reynolds. "The anti-smoking forces have so supercharged the environment, we find there's no positive benefit from us seeking publicity." As Reynolds prepares to introduce Camel Ninety Nines, a longer-length cigarette in a hard pack; continues testing Horizon, a brand that it promotes as having improved-aroma smoke, and readies an image overhaul for its flagship Winston brand, it does so without publicity or public relations campaigns.
"All the pre-launch publicity is nice if you can do it, because you end up getting something almost for free," said Emanuel Goldman, who follows the tobacco industry for Paine Webber Inc. "But today, a company might get not only the launch coverage, but coverage of the attacks launched by the anti-smoking groups."
The last time Philip Morris, the industry's sales leader, undertook a large-scale publicity and public relations campaign was for Virginia Slims Superslims in fall 1989. The debut of the Bucks and Bristol economy brands, as well as new advertising for brands including Benson & Hedges, Cambridge and Merit Ultra Lights, have gone unheralded.
"When there's a story, we do get something out," said John Nelson, vice president of corporate affairs. He said Philip Morris planned publicity and public-relations programs pegged to the introduction of Marlboro Medium, a new variety of America's largest-selling cigarette.
At American Tobacco, where marketing executives are introducing an economy brand called Bull Durham, and changing a long-running advertising campaign for Carlton, they would "rather focus their efforts elsewhere," said Roger Baker, communications director for the parent, American Brands. One reason, he said, is because they believe the media are "deluged with new-product announcements" and theirs might not draw coverage.
Joe S. Epley, president of the Public Relations Society of America and of Epley Associates, a public relations firm in Charlotte, N.C., commented: "Any corporation, whether selling tobacco or anything else, has to look at the reality of the marketplace and adapt. Whether you do more of one technique, or another technique, or just quietly introduce a product, each situation has to be evaluated in its own light."

HEADLINE: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week

 BODY:
The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.
By late in the day on Friday the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 5.53 percent and the six-month bill was at 5.67 percent.
The Federal National Mortgage Association plans to announce the interest rates tomorrow for a two-part Fannie Mae financing totaling $1.4 billion equally divided between five- and 10-year maturities.
The following fixed-income issues are scheduled this week:
 
TAXABLE
WEDNESDAY

HEADLINE: The Media Business;
For Papers, a Way to Deliver Profits

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
In the four months since postal rates jumped sharply, what had been a mild interest among newspapers regarding the door-to-door delivery business has become an industrywide fascination that shows signs of evolving into a passion.
Indeed, the door-to-door delivery business has emerged as one of the most enticing ways for newspapers to generate new revenues while also satisfying the increasing number of advertisers who wish to aim their messages to specific ZIP codes or even specific addresses. 
 "It's spreading from the top metro papers across the board to medium and smaller papers," said Stephen L. Thompson, the publisher of Optimum Delivery, a Dallas-based newsletter about the private postal industry.
 
Two Fierce Rivals
 At the center of this growing interest with the delivery business are Publishers Express Inc. and Alternate Postal Delivery Inc., two fierce rivals that are competing to build national delivery networks to challenge the United States Postal Service in delivering magazines, catalogues, advertising circulars and other second- and third-class mail.
Both companies are scrambling to recruit newspapers that agree to set up delivery systems in designated areas, and both charge catalogue and magazine companies less than postal rates for delivery.
The premise for both companies is that newspapers already have delivery systems, which they could expand to deliver other publications and advertising to every household in their communities.
Just as important, a newspaper creating such a system might also stop someone else from doing so. The newspapers, in turn, make their profits from local retailers by selling ads that are included in the package of material that is delivered.
 
Opening 'a Lot of Doors'
 "If we can do it properly, it will open up a lot of doors for us," said James P. Bustraan, circulation director of The News and The Sun-Sentinel in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Sun-Sentinel, which is part of the Alternate Postal Delivery network, is in its second month of delivering Good Housekeeping, The Ladies' Home Journal and some other magazines that had been delivered by mail in the Fort Lauderdale area.
The magazines, along with catalogues and advertising circulars, are packaged in plastic bags that a carrier force of about 700 -- mostly housewives -- place on front porches. Though such deliveries are available now only on a limited basis, Mr. Bustraan said the paper should be able to deliver magazines and catalogues to any of the roughly one million addresses in the Fort Lauderdale area in the near future.
Given the newspaper industry's history of making slow, cautious changes, the move to create delivery systems has moved very rapidly.
Because many papers also have supplemental publications that are delivered to nonsubscribers by third-class mail, setting up their own delivery system is a way of cutting postage costs, even if they do not join one of the two delivery networks.
 
Added Piece of Business
 But a number of papers are joining the networks to get a piece of the delivery business.
Alternate Postal Delivery, which is based in Grand Rapids, Mich., has added seven papers to its network in recent months, including The Sacramento Bee in California, The News & Record in Greensboro, N.C., and Newsday on Long Island. The company now has systems in 21 markets, and Phillip D. Miller, its president, said he expected it to be in 31 markets in the coming months, including San Francisco and St. Louis, and in 95 of the top 150 markets by 1995.
Publishers Express, which is owned by nine communications companies, including Time Warner Inc. and The New York Times Company, has concentrated on developing technology to allow each package of magazines, catalogues, samples and advertising circulars to be labeled for a specific household.
The company, which is based in Atlanta, has only recently begun to move aggressively to assemble its newspaper network, which includes The Miami Herald and The Salt Lake Tribune and The Deseret News in Salt Lake City.
 
A Goal of 75 Markets
 Howard Rosen, the president of Publishers Express, said Charleston, S.C., and several towns in Indiana would be added within the next week or so. By 1995, Publishers Express wants to be in the top 75 markets.
To some minds, the concept has not proved to be a viable business. The alternate delivery business has been tried in the past and failed for a variety of reasons, ranging from prohibitive costs of hiring a large delivery staff to an inability to assure mailers a dependability of delivery comparable to that of the Postal Service.
Lon Danielson, general manager of The Palm Beach Post in Florida, said alternate delivery had failed there because "doorsteps were too far apart" to make it economically feasible to place the package on each porch, which advertisers demand. Also, in Palm Beach, Fla., many residential areas are guarded and private delivery companies are not allowed access, while the postman is.
 
'A Lot of Unknowns'
 "There are a lot of unknowns out there yet," said Gary T. Stout, the Gannett Company's president of offset operations, which includes alternate delivery.
Late last year, Mr. Stout signed a one-year agreement with Alternate Postal Delivery, giving the papers in 16 of the largest cities where Gannett operates papers, including Nashville and Honolulu, the right to set up delivery systems.
Mr. Stout said top executives at each paper were evaluating whether to start an alternate delivery operation, and, if so, whether to join Alternate Postal Delivery's network, or that of Publishers Express, which has also courted many of the papers.
"I know a couple of them are very, very warm and have a lot of confidence in the idea," Mr. Stout said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Further Fall Seen in Foreign Rates

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
So far this year, global demand for capital has not forced American interest rates higher, despite concerns to the contrary.
If anything, credit market analysts said, the pressures from overseas will probably ease over the next six to 12 months, as the recession in the United States, Britain and Canada spreads to the rest of the industrial world. Foreign interest rates, off their peaks from a year ago, will fall further, the analysts added. 
 Still, a decline in foreign interest rates will not automatically push down long-term bond yields in the United States, the analysts said.
 
 'A Beneficial Direction'
 "Last year, the surprise was the spike in foreign rates, and the nervousness in our markets that it was pulling up rates here," said Nicholas Sargen, a director in bond market research at Salomon Brothers. "This year, foreign rates will be moving in a beneficial direction. We think that rates in most overseas bond markets are going to be coming down. The real question is whether the American market will benefit from declines in rates abroad."
Meeting hefty needs for capital in countries like Germany and Japan did have an adverse effect on American interest rates in 1990. And as estimates of the probable costs of German reunification and rebuilding Eastern Europe and Kuwait have mounted, it seemed probable that competition for capital would remain intense this year.
 
Problem for Governments
 Another mammoth undertaking -- satisfying the Soviet Union's need for credit -- has always been seen as a problem for government creditors, not the private capital markets.
The needs for capital remain. But the economic slowdown in the United States and abroad has stretched out the period in which they will be met. "We have had such a slowdown that private-sector needs for credit in the large industrial countries has declined," said Lars Peterson, an international economist at the First Boston Corporation. "Market participants should be aware of foreign demand for capital, but it is not an immediate problem."
Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs International, said growth among the leading industrial countries this year was likely to be half of the 1990 pace. "The fact that there is no capital crunch is more the result of a weakening demand for capital than anything else," he added. "The test will come around the middle of 1992, when demand picks up."
 
Inflation Called Real Issue
 Even as much of Europe and the Far East starts to slow, the American economy is showing signs of a recovery after nearly 11 months of recession. Under those circumstances, "the real issue in front of the bond market is whether the recovery will be inflation-prone or not," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company.
Fresh information on inflation will not surface until the middle of June. And analysts expect that reports scheduled to be released this week will corroborate the notion that the recession has bottomed out.
The May survey of the nation's purchasing managers, scheduled for release today, is expected to show that while conditions in the nation's manufacturing sector improved for the third straight month, output was still weak.
 
Small Bounce for Auto Sales
 Similarly, auto sales, widely seen by credit market participants as a useful barometer of consumer activity, may show a small bounce when sales figures for the final 10 days of May are released later in the week. But analysts said an improvement would not mean that Detroit was rebounding sharply. "The public is starting to buy a few more cars," said Maryann N. Keller, an auto analyst at Furman Selz.
Vehicle sales, which have been running at an annual rate of about 5.5 million units, should move up to about 6 million in coming months, Ms. Keller said. "That is a lot better, but it is not terrific," she added, saying that auto production was not likely to pick up until the fourth quarter.
 
Rise in Jobless Expected
 Most economists do not harbor much hope that the monthly report from the Labor Department on employment conditions, expected on Friday, will show that recent patterns will suddently be reversed. The pace of layoffs probably slowed last month, economists said, but the overall unemployment rate, which dipped to 6.6 percent in April, probably moved up again.
Based on recent forecasts, most analysts were projecting that nonfarm payroll employment fell by 75,000 last month, down from 124,000 in April. Despite the smaller decline, most forecasters project that the unemployment rate probably rose to 6.8 percent.
A rise in the jobless rate would doubtless set off political alarms in Washington, but the Federal Reserve will probably not respond by immediately easing monetary policy. "I think there is still an inclination at the Fed to ease one more time, given the weakness of the economy and the desire to assure the recovery," said Leonard J. Santow, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting firm. "But they won't do it until the inflation numbers allow them to do it in a credible way."
Right now, "the bond market is standing in the way of the Fed," said Mr. Kudlow of Bear, Stearns. "I don't expect any more easing moves this year, but they have to wait for a rally before they even think of doing something."

HEADLINE: U.S. Still Seeks Lower Rates Abroad

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 2

 BODY:
When the industrial world's finance ministers gather here on Tuesday, the United States will continue to press other countries to lower their interest rates, American officials say.
At the annual ministers' meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady will ask the industrial nations to tilt their policies more vigorously toward growth, these officials said. 
 Mr. Brady may not hammer so hard on lowering rates as he has in recent months, however, because some European countries, notably Spain and Britain, have recently cut interest rates. Nonetheless, Germany, with its robust growth and dire fears of inflation, is expected to reject his call for lower rates, just as it rebuffed his pleas at the Group of Seven meeting in Washington in April.
The annual meeting of the O.E.C.D., a Paris-based organization that seeks to foster economic cooperation and growth, brings together finance, trade and foreign ministers from 24 industrial nations.
 
 Concern About Recession
 Explaining why Washington believes more needs to be done to lower rates, Alan P. Larson, the permanent American representative to the organization, said, "There has been a tendency in the past year to overestimate inflationary pressures and underestimate recessionary pressures."
Policy makers in some countries have derided Mr. Brady's campaign to lower rates, accusing him of meddling in their affairs and being too casual about inflationary pressures.
Officials doing preliminary work for this week's meeting said the ministers would strive to resuscitate stalled world trade talks. In addition, in a move that aims to integrate Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia into the West, the ministers have invited officials from those three countries to the session to sign accords that could lead to their membership in the group later in this decade.
At the meeting, which is expected to help define the issues for the Group of Seven summit in London in July, the ministers will also debate whether and how much financial and technical aid the West should give the Soviet Union. The Group of Seven consists of the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada.
 
Upbeat Outlook
 Despite the recessions in the United States and Britain, Jean-Claude Paye, the O.E.C.D.'s secretary general, gave an upbeat economic outlook last week for the industrial world. He said its growth would rebound to 2.5 percent in the second half of this year and 3 percent next year, after being flat in the first half of 1991.
Some officials of the organization acknowledged that these assessments were intentionally buoyant. "There is good reason to intentionally be a little overoptimistic," one official in the organization said. "It's very important for the Group of 24 industrialized countries to give the outside world a hopeful sign."
In recent years the ministerial meetings have emphasized keeping inflation down, liberalizing trade and persuading Washington to reduce its budget deficit. This year there will clearly be more concern about stimulating growth.
"The United States will want everyone to keep their eye on the ball, and growth is an extremely important objective," said one American official, noting that growth will help not only industrial nations, but also Eastern Europe and the third world. This official said that unlike some countries, Washington regards persistent high interest rates "as a problem" and "not a virtue."
 
'Two Schools of Thought'
 The nub of the dispute is that Washington thinks that Germany's powerful central bank might be overzealous in raising rates to fight inflation and that the Bundesbank's high rates are braking growth in Europe and elsewhere. But Germany, enjoying strong growth and seeing its inflation increase, says high rates are warranted.
"There are obviously two schools of thought," said Katsunari Suzuki, Japan's permanent deputy representative to the O.E.C.D. "One is more interested in controlling inflation and the other one is more interested in encouraging economic growth. These two schools of thought naturally reflect the state of the economies in their respective countries."
With its unemployment rising, France backs Washington's call for lower rates, while Japan is in no rush to reduce rates.
In a speech on Thursday in Zurich, Karl Otto Pohl, the departing president of the Bundesbank, gave Washington little hope that Germany's central bankers would bend to pressures to lower rates. "You will understand why interest rates in Germany must be so high," he said. "In real terms, they must be high because we have a crazy demand for capital." 
 
Momentum for Trade Talks
 O.E.C.D. officials see the meeting as an opportunity to put some momentum into the faltering four-and-a-half-year talks to liberalize world trade that are known as the Uruguay Round because they began in that country. Few officials expect major breakthroughs on the issues bogging down the talks, most of all reducing subsidies to farmers, where Washington is at loggerheads with the European Community. Some officials said the ministers would call for reaching an agreement by the end of this year.
The ministers will also debate limiting what is known as tied aid to Eastern Euriope and the Soviet Union. Under these arrangements, industrial nations grant aid on condition that the recipients use the money to buy goods from the donor nations. Washington is pushing for an end to such aid, but some European nations want it continued.

HEADLINE: Rise Seen In Hiring in 3d Quarter

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
Recent graduates and other job seekers may soon find that jobs are not so scarce.
A survey of business hiring plans by Manpower Inc., the nation's largest temporary-employment agency, forecasts a notable upturn in the third quarter, which begins on July 1. Such a development is eagerly awaited by economists since a recovery cannot take hold as long as people are losing jobs and incomes. 
 "This is the first sign of a positive trend we've seen since the third quarter of 1989, when hiring projections began to slide," said Mitchell S. Fromstein, president of Manpower, based in Milwaukee, which conducted the survey.
 
Expansion by 22 Percent
The quarterly survey, published over the weekend, found that 22 percent of 15,000 businesses intended to expand their work forces during the summer while 10 percent planned to cut employment during the quarter, producing what Manpower called a net hiring strength factor of plus 12.
This is considerably ahead of the first two quarters of 1990, when the strength factors were the lowest since 1982, and exceeded the normal jump for this time of year.
When adjusted for seasonal variation, the latest figure of plus seven compares with plus one in the second quarter and represented what Manpower called the first trend reversal after nine straight quarters in which the strength factor either declined or remained unchanged.
 
A Predictive Indicator
 Although employment itself is considered a coincident indicator of business conditions, shifting about the same time as the economy at large, the Manpower survey is regarded as a leading, or predictive, indicator since it deals with intentions. Mr. Fromstein said in an interview that these were usually carried out. "What was projected usually happens," he emphasized.
Another predictive labor market indicator, published each Thursday by the Labor Department, is the number of people who have filed initial claims for unemployment insurance. This series seems to have peaked in March, when claims soared above 500,000, well above the 450,000 level of recent weeks.
The Government's monthly report on the labor market, covering May, is to be published on Friday. Analysts expect further modest payroll job losses, along with a probable uptick in the unemployment rate, which eased two-tenths of a point in April, to 6.6 percent.
Manpower's hiring-strength figures do appear to have anticipated both the brief 1980 recession and the extended 1981-82 recession, though by far the weakest figures were in 1982.
The survey, based on telephone interviews with public and private employers in 476 cities, has been conducted quarterly since 1976.
The latest data showed improvement in all four geographic regions, including the sharply depressed Northeast, where responses remained at 1982 recession levels.
Seasonally adjusted, the Northeast moved from a strength factor of minus seven to zero for the third quarter, with the Midwest improving from four to ten, the South from three to eight and the West from three to seven, according to supplementary Manpower data.
 
Some Exceptions in Gains
 By types of business, all sectors except transportation, public utilities, education and public administration show strong recovery from the second-quarter lows, Manpower said.
The most notable increases are expected to be in construction, the manufacture of nondurable goods and in wholesale and retail trades and services.
Mr. Fromstein remained cautious, however, about the projected upturn in hiring. "It is difficult at this early stage to predict a sustained recovery," he said. "But the first step toward that result is clearly in evidence."
