HEADLINE: Market Place;
Trends Expected To Aid Brinker

BYLINE: By Thomas C. Hayes

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
STOCKS of restaurant companies with casual themes and varied moderate-priced menus have lit up Wall Street this year, rising in market value as a group by nearly 50 percent.
The group is prospering despite the recession because of the bulging numbers of aging adults and families with school-age children who often favor more leisurely full-service meals over quick trips to a McDonald's or Burger King. 
 Analysts say Brinker International Inc., operator of the fast-growing Chili's chain, should continue to outpace much of this group, which also includes Cracker Barrel, Sbarro, Buffets and Shoney's. Brinker's shares closed Friday at $39.125, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. They have risen 69 percent this year.
Michael G. Mueller, restaurant analyst at Montgomery Securities Inc. in San Francisco, said that Brinker, which changed its corporate name last month from Chili's Inc. while retaining the name for the chain, has one of the best-regarded management teams in the restaurant business. "They are good at delivering what they promise and the balance sheet is very strong," he said. "Five years from now, Brinker will be a much bigger company relative to where it is now than a fast-food company like McDonald's."
Demographic trends should help. The number of people in the 45-to-54-year-old age group is expected to increase by 47 percent this decade, with the 35-to-44 age group rising by 18 percent. The 25-to-34 age group will narrow by 15 percent, and the 18-to-24 group by 3 percent.
And big chains controlled just 22 percent of the $75 billion market for moderate-price full-service restaurants last year, compared with 65 percent of the $77 billion fast-food market. That means chains could grow more rapidly by piling up market share in the moderate-price sector, even if a sluggish economy keeps overall sales tepid.
Several analysts expect Brinker's earnings to climb another 50 percent or so by 1993, to about $2.05 a share, compared with an estimated $1.37 for the current fiscal year, which ends on June 30. In the first three months of the year, when the recession and the Persian Gulf war emptied many restaurants, Brinker's sales rose 25 percent, to $107.2 million, and net income rose 71 percent, to $6.4 million, or 34 cents a share.
The company's pretax earnings have soared more than fivefold since 1986, to an estimated $39 million for the 1991 fiscal year. Equity has risen to more than $200 million since the company went public in 1984 with $24 million in equity.
Norman Brinker, the 60-year-old chairman and chief executive, said in an interview that the company calculated a year ago that it should reach $1 billion in sales by 1995, up from $530 million this year, with its total employment increasing to 50,000, from 25,000.
He said the main challenges were internal: developing managers and buying or leasing good locations not only for Chili's but for two new divisions, Regas Grill and Romano's Macaroni Grill. The new concepts were added by acquisitions in 1989 as part of Mr. Brinker's goal of keeping yearly sales and profits growing faster than 20 percent. With no long-term debt except for property leases and with $32 million in cash, Mr. Brinker has few worries about financing more expansion.
Analysts say the rapid growth of Chili's is bound to slow. The chain includes 239 restaurants in 37 states, up from seven locations when Mr. Brinker and his partners acquired control of the Dallas-based company in 1983. They plan to add at least 40 Chili's a year, with an eye toward building Regas Grill and Macaroni Grill into faster-growing generators of sales later in the decade.
Patrons pay an average of $7.50 each on a visit to Chili's, but at the handful of Regas and Romano's sites the average cost is higher, at $15 apiece per person. Regas, with steak and seafood, appeals more to adults. Macaroni Grill is following the path of Olive Garden, a family-style chain featuring varied Italian dishes that General Mills has rapidly expanded in recent years. Brinker has 14 locations for Regas and 3 for Macaroni Grill. Chili's was started in Dallas and expanded nationwide.
An old hand at developing menus for shifting consumer tastes, Mr. Brinker founded the Steak & Ale chain and merged it into the restaurant group of the Pillsbury Company, which included Burger King and later Bennigan's and Poppin' Fresh restaurants. After heading the group for a year, he resigned in 1983 and began anew at Chili's.
Burgers contributed 70 percent of the sales of Chili's in 1984, but Mr. Brinker slowly transformed and broadened the menu. New items like fajitas, salads, barbecue ribs and chicken sandwiches now contribute 60 percent of sales, with burgers at 9 percent.
Brinker's shares are priced at a steep 30 times earnings, but John J. Rohs, a managing director and restaurant analyst at Wertheim Schroder & Company, in New York, said the premium was warranted because of past performance and growth prospects, despite some weakness in recent weeks.
And Steven A. Rockwell of Alex. Brown & Sons Inc., in Baltimore, predicted that the shares could reach $54 in a year if earnings estimates proved accurate. "There is no sign of any weakness in the company's fundamentals," he said. But he added that the overall condition of the market must remain favorable if the stock is to remain strong.

HEADLINE: The Talk Of The Book Show;
Hot Books, Cool Town For 10,000 At Meeting

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
After a steamy and nondescript Saturday, the air-conditioning and some hot books appeared yesterday to give an upbeat twist to the plot involving more than 10,000 booksellers and publishers thrown together, like passengers on a giant ocean liner, in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan.
 It was not that the "R" word had been abruptly conjured away by the fertile literary minds of those attending the four-day American Booksellers Association convention, which ends tomorrow. But nobody had been mugged, and amid the hubbub of publishers imagining great things for their books, the recession did seem to be further away and, with any luck, on the wane. 
 "People came here thinking that having gone through a war and the recession, the worst part of the year was already behind them," said Jack Romanos, the president of Simon & Schuster's mass-market division. "They want to believe that sales will now pick up."
In the first five months of the year, said George Craig, chief executive of HarperCollins, "we have taken a beating on adult fiction, nonfiction and mass-market books."
If there is to be an imminent upturn, an unusually rich array of fall books by best-selling authors should help. Stephen King, Danielle Steel, Len Deighton and Tom Clancy all have new works, and there is even Alexandra Ripley's long-awaited sequel to "Gone With the Wind." But the most talked-about book at the convention was Amy Tan's "The Kitchen God's Wife," her second novel, which is to be published later this year by the Putnam Berkley Group.
"Her impact seems to be so great; we need Amy Tans by the shovelful," said Constance Sayre, a publishing consultant at Market Partners International.
Nothing, however, stirs the imagination of publishers and booksellers like a first novel; the thought of coaxing an undiscovered talent to stardom can send them into paroxysms. Several first novels caused excitement and were being talked about by the hordes of foreign publishers stalking the aisles in pursuit of books that will sell in their markets.
Among them were Donna Tartt's "The God of Illusions" (Alfred A. Knopf), which was being compared to William Golding's "The Lord of the Flies;" J. F. Freedman's thriller "Against the Wind" (Viking Penguin), which some likened to Scott Turow's "Presumed Innocent;" Alan Kuzweil's "A Case of Curiosities" (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich), which is said to evoke Umberto Eco's "The Name of the Rose," and Ethan Canin's "Blue River" (Houghton Mifflin), for which no comparison had emerged.
In nonfiction, pickings were much slimmer. "There is suprisingly little good nonfiction about," said Ashbel Green, a vice president of Alfred A. Knopf. Nik Cohn's "The Heart of the World" (Knopf), a study of Broadway, was one of the few nonfiction works to provoke foreign interest.
How soon all the big new books will have a significant impact on sales remained a much-debated question. "The uplift is there," said William W. Rickman, the president of Kroch's & Brentano's, a chain of 19 stores in the Chicago area. "My impression is, we have bottomed out." But Jack Hoeft, the president of Bantam Doubleday Dell, said, "The fall will be difficult and I see a long pull to Christmas."
The booksellers convention is always frenetic, but it is more so this year because it is being held in New York. There are an estimated 15,000 writers living in New York City, and many have decided the convention provides a rare opportunity to exercise their egos and promote themselves. Of course, they expect suitable hospitality from their publishers.
Moreover, unlike the times when conventions are held out of town, New York publishers have to run their offices at the same time; and when they get home, everyday chores await them. "It's such a drag having to feed the cat, open the mail and cook your own meals," said Pat Connolly, a marketing consultant. "God, I yearn for room service."
Foreigners have also complicated matters by arriving in unprecedented numbers. However squalid its residents may find it, New York still has much glamorous appeal overseas. "It's the first, second, third and fourth worlds combined," explained the writer Gloria Steinem.
There were, for example, 2,300 French publishers in town, according to Antoine Audouard, the managing director of the Paris-based Fixot house. The opening of Eastern Europe has also provoked a novelty: neo-capitalists from the Soviet Union and its former satellites hunting for books. More than ever, publishers thus have had to divide their time between discussions with booksellers -- the original aim of the convention -- and negotiations over foreign rights.
"This time, the A.B.A. is so important because the town is New York, and New York, it IS publishing," said Maria Giulia Castagnone of Milan's Sperling & Kupfer publishers. She had snapped up Bob Woodward's "The Commanders" for the Italian market.
The fact that foreign publishers are New Yorkophiles was evident in the appointment book of Marcella Ber
Mr. Audouard of Fixot described the A.B.A. as indispensable. It was a chance, he said, to breathe "l'air." It was also, he hinted, a chance to make some pretty serious francs. Four years ago, for example, he picked up the French rights to Betty Mahmoodi's "Not Without My Daughter" for $5,000 at the A.B.A. Fixot has sold 2.4 million copies of the book in France.
This A.B.A. seemed a little "muted" -- that was the favored word -- compared with the high jinks of the Las Vegas convention last year. So around noon yesterday, word went out that HarperCollins had what one foreign agent called "an incredibly hot and secret book."
Mr. Craig, chief executive of HarperCollins, was dismayed. "As soon as I find out what it is," he said morosely, "I will let you know."
Even in drab reality, the convention offered some encouragement to American industry. People from throughout the world were in the Javits center looking for books, new marketing ideas and other inspiration. "This is one American industry in which there is very little foreign competition," said Peter Jovanovich, the chief executive of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. "We are still the world leader in the field. You go into a store in Tokyo, and it is dominated by American books."
True value and niches are in. Children's books, religious books and scientific books have all held up much better in the recession than general-interest works. Backlists are being successfully revived -- notably by Bantam Doubleday Dell -- with newly aggressive marketing. A book, it is being recalled, is something to keep, not merely an object with which to make a quick publicity splash.
Typical of the trend is Alfred A. Knopf's re-release of J. M. Dent's Everyman's Library -- classics of literature that will be printed on wove paper with full-cloth, sewn bindings and sold for about $20 each. A year after that, the Random House imprint -- Knopf's rival within the Random House empire -- will reissue the classic Modern Library series with similar fanfare.
"The Everyman idea is a great idea -- people are looking for quality," said Mr. Rickman of Kroch's & Brentano's.
But is the A.B.A. worth it? The convention -- between parties, booths and other promotions -- costs major publishers hundreds of thousands of dollars. In a few cases, the figure goes over $1 million. With the difficult times, this spending is under intense scrutiny.
Taking an unprecedented step, Thomas J. McCormack, the chief executive of St. Martin's Press, withdrew from this year's convention. "I just do not think it is useful," he said. "I can spend that money a lot better on other things."
Mr. Hoeft, the president of Bantam Doubleday Dell, said deciding whether the A.B.A. was worth it was "a tough one. We are going to evaluate it every year." The company has cut its participation at the Frankfurt Book Fair this year. Instead of sending 30 people, it will send about half that number, and the company's booth will be half the size.
Other executives, including Charles E. Hayward, the president of Simon & Schuster's trade book division, said the fact that so many foreign rights sales were now made at the A.B.A. convention added to its value.
The real value, however, may lie elsewhere. In an industry that thrives on people's desire to escape reality through books, the A.B.A. is an opportunity to dream a little and dream together. And if you can talk your way out of a recession, you can probably dream your way, too, especially in the irrational world of books.

HEADLINE: Political Alliance Ruling Panama Breaks Up

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, May 27

 BODY:
The political alliance that fought Panama's military dictatorship for years and led the return to democracy 16 months ago has fallen apart, with the Christian Democratic Party going into opposition to the Government of which it was previously the strongest component.
Both sides say this was a normal step at some point in the democratic transition, although Ricardo Arias Calderon, the Christian Democratic leader, said he thought it was "premature." 
 "But the initiative was not ours," he added.
 A combination of differences over economic changes and animosities over the power exercised by various people appear to have led to the decision of President Guillermo Endara to oust the Christian Democrats in April.
The rupture was preceded by days of venting of political emotions in which Mr. Endara accused Mr. Arias of trying to tap his telephones and the President's wife, Ana Mae de Endara, asserted that the Christian Democrats had used parliamentary tactics amounting to a coup attempt.
Ruben Carles, the Comptroller General, whose influence over economic policy was one thing the Christian Democrats had criticized, said the Christian Democrats "had thought they were in a position to push the President around, but they miscalculated."
Constitutionally, Mr. Arias Calderon remains First Vice President in the Government that was elected in May 1989 and took office after the removal of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in the United States' invasion of December 1989. But he has no office and no assigned duties, and his party lost the five Cabinet posts it held, along with other important jobs.
"I now consider myself the chief of the democratic opposition," Mr. Arias said. "We are going to examine rigorously all Government proposals, but with strict respect for democracy."
The Christian Democrats are the largest single force in the National Assembly, with 28 seats; what is now the three-party Government coalition has 27 seats. The Democratic Revolutionary Party, or P.R.D., the political organization created by Omar Torrijos Herrera, who preceded Mr. Noriega as the military strongman, assumes new importance because its 10 seats allow it to form a majority with either side.
"This gives new life to the followers of Torrijos and Noriega," Mr. Arias said. "We think the P.R.D. will ask for some tolerance by the Government for crimes of the past."
Mr. Carles, who like Mr. Arias was exiled by General Torrijos and came back at the beginning of the 1980's to help build the opposition, said the other forces in the Government had no disagreement with the Christian Democrats over the need to maintain democracy and respect for human rights.
"But the Christian Democrats need to define themselves more on economic questions, like repaying the foreign debt and going forward with privatizations," he said.
Mr. Carles argued strongly for recognizing and repaying the debt, which he put at $6 billion, as a means of restoring Panama's credit standing. But he asserted that the Christian Democrats had doubts on that point.
Mr. Arias said he felt that the Government had paid too much attention to restoring credibility in the eyes of foreign creditors and not enough attention to repaying some of the "social debt" that had built up in recent years among the poorest Panamanians.
"This Government has done nothing to help those who will suffer from the economic reorganization," he said. "We want a government oriented more toward the middle and lower-middle classes."
Mr. Carles said that many of the belt-tightening measures being undertaken by the Government at the behest of creditors and would-be creditors, like raising the retirement age for women from 50 to 60, were necessitated by the fact that "during the military dictatorship the Government granted special favors to everybody."
"The holiday is over now," he said. "This Government wants to eliminate special privileges, so everybody is against us." But he added, "A democracy needs an opposition -- an intelligent opposition pursuing issues."

HEADLINE: Americans Complain of Bias By Japanese Bosses in U.S.

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif.

 BODY:
As more and more Japanese companies open for business in the United States, Americans contend that there is a new kind of discrimination: They say Japanese employers are reserving the best jobs for Japanese managers.
There are no statistics to document the extent of the problem, and it clearly does not apply to every Japanese employer in the United States. Japanese companies employ less than 1 percent of 118 million working Americans. 
 But some mighty names in Japanese industry -- Matsushita, Sumitomo, NEC Electronics -- settled lawsuits charging discrimination against American managers in just the past year.
 
Top-Heavy With Japanese
 Beyond specific complaints of discrimination, critics say Japanese companies in the United States are top-heavy with Japanese managers. Japanese men hold more than half of the top 20 or so management jobs in many Japanese banks and trading companies in America, and sometimes all but one or two.
The proportions are smaller in most manufacturing companies, but they still far exceed the proportions of Europeans in the top ranks of European companies in America, or of Americans in American companies abroad, corporate consultants say. As Japanese companies continue to expand in the United States, these consultants say that the big ones are redoubling their efforts to avoid discrimination but that the arrival of smaller, less sophisticated newcomers presage more skirmishes with American employees.
Some recent cases put the issue in stark relief. In a lawsuit against a Ricoh Corporation plant here, to be heard in September in Federal District Court in San Francisco, Chet Mackentire, a former top marketing executive making about $75,000 a year, says he was dismissed solely because he was American.
Mr. Mackentire asserts that after he paved the way for the company to reach American customers with a new product, optical disks used for storing information in computers, his functions were assigned to a Japanese man. "They keep us long enough to learn what we know," he said. "Americans are disposable commodities for them."
 
'Reasonable Cause' to Sue
 Investigators for the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission found that Mr. Mackentire had a reasonable cause to sue. The commission investigators wrote that the Japanese man was less qualified for the job, in both experience and education, than Mr. Mackentire, and that the atmosphere at the company was "tainted with national origin bias." Americans, the finding said, would be excluded from meetings of their Japanese bosses and subordinates.
The Japanese do not deny that they rely heavily on Japanese managers, but they attribute that reliance to cultural considerations, not discrimination. Because the Japanese share a common tradition and approach to doing business, they say, it is simply more efficient and comfortable for them to look to themselves for leadership, at least for now.
"We admit that the number of Americans in management is quite limited," said Takii Mitsuo, executive director of the Japanese External Trade Organization in New York, which promotes trade with the United States. "Japanese companies like to keep management the Japanese way. It's due to cultural and language issues. They need the deep human relationships that they have with the parent companies in Tokyo."
Justin L. Camerlengo, a spokesman for the Matsushita Electric Industrial Corporation of America, added that Japanese companies were cautious with their American investments. "They like to watch them for a long period of time before turning them over," he said. At a fast-growing Matsushita factory in Georgia with 750 employees, Mr. Camerlengo said, 42 of 100 managers are Japanese, but that is down from 58 a year or two ago. He added the number would continue to slide.
Late last year, a Federal court in Chicago penalized the Quasar television set company, a Matsushita subsidiary in Franklin Park, Ill., $2.5 million in damages for discrimination on grounds of national origin, a violation of the 1964 Civil Rights law. Three managers had complained that the company had dismissed 66 American managers to cut costs five years ago but retained all its Japanese managers. The company is appealing the decision.
The defenders of Japanese companies find additional support, or at least understanding, from some American experts.
In view of Japan's commercial success, Robert E. Cole, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley who has studied the the Japanese automobile industry in the United States, said "it's easy to think your way is best."
"They tend to be less willing to relinquish control to local units," Mr. Cole said of the Japanese. "The power is really kept in Tokyo."
It is possible, too, that the Japanese are no more discriminatory than Americans -- that they just have not lived in a society that has sensitized people against open displays of discrimination.
"In the United States we have this notion that discrimination is wrong," said Linda Krieger, a former Equal Employment Opportunity Commission lawyer who is now a lecturer at Stanford Law School. "So we're more covert -- even if we have the same attitudes."
But to critics, the heavy reliance on managers of a single nationality -- and, for that matter, on men -- betrays ignorance or open defiance of American law. The law protects people of various nationalities, Americans included, from workplace discrimination in just the same way that it protects women and minority groups.
Job discrimination by the Japanese is a delicate issue, and American and Japanese officials discuss it reluctantly. The Bush Administration, eager to lure Japanese investment to the United States, treats the issue gingerly. And the last thing the Japanese say they need is to be labled as chauvinists, which could taint the rapport they have built with American consumers.
The Standard & Poor's directory of corporations shows 11 Japanese names among 13 officers listed by the Sumitomo Bank of California in San Francisco, and 47 among 72 names at the Bank of Tokyo Trust Company in New York, some of whom are likely to be Americans of Japanese descent. But the Bank of California in San Francisco, owned by Mitsubishi and once a target of a Federal affirmative action investigation, shows just two Japanese names among 48 officers.
Some Japanese companies are clearly trying hard to diversify their work forces, in some cases after skirmishes with the courts and Federal regulators. The automotive giants Toyota, Honda and Nissan have relatively small numbers of Japanese executives in the United States and growing representations of female and minority workers in their American operations.
Still, the records of public agencies that investigate job discrimination show a pattern of complaints against Japanese companies, especially here in California, which has 246 of the 1,433 American manufacturing plants that are owned entirely or partly by the Japanese. In response to a legally enforceable request from The New York Times under the Freedom of Information Act, the Labor Department's Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs in San Francisco disclosed agreements negotiated with eight Japanese employers to end discriminatory practices, mostly over the last three years.
 
Not Particularly Meaningful
 The number of agreements is not particularly meaningful. The regional office, which covers California, Nevada, Arizona and Hawaii, investigated 454 companies last year, mostly in California, and all but 86 were found in violation of antidiscrimination regulations, most of them minor. No record is kept of the national ownership of the companies investigated, and the eight were just those the staff knew to be Japanese. But the number appears roughly in line with the relatively small number of Japanese companies in the United States.
Although none of the eight employers admitted to wrongdoing, all were found with multiple violations of the Presidential order that authorizes the compliance office to investigate companies and audit their affirmative action programs. The violations dealt with the entire work forces, including managers. Several of the companies were found to have minuscule numbers of female, black and Hispanic workers, even though many qualified women and minority members lived nearby. Others had not instituted affirmative action programs, with the attendant hiring plans and records of work-force composition.
At the Ricoh plant in San Jose, officials referred questions about Mr. Mackentire's lawsuit to the company's lawyer, Dov M. Grunschlag. "The company's position is simply that he was laid off as part of a reduction in force in a division that was losing money and where all the middle management positions were eliminated at the same time," Mr. Grunschlag said. "There's nothing unusual in that. In certain economic conditions, that happens."
But no Japanese, either workers or managers, were dismissed. And the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, in determining that Mr. Mackentire had cause to sue, contended that the Japanese man who replaced him was less qualified for the job in both experience and education.
 
Lawsuits Settled
 Japanese companies are also accused of discrimination against rank-and-file workers, although their record in this regard appears no better or worse than that of American companies. Since the start of the 1980's, at least a score of other companies, including Honda, Hitachi, and several banks, have settled suits by employees or charges by Federal agencies for discriminating against women and minority members.
One case is the first involving a Japanese company that the E.E.O.C. is pursuing in Federal court on its own, rather than leaving it to plaintiffs. It concerns a Los Angeles employment agency affiliated with Recruit Cosmos, the real estate company at the center of the stock and influence-peddling scandal that toppled Prime Minister Takeshita last year.
The commission says workers at the employment agency, Interplace/ Transworld Recruit, which specialized in placing workers for Japanese employers in California, devised their own variations of a practice that the E.E.O.C. has recently found several American-owned employment agencies to be using as well. Interplace agents used code words among themselves to specify potential workers by sex, race and nationality. "Talk to Adam" meant the employer wanted a man. "Talk to Mariko" meant he wanted a Japanese. "Talk to Eve; suite 20-30" meant the client wanted a white woman aged 20 to 30.
The employment agency's lawyer, Walter Cochran-Bond, would not discuss the charges, saying the company was in the midst of negotiations to reach a settlement.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chet Mackentire, a former top marketing executive at the Ricoh Corporation plant in San Jose, Calif., says he was dismissed solely because he is American. (Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times) (pg. B6)

HEADLINE: CASH CRISES FORCE LOCALITIES IN U.S. TO SLASH SERVICES

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
Weakened by recession and by drastic reductions in state and Federal aid, cities and counties around the country are shedding or slashing many of the services that have helped define their mission for decades.
As mayors and governing bodies try to balance their budgets for the 1992 fiscal year, which begins on July 1 for most, the reductions are epidemic. Honolulu is cutting back on road repairs. Sacramento, Calif., cannot open its new main library. Salt Lake City cannot build a fire station for a growing neighborhood. Houston is eliminating 111 hospital beds for indigent patients. Bridgeport, Conn., plans to stop cleaning its streets on July 1 and may stop guarding its beaches this summer. 
 Urban experts and mayors around the country say that not since the 1930's have so many cities faced such crippling fiscal constraints or lack of Federal, state and taxpayer support. "Cities are facing the toughest times since the Great Depression," said Mayor Sidney J. Barthelemy of New Orleans, president of the National League of Cities.
 
'The Day of Reckoning'
 Urban specialists confirm that bleak assessment and say the new fiscal year will bring a huge shakeout in services. "The day of reckoning cannot be put off any longer," said Richard P. Nathan, director of the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University of New York in Albany.
To be sure, some welcome the day of reckoning. Daniel J. Mitchell, an economist who is a senior fellow at the Heritage Foundation, a Washington research organization that stresses private enterprise, said the end of the boom of the 1980's would "hopefully force these governments to not waste so much money."
The hardest-hit cities and counties are in the Northeast and Middle West, which have lost tax revenue as jobs and businesses fall victim to the recession. But Western and Southern cities with stronger economies are also struggling to meet the service demands of their growing populations.
As cities raise taxes and cut spending, economists fear that the money taken from consumers' pockets could inhibit recovery from the recession.
Researchers may take months to provide a national picture of the changes occurring in city budgets and services, but 50 interviews with professional organizations and municipal officials across the country provide a snapshot report. Whether the cities surveyed were large or small, growing or shrinking, well managed or not, officials in most places said they had already made all of the easy budget reductions and had begun cutting highly visible, direct services.
The service reductions and tax increases are driving out middle-class residents, leaving behind people with a greater share of social problems and needs, further adding to the cities' burdens. This trend makes it harder and harder for cities to muster the kind of broad political support that gave rise to Federal antipoverty programs in the 1960's and revenue sharing in the 1970's. "I'm pretty pessimistic," Mr. Nathan said.
He and other experts say that cities cannot possibly solve their social problems alone, but that no one wants to help them until local officials prove that they know what they are doing and can spend money wisely.
 
The Libraries Suffer
 The decline of public libraries is one barometer of the problems facing local governments across the country. "These are the worst cutbacks that libraries have gone through in this century," said Linda F. Crismond, executive director of the American Library Association.
The library association recently conducted a 50-state survey that found widespread reductions in hours and many branch closings. In Montana, Missoula Public Library was recently closed for three weeks. In Massachusetts, cities closed 20 branch libraries and many bookmobiles. In Pennsylvania, the state plans to reduce library aid by $2.5 million.
Even some libraries in high-growth states like Nevada are, as one librarian put it, "planning for disaster." In New York, Mayor David N. Dinkins has proposed a 33 percent reduction that will, according to his budget statement, "result in many branch closings and reduced days of service in all boroughs."
Sacramento spent $25 million building its new downtown Central Library and had expected to open it in January 1992. But the city, which faces a $26 million gap in its $234 million budget for fiscal year 1992, plans to delay the opening for six months.
"We've never had this much of a budget deficit," said Sacramento's Mayor, Anne Rudin. But she conceded that in searching for ways to save money she had found some surprising inefficiencies. "Every time someone needs medical help and calls 911, they get an ambulance and a fire truck," she said.
In St. Louis, Mayor Vincent C. Schoemehl Jr. decided that hot-house flowers are expendable. The city is closing its Jewel Box, an Art Deco glass and steel pavilion of greenhouses that is a St. Louis institution. "A tropical rain forest is not part of the central mission of St. Louis," the Mayor said.
The big cities have the big problems, but thousands of counties and small cities are also slashing services. Facing what officials call its worst and most chaotic budget problems in memory, Suffolk County, L.I., has begun furloughing most of its 12,000 employees every Friday. Yet the furloughs, which are reducing street cleaning, nursing home programs, consumer-protection investigations and hundreds of other services, will make up only $4.5 million of the county's $60 million budget gap this fiscal year.
Nearly all of the nation's 425 counties with populations over 100,000 are also looking to reduce services or raise taxes or both, said James D. Golden, director of research for the National Association of Counties. "I would say that we have more counties in a fiscal crunch than ever before," he said, "and it is going to get worse because counties typically lag behind cities by about two years in feeling the effects of reduced Federal and state funding."
And the smaller counties have the most problems. "Rural America has had a tough time for the last five years, what with farm problems and unemployment. The situation is bad and it's getting worse," Mr. Golden said.
If Bangor, Me., cannot raise $50,784 in tax revenue to pay "the world's best children's dentist," in the words of City Manager Edward A. Barrett, Bangor will lose $64,500 in Federal Medicaid grants, and more than 600 indigent children will be at risk of decaying teeth.
The dentist, Dr. John C. Frachella, is so highly prized that his 20-year-old dental clinic for the children of low-income families appears on Mr. Barrett's "end of the world scenario" of service reductions.
In California, where the tax revolt began in 1978 when voters halved their property taxes by passing Proposition 13, many cities are having trouble. In 1989, cities collected 17 percent less tax revenue per person than they did in 1978, according to James R. Harrington, the assistant director of the League of California Cities. Last year, almost a third of California's cities cut services, and a quarter raised taxes.
Los Angeles is facing a $177 million gap in next year's budget, after having just closed a $126 million gap in the current year's budget with service reductions and salary reductions.
 The city is considering cutting the 8,417-member police force by not hiring officers to replace 445 who leave. Mayor Tom Bradley has proposed reductions in library hours, tree trimming, park and recreation programs, traffic signal repairs and street resurfacing, along with new taxes on property transfers and cable television and increases in water and sewer fees.
San Francisco officials say they are still cutting into the fat of government. "We are a shining example of a city that is not slashing services," said Scott Shafer, press secretary to Mayor Art Agnos. The city froze the wages of city workers, laid off 150 people, raised parking taxes and transit fares to rein in a projected $135 million gap in next year's $1.36 billion budget.
Philadelphia has yet to get its finances under control. City Council's budget proposals, considered speculative at best, do not reduce services, but do not provide $26 million for the projected growth in demand for programs for abused children or an $11 million subsidy owed to local mass transit.

HEADLINE: U.S. Officials Believe Iraq Will Take Years to Rebuild

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
Three months after the Persian Gulf war devastated Iraq's military and many of its civilian industries, the country remains seriously incapacitated, facing a potentially catastrophic health crisis this summer and many years of rebuilding its civilian economy, Bush Administration analysts say.
A comprehensive assessment of the damage from the intense 43-day allied bombardment remains classified within the Administration, which has been reluctant to divulge details. But an overview of the damage to key sectors of Iraq's economy emerged in recent days from a series of interviews with Administration analysts, who agreed to discuss it if they were not identified. 
 The assessment indicates that Iraq's electrical power industry may have been damaged well beyond the intentions of allied war planners, who developed a still-secret weapon that dropped thousands of metallic filaments onto the electrical network at key points to create huge short-circuits and blackouts on the night of January 17th, when the war began. This was followed by precision strikes on power plants.
 
Most Power Still Out
 Even now, 80 percent of the the nation's power grid is out of service, and electrical shortages are aggravating the crisis in health care.
In addition, allied warplanes wrecked Iraq's civilian telecommunications system, described as a total loss by one estimate; and the bombing campaign seriously damaged the national network of roads and bridges, crippling commerce in a nation that straddles two major river valleys, those of the Tigris and the Euphrates. Generally, the war damage seems less visible in Baghdad than in many areas of the countryside.
The critical sector of oil production, the dynamo that drives Iraq's economy, requires a major infusion of cash, about $1.5 billion, to get its export pipelines going at prewar levels; and Iraq may not be able to maintain its gasoline production without Western technology, spare parts and expertise in the near term. Because of the international trade sanctions imposed after the invasion of Kuwait, however, Iraq has been unable to import urgently needed equipment and has not sold a cargo of oil, its principal source of income, since last August.
One of the major mysteries remains how many Iraqi soldiers and civilians died. United States intelligence agencies assert that they have not addressed this question and the Bush Administration has not indicated any official interest.
Intelligence officers connected with the United States Central Command conducted what they described as a purely mathematical exercise at the end of the war to estimate Iraqi war dead by subtracting prisoners of war and an assumed percentage of deserters and then assigning a mortality rate to those Iraqis who remained on the battlefield.
By this method, the command derived an unofficial death toll of about 100,000 Iraqi soldiers, and Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the allied commander, was said to have provided this unofficial tally in private briefings to members of Congress.
Some analysts have questioned this unofficial number, arguing that the United States estimate of 540,000 Iraqi troops in the war zone overstated the size of Iraqi forces and that desertion rates were underestimated. They also argued that such a large number of battle deaths would have been accompanied by at least as many wounded, and that no evidence of this has been detected by foreign relief agencies working with Iraq's medical system.
The Iraqi Government has not come forward with any authoritative estimate of war dead. Other unofficial estimates of Iraqi war dead have put the figure at 25,000 to 50,000.
 
Civilian Death Toll
 Allied war planners sought to minimize civilian deaths in Iraq, though there were notable mistakes, including the attack on an air raid shelter in Baghdad that apparently killed more than 300 civilians.
A report issued this month by the environmental group Greenpeace estimated the number of Iraqi civilians killed during the war at 5,000 to 15,000, based on a review of statements by allied officials and other unofficial sources.
Overall, the American analysts say, the Iraqis are struggling precariously under a patchwork of short-term fixes and remedies that will probably deteriorate in the months ahead if the Bush Administration maintains trade sanctions in an effort to force President Saddam Hussein from power.
 
Similarity to U.N. Report
 The Bush Administration's internal findings parallel those reported by a special United Nations mission to Iraq in March, which concluded that because of the damage inflicted on it, "Iraq has, for some time to come, been relegated to a pre-industrial age, but with all the disabilities of post-industrial dependency on an intensive use of energy and technology."
Some Administration officials had criticized the United Nations report, prepared under the supervision of Under Secretary General Martti Ahtissari, for describing the damage to Iraq with terms like "near apocalyptic." But in their detailed review of each sector of Iraq's economy, the United Nations and United States assessments are not dissimiliar.
The Central Intelligence Agency estimates a national repair bill in Iraq of up to $30 billion, about half of which would have to come from hard currency earnings on resumed shipments of oil to world markets. Add to this the $8 billion Iraq owes this year on its $80 billion in national debt, none of which has been paid, and a yet-to-be-determined bill for war reparations to Kuwait, and the outline of Iraq's post-war economic crisis takes an ominous shape, with or without Mr. Hussein.
 
Risks of U.S. Policy
 Some analysts within the Administration suggested that its policy of maintaining sanctions was a risky course, both because of its impact on the Iraqi people and because it may backfire or fail.
One senior analyst said that as the Bush Administration discovered last fall when sanctions did not dislodge Iraq from Kuwait, there is no direct linkage between economic pain and political change in a police state like Iraq. This makes a sanctions-based strategy "inherently unpredictable," he said.
"To the extent Iraqis are convinced that life will be abnormal and harsh as long as Saddam is around, that is clearly an incentive for change," the senior analyst said. "But in a regime based on fear, the primordial interests of survival suggest that people would rather go hungry than take the risk of being dead."
United States analysts say they do not know how much Mr. Hussein has in the way of hard currency to buy food and medicine in the short term, which he has been permitted to do since the United Nations began allowing humanitarian shipments on March 22. While $4 billion of Iraqi cash is frozen in foreign banks, they say Iraq is close to exhausting its cash reserves.
At the outset of the war, the Bush Administration said its objectives included the elimination of Iraq's offensive war making ability and weapons of mass destruction. But in carrying out a strategy to achieve these goals, the Pentagon appears to have miscalculated the multiplying effects on public health of its large-scale destruction of Iraq's electricial power system, which fed civilian as well as military industries.
The system powered water purification and sewage treatment plants, the loss of which led to a sharp increase in disease during and after the war.
A report issued by a Harvard University study team this month said that "the collapse of electrical generating capacity has been a crucial factor in this public health catastrophe." The team predicted tens of thousands of additional war-related deaths by the end of the year, a finding the Administration has not disputed.
"Without electricity, hospitals cannot function, perishable medicines spoil, water cannot be purified and raw sewage cannot be processed," the study team's report said.
 
Short-Circuiting Power System
 Many of Iraq's electrical power plants were struck on the first night of the allied air war. Iraqi engineers and technicians later told Western visitors that allied warplanes dropped thousands of metallic filaments onto electrical transformers and power lines, causing a spectacular short-circuiting process.
"It was really metallic threads, like a person's hair, very fine," said Julia Devin, a member of the Harvard team that toured Iraq in late April and early May and who returned with samples of the filaments collected from Iraqi plant technicians.
An Air Force official this week confirmed the description of the attack.
Tomahawk cruise missiles and guided bombs dropped from warplanes thereafter destroyed individual generating units, and these repeated attacks knocked out half of the country's generating capacity and damaged a large part of the other half, according to one Administration analysis.
An Iraqi official last week said engineers had restored 1,580 megawatts of generating capacity out of what Western officials say was a prewar level of about 9,000 megawatts.
The Iraqi Government announced this week that eight-hour daily blackouts will be a continuing feature even where electricity has been restored in major cities. Many smaller towns and villages still are without electricity.
The longer term prospects for repairing the system may deteriorate due to the country's lack of access to Western technology, spare parts and expertise.
 
Communications Badly Hit
 Of equally high priority on the allied target list was Iraq's telecommunications sector. Bombers struck telephone exchanges, microwave relay stations and cable networks, along with dedicated military links.
The multibillion-dollar telecommunications system that Iraq had built with state-of-the-art Western technology is the most severely damaged segment of Iraq's civilian economy, United States analysts say.
"The Iraqis are going to have to completely rebuild the system and they cannot do it without foreign equipment and expertise," said one analyst.
While some telephone and telex circuits to the outside world and among major Iraqi ministries and military complexes have been restored, most Iraqis are likely to be without telephone service for the foreseeable future.
 
Oil Production Resumed
 Iraq resumed oil production in April and, according to a Central Intelligence Agency estimate, could be exporting one million barrels per day -- about a third of its prewar production level -- by summer's end if sanctions are lifted. With a $1.5 billion investment in new pumps for its export pipelines through Turkey and Saudi Arabia, Iraq could be exporting 2.7 million barrels per day by the end of 1992, according to the C.I.A. estimate.
Refining oil for domestic gasoline consumption has been more problematical. Most major refineries suffered serious damage and Iraqi engineers will need foreign assistance and parts to repair them.
Repairs at two large refineries enabled Iraq to lift gasoline rationing this month, but United States analysts say they are not sure the country can maintain gasoline output without access to spare parts and chemical additives produced outside the country.
 
Damage to Transportation
 Iraq's highway and rail system is pocked by bomb craters and downed bridges. About 40 major bridges across the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers will have to be replaced, which can probably be done without foreign assistance, analysts say. Another 10 bridges are seriously damaged.
Perhaps as important as this damage, Iraq's only tire factory, whose output served the whole country until it shutdown last fall, remains idled by lack of access to imported raw materials.
Though Iraqi military engineers have worked around much of the damage with temporary bridges, transportation disruptions and bottlenecks, especially in southern Iraq around Basra, will have a significant impact on traffic and distribution for many months if not years.
 
Public Health Endangered
 The threat to public health in Iraq is of great concern to international relief agencies and health experts. Daily power blackouts are causing re-contamination of some drinking water supplies and threaten the country's ability to operate sanitary hospital wards and operating rooms, where refrigeration of drugs, vaccines and blood is of critical importance.
Some back-up generators have failed for lack of fuel and parts.
United States analysts said the compounding effect of continued poor sanitation in many parts of the country, the onset of summer heat and shortages of doctors and nurses could speed the growth of cholera, typhoid and gastroenteritis that may already have claimed tens of thousands of lives. Many foreign health workers left Iraq before and during the war and have not returned.
Inflation has priced baby formula above the income level of many poor families, and transportation problems along with the closing of many regional health clinics have seriously retarded the level of health care services.Increasing child mortality is the most serious concern, public health experts and relief officials say.

HEADLINE: Fiscal Epic by Moscow and Harvard Gets Skeptical Reviews

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
It resembled a Hollywood deal.
First, a group of Soviet economists with another raw script for Soviet economic reform teamed up with rewrite men from Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government. Then they acquired a catchy working title: "The Grand Bargain." 
 They put out their idea in the form of an op-ed piece in The Washington Post by a Harvard professor, Jeffrey Sachs. All that remained was cajoling one major studio -- the Soviet Union -- into making the film and a major consortium of Western industrialized democracies -- led by the United States -- into bankrolling it.
Whatever the outcome, the process has raised both hopes and hackles in the Bush Administration, which prides itself on having a pretty fair stable of deal makers and scriptwriters of its own. "An economic program written in the Soviet Union and perfected at the Kennedy School?" the Deputy Secretary of State, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, harrumphed to colleagues in the West Wing of the White House last week. "What could be better? At least they are ideologically compatible."
 
Grumbling in the Capital
 And while President Bush late last week made Western aid for Soviet reform seem to be a possibility -- though no numbers remotely resembling the Grand Bargain's $30 billion annually were mentioned -- grumbling could be heard for days beforehand in the State Department, the Defense Department and the White House. The gist of the discontent: that the Harvard academics may have given the Soviet economists unrealistic expectations, setting them and their political backers up for disappointment.
The essence of the Grand Bargain is a simple quid pro quo: massive infusion of Western aid up to $30 billion annually, with $3 billion or so coming directly from the United States. In return, the Soviets were to undertake fundamental economic reforms, moving their system from a command economy to a market one. Built into the plan are stages, incentives, carrots and sticks.
The $30 billion, which would be tied to continuing reforms in both the economic and political spheres, would help ease inflation caused by making the ruble a convertible currency, shore up transportation and communications, and finance importing consumer goods.
But the appearance of this proposal and the brainstorming sessions between the Harvard group and a team of Soviet economists led by Grigory A. Yavlinsky blurred the lines between those who teach government and those who govern, according to several Administration officials.
 
Grand Design or Grand Mischief?
 Even though the shuttle flights linking Boston, New York and Washington have long been populated with academics bearing policy prescriptions, Administration officials are discomfited and a bit dyspeptic at what they describe as well-meaning but potentially mischievous meddling.
The situation has produced a classic standoff between the styles of the Cambridge classroom and those of the Washington office. What one side calls "vision" the other calls "hubris;" what one group sees as prudence, the other sees as bureaucratic narrowmindedness.
"First of all, what we are trying to do is push back the edge of the envelope," said one of the Cambridge-based architects of the Grand Bargain, retreating, Washington-style, into anonymity. "We can do it because we don't have the pressures of government. The notion that we should curtail our imagination at a truly revolutionary moment doesn't seem right to me."
Commenting on the kind of reception academic prescriptions receive in Washington, one Administration official acknowledged, "You always have the 'not invented here' problem.
"But the difficulty is that there are substantive problems. The mischief here is talking about dollar figures for which these guys bear no responsibility."
 
'Boutique Foreign Policy'
 Referring to another Harvard professor involved in the project, Robert D. Blackwill, the Administration official added: "It's easy for Blackwill or Sachs to say we ought to have $30 billion or $3 billion or $1 billion. But none of them have to persuade Congress to make the cuts that would obviously have to come.
"If these numbers really increased official expectations in the Soviet Union, then it really was mischievous."
Another problem with independent deal-making in diplomacy, he said, is that it is unclear who speaks for whom. "Just as we don't know to what extent Yavlinsky speaks for Gorbachev, the Soviets may have trouble knowing who speaks for the Administration," he said.
Another Administration official expressed some of the same skepticism that once led President Bush to refer scornfully to "foreign policy from the boutique at Harvard Yard."
"It reflects a certain way of thinking about solving political and economic problems," this Administration official said. "Clever, but ultimately technocratic. 'We can tell them what to do with the right combination of carrots and sticks.' It's a little presumptuous."
Mr. Sachs, who is credited as the architect of the painful economic reform under way in Poland, answered: "I'm on leave from Harvard working in the real world. I don't regard this as an academic venture.
"I'm not promising Soviet reform. I'm not reading Gorbachev's mind. What I believe is that there is a moment to make something possible. But I would not give a penny before we have a very clear idea of what they are ready to do."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Primary Offers Outlet for Voter Tax Anger

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 31

 BODY:
After months of anger among taxpayers and fear among Democrats, legislators face the voters in party primaries on Tuesday for the first time since some of the lawmakers voted for Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax package.
There is no statewide office on the ballot to heighten voter interest, and there is only a handful of contests in the 40 election district races. As a result, Midge Trainor, director of the state Division of Elections, estimates that only about 11.5 percent of the state's 3.6 million voters will go the polls, which will be open between 7 A. M. and 8 P.M. 
 About 1.7 million registered voters are independents who cannot vote in the party primaries unless they go to the polls and declare themselves a member of the party in whose election they wish to participate. There are about 1.2 million registered Democrats and 774,000 Republicans.
 
Focus on Democratic Party
 Each legislative district, with an average population of 193,000 people, is represented by one senator and two Assembly members. The Democrats hold a 23 to 17 majority in the Senate and a 43 to 37 edge in the General Assembly.
The Republican Party is hoping that a replay of the outrage over taxes that almost unseated Governor Florio's fellow Democrat, United States Senator Bill Bradley, last November will divide the Democratic Party in the primary and help the Republicans capture one or both legislative houses in the fall.
But Steve DeMicco, executive director of the State Democratic Committee, said he was "gratified" by the low number of contests in the Democratic primary and the fact that challenges keyed to the Governor's tax program had been "milder" than he expected.
"We're not encountering the number of angry contests predicted by the Republicans," he said. "We'll have no trouble coming together as a party after the primary.
"There is some anger and some frustration among voters that will surface in November, but I believe it is more bipartisan than the Republicans hope. There will be problems to be faced over economic issues, taxes, auto insurance and health insurance costs, but a larger issue is how we're conducting politics and what people think of government, and that's an issue both parties have to address."
Assemblyman Robert D. Franks, the state Republican chairman, said that despite the comparatively quiet Democratic primary, there was still a reservoir of anger over the Democratic administration's policies that could be tapped in November.
"The edge may be off slightly, because it takes a lot of energy to stay angry," he said, "but the anger and frustration over the administration's failure to deal with people in a real way is still there."
In addition to the party candidates who will be on Tuesday's ballot, more than four dozen independent and minor party candidates have filed for the November legislative election.
Mr. Franks said the Republican Party also was supporting the candidacies of more black and Hispanic candidates, "and we're doing it beyond those districts with large minority populations."
In the Seventh District in Burlington County, now represented by Democrats in the Senate and both Assembly seats, the Republican candidates for the Assembly will be Jose F. Sosa, the deputy mayor of Mount Holly, and Priscilla B. Anderson, the Mayor of Willingboro, who is black. They are unopposed in the Republican primary.
In the 11th District in Monmouth County, Mayor Thomas Smith of Asbury Park, a black, will be one of two Republicans running for Assembly seats now held by Democrats.
The reapportionment of the state's 40 legislative districts after the 1990 census also created more problems for Democrats than it did for the Republicans, since most of the population shift was away from urban areas represented by the majority party. The combination of district changes and voter anger prompted a number of Democratic legislators to pass up the coming election.
One veteran Democrat, former Senate President Carmen A. Orechio of Nutley, saw his 30th Legislative District in suburban Essex County moved to the south to form a new district that extends from Lakewood in Ocean County to Bordentown in Burlington. Mr. Orechio found himself in the 36th District represented by a fellow Democrat, Senator Gabriel M. Ambrosio of Lyndhurst, and decided to call it a career after 18 years.
Other Democrats whose names will be missing from Tuesday's ballot include former Senate President John F. Russo of Toms River; the Senate majority leader, Daniel J. Dalton of Turnersville; Senator Richard Van Wagner of Middletown, and Assemblymen David C. Schwartz of New Brunswick, Frank M. Pelly of North Brunswick, Michael F. Adubato of Newark, Edward H. Salmon of Millville, James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge and Joseph D. Patero of Manville.
 
Key Contest in Middlesex
 By contrast, the only Republican who decided not to seek a new term is former Assembly Speaker Chuck Hardwick of Westfield.
The most closely watched primary contest is the one for the Democratic Senate nomination in the 18th District in Middlesex County, where the incumbent, Thomas H. Paterniti of Edison, who has been in the Legislature for 12 years, is being challenged by Harry S. Pozycki, a former Metuchen Councilman. Party officials say each man could spend $150,000 before the campaign ends.
In the neighboring 19th District the party is trying to oust one of its former stalwarts, George Otlowski of Perth Amboy, who has been in the General Assembly 18 years. Mr. Otlowski, who recently resigned as Mayor of Perth Amboy, is considered a liability because of city problems he encountered as Mayor.
But Mr. Otlowski is not leaving without a fight. He has filed for a new nomination against the regular Democratic organization slate of Thomas J. Deverin of Carteret, an incumbent, and Jay Ziznewski of Perth Amboy, a newcomer.
In the 15th District in Mercer County, which includes Trenton, the State Capital, G. Dallas Dixon of Trenton, the former Mercer County Democratic chairman, is running for one of the two Assembly nominations against the incumbents he supported in the past, Gerard S. Naples and John S. Watson, both of Trenton.
 
Fight Among Republicans
 The Republicans are not without a potentially divisive fight of their own. In the 16th District in Somerset, Hunterdon and Morris Counties, two incumbent Assemblymen, Walter J. Kavanaugh of Somerville and John S. Penn of Far Hills, are being opposed by Pete Biondi, the Mayor of Hillsborough, and Lois G. Rand of Bernardsville, who ran unsuccessfully for the Republican nomination for governor in 1989.
And in the Second District in Atlantic County, Senator William L. Gormley of Margate, a moderate Republican who also ran in the 1989 gubernatorial primary and is considered a potential candidate in 1993, faces a rocky road to re-election this year.
He is being opposed in the primary by Domenic F. Cappella, the Ventnor City Administrator. If he survives that challenge, he will face two opponents in November.

HEADLINE: White Flight From Schools Leveling Off

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
After two decades in which white families have increasingly spurned New York City's public schools, the number of white families leaving the system appears to have leveled off, an ethnic census of the city's public-school children indicates.
The census also suggests that an influx of immigrants from Central and South America may soon make Hispanic residents the system's dominant ethnic group. 
 Specialists say those trends, which are highlighted in the Board of Education's census of its 955,154 students, will affect who will run the system, who will teach and what kinds of programs will be offered.
Some specialists said they would not be surprised if, for example, there were dramatic curriculum changes to include more of the history and literature of Latin America. Others say that schools will have to improvise ways to educate many immigrant adolescents who do not know English.
 
Reasons Called Complex
 The reasons for the leveling off of flight by non-Hispanic whites are complex, the specialists say. They include a weakened economy in which many middle-class parents cannot afford private schools, an influx of refugees from Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union and an increase in the white birth rate in the last decade.
Many middle-class non-Hispanic white parents also say they are more eager than their parents were to send their children to racially mixed schools, even if their children are in the minority.
"We and most people we know are basically 60's people," said Elspeth Schell, whose three children attend public schools in lower Manhattan. "The idea of public education comes with the things we grew up with -- democracy and multiculturalism, as we call it now -- and a lot of people are just thrilled to be able to send their children to an integrated and democratic type of school."
Ms. Schell said she and her husband, Jonathan Schell, the writer, had considered several private schools but had heeded a friend's suggestion that they investigate Public School 234 nearby.
"My husband came back with tears in his eyes and said, 'I just found the most wonderful principal and the most wonderful school,' " Ms. Schell said.
According to the board's census, the proportion of whites in public schools has stood at close to 19 percent for the last three years, with declines of a few tenths of a percentage point each year. This year, for example, the system lost only 339 white students.
The proportion of non-Hispanic black children, the largest ethnic group, has remained steady at 38 percent, while Hispanic children now make up 35 percent. And the number of Asian students has doubled to 75,635 in 1990, from 38,197, now making up 7.9 percent of the system's population.
With such a shift in ethnic makeup, only two of the city's 32 school districts have white majorities -- District 26 in Queens and District 31 on Staten Island.
Robin Willner, the board's executive director for strategic planning, said the number of white students in public schools had remained level because "families that were going to leave left and those that are here in specific neighborhoods are using the public schools."
 
Influx From Eastern Europe
 At the same time, she said, about 8,053 Soviet immigrants, 661 Yugoslavs and 498 Romanians have entered New York's public schools.
Even without reading a newspaper, "if you look at these figures, I could tell you what happened in the world," she said. "We never had people coming from Romania before, from Yugoslavia."
Emanuel Tobier, professor of economics and planning at New York University, also noted that the white birth rate rose to 38,992 in 1988 from 35,779 in 1978.
In few places is the leveling off of white flight more apparent than in Public School 84 on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Over 20 years the school had seen its white population dwindle to 7 percent from 33.
But three years ago the school started a dual-language program -- subjects are taught in English one day and in Spanish the next -- and it has enticed parents from the heavily middle-class neighborhood who want their children to be fluent in a foreign language. Now, with an infusion of private-school transfers and the addition of Russian immigrants, whites make up 10 percent of the students at P.S. 84.
 
Personal Belief Cited
 "I'm a lawyer, my husband is a doctor, and the circles we travel in are largely circles where people send their children to private school," said Holly Hartstone, whose two children attend P.S. 84. "But I believe in public education, and I believe my children could get a good education in the public-school system."
Ms. Hartstone said she believed that too many people rejected public schools without checking to see whether a specific neighborhood school had an able staff and a robust program. She does not mind that her children may be part of a racial minority.
"It's a life experience that will help them be more understanding and open people than they could be if they always had the comfortable experience of being in the majority," she said.
Barbara Iverson, whose daughter, Dena, is a second grader in a lively class composed of black, white and Hispanic children, said, "My children are uncomfortable when there isn't much variety."
 
New Hispanic Growth
 In analyzing the school census, Louis Winnick, an urban specialist with the Fund for the City of New York, said the growth of Hispanic pupils had outpaced that of blacks because of a high birth rate and rising immigration. A survey in March found there were 17,261 recent immigrants from the Dominican Republic, 3,251 from Colombia, 3,134 from Mexico, 2,711 from Ecuador, 1,363 from El Salvador and 1,516 from Honduras.
While there has been large immigration from black Caribbean countries, Mr. Tobier said, the gain may have been offset by middle-class American blacks who have left for the suburbs or for their family roots in the South.
"Hispanics will be the dominant group or co-equal with blacks," he said, "and it will obviously be a contributory factor in who gets to teach and who gets to run the system."
Mr. Winnick said, however, that he believed a Hispanic plurality might not quickly translate into dominance of the seven-member Board of Education, which has two black, two Hispanic and three white members. Because of the large number of Hispanic nationalities, there is considerable political fragmentation, he said. Moreover, he said, Hispanic people have not registered to vote in sufficient numbers, and many of those that have often do not vote.
The new trends pose challenges to a system that cannot find enough Spanish-speaking teachers and has not seen Hispanic administrators in numbers that reflect those of Hispanic students.
"The school system will have a more complicated task than it's ever had before in its entire history," Mr. Tobier said.

HEADLINE: Nancy Gutman, Student, Is Wed

 BODY:
Nancy Esther Gutman, a daughter of Roberta B. Gutman of Greenwich, Conn., and Daniel L. Gutman of New York, was married yesterday in Greenwich to Howard Simon Schrader, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Schrader of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. Rabbi Martin Sofer, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Homestead Inn.
The bride, 33 years old, is keeping her name. A graduate of Barnard College, she is a doctoral candidate in economics at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Her father is an investment manager at the Tucker Anthony brokerage in New York. Her mother teaches emotionally disturbed children at St. Vincent's Hospital in Harrison, N.Y. 
 The bridegroom, 32, is an associate in the New York office of Dechert Price & Rhoads, a Philadelphia law firm. He graduated from Brown University and received a law degree from Columbia University, where he was an editor of The Law Review. His mother, Cecile Schrader, is a retired New York City schoolteacher. His father retired last month as the publisher of Harper's Bazaar.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Grand Bargain-Hunters

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
After some badgering, an official U.S. source responsible for knowing the extent of Moscow's current subsidy of Communism in Cuba disgorged this figure for 1990: $4.5 billion. That does not include the aid that the folks who gave the world Chernobyl are giving Fidel Castro to install uninspected nuclear reactors a stone's throw from Florida.
 Let's assume that our bailout establishment -- including Kansas Senator Bob Dole, who never met a grain credit he didn't like -- succeeds in pouring $1.5 billion in unsecured credit down the Kremlin drain. President Bush, alternately looking stern and professing much anguish, will soon do that as a "humanitarian gesture" to put bread on Moscow's tables.
 
 That means U.S. taxpayers will be reimbursing the Kremlin for one-third of its current annual subsidy to hard-line Communist Cuba. We will be underwriting Moscow's continuance of the cold war.
 Does that make sense? Are we really ready to increase our deficit, or to raise our taxes, or to crack down on our students to repay loans -- to enable Mikhail Gorbachev to keep a Communist foothold in the Caribbean?
 Here is a proposal stunning in its simplicity: If Kremlin humanitarians want to feed their people next month, let them cut off all aid to Cuba this month. Then they will be able to buy our grain and meet their food crisis.
 The bailout establishment sniffs at such thinking as simplistic. At Harvard, the current management of the Charles River Gang is mapping a giveaway of far greater sophistication: a "Grand Bargain" of a quarter of a trillion dollars or so, over five years, in return for Soviet promises of reform.
 The Grand Bargain-hunters are all nice guys. Graham Allison of the J.F.K. School would have been national security adviser in the Dukakistocracy; Robert Blackwill is a classy scholar afflicted with the fear of "who lost Gorbachev?"; Grigory Yavlinsky is a 39-year-old economist trotted out by Mr. Gorbachev when reform is in season (and who shows a nice understanding of Western ways by reportedly cutting himself in on the bundle he seeks).
 Their notion of capitalist-paid crutches for a bailout of the Communist system seems ludicrous; it is divorced from political reality and economic logic. The "Grand Bargain" is significant, however, because it sets a far-out price on helping keep Mr. Gorbachev in power. This will permit the "sensible" types to move in and settle for a cheaper bailout: a petite bargain.
 Mr. Bush and Secretary Baker, split-the-difference types, will put on a horrified look at the Harvard stalking horse. Then they will insist the ransom put on reform should be less, with more Soviet promises of a loosening of the command economy, perhaps throwing in fewer shootings of Baltic border guards. Maybe, as the sweetener before the limited-modified-bailout, we'll get a small reduction of Soviet arms spending and the Castro subsidy.
 Already, Mr. Bush is giving way gracefully: nice-again Mr. Gorbachev will be invited to the G-7 summit meeting to rattle his tin cup like a menacing beggar and be given quick fixes to help him stay in power.
 That entire approach is a historic mistake. Richard Nixon, writing in The Washington Post, persuasively denounces bailout proposals as "counterproductive Western painkillers" that would postpone the drastic economic and political changes needed to save the Soviet peoples.
 Communism with a reformist face is a fake. Pouring in public money from the West to shore up five more years of half-measures in the Kremlin is a guaranteed loser. The only way for businesses in the Soviet republics to attract private capital in nation-building sums is to take up the money-magnet called capitalism.
 The economic answers are no secret. Reducing the Red Army to the size of our own will avert national bankruptcy; selling houses, apartments, land and factories to the people will absorb the "ruble overhang" and make currency convertible; unleashing the profit motive will put bread on the table. The political climate required for this is called freedom.
 Impossible? Stranger things have happened under the impetus of necessity in the fullness of time. If the writing of Richard Nixon can proudly be featured in The Washington Post, the liberating idea of private property can be embraced in the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By SUSAN HELLER ANDERSON

 BODY:
HENRY ROSOVSKY, who has enjoyed many honors and much affection from Harvard University, is getting a building named after him.  Dean Rosovsky is acting dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences until July 1 and was dean of the faculty from 1973 to 1984. He has a chair in the economics department, where he has been a professor since 1965. He is a member of the Harvard Corporation, the seven-person board that runs the school.
