HEADLINE: Enter Senate, Begin Chasing Money

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 31

 BODY:
John F. Seymour, the new Senator from California, says he needs to do one thing in the next 30 days to gain credibility as a political heavyweight, and it has nothing to do with legislation.
Mr. Seymour, a moderate Republican, has to raise $1 million by the end of June. And that's only the beginning. 
 To win election in 1992 to the Senate seat he was appointed to fill in January by Gov. Pete Wilson, Mr. Seymour says he needs to collect $15 million to $20 million over the next 17 months. If he meets that goal, and succeeds in hanging on to the seat vacated by Mr. Wilson, Senator Seymour will immediately have to work the money circuit all over again to win a full six-year term in 1994.
Without the money to buy the television commercials that would give him visibility, Mr. Seymour says he will lose. So for Mr. Seymour, the hard part is not getting the job but keeping it. And keeping it means spending less time learning his way around the Capitol and more time campaigning and raising money so he can tell voters just how good a Senator he is -- or could be.
 
A Necessary Money Chase
 "I'm leveraging it for everything it's worth," Mr. Seymour said of his newfound incumbency. "That's how I win the election."
Though Mr. Seymour's predicament is unusual, because California is the most expensive state in which to run a campaign, it nevertheless magnifies what some say is the twisted condition of the American political system.
"It is an outrageous amount of money," Ellen S. Miller, executive director of the Center for Responsive Politics, a bipartisan research group, said of Mr. Seymour's fund-raising targets. "It demonstrates how the system has evolved into one in which a successful money chase becomes the determinant of political opportunity and viability."
Mr. Seymour, a former mayor of Anaheim who was a state senator when Governor Wilson elevated him, acknowledges that his task is nothing less than political torture. "I'm frustrated by the fact that I've got 17 months until November of 1992," Mr. Seymour said as he was driven to a recent fund-raising reception in San Diego. "And I'm sitting here with a name I.D. of 37 or 38 percent and having to raise $15 million and wondering, "Can I do it? Will it happen?' "
 
A Slew of Dinner Speeches
 Barely five months in office, the 53-year-old Mr. Seymour officially began his drive for money this week with the first of what he says will be 20 fund-raising events in the next four weeks.
On Tuesday he courted donors at an oceanside restaurant in La Jolla, on Wednesday at a supporter's home in San Francisco and on Thursday at a gala dinner in his hometown, Anaheim, where the guest of honor, the Senate's Republican leader, Bob Dole, told the high rollers, "John and I are just politicians after your money." Mr. Dole was only half joking.
California citizens are paying a price for the dependence of their elected representatives on huge sums. Mr. Seymour cannot help but be distracted from his legislative duties as he prowls for donations.
While the obsession with raising money by the state's senior Senator, Alan Cranston, got him re-elected in 1986, it also got him into trouble. Once one of the nation's leading Democrats, he has lost influence now that he faces a possible reprimand from his colleagues for his efforts on behalf of a big contributor and former savings and loan operator, Charles H. Keating Jr. Mr. Cranston plans to retire in 1992, guaranteeing a second multimillion-dollar race for a California Senate seat.
 
'Unprofessional,' but Inescapable
 Unlike Mr. Cranston, who relished what he called "raising dough," Mr. Seymour, who made a fortune in the real estate business, professes to detest the process. "It's very unprofessional," he said. "On the other hand, I came to realize a long time ago that it's part of the profession of politics."
Mr. Seymour probably owes his current position as much to his fund-raising prowess as to his long friendship with Governor Wilson. Asked what the rather colorless lawmaker brings to the office, even Mr. Seymour's admirers talk far more about his tenacity and stamina than his legislative skills or his vision for his state, the nation or the world.
Mr. Seymour says he is working the same 18-hour days he toiled to make it as an entrepreneur. He has returned to California virtually every weekend since he took office and often uses the trips to solicit donations. He faces a challenge in the primary from Representative William E. Dannemeyer, a staunch conservative from Orange County. In the general election, Dianne Feinstein, the former San Francisco mayor who spent nearly $20 million in her failed bid for Governor last year, is running as the early favorite.
"The Governor chose him for a very pragmatic reason," said Representative Vic Fazio, a California Democrat, noting Mr. Seymour's reputation for leaning on his real estate and development contacts for contributions. "I don't think it's indicative of his legislative skills or accomplishment as a public servant. But I don't underestimate his ability to make the race a close one," added Mr. Fazio, who heads the fund-raising apparatus for his party's House candidates.
In a demonstration of how important Mr. Seymour's seat is to Republicans, both Mr. Dole and Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, the party's chief Senate recruiter, appeared with Mr. Seymour at fund-raising events this week to urge supporters to donate as much as they can before June 30, the next Federal Election Commission deadline for reporting campaign receipts.
 
Using Money to Attract More
 "John has to close his books out on June the 30th," Mr. Gramm told donors snacking on rotini pasta and Caesar salad in La Jolla. "And that's going to be the first time that people are going to start looking to see have we got the ball rolling. So if you haven't written your $1,000 check yet, to go in that first report, please get it in."
Wherever he goes in California, Senator Seymour plays the part of a veteran Washington player, pushing the Republican themes of a balanced budget, line-item veto and a tough anticrime package. At a meeting with editorial officials of a San Diego television station the other day, he boasted, "I've been telling the White House" that the economy is headed for trouble. Referring to Carla A. Hills, the United States Trade Representative, as Carla, and to Edward R. Madigan, the Secretary of Agriculture, as Ed, he said they had done favors for California on his behalf.
But Mr. Seymour, who said Queen Elizabeth II of England, on her recent visit, figured out who he was only after he identified himself as "the Senator from Disneyland," which is based in Anaheim, acknowledges that much of what he does will go unrecognized among the state's 30 million people unless he can promote himself on television.
"The reality is, I'm going to have to spend a lot of money on television to tell people who I am and what I stand for," he said. "Just in the media market of Los Angeles, a 30-second sound bite costs you $30,000."

GRAPHIC: Photo: After he was appointed five months ago, Senator John F. Seymour of California found out that the hard part was not getting the job but keeping it. He has to raise $1 million in campaign money by the end of June, then $15 million to $20 million over the next 17 months. (Bart Bartholomew for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CAREERS;
East Europe Latest Lure For M.B.A.'s

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
THE shifting economies of Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia have become magnets for M.B.A.'s and other students wanting a taste of what one dean calls a laboratory for capitalism.
Last spring two dozen students in the middle of their two-year programs at three graduate business schools -- Cornell, the University of Michigan and the University of Pennsylania -- made arrangements to work in Eastern Europe. Some paid their way and some deans used school funds to help or raised money from donors. Students received allowances for room and board from the companies or government entities for which they worked. 
 This year the programs have increased sharply, with almost every major business school sponsoring at least a few students.
Now there is a formal program with paid administrators, set up last October by the three business schools plus 12 others, including Columbia, New York University, Dartmouth and the University of California at Los Angeles. Its name is the MBA Enterprise Corporation and it has its headquarters at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill.
Operating a little differently from summer programs, this one sends abroad M.B.A.'s who have just received their degrees and agree to spend 12 to 18 months in the former Communist nations. Seed money of $25,000 an individual has been provided by the United States Government and private donors.
Lynne Gerber, executive director of the corporation, said there were 180 applicants for the 50 places open this year. One sponsor that has provided money for the program, she said, is the Sara Lee Corporation, a diversified food company interested in joint ventures. She said many corporations were interested in hiring the M.B.A.'s after they returned.
Next year, she said, the corporation hopes to send 50 M.B.A's to Southeast Asia after a pilot group of half a dozen goes to Singapore, Indonesia, Hong Kong and the Philippines this fall.
James Schmotter of Cornell's Johnson Graduate School of Business and a founder of the MBA Enterprise Corporation, has been busy with the summer group going abroad from Cornell. Students there were among the first to conceive a summer program a year ago, and he said that the 11 chosen had flown abroad for their internships -- nine to Hungary and two to Czechoslovakia. To his surprise there were 42 applicants.
"My role was the selection of the students," he said last week. "They get a stipend before leaving and air fare is paid. The companies where they work supply room and board."
The Cornell group consists of one Japanese student with banking experience who will be accompanied by his wife and child; a Canadian and a student from Iceland. Also making the trip are a West Point graduate and a former naval officer, as well as a woman M.B.A. candidate who served in the Peace Corps and another who is working toward both an M.B.A. degree and a master's degree in natural resources. All received some language training and studied the cultural background of the host country.
"They will be doing things they don't do here -- getting their hands dirty," Dr. Schmotter said, explaining that quite a few will be working in "manufacturing settings."
"Being a generalist in these countries is important," he said. "The students have to be adaptable rather than just function as a marketer, an accountant or as a financial specialist."
The University of Pennsylvania's Wharton graduate business school and the allied Lauder International Institute reported that about 40 of its students would teach business courses this summer in English in Leningrad and in Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, concentrating on basics like accounting, management, marketing and finance, the usual required courses for M.B.A.'s.
Herbert S. Levine, professor of economics and co-director of the Lauder Institute, made the arrangements for the unusual teaching experience.
"I placed a little notice in a Wharton newsletter." Dr. Levine said. "It offered room and board and a tiny salary in rubles." He expected only a handful of responses, but soon he had to phone friends in the Soviet Union to "report an embarrassment of riches," he said.
He said the students would teach basic business courses under the auspices of a Russian business school called the Herzen Pedagogical Institute.
One student who will teach accounting obtained 100 copies of the Scott Paper Company's annual report, which he will use as a text. A husband-and-wife team will help the Russian business school students evaluate real estate, an important matter for future private ownership.
"A lot of this help is going on," Dr. Levine said. "It is a matter of flowers rising out of the debris."

HEADLINE: Austin, Tex., Offers Insured Bonds

 BODY:
The City of Austin, Tex., is offering $56.8 million in combined utility systems revenue refunding bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Underwriters said the tax-exempt bonds had a maximum yield of 6.875 percent for a bond due in 2007. For shorter maturities, there are serial bonds with yields ranging from 4.5 percent in 1991 to 5.8 percent in 1996, 6.35 percent in 2001 and 6.55 percent in 2003. 
 Proceeds from the sale will be used to help finance the early redemption of other bonds sold when interest rates were higher.
The offering features an insurance policy covering interest and principal payments on the bonds, giving the issue a rating of triple-A from both Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: O.E.C.D. Sees Recovery for U.S. in 2d Half

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 3

 BODY:
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a 24-nation group promoting economic growth, forecast today that the United States would lift itself out of recession in the second half of this year and that unemployment would stop climbing during that period.
The Paris-based organization, widely respected for its economic projections, said the American economy would grow at an annual rate of 2.7 percent in the second half, compared with a 1.8 percent drop in output in the first half. 
 The organization's economists also projected that American economic growth would climb to 3.3 percent for all of 1992, compared with an anticipated decline in production of two-tenths of 1 percent for all of this year.
Two reports from Washington today supported the case for recovery. The Commerce Department said spending on new construction in April rose more than it had in 14 months, and the purchasing managers' index of economic activity increased to 45.4 percent in May from 42.1 percent in April. [Page D5.]
The O.E.C.D. released its projections a day before finance, trade and foreign ministers from its member nations gather in Paris for the group's annual ministers meeting, which will assess the world's economic situation. At the meeting, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady will again urge other industrial nations to lower interest rates to stimulate growth, American officials say, and Germany, with Europe's largest economy, is once again expected to rebuff his suggestions.
Some economists have suggested that the O.E.C.D., seeking to stimulate consumer confidence and investment, is intentionally making optimistic projections. But at a news conference today, senior O.E.C.D. officials defended their forecast, saying they foresee a rebound because of lower interest rates in the United States, Canada, Britain and some other European countries. In addition, they said the victory of the allied coalition in the Persian Gulf war helped raise consumer confidence.
"From now to 1992, all the countries of the industrial world will be growing," one senior official said.
 
6.7% Unemployment Rate
 The O.E.C.D.'s economists said inflation in the United States would be 4 percent this year and 3.6 percent in 1992, compared with 4.1 percent last year. They project that American unemployment will be 6.7 percent in the second half, the same level as in the first half, and will dip to 6.3 percent next year. That compares with 5.5 percent last year.
The rebound the economists foresee will be weaker than the rebound after the 1981-82 recession, which was followed by growth of 3.6 percent in 1983 and 6.8 percent in 1984.
"We don't expect a vigorous recovery, notably because the slowdown wasn't profound and didn't last very long," said the O.E.C.D.'s Secretary General, Jean-Claude Paye, last week referring to the anticipated second-half rebound.
For the industrialized democracies, the O.E.C.D. projects growth of 2.4 percent in the second half, at an annualized rate, and 2.9 percent next year, compared with growth of just three-tenths of 1 percent in the first half of this year.
The group forecast growth of 3.6 percent for Japan next year, the same rate it sees for Japan this year. It expects Germany's unification boom to fade, projecting growth of 2.2 percent next year in what had been West Germany, down from 2.8 percent this year and 4.5 percent last year.
 
Hills Seeks Progress
 At a separate news conference here today, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said that she wanted to make progress in international trade talks a priority of this week's ministers meeting. She said the major snag remained the European Community's refusal to agree to substantial reductions in three areas of protecton for farmers: export subsidies, income supports and import barriers.
Mrs. Hills said the negotiators in the current Uruguay Round of trade talks would have to make major progress in June and July if the talks are to end this year. Officials from many countries say that an agreement in the 108-nation talks needs to be reached this year because 1992 is an American election year, which will make it hard to reach an accord next year.
"It's important to wrap it up as soon as possible," Mrs. Hills said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Modest Price Rises Posted In Dollar and Gold Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar moved moderately higher yesterday on expectations that United States interest rates would remain firm amid signs that the economy is recovering.
Gold prices also posted modest gains. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold picked up $1.60 to close at $363.00 a troy ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $362.00, up 70 cents. 
 Analysts said the dollar rose in response to growing signs that the recession was bottoming out and the economy was regaining strength.
Kevin Logan, chief economist for the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York, said traders reacted to the survey of corporate purchasing executives released yesterday, signaling an improvement in the manufacturing sector, as well as to the Government's report Friday that its chief economic forecasting gauge, the index of leading economic indicators, rose six-tenths of 1 percent in April.
The growing evidence that the economy is recovering sent the dollar higher because of the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would not need to push interest rates lower to stimulate business activity. The dollar, like all currencies, draws support from higher interest rates because higher yields increase foreign demand for United States investments.
The British pound was little changed against the dollar. Sterling was unchanged at $1.6970 in New York, and in earlier London trading, the pound fell to $1.6970, from $1.6990 late Friday.
The dollar rose to 139.15 Japanese yen in New York from late Friday's 138.30. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar advanced to 138.37 yen, from 137.97 yen Friday, and in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 139.05 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.7485 German marks, up from 1.7430; 1.4900 Swiss francs, up from 1.4855; 5.9220 French francs, up from 5.9090.

HEADLINE: Purchasing Index Shows Sharp Gain

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Spurred by a sharp increase in new orders, the nation's manufacturing economy improved in May, according to a monthly report issued yesterday by corporate purchasing managers.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of economic activity increased to 45.4 percent in May, up from 42.1 percent in April. The May reading was the highest since August, when the index stood at 47.6 percent. 
 But the May index still indicates that the nation's economy remains sluggish, economists and the association said. A reading below 50 percent indicates that the manufacturing economy is declining, while a reading above 50 indicates expansion.
 
Wide-Ranging Survey
 The purchasing managers' report is considered an important economic indicator because it is based on a survey of managers from a wide range of industrial companies. It is the first important indicator each month of how the economy performed in the previous month.
The purchasing managers' report followed a report on Friday that the Government's main economic indicators increased six-tenths of 1 percent in April. The Commerce Department said the increase followed similar gains in March and February.
"The figures indicate that economic activity is picking up," said Andrew F. Brimmer, a former governor of the Federal Reserve and president of Brimmer & Associates, an economic consulting firm in Washington. "These figures can be taken as an indication of strengthening economic activity in the future because they are, for the most part, below 50 percent. The economy is weak but improving."
Mr. Brimmer predicted that the second quarter would represent the "the trough" in the economy and that the third quarter "should show positive growth that should continue in the fourth quarter."
 
Poised for Growth
 Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the association's business survey committee and director of corporate purchasing at Pitney Bowes Inc., said that the May figures indicated that the economy had begun to expand and that the manufacturing sector should begin showing improvement.
"With inventories at very low levels and inflation in check, if not declining, the manufacturing economy appears posed to grow," he said.
The purchasing managers' index of new orders jumped to 50.6 percent in May from 45.9 percent in April, ending 10 consecutive monthly declines. Mr. Brimmer and other economists said that the increase in new orders was particularly significant because it would affect the level of production in the months to follow.
 
Production Soars
 The production index rose sharply in May, to 48.8 percent from 43.1 percent in April. It was the highest level of producion since August of last year, when the production index reached 49.2 percent.
The purchasing managers' price index rose slightly, to 36.9 percent in May from 36.3 percent in April. The report said that the May level was the second lowest since April 1982. Inventories declined in May, with the inventories index falling to 37.5 percent, from 39 percent in April.

HEADLINE: Bond Rating Is Affirmed for New York City

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Despite continuing uncertainty over its budget, the Dinkins administration won a vote of confidence from a major bond rating agency yesterday as Standard & Poor's affirmed its rating of city bonds, finding the city's challenges manageable and its assumptions realistic.
But in affirming its A- rating, which surprised some city officials who were bracing for a downgrading, Standard & Poor's complicated the already complex effort by Mayor David N. Dinkins to avert the worst of the service cuts called for in his budget. 
 For the city, the good news is that the rating could ease the way for the city to sell $600 million in bonds tomorrow at a favorable interest rate. Mayor Dinkins praised the rating decision and said it showed confidence that he would "take any and all actions" to keep the budget in balance.
The bad news is that to maintain the rating the city may be unable to take advantage of bond refinancings or other fiscal gimmicks to reduce Mr. Dinkins's proposed service cuts, making it more likely they will be made.
The reason is that the Mayor proposed sharp service cuts and thousands of layoffs, and then, in an effort to avert them, began negotiations with the municipal unions, the state and the Municipal Assistance Corporation, a state body set up during the 1970's to sell bonds for the city.
 
A Refinancing Offer
 The M.A.C. has offered to refinance bonds to provide $350 million to the city next year to avert some service cuts and help the city develop a long-term plan to shrink the size of government. But it said it would not take any steps that would lower the city credit rating.
The unions, in turn, have made their help contingent on some assistance from the M.A.C., saying they would not make "givebacks" without a long-term plan to solve the city's problem.
Standard & Poor's said yesterday that any use of bond refinancing to pay for continuing city operations would be "inconsistent" with the current A- rating, thus making assistance by the corporation less likely. If the rating agency had downgraded the city bonds, this concern would have been swept away, some officals noted.
"We are not going to do anything that involves a city downgrading," said Felix G. Rohatyn, the M.A.C. chairman.
First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said union leaders could not count on the M.A.C. money anytime soon and would "have to decide whether it is in their interest to deal with the impact of the cuts on their members."

HEADLINE: Hartford Foe Of New Tax On Income Now Backs It

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 3

 BODY:
The majority leader in the State Senate, who only four days ago stood before his colleagues to nail down why Connecticut should reject an income tax, proposed a steep wage tax of his own today.
The leader, Senator Cornelius O'Leary, Democrat of Windsor Locks, said the reality of the state budget crisis was permanently altered when Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. vetoed the legislature's plan without an income tax on Friday night. The sooner lawmakers start accommodating themselves the better, he said. 
 "They're faced with the reality of the veto," Mr. O'Leary said of his fellow lawmakers. "I've added this to the mix in order to focus the debate."
The legislative plan passed both chambers last week before it died about 20 minutes after reaching Mr. Weicker's desk. The measure, which Mr. Weicker called anti-business and hostile to the poor, would have raised $960 million in new taxes to resolve Connecticut's budget crisis, mostly through an expansion of the sales tax.
 
A Flat Tax on Income
 Mr. O'Leary's new proposal, by contrast, would leave most of the state's current tax structure intact. But to resolve the huge shortage in revenues attributed to the recession, a flat 9 percent tax would be imposed on income over $100,000 for couples filing jointly or $75,000 for an individual.
With the high exemption level, only about 125,000 high-income households would be affected, Mr. O'Leary said. But some of them, he added, would take a much bigger hit than under Mr. Weicker's proposal, which called for a 6 percent tax on income over $25,000 for couples filing jointly or $12,500 for an individual.
The new plan, to balance a budget of about $7.7 billion in the fiscal year starting July 1, drew little enthusiasm from members of either party or either chamber of the General Assembly.
But Mr. O'Leary reported that many people who had seen his plan said they would remain "flexible." Other lawmakers said the symbolism of Mr. O'Leary's announcement would carry greater significance than the substance.
First, they said, by openly proposing a new plan, Mr. O'Leary has formally dashed any notion of trying to override Mr. Weicker's veto, which would have required a two-thirds vote in both chambers. The Senate, which passed the plan without an income tax by 22 to 14 last week, was considered to have best chance of overriding the veto; it needed but two more votes to obtain two-thirds of its 36-member chamber. The House barely passed the plan, 77 to 71.
A second symbolic thunderclap in Mr. O'Leary's announcement is that a leader of the coalition against an income tax has now walked into the opposing camp with full colors flying.
Mr. O'Leary said today that his package was put together over the weekend. And he said it was unquestionably better than the one he endorsed and voted for last week.
"The selling point is fairness and equity," he said.
Other Democrats were noncommittal today about Mr. O'Leary's reversal, but did not pronounce the plan doomed outright. This group included the Senate President pro tem, John B. Larson, who has cultivated a reputation as a firebrand in his opposition to the income tax -- he called it "voodoo economics" in a debate last week in the Senate. Democrats control majorities in both chambers of the General Assembly but have been deeply split over the income tax.
Some lawmakers speculated that Mr. O'Leary was simply setting the example in public for a private decision that other lawmakers may have to make if they, too, conclude that Mr. Weicker's veto is a wall that cannot breached.
"For many people, putting a conventional package together, knowing it would be vetoed, was the first act of a drama that now moves into a second act," said Representative Miles S. Rapoport, a Democrat from West Hartford who supports the wage tax. "Some people are open to voting for an income tax, but they did not want to be seen as lusting after it -- they wanted to be pulled into it kicking and screaming, and we're doing that."
 
Ticklish Questions Remain
 Connecticut's regular session concludes Wednesday at midnight, but most lawmakers say the real work on a budget will not begin until next week in a special session. And the questions of that next act are expected to be as ticklish as ever. If a majority of lawmakers do conclude that getting a budget past Mr. Weicker without some kind an income tax is impossible, what kind of income tax might muster majorities in the House and Senate?
A tiny, temporary income tax, perhaps -- even called by another name, as some have suggested -- might gain broader support in the legislature, lawmakers say.
But as Mr. Weicker stressed in his veto message on Friday, the point is not simply to impose an income tax, but rather to lower significantly the taxes paid by business and so stimulate the state's faltering economy.
Cutting those business taxes, however -- given the crushing revenue shortfall, which is projected to affect about 30 percent of the state budget over the next 13 months -- might be impossible with a small income tax.
Another big variable in wooing votes from the minority Republicans for an income tax is a package of controls on state spending. These controls, included in last week's legislative budget proposal, were resurrected today in Mr. O'Leary's plan.
The minority leader in the House, Representative Edward C. Krawiecki Jr., a Republican from Bristol and an architect of the plan without an income tax, said today that he strongly disliked Mr. O'Leary's income tax. But he said his focus would continue to be on the spending package. Taxes are negotiable, Mr. Krawiecki said; spending is not.

HEADLINE: Hard-Liners in China: Old, but by No Means Out

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 3

 BODY:
Two years ago, when China's hard-liners used troops and tanks to crush the democracy movement here, most Chinese and foreigners predicted that the aging leadership would not last even a couple of years.
Yet it has. Far more than most people expected, Prime Minister Li Peng and those around him have consolidated their hold and imposed a sullen stability on the land. At times, China is still likened to a volcano, but few see an eruption soon. 
 "It'll be like this for another five years, maybe even 10 years," said a senior Chinese official, who has close ties to the change-minded faction that is now hibernating. "Even after the old men die, those who are now in power will remain for awhile, and they think the same way: They were all trained in the Soviet Union in the 1950's, and they really believe in central planning."
Of course, that forecast may be no more accurate than those of two years ago. Perhaps the real lesson of the last few years is that no one can reliably predict what will happen in China.
Yet whatever the future may hold, two contrary trends seem to have emerged in the two years since the crackdown at Tiananmen Square.
The first is that the hard-liners have been successful in defusing economic and political challenges, so they could well remain in power for years to come. The second is that they have managed to do what the democracy movement never really intended to do: turn many Chinese, particularly the young and educated, away from Communism.
"Socialism is rubbish; everybody knows that," said a university senior with relatives at the highest levels of government. "I used to think that socialism was basically good, but that there were specific problems like corruption that needed to be addressed. But now I've gradually come to realize that the problem is socialism itself."
"If you had a secret poll of my classmates, not one of them would say that socialism has a future," the student said. "Not one of them."
 
Many Still Believe in Communism
 This may be beside the point, for it is still easy to find people -- especially older officials and those outside the biggest cities -- who strongly believe in Communism. But it is striking that at the time of the democracy movement in 1989, the aim was not to overthrow the Communist Party but to reform it; now it is becoming increasingly common to hear bitter criticism of the party itself. Often, the harshest appraisals come from party members.
One such party member was recently talking with some army generals and they discussed various strategies for catching up with American military technology. He recalled mischievously, "I was tempted to tell them: 'Yes, there is a way we can catch up -- capitalism!' "
Economic discontent spurs the disenchantment, but still the hard-liners have managed the economy somewhat better than many Chinese and foreigners initially expected. Late in 1989, there were expectations of worker sabotage and wildcat strikes, and doubts about whether the Government would be able to meet factory payrolls or to pay farmers for their grain.
The Chinese economy did indeed suffer its worst slowdown in a decade, but this was largely the result of a tight money policy intended to reduce inflation. This year, the economy is again growing rapidly -- although the growth is also induced by a more generous monetary policy -- with industrial growth up 13.2 percent in the first four months of this year, compared to the same period a year earlier.
Inflation, which was a sensitive political issue in 1989, has been almost extinguished. Exports have soared, and so China's foreign-exchange reserves are rising, improving the nation's ability to repay its foreign debt.
Still, the Government has done almost nothing to restructure the state-owned sector of the economy to make it more efficient, and inflation could resume late this year or next year. In addition, many Chinese seem so fed up with the leadership in Beijing that the Government has failed to get political credit for its economic achievements.
Not only is it becoming more common to hear Chinese speak warmly about capitalism, but a growing number also seem to be questioning the conventional wisdom that the Communist revolution was a good idea that went astray over time. More and more people say that the entire revolution may have been a mistake from the start.
"As far as I can see, the Communist revolution was a bad thing for China," an official with minister-level status said bluntly.
Asked how many other officials of his rank, at the peak of the Chinese political system, still believe in Marxism, he said: "It's hard to say, but probably very few. Many fewer than half."
 
Cities Seem the Most Hostile
 Such anti-Communist views seem most pronounced in Beijing and other major cities; elsewhere, there is indignation at corruption and other problems, but most people seem absorbed by matters of daily life rather than by politics. While there is no reliable measure of Chinese public opinion, some scholars say they believe that the Communist Party could still win a free election in China on the basis of support in the countryside, but that its margin of victory would be less than it would have been a few years ago.
Given the growing disillusionment and resentment, it is all the more remarkable that Prime Minister Li and other hard-liners have maintained power so effectively.
Nicholas Lardy, a China scholar from the University of Washington, noted that huge price increases in rice and other basic foods last month caused no significant public protest. In other developing countries, such price rises have toppled governments.
Mr. Li predicted last month that he would remain in office at least until his term expires in 1993, and most people believe he is right. To be sure, he has shown a measure of flexibility in economic matters, and there are some signs that China is resuming the path of economic restructuring that it followed until a few years ago.
But some Chinese doubt that there will be far-reaching changes until Deng Xiaoping, the nation's supreme leader, and other top leaders die. Mr. Deng, who will turn 87 in August, is frail but appears reasonably healthy, and his older sister is still alive at the age of 90.
 
Uncertainty of Public Opinion
 From a Western viewpoint, it might seem that protests are most likely when people are angriest, but that may not be the case in China. For the last four decades, protests have been linked not only to the amount of steam building up among the public, but also to the Government's tolerance of criticism.
Thus it may be that whether there are new demonstrations may depend less on the level of popular fury than on whether there are splits within the leadership, as in 1989, that allow protests to begin without an immediate crackdown.
For now, dissidents say, the certainty of repression has made the possibility of any uprising remote -- unless a senior leader dies or there is some other shock to the system.
"My generation of students isn't going to take to the streets," said the graduating senior at People's University. "The controls are too great and we're simply too scared."
"But there will be another group that will march," she said, "and when they do, it's hard to say if there's anything they won't say."

HEADLINE: SUPREME COURT ROUNDUP;
Ban Stays on Abortion Funds Abroad

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
The Supreme Court refused today to hear a challenge to a Federal policy cutting off Federal family planning grants to any overseas organization that spends money, from whatever source, on activities related to abortion.
The Court's action, in an unsigned one-line order, came 10 days after a 5-to-4 decision upheld limits on abortion counseling in federally financed family clinics in the United States. 
 The restrictions at issue in the case today were in some ways more sweeping. The regulations upheld last month in Rust v. Sullivan permit the domestic clinics to set up administratively separate offices in which they may provide abortion information with non-Federal money.
The overseas regulations provide that the foreign organizations must forfeit their Federal aid even if they segregate other sources of money for activities like providing information about abortions or lobbying against restrictive abortion laws.
 
Rules Announced in 1984
 The regulations were first announced by the Reagan Administration at an international family planning conference in Mexico City in 1984, and have been continued in effect under the Bush Administration. The Mexico City policy, as it is known, was upheld last year by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York.
The Federal money is spent through the Agency for International Development, which gives it to organizations here and abroad. The agency is the major source of family planning funds in the world. The $220 million it spent last year accounted for 40 percent of such spending in the third world.
The Planned Parenthood Federation of America, which brought the lawsuit in 1987, filed the Supreme Court appeal, Planned Parenthood v. Agency for International Development, No. 90-1169. The Justices deferred action on the appeal until they decided the Rust case, since both cases raised somewhat similar constitutional arguments based on the First Amendment's guarantee of free speech.
Planned Parenthood's argument was that its own free speech rights had been infringed by the restrictions placed on the overseas organizations to which Planned Parenthood wanted to give money.
It argued that its right to carry out its programs, including providing information about abortion, is necessarily curtailed because the overseas organizations are as a practical matter forced to abide by the Mexico City restrictions, and reject the Planned Parenthood programs. The suit argued that the overseas recipients could not afford to jeopardize their Federal money, on which they are dependent.
 
Rules on Any Funds
 Federal law since 1973 has prohibited Federal money from being used for providing abortions overseas. The Mexico City policy went further, requiring overseas recipients of Federal money to agree not to use funds from any source for activities defined as "actively promoting abortion as a method of family planning."
In the regulations, "abortion as a method of family planning" is defined as any abortion that ends a pregnancy not caused by rape or incest or that is not needed to save a pregnant woman's life. "Actively promoting abortion" is defined as providing factual information, with the exception that the family planning worker may "passively" answer the question of a pregnant woman who "clearly states" that she has already decided to have an abortion, if the "ethics of the medical profession" require a factual response about where a safe, legal abortion may be obtained.
There were also these other developments at the Court today:
 
Judicial Elections
 The Court ruled unanimously that elections to fill 12 judicial vacancies in Louisiana should not have taken place last fall because the Justice Department had not approved changes in voting procedures for the districts at issue.
Louisiana, along with other Southern states and portions of some states in the North, are required by the Voting Rights Act of 1965 to submit for Justice Department approval, in advance, any changes in voting procedures, from the placement of polling places to the creation of new districts.
In this case, Clark v. Roemer, No. 90-952, the Justice Department had refused to clear some changes and had not ruled on others. A special three-judge Federal court permitted elections to take place in districts where it found that the changes had been approved "by implication." The Justice Department joined black plaintiffs in arguing that the elections should have been blocked.
Writing for the Court today, Justice Kennedy agreed that there was no approval "by implication" under the law and that a state must explicitly submit and receive approval for all changes. Justice Kennedy said the lower court should now decide whether the judges who were elected must be removed from office.
The Court is expected to decide later this month, in cases from Louisiana and Texas, the broader question of whether judicial elections are covered by the principal provision of the Voting Rights Act.
 
Environmental Suits
 Accepting an appeal from the Department of Energy, the Court agreed to decide whether Federal agencies can be assessed fines for violating either state laws on water pollution control or the principal Federal toxic waste law.
The case, U.S. v. Ohio, No. 90-1341, is an appeal from a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati. That court held that Congress had waived the Federal Government's sovereign immunity, raising the potential of millions of dollars in fines. The case began as a lawsuit by the state to require the Government to clean up and pay for environmental damage at the Energy Department's uranium processing plant in Fernald, Ohio.
 
Libel
 The Court refused, without comment, to hear an appeal in a libel case against a New York-based scientific journal. The case, a lawsuit based on the journal's publication of a letter to the editor, had twice been dismissed by New York's highest court. The plaintiff, Immuno AG, an Austrian-based medical company, argued that the New York Court of Appeals had deliberately misinterpreted a recent Supreme Court ruling on the role of "opinion" in libel suits. The remaining defendant in the eight-year-old lawsuit was Dr. Jan Moor-Jankowski, editor of the Journal of Medical Primatology. (Immuno AG v. Moor-Jankowski, No. 90-1579).

HEADLINE: Bush Clears Soviet Trade Benefits and Weighs Role in London Talks

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
President Bush today granted an extension of trade benefits for the Soviet Union and was said to be increasingly receptive to inviting President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to London at the time of the July summit meeting of seven leading industrial nations.
In a move intended to help Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Bush took the technical steps necessary to allow $1.5 billion in credits for additional food purchases to be granted to Moscow. In December, the President, for the first time, approved measures allowing the Soviets $1 billion in credits. 
 At the same time, after recent contacts between Mr. Bush and Prime Minister John Major of Britain, officials said the President seemed increasingly inclined toward inviting Mr. Gorbachev to London in conjunction with the economic summit meeting July 15-17.
 
Invitation to Gorbachev
 The current thinking, the officials said, was not to ask Mr. Gorbachev to take part in the discussions of the industrialized nations, known collectively as the Group of Seven, but to be on hand in London either before or after the economic summit meeting. He would then hold talks with the members of the Group of Seven, either separately or in groups, about ways to promote liberalization of the Soviet economy and to make his case for large-scale economic aid from the West.
Although the White House reiterated today that no decision on this matter has been made, Mr. Gorbachev's request, coupled with the wishes of Germany, Canada, Italy and France to satisfy him in some way, have put Mr. Bush in a difficult position -- to flatly reject the Soviet leader's appeal would create problems with both Moscow and the Western allies.
Mr. Major, as host of the summit meeting, would have to issue the invitation, but everyone is waiting for approval from the White House. A British Government spokesman said today that a decision on inviting Mr. Gorbachev to London "would be taken quite soon." Mr. Bush has held similar private contacts on this subject with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, as well as with the leaders of the other members of the Group of Seven -- Italy, Canada, France and Japan.
Both Washington and the industrial nations appear eager to avoid embarrasing Mr. Gorbachev, even though they have serious doubts that he has yet produced a realistic economic-liberalization proposal that they could respond to in London.
American officials remain concerned that even an invitation to Mr. Gorbachev to be indirectly associated with the economic summit meeting is going to raise unrealistic expectations in Moscow. A lot of the dicussions between the allies now are focused on how to satisfy Mr. Gorbachev's request to come to London to present his latest proposals -- without raising expectations for grants that will not be met.
Nevertheless, the President's action today, coming on the heels of Saturday's agreement in Lisbon between American and Soviet negotiators resolving differences on a conventional-arms-reduction treaty for Europe, provided fresh signs that Soviet-American relations are again warming, after a period of coolness last winter prompted by the Kremlin's crackdown in the Baltic republics and Mr. Gorbachev's tilt toward domestic hard-liners.
The warming in American-Soviet relations seems largely a result of Mr. Gorbachev's increasingly desperate economic plight, which is pushing him to adopt domestic and foreign policies more in tune with the West in the hope of gaining Western economic aid. The Bush Administration is trying to use its economic leverage over Mr. Gorbachev to wring concessions from him on arms control.
On the Soviet trade benefits, what Mr. Bush technically did today was to notify Congress that he was using his discretionary authority to waive for 12 more months the requirements of the Jackson-Vanik amendment for four countries: the Soviet Union, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia and Mongolia. Today was the deadline for extending the waiver, and Congress now has a month to consider it.
The Jackson-Vanik amendment is part of a 1974 law that requires countries to permit free emigration to qualify for American trade concessions.
"Numbers of Soviets emigrating rose from 2,000 in 1986 to over 370,000 in 1990," Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said in announcing today's waiver. "The Administration believes that this positive trend will continue."
Waiving the Jackson-Vanik provision does two things. First, it enables American exporters who want to sell goods to the Soviet Union to obtain Government-guaranteed bank credits to finance those exports and lets the Soviets obtain similar bank guarantees to finance imports of American products.
Second, once the President waives the Jackson-Vanik requirement, he can grant most-favored-nation treatment to the Soviet Union, which allows the Soviets to export their products to the United States at the lowest possible tariffs. For such trade to go ahead, though, the White House would have to send the trade agreement signed by Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev last June to Congress for approval.
The President has refrained from making such a move, and did so again today, because he had tied most-favored-nation status to Soviet adoption of a free emigration law, codifying recent liberal emigration policies.
The law was enacted by the Supreme Soviet on May 20, but it will not be put into effect until January 1993, and even then it has some restrictive clauses that the Administration is still uncertain about. American officials are now in the process of trying to decide whether this law, with all its fine print, really will codify free emigration from the Soviet Union. They appear to be convinced that it will, because the officials say they expect the trade bill to be sent to Congress before the end of June.

HEADLINE: Construction Spending Up 0.8% in April

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
Spending on new construction projects rose eight-tenths of a percent in April from March, the largest gain in 14 months, the Commerce Department said today.
Analysts said the strong rise was a sign that some parts of the building industry might be climbing out of the economic doldrums. 
 The spending rise -- to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $392.6 billion -- followed a revised 2.1 percent drop in March. April's rise was the strongest gain since March 1990, when spending went up by 2.2 percent.
The improvement was concentrated, however, coming in nonresidential building like industrial plants, offices and commercial projects. Residential construction spending was down in the month, as were taxpayer-financed projects like road building.
 
Mixed Signs
 "I don't know whether we can take this as a sign that we've turned the corner on nonresidential spending," said Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI/McGraw Hill Inc. in Lexington, Mass., "but it's consistent with the view that things cannot get a whole lot worse in that sector."
The building industry led the economy into recession last year and has slumped to severely depressed levels. For instance, while April's spending gain was a clear improvement over recent months, it still reflected a 12 percent decrease from a year earlier, when construction spending was at a $444.7 billion rate.
But housing starts improved in April, as did sales of new and existing homes. Accordingly, a pickup in spending for single-family home projects is anticipated later this year.
The April rise in housing starts was one of a series of recent indications that have bolstered hopes for a summer recovery from the recession. On Friday, the Government said its main forecasting gauge for the future of the economy rose in April for a third straight month, and the nation's purchasing managers today reported an improvement in orders during May.
The construction spending report showed that outlays for single-family building rose to a yearly rate of $86.3 billion in April from $85.3 billion in March. But spending on apartments was down to $14.4 billion from $16.4 billion.
Nonresidential spending was up by 4.4 percent, to a rate of $95.7 billion, the biggest gain in more than two years, since a 5.1 percent rise in December 1988, according to Commerce Department officials.
Within that category, spending on industrial projects rose to a $21.3 billion annual rate, from $20.2 billion in March, while office construction spending rose slightly, to $22.8 billion in April from $22.4 billion.
Dave Seiders, senior economist with the National Association of Home Builders, cautioned that high vacancy rates in office buildings built in the 1980's would prevent any major expansion soon in office building.

THE ECONOMY
A law intended to encourage involvement of minority-owned firms in managing assets seized from failed savings and loans appears to be having little effect. Government documents show that Federal contracts to manage everything from multimillion-dollar loan portfolios to small apartment buildings have gone almost entirely to companies owned by whites. [Page A1.]
The U.S. will lift itself out of recession in the second half and unemployment will stop climbing in that period, the O.E.C.D. forecast. The group is widely respected for its projections. [D1.] 
 A suit by R. H. Macy that asserts that California's Proposition 13 unfairly assesses strikingly higher taxes on newly purchased property will be heard by the U.S. Supreme Court. [D1.]
The manufacturing economy improved in May, spurred by a sharp increase in new orders, according to the purchasing managers' index, which rose to 45.4 percent from 42.1. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed as Dow Rises 7.83, to 3,035.33

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices ended on a mixed note yesterday, with the blue chips extending their gains for the sixth straight day but the broader market moving lower.
Drug shares gave way as investors switched from growth stocks to cylical stocks in anticipation that the recession may soon be over. 
 Advancing to its second record in two sessions, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 7.83 points, to 3,035.33, with Caterpillar, International Paper and Disney accounting for most of the gain.
Caterpillar climbed 1 3/4, to 53 1/2; International Paper 1 5/8, to 72 1/4,and Disney 2, to 118.
The Dow transportation index, hitting another new high, rose 12.87 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,241.89, in yet another sign that investors expect the economy to improve from now on.
Trading, though, slid from a strong 232.1 million shares on Friday to 174 million yesterday. Birinyi Associates, which monitors program trading, said that waves of computer-driven buying lifted the blue chips almost 14 points, implying that if not for program trading, the Dow might also have declined.
 
Big Board Gains Slightly
 In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks dropped 1.77, to 388.06, as investors took some of their profits home. Big Board advances narrowly led declines, 808 to 750. But while only two stocks fell to new lows, 139, including General Electric, rose to new 52-week highs. G.E. rose 1/4, to 77 1/2, on 1.5 million shares after a new high of 77 5/8.
Investors continued to move into the smaller stocks as represented by the Nasdaq composite and the American Stock Exchange's market-value index, both of which edged higher.
Repeating an old market maxim to explain what happens when a handful of stocks tell the whole story, Abby Joseph Cohen, co-chairman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company, remarked, "It's a market of stocks and not a stock market."
The market, she said, "really didn't have a set course -- it was bouncing back and forth and was not indicative of any clear direction." Part of the reason, she said, was the weak bond market.
"What we saw was some individual stocks that did quite well and some that didn't," she added.
Among the first group, she mentioned "the deep cyclical, economically sensive stocks, like Dow Chemical and Caterpillar." Investors in these two, Ms. Cohen said, "are increasingly convinced the recession is just above over and both stocks are considered core holdings of cyclical stocks."
Among the second group, she mentioned individual economically sensitive stocks where there was specific news and some growth issues, like Eli Lilly and Tambrands.
Dow Chemical rose 1 1/4, to 56 3/4, in heavy trading while Caterpillar tacked on 1 3/4, to 53 1/2, again in brisk trading. Lilly fell 2, to 77 1/2, while Tambrands sank 2 3/4, to 51.
Declines of 2 or more points came in Eli Lilly, Merck, Johnson & Johnsonb and Pfizer. Medtronic, a pacemaker producer, fell 2 1/8, to 116 3/4, although analysts forecast it would split its stock shortly.
The Pacific Stock Exchange's high-technology index rose a little, with Intel, which introduced a new supercomputer on Friday up 2 3/4, to 58 1/2, on 3.6 million shares. Sun Microsystems, leading the Nasdaq market, fell 3/8, to 36 1/2, on 4.3 million shares after A.T.&T., owner of 19 percent, said it would sell the stake following its takeover of NCR.

 TOKYO, Tuesday, June 4 (Reuters) -- Stock prices closed lower here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 355.75 points, or 1.37 percent, to 25,556.86 at the end of the afternoon trading session.

HEADLINE: Sticks and Carrots for the Soviets

 BODY:
Is the prospect of reeling the Soviet Union into the Western economic orbit worth an infusion of Western aid, say $30 billion a year for five years? Many Americans say no. Just let the Soviet economy collapse. Don't prop it up at a time when the Soviets are still spending billions on new armaments and aid to Cuba.
But that shortsighted view misses the point that this is a historic opportunity for the West to change the very character of a nation that has posed a military threat for four decades. 
 The purpose of a Western aid package is to transform, not prop up, the Soviet economy. A ferocious battle now rages in Moscow between forces pushing for radical change and forces clinging to centralized control. President Mikhail Gorbachev is wavering. In this political maelstrom, Western aid could be decisive in tipping the scale toward the reformers.
The gamble is worth taking. If the Soviets renege on reform, U.S. taxpayers would lose perhaps a modest $3 billion a year, the American share of Western outlays. But imagine the other possibility. If the aid turns an archenemy into an archally, or even an innocuous neutral state, it would save the U.S. in defense alone many times $3 billion a year -- a stroke of genius.
A Western aid package need not be a giveaway. The aid, under proposals developed by Soviet and American economists, would be conditioned on three specific radical economic reforms and staged so that backsliding would lead to swift termination.
First, Moscow would have to balance its budget. Only then can it stop flooding the market with new rubles, which threaten to spark hyperinflation. Balancing the budget would inevitably force Soviet leaders to end subsidies of inefficient businesses and cut military expenditures.
The next step would decontrol prices. Markets, not bureaucrats, would then make most economic decisions. Finally, property would have to be taken away from bureaucrats and handed over to ordinary citizens.
Stabilization, price reform and privatization would transform the economy and, if successful, end the frightening disintegration of a nuclear-armed country.
The political impact would be no less radical. Moscow's chokehold over the economy would be irreparably broken; hundreds of thousands of ordinary citizens would soon be in control of their lives. The West's demands would decentralize political control along with economic control.
The West might well want to require strong steps toward a free press and competitive elections as a condition for aid. However, it will also be tempted to make Soviet military spending and an end to repression of the Baltics explicit conditions for aid. This would probably be a mistake. Such demands would arm the hard-liners who oppose reform and help them scuttle the deal. These demands are better left as implicit conditions, in expectation that economic and political reform will bring them about.
The pell-mell of markets will threaten Soviet bureaucrats and frighten ordinary citizens. They will be tempted to backslide and delay, to postpone the pain. All the West can do is lend a helping hand, perhaps persuading the fearful. If aid is strictly conditioned and parceled out step by step, it will do no harm. And it just might propel reform, with incalculable benefit.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Soviet Solution

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Look at these people -- politicians, economists, diplomats and journalists in the West. See how hard they work, to ignore the one overriding need of the people of the Soviet Union: the need for a brand new government.
 Everywhere else that Communism has collapsed, the West has understood that the first thing the people wanted, and the starting point for any hope of real change, was to get rid of the collection of bureaucrats, policemen, wardens and propagandists that made up the failed, hated government -- particularly the Communist political leaders who had perched for so many brutal years atop the whole corrupt apparatus. 
 Nobody questioned the urgent need for the Poles to get rid of what remained of the Communist Party and its disgraced leaders. Nobody warned Vaclav Havel against bringing a whole new democratic era to Czechoslovakia. Nobody scolded East Germany for trying to bring to trial some of the men who made death the penalty of climbing over the Berlin wall.
 Yet when it comes to the Soviet Union the West not only agrees that the very men who ruled the empire at the center, who for years preached and enforced the wretched economic doctrine that wrecked the Soviet Union and who ran the whole national landscape of political prisons, should not only remain in control but solemnly considers how to raise a couple of hundred billion dollars to make sure they do.
 Are we mad? Someday historians will write books trying to answer that question. How did it come to be that twice in less than a year, the West looked straight at the possibility of great achievement for civilization, shuddered and walked away?
 In February, the United States walked away from the ouster of Saddam Hussein and allowed him to remain in power. In June the whole West looks at the possibility that the Communist system may disappear from the Soviet Union and scratches its head about how much money to contribute so that the apparatchiks who helped build it can stick around for more years of criminal misrule.
 Maybe we don't need historians. In Iraq, it was failure of moral stamina and political compass by a President and a few of the men around him.
 About the Soviet Union it is more complicated. There are legions of Western specialists and diplomats -- President Bush and Secretary of State James Baker included -- who long ago committed their reputations to the political survival of Mikhail Gorbachev and cannot let go.
 Money is involved, too -- big money, the dreams of European and American businessmen of Western-guaranteed big deals with a Soviet Government they helped save.
 But probably most important is fear: if Mr. Gorbachev goes, who knows what instability may follow in the Soviet Union and its neighbors?
 Nobody knows that. But we do know that ever since World War II, what created instability in Europe has been the existence in the Soviet Union of a Government ruled by a Kremlin few and swallowing within its borders a variety of captive nationalities.
 It is not the West's right to bring down the Gorbachev Kremlin-based Government or to plot against it. But neither do we have the right to intervene by using massive aid to prolong the present Government, which has dug itself deeper into disaster every year and whose rule is clearly sputtering to an end.
 Mr. Gorbachev does not need hundreds of billions of dollars to do what his country requires. All he needs is to recognize that he has failed economically and resign while he has honor, first as head of the party and within three months as head of state.
 During those months, nationalities that want to secede should be allowed to do so -- six to eight would. The rest could prepare for elections that would choose a new president and council. He would preside over a decentralized federation that would wipe out any special status for the Communist Party, and create a new economic and political nation. The West could assist to the best of its ability, without fear of merely prolonging tragedy.
 The Soviet people would not then enter into a promised land of prosperity and guaranteed stability; seven decades of Communism are heavy heritage. But they would at last have the essential base -- a new society, free not only of the gulag but its doctrines, its apparatus and its masters and servants.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Tough Tests Don't Create More Inner-City Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Education Reform vs. Civil Rights Agenda" by Chester E. Finn Jr. (Op-Ed, May 18) discusses incentives for inner-city kids to excel in, and finish, high school. The author attacks the problem from the other side, by offering tests to evaluate the graduating student. I'm not sure this measure will help the inner-city student though. 
 Mr. Finn, a Reagan Administration Assistant Secretary of Education, says that college admissions remain largely unaffected by the poor performance of our students. Certainly, then, businesses will get the most use out of these standardized tests. Here lies the problem: there simply are not enough jobs for the inner-city students who finish high school. Offering means of ranking students who will not receive jobs seems farcical, if not insulting.
Somehow, inner-city students must be made more desirable to business. The solution may well be in more vocational training (as in Japan and Germany) or simply more directed training (as in Britain). To an inner-city student, the difference between learning engineering instead of grammar may be crucial to getting a job. But moving away from broad liberal arts training is anathema to Americans. While it may be a way to ease our economic woes, we don't see it as an improvement of our educational system.
However, as long as we consider economic realities and educational ideals as separate, I don't think the answer to inner-city schooling can be found. Students drop out of or don't excel in inner-city schools because there are other, more relevant concerns in their lives. Raising the living standards of the inner-city population will let these problems begin to take care of themselves.
Unfortunately, the people debating these issues are hampered by the luxury of financial stability. What Mr. Finn ignores is that if the jobs are not there, and college is out of the question, standardized testing will make no difference to a student. To reach these students, we must effect fundamental change. It just doesn't make business sense now for many inner-city students to continue high school. To change this will present many theoretical and logistical problems. The proposed inequalities between urban and suburban education may well be unconscionable to many. But they may also be the only way out of a bad situation.MARK S. SAUDEK
Providence, R.I., May 20, 1991
The writer is a member of the English and history faculties at the Moses Brown School.

HEADLINE: Chip Pact Set by U.S. And Japan

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
Negotiators from the United States and Japanese agreed today to extend for at least three years a set of rules covering bilateral trade in computer chips, a participant in the talks and trade experts said.
The new agreement is to be signed Tuesday, if officials in Tokyo approve it tonight. Approval of the pact is considered almost certain because it results partly from negotiations late last week in Tokyo between a senior Commerce Department official and Japanese officials, some officials said. 
 As in most bilateral trade agreements, both sides made compromises. The Japanese Government and industry initially opposed any extension of the rules, which were established in a 1986 agreement that will expire on July 31, and contended that any new agreement should run for no more than two years.
 
Option to Renew
 The American industry had pushed for a five-year agreement. The compromise was a three-year agreement, with a review at the end of that period and an optional two-year renewal.
The most controversial clause concerned American companies' access to the Japanese chip market. The 1986 agreement included a secret letter of understanding between the two Governments calling for the American share of the Japanese market to rise to 20 percent.
In 1987, after the American market share remained well below 20 percent, the Reagan Administration placed import duties of 100 percent on $300 million worth of Japanese power tools and color television sets. The Japanese Government complained frequently that the secret letter did not authorize such unilateral action.
 
Santions Are Suspended
 The new agreement suspends the $155 million in sanctions still in effect and specifies the 20 percent figure as a benchmark, not a basis for further unilateral sanctions.
Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico and chairman of the Senate Defense Industry and Technology subcomittee, said that a longer agreement with a sanctions provision sanctions would have been preferable but might not have been feasible, given Japan's reluctance to set any benchmark for American penetration of its semiconductor market.
"I don't know if it's totally adequate, but it may be all we can reasonably expect at this stage," he said. "Three years is not unreasonably short, if that's the best we can do."
The American semiconductor industry praised the pact as the best it could obtain.
"We view the new agreement as a positive step forward in opening the Japanese market and preventing dumping," the selling of products below cost, said Thomas G. Beermann, a spokesman for the Semiconductor Industry Association, based in San Jose, Calif.
A Japanese official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the new semiconductor agreement was an improvement over the 1986 pact because it limited Government intervention in the semiconductor market.
 
Separate Formulas Accepted
 But an American expert on semiconductor trade, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said, "It's not that radical a departure; it's a continuation of the 1986 agreement."
Negotiators said they agreed to use two different formulas for calculating the American market share in Japan. American officials put this at 13 percent last year, while Japanese officials insisted that it was 19 percent.
The differences are over how to count computer chips made in Japan under the brand names of American companies, how to count chips made in the United States for the Japanese subsidiaries of American companies, and how to count the sales of small producers of chips. The new formulas would still allow each country to continue to claim considerably different market-share percentages from the same facts.
Both countries also agreed that their companies would keep extensive records of the prices and volumes of chips they sell to expedite any legal cases involving charges of dumping.
 
Problems Resolving Cases
 Current cases can last a year or more. In an industry with product cycles of two years or less, this means that anti-dumping cases are often not decided until after the product at issue is obsolete and no longer widely sold.
Negotiations on the chip accord were conducted in Tokyo late last week by J. Michael Farren, the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade. The remaining issues were worked out in Washington in the last several days by S. Linn Williams, the deputy trade representative, and Naomichi Suzuki, a top official of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry.
Laura D. Tyson, a professor of economics and business administration at the University of California at Berkeley, agreed that a clause authorizing sanctions would have been desirable but said it was not necessarily something the Japanese would ever accept.
"The absence of sanctions should be considered in the context of Japanese-American relations, that the Japanese only move on these things when someone pushes them," she said. "The fact that we've excluded sanctions suggests to me that we need to continue to push them."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 8, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Articles in Business Day on Tuesday and Wednesday about an agreement between the United States and Japan to extend regulations covering trade in computer chips referred incorrectly to a provision. Only Japanese companies will be required to keep detailed records of prices and volumes of semiconductors shipped; United States companies are not subject to the requirement.
