HEADLINE: Chip Technology's Friendly Rivals

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
It is one of the computer industry's nastiest rivalries, fraught with name-calling and accusations. The winners could well make the chip that will come to dominate the business.
On one side stands a group of companies led by MIPS Computer Inc. and inspired by John L. Hennessy, a computer scientist at Stanford. On the other side, a band of companies, led by Sun Microsystems Inc., that follow David A. Patterson, a computer scientist at Berkeley. Each group has its own chip, and each denounces the rival design as inadequate. 
 And how are Dr. Hennessy and Dr. Patterson getting along with each other?
Just fine, thank you. Why, last year they joined to write one of the most widely used computer science textbooks, which has brought a new, rigorous philosophy to computer design. They see themselves as allies in promoting a radically simplified approach known as reduced instruction set computing, or RISC.
Both researchers say corporate rivalry matters far less to them than the shared thrill of creating new technologies. "I've been delighted that what I thought were good projects and good technical ideas have been commercially accepted," Dr. Hennessy said.
RISC streamlines hardware to significantly speed computer operations. It has "freed the genie from the bottle" said Gordon Bell, one of the nation's leading computer designers, by stripping away time-wasting functions.
In the last five years, RISC's advantages -- higher speeds, lower costs and quicker product development -- have allowed it to sweep the market for work stations, high-powered desktop computers. Now, many industry executives say, RISC is poised to conquer the rest of the industry -- from supercomputers to personal computers.
The simplicity of RISC technology has permitted many new companies to make chips and work stations. "Hennessy and Patterson have led a palace revolt in computer design," said Andrew S. Rapaport, president of the Technology Research Group, a Boston-based consulting firm.
RISC advocates say they realized they had won the intellectual battle over computer design when their opponents' marketing brochures began to boast about the adoption of RISC features.
"First you come up with a crazy idea and people say no," said David Ditzel, a Sun Microsystems computer designer who, as a graduate student, wrote Berkeley's first RISC research paper with Dr. Patterson. "Then you make it work, then they steal your idea, and then they claim it was their idea all along and then the transformation is complete."
First explored by researchers at the International Business Machines Corporation in the mid-1970's, RISC was more fully exploited and promoted by Dr. Patterson and Dr. Hennessy. Dr. Patterson, unaware of the earlier I.B.M. work, came up with the idea of building RISC computers after spending a year on sabbatical at the Digital Equipment Corporation in 1979.
Digital's VAX computer, more like a fully loaded Cadillac than a stripped-down racing car, offered programmers a huge set of instructions capable of meeting every contingency. But it was difficult to speed up the VAX computers with new chip technology.
Dr. Patterson felt that computer architecture had become too complicated for him to assign his students design projects that they could complete in a school year. But, on returning to the University of California at Berkeley, he recognized that RISC projects could quickly yield working computers.
Dr. Hennessy's Stanford University group soon learned about the Berkeley research and decided to start its own project. He left Stanford to found MIPS, but later returned.
Both scientists shuttle comfortably between academic and corporate settings. Dr. Hennessy, 38 years old, is the one more interested in business. The stock he received as a founder of MIPS, which has gone public, has made him moderately wealthy. He still regularly consults there.
 
Happiness Over Wealth
 Dr. Patterson, 43, consults at Sun Microsystems and at Thinking Machines, a maker of supercomputers. He rejected the chance to start a company. "I made the choice between being happy and being wealthy," he said. By the mid-1980's, two competing chips emerged from the Berkeley and Stanford research projects and were adopted by Silicon Valley rivals. Sun Microsystems designed a chip based on Berkeley's model and MIPS Computer, the Stanford one.
Throughout the decade, Dr. Hennessy and Dr. Patterson met frequently at conferences and found they shared the same views on computer design. Year after year, they bemoaned the failings of computer science textbooks. So they decided to produce their own.
They approached the writing process as systematically as they approach computer design. Beginning in 1988, they met twice a week, producing what they called alpha and beta versions of the text, borrowing the labels that software designers attach to their preliminary efforts. Before the book was published last spring, it was tested, used, reviewed and debugged by almost 300 students and by the country's 20 to 30 leading computer designers.
 
Floppy Disk by Fed Ex
 As their textbook developed, so did their mutual dependence. Dr. Hennessy remembers the frequent calls from Dr. Patterson, who would say, "I have to teach a class in two days and I need material for my lecture." Dr. Hennessy would race to finish a chapter in time to dispatch it -- on a floppy disk -- by Federal Express so that copies could be printed at a copy shop in Berkeley in time for Dr. Patterson to hand them out in his class.
Not specifically pro-RISC, Dr. Hennessy and Dr. Patterson's 594-page book, "Computer Architecture: A Quantitative Approach," (Morgan Kaufmann Publishers Inc.) explores trade-offs between cost and performance. Widely read by students, it has also become the primer for a new generation of software and hardware designers. David Cutler, a designer at the Microsoft Corporation who is writing the company's new version of the OS/2 software that controls a personal computer's operations, bought copies for all the members of his design team.
"It's the computer science equivalent of Samuelson's textbook on economics," said Dennis Allison, a designer at Hal Computer Inc. in San Jose, Calif.
Many of the colleagues of the two professors never thought of them as collaborators. "A lot of people are startled to learn that we've written a book together," Dr. Patterson said. "At one computer conference we won an award for being the most unlikely bedfellows."
Some others see them as intellectual bullies. Val Popescu, president of Metaflow Technologies Inc., a San Diego chip design company, said RISC had acquired such devout believers that any who disputed its value were treated as outcasts.
"It's simply a club mentality," he said. "These people go to conferences together and share the same ideas that have nothing to do with what the industry needs. You have a bunch of professors from Stanford and Berkeley saying something, but the market reality is not in favor of the RISC camp." RISC's detractors say that among its drawbacks is the requirement for new software, which can be expensive to develop.
Opposing the RISC proponents is the powerful Intel Corporation, which is investing more than $600 million this year to make sure that its next chip, the i586, is fast enough to preserve Intel's dominance over I.B.M.-compatible personal computers. But recently a coalition of 21 computer and software vendors, including Digital, Compaq and Microsoft, endorsed the MIPS RISC chip for use in desktop computers. In the other RISC group, Sun's allies include the Amdahl Corporation, Fujitsu and Texas Instruments.
And Dr. Hennessy and Dr. Patterson? They are back at work trying to bring about the next computer revolution. At Stanford, Dr. Hennessy is exploring new ways to hook together dozens of RISC chips in tandem. And at Berkeley, Dr. Patterson is trying to reinvent the computer disk drive business, an effort that many industry executives believe will have as big a commercial impact as RISC.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John L. Hennessy, left, and David A. Patterson lead opposing factions in a computer industry rivalry but collaborated to write a popular computer science textbook, "Computer Architecture: A Quantitative Approach." (Shane Harvey for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Head of Division Named At Kaufman & Broad

BYLINE: By N.R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
The Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation has announced that Roland Osgood, a seasoned figure in the California housing industry, will head a new home building division for the company, the largest builder of single-family housing in California.
Mr. Osgood's unit, Kaufman's ninth, will develop and market single-family homes for entry-level buyers and the trade-up market in the three-county area of Riverside, Orange and San Bernardino. They will carry a still-undecided brand name, and are intended to move Kaufman beyond its popular entry-level housing line known as the California Series. 
 Mr. Osgood, 52, has worked in the California housing business for 23 years. Until last September, he had been president of residential development for the Irvine Company, Orange County's largest land developer. He joined that company in 1979 and built as many as 3,000 housing units a year, ranging in prices from $70,000 to $1.5 million. Several years ago, Irvine left the home building industry, and Mr. Osgood said he yearned to return to it. "I went to Irvine to build homes, and I left Irvine to build homes," he said in a telephone interview.
Bruce Karatz, the chief executive and president of the Los Angeles-based Kaufman & Broad, which is also the largest builder in metropolitan Paris, said he hoped Mr. Osgood would enable the company to "broaden its product line and increase its penetration within one of the state's largest and most important housing markets." The company said continued population growth and expected economic expansion in Southern California during the 1990's should create adequate demand for more than one Kaufman & Broad brand.
Mr. Osgood said that the California market continued to be soft, but that he thought it would begin to revive in about six months. "I think this is an opportune time to tie up land," he said.
Mr. Osgood said he would initially focus on building housing in key planned communities throughout Orange County, chiefly attached and detached single-family homes priced from less than $200,000 to about $300,000. Most Kaufman & Broad homes sell for between $90,000 and $170,000. Mr. Osgood said that he expects to deliver the first batch of homes in about a year, and to reach annual production of 400 to 500 homes within three years.
After studying at California State University at Long Beach, Mr. Osgood worked for five years as an accountant, not because he liked numbers but because he was murky about what he wished to do. One of his clients, Broadmoor Homes, lured him into real estate. He worked at Broadmoor for 11 years, rising to chief operating officer, before switching to Irvine.
Mr. Osgood lives with his wife, Diane, in Newport Beach in something beyond an entry-level home, and he has four children from a previous marriage.

HEADLINE: A Bold French Insurance Chief

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 3

 BODY:
Claude Bebear, a charismatic silver-haired man who personifies the new aggressiveness of French business, sometimes seems devoted to one goal: proving that insurance executives do not have to be dreadfully dull and cautious.
Mr. Bebear, chairman of Groupe Axa, one of France's largest insurers, once organized an expedition of 80 executives, tents and all, into the Sahara to spur team spirit. He once personally returned a stolen Ferrari to a policyholder -- and got a speeding ticket along the way. 
 But leading an exciting life is not his only goal -- he also wants to lead one of the world's biggest insurance companies. For that goal, he hopes to invest up to $1 billion in the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, the faltering New York-based insurance giant, in exchange for a controlling stake.
 
Weakened by Investments
 Equitable, which has been weakened by investments in "junk bonds" and real estate, is hunting for affluent investors to raise about $1 billion in capital and will relinquish in return up to a 40 percent stake. Equitable said recently that it hoped to have an investor group lined up in the next few weeks.
For Mr. Bebear (pronounced bay-bay-are), Equitable would be his second attempt to enter the United States market. Two years ago, he lost an opportunity to buy Farmers Group Inc., the big California-based insurer, when an attempted takeover of Farmers' parent by a foreign raider was repelled.
To buy into Equitable, Mr. Bebear has "several billion dollars" at the ready thanks to recent sales of an odd collection in Axa's constellation, including stakes in a French cement maker, a large seed company and West Africa's largest brewery. If he needs more, he could sell some of Axa's $10 billion real estate portfolio.
"We hope to double our size in the next decade, which shouldn't be so difficult considering that we have increased our size sixtyfold in the last 15 years," Mr. Bebear said. Groupe Axa had $9.4 billion in premiums and $306 million in profits last year.
Depending on how big a piece of Equitable it gets, Axa could double its size overnight. But winning that prize might not be easy. Among the other potential investors in Equitable are American International Group Inc., the big insurance company based in New York, and two powerful Japanese insurers, Meiji Mutual Life and Nippon Life. Equitable may choose to raise money from an array of investors in which Axa would play only a part, albeit a major one.
None of those factors intimidates Mr. Bebear, who displays eight rifles in his office here and hunts alligators and leopards in his spare time. The office, in a sumptuous former bank building, is in one of Paris's elite districts only a block from the Elysee Palace and a far cry from the Normandy province from which Mr. Bebear moved Axa last year.
Mr. Bebear is often called "the leading visionary" of France's insurance industry. "He is a great insurance man," said Christiane Marcellier, an analyst with DLP James Capel, a Paris brokerage. "He knows the business. He knows its peculiarities."
Mr. Bebear's response is a modest one: "I am not the genius of French insurance," he said. "There are better insurers than I. I have gotten a lot of recognition because I am the person who has shaken up the industry."
"Shaken up" might be an understatement. Since taking the helm of a tiny provincial insurance company in 1974, he has turned it into Europe's eighth-largest insurer by making more than a dozen major and minor acquisitions. Besides the Sahara expedition, he led Axa executives on a whistlestop tour of six European countries, on the fabled Orient Express train.
The Sahara trip came after Mr. Bebear's small mutual insurance company swallowed two large French insurers, including a money-loser twice its size. Confronted with the daunting prospect of meshing all these together, Mr. Bebear organized the African expedition to get top managers to know each other better and think through what had to be done to create a unified group.
"When you're in the desert, you cannot reflect about things in an ordinary way," he said. "You can ponder everything without constraints." On his office coffee table is a 220-page scrapbook stuffed with pictures, of camels, campfires, sand and shrubby oases, from the weeklong trip to Tenere, Niger, in 1986. On the cover, 80 Axa executives are sitting on a sand dune arrayed in an A-X-A spellout.
Two years later, the Orient Express chugged 120 top managers through Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany, Austria, Hungary and Italy. In each country, local experts spoke to Axa executives, giving them information on the insurance market.
For Mr. Bebear, taking control of Equitable would fulfill a longtime ambition of entering the United States in a big way. "I have long thought that insurance would become international, like manufacturing and banking," he said. "To compete, it is necessary to either find a niche or become very big and very international."
The 55-year-old Frenchman clearly prefers becoming big and international. "Our strategy is to be one of the biggest players in the world," he said.
Mr. Bebear says that as Axa's clients become global companies, Axa must become global, too, so it can provide clients with insurance in not just France, but also in Britain, the United States and elsewhere. If Axa does not grow along with its clients, then they might turn to other global insurers that can provide them with one-stop global packages, he says.
The son of a schoolteacher, rather than the scion of a patrician family, like many top-level French executives, Mr. Bebear is palpably unhappy that two-thirds of Axa's revenues still come from France. He wants France to represent less than half so Axa does not have to rely on France's fickle economy. More than half of Axa's premiums are from auto, property and casualty insurance, with 38 percent from life insurance.
Axa already owns insurers in Britain, Spain, Italy, Belgium, Japan and five other countries. Being international, Mr. Bebear said, enabled Axa to spread out the cost of major investments, like its new computer system.
Two years ago, when Axa offered $4.5 billion to buy Farmers, Axa made its offer as part of a $21 billion hostile bid by Sir James Goldsmith, the British-French financier, for B.A.T. Industries, the London-based conglomerate that owns Farmers. Sir James had promised, if he won the battle, to sell Farmers to Axa, but when he withdrew his bid, Axa gave up its bid for Farmers.
Mr. Bebear already has lots of practice in making acquisitions. In 1982, Mutuelles Unies, the small cash-rich insurer he headed, purchased Groupe Drouot, which was twice the size of Mr. Bebear's company. Drouot lost $40 million in 1983, but after Mr. Bebear streamlined it and invigorated its marketing, it earned $40 million two years later. He said that if he had the same short-term quarterly report mentality that American executives had, he never would have bought a problem-plagued turnaround candidate like Drouot.
 
Bitter Battle Won
 In 1985, Mutuelles Unis renamed itself Axa, and in 1986 acquired another large insurer, Groupe Presence, winning a bitter battle with Compagnie du Midi, a powerful French holding company.
In June 1988, Axa expanded again when Midi agreed to merge its insurance activities with Axa's to help escape hostile overtures from Italy's largest insurer, Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A. Midi's chairman, Bernard Pagezy, had to swallow some pride in turning to his longtime rival, Mr. Bebear, to rescue him.
Soon, Mr. Bebear and Mr. Pagezy clashed, and with Generali's help, he took control of Midi and ousted Mr. Pagezy in 1989.
With the merging, melding and restructuring of Axa behind it, many analysts say now is a better time for Axa to make an American acquisition than when it bid for Farmers. Nonetheless, Axa's share price dropped once the company's interest in Equitable became public because many investors questioned the wisdom of Axa's entangling itself with a company with Equitable's problems.
Sounding more like a hunter than an insurer, Mr. Bebear said that success came to those willing to be audacious. "Now is the time to expand into America," he said. "You should expand in a market when it is having problems, not when it is in robust health because then you have to pay too much. You have to have courage, the courage to take calculated risks."

HEADLINE: Chief Plans Big Role for Small Panel

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
By Washington standards, the National Science Foundation is one of many small Government organizations relegated to the back of budget books as "other independent agencies."
Although it is dwarfed in size and budget even by companion technical agencies, like the National Institutes of Health and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the National Science Foundation is in a period of extraordinary growth. 
 And to Dr. Walter E. Massey, beginning a six-year term as director of the foundation, its size belies its growing influence.
The foundation, which has a $2.3 billion budget this year, has taken a major role in big interagency programs to study global climate change, to develop high-performance computer technology, and to sponsor research to improve industrial competitiveness to improve science and mathematics education and literacy, he said. And he said the agency is expanding its role as the major Federal sponsor of nonmedical basic research at colleges and universities.
"The N.S.F. is establishing a bigger presence in Washington and will play a significant role in some major undertakings," said Dr. Massey, a physicist who was vice president for research at the University of Chicago until he took his new job on March 4.
 
Seeking to Double Budget
 President Bush has continued an initiative begun by the Reagan Administration in 1987 to double the foundation's budget, then $1.6 billion, over five years. Congress did not appropriate all of the annual money requests. But the foundation, which frequently received budget increases of 15 percent or more while other agencies had to settle for the same money or less, expects to reach the goal of $3.2 billion in 1994.
The political priority given the agency, which annually awards 13,000 to 15,000 research grants in all fields of natural and social science and engineering, stems from the belief that research is the basis of future economic growth.
Dr. Massey, 52 years old, took over after the controversial term of Erich Bloch, an engineer and former International Business Machines Corporation executive who changed the course of the agency. Mr. Bloch, whose frank and sometimes confrontational style alienated some scientists as well as some people at the foundation, pushed to increase the agency's budget. In addition, he gave more emphasis to applied technology research, which would have a more immediate economic payoff for the country than the basic research the foundation had historically sponsored.
Mr. Bloch started an ambitious program of creating research centers that would combine the resources of universities, industry and government to advance key technologies. The centers, collaborative projects in which participants from different institutions share knowledge and equipment, were opposed by some scientists who felt they drained money from existing research.
But Dr. Massey said he supported the centers program, which includes 25 science and technology centers, 19 engineering research centers, 9 materials research laboratories, 5 national supercomputer centers and 41 smaller industry-university cooperative research centers.
The science and technology centers, for instance, are multimillion-dollar projects that have been designed to study things like tiny semiconductors that might be used in future computer circuits, the way microbes affect hazardous waste disposal and better mathematical models for predicting weather.
 
Grants to Individuals
 "We will continue the efforts begun by Erich Bloch," said Dr. Massey, who is known for a more congenial management style than his predecessor. "I think the direction in which the agency is now heading is a proper one." One area that will get more attention, he said, is increasing the size of grants to individual scientists. The average foundation grant is now about $55,000, which critics say is hardly enough to support a researcher and even one graduate student assistant.
Dr. Massey, formerly director of the Argonne National Laboratory in Illinois and professor of physics and dean at Brown University, was no stranger to Washington or the foundation before his appointment as director. Well known in science policy circles, he was a member of the President's Council of Advisers on Science and Technology, a group formed to advise President Bush on scientific issues. He had also served on the National Science Board, the science foundation's governing body, and on numerous Federal scientific boards and commissions.
A graduate of Morehouse College in Atlanta, Dr. Massey received his M.S. and Ph.D degrees in physics from Washington University in St. Louis. Dr. Massey's personal research has been in methods of calculating the low-temperature properties of strongly interacting fluids.
Dr. Massey has long been a supporter and originator of science education programs designed to get more young pupils, particularly members of minority groups and girls, interested in science careers. While at Brown University, for instance, Dr. Massey founded and directed a program to educate science teachers for inner-city schools. "The N.S.F., which has science education as one of its major goals, has done fairly well lately in this area and this is certainly something I will emphasize," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Walter E. Massey, physicist, who has become ninth director of the National Science Foundation. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Court's Ruling Widening Ban on Juror Exclusion by Race

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's 6-to-3 decision yesterday holding that jurors may not be excluded on the basis of race from serving in civil cases. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy's majority opinion was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun, John Paul Stevens and David H. Souter. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor filed a dissenting opinion, which was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justice Antonin Scalia; Justice Scalia also filed a separate dissent.
 
FROM THE OPINION
 We must decide in the case before us whether a private litigant in a civil case may use peremptory challenges to exclude jurors on account of their race. Recognizing the impropriety of racial bias in the courtroom, we hold the race-based exclusion violates the equal protection rights of the challenged jurors. . . . 
 Thaddeus Donald Edmonson, a construction worker, was injured in a job-site accident at Fort Polk, La., a Federal enclave. Edmonson sued Leesville Concrete Company for negligence in the United States District Court for the Western District of Louisiana, claiming that a Leesville employee permitted one of the company's trucks to roll backward and pin him against some construction equipment. . . .
 During voir dire, Leesville used two of its three peremptory challenges authorized by statute to remove black persons from the prospective jury. Citing our decision in Batson v. Kentucky, (1986), Edmonson, who is himself black, requested that the District Court require Leesville to articulate a race-neutral explanation for striking the two jurors. The District Court denied the request on the ground that Batson does not apply in civil proceedings. As impaneled, the jury included 11 white persons and 1 black person. The jury rendered a verdict for Edmonson, assessing his total damages at $90,000. It also attributed 80 percent of the fault to Edmonson's contributory negligence, however, and awarded him the sum of $18,000.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 The full court then ordered rehearing en banc. A divided en banc panel affirmed the judgment of the District Court, holding that a private litigant in a civil case can exercise peremptory challenges without accountability for alleged racial classifications. The court concluded that the use of peremptories by private litigants does not constitute state action and, as a result, does not implicate constitutional guarantees. . . .
 We granted certiorari, 498 U.S. (1990), and now reverse the Court of Appeals.
 In Powers v. Ohio, (1991), we held that a criminal defendant, regardless of his or her race, may object to a prosecutor's race-based exclusion of persons from the petit jury. . . .
 Powers relied upon over a century of jurisprudence dedicated to the elimination of race prejudice within the jury selection process. . . . While these decisions were for the most part directed at discrimination by a prosecutor or other government officials in the context of criminal proceedings, we have not intimated that race discrimination is permissible in civil proceedings. Indeed, discrimination on the basis of race in selecting a jury in a civil proceeding harms the excluded juror no less than discrimination in a criminal trial. In either case, race is the sole reason for denying the excluded venire person the honor and privilege of participating in our system of justice.
 That an act violates the Constitution when committed by a government official, however, does not answer the question whether the same act offends constitutional guarantees if committed by a private litigant or his attorney. The Constitution's protections of individual liberty and equal protection apply in general only to action by the government. Racial discrimination, though invidious in all contexts, violates the Constitution only when it may be attributed to state action. Thus, the legality of the exclusion at issue here turns on the extent to which a litigant in a civil case may be subject to the Constitution's restrictions.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 Although the conduct of private parties lies beyond the Constitution's scope in most instances, governmental authority may dominate an activity to such an extent that its participants must be deemed to act with the authority of the government and, as a result, be subject to constitutional constraints. This is the jurisprudence of state action, which explores the "essential dichotomy" between the private sphere and the public sphere, with all its attendant constitutional obligations.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 Our cases have found state action when private parties make extensive use of state procedures with "the overt, significant assistance of state officials." It cannot be disputed that, without the overt, significant participation of the government, the peremptory challenge system, as well as the jury trial system of which it is a part, simply could not exist.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 By enforcing a discriminatory peremptory challenge, the court "has not only made itself a party to the (biased act), but has elected to place its power, property and prestige behind the (alleged) discrimination." . . .
 . , . The peremptory challenge is used in selecting an entity that is a quintessential governmental body, having no attributes of a private actor. The jury exercises the power of the court and of the government that confers the court's jurisdiction. . . .
 If a government confers on a private body the power to choose the government's employees or officials, the private body will be bound by the constitutional mandate of race-neutrality. . . .
 Were it not for peremptory challenges, there would be no question that the entire process of determining who will serve on the jury constitutes state action. The fact that the government delegates some portion of this power to private litigants does not change the governmental character of the power exercised. . . .
 Finally, we note that the injury caused by the discrimination is made more severe because the government permits it to occur within the courthouse itself. Few places are a more real expression of the constitutional authority of the government than a courtroom, where the law itself unfolds. . . .
 Race discrimination within the courtroom raises serious questions as to the fairness of the proceedings conducted there. . . .

 	 	 		. . .	 	 Racial discrimination has no place in the courtroom, whether the proceeding is civil or criminal. . . . The Constitution demands nothing less. We conclude that courts must entertain a challenge to a private litigant's racially discriminatory use of peremptory challenges in a civil trial.
 It may be true that the role of litigants in determining the jury's composition provides one reason for wide acceptance of the jury system and of its verdicts. But if race stereotypes are the price for acceptance of a jury panel as fair, the price is too high to meet the standard of the Constitution. Other means exist for litigants to satisfy themselves of a jury's impartiality without using skin color as a test. . . .
 By the dispassionate analysis which is its special distinction, the law dispels fears and preconceptions respecting racial attitudes. The quiet rationality of the courtroom makes it an appropriate place to confront race-based fears or hostility by means other than the use of offensive stereotypes. Whether the race generality employed by litigants to challenge a potential juror derives from open hostility or from some hidden and unarticulated fear, neither motive entitles the litigant to cause injury to the excused juror. And if a litigant believes that the prospective juror harbors the same biases or instincts, the issue can be explored in a rational way that consists with respect for the dignity of persons, without the use of classifications based on ancestry or skin color.
 
FROM THE DISSENTS
By Justice O'Connor
 The Court concludes that the action of a private attorney exercising a peremptory challenge is attributable to the government and therefore may compose a constitutional violation. This conclusion is based on little more than that the challenge occurs in the course of a trial. Not everything that happens in a courtroom is state action. A trial, particularly a civil trial, is by design largely a stage on which private parties may act; it is a forum through which they can resolve their disputes in a peaceful and ordered manner. The government erects the platform; it does not thereby become responsible for all that occurs upon it. As much as we would like to eliminate completely from the courtroom the specter of racial discrimination, the Constitution does not sweep that broadly. Because I believe that a peremptory strike by a private litigant is fundamentally a matter of private choice and not state action, I dissent.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 The peremptory challenge "allow(s) parties," in this case private parties, to exclude potential jurors. It is the nature of a peremptory that its exercise is left wholly within the discretion of the litigant. . . . By allowing the litigant to strike jurors for even the most subtle of discerned biases, the peremptory challenge fosters both the perception and reality of an impartial jury. In both criminal and civil trials, the peremptory challenge is a mechanism for the exercise of private choice in the pursuit of fairness. The peremptory is, by design, an enclave of private action in a government-managed proceeding.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 The Court errs also when it concludes that the exercise of a peremptory challenge is a traditional government function. . . . Whatever reason a private litigant may have for using a peremptory challenge, it is not the government's reason. . . .
 Racism is a terrible thing. It is irrational, destructive and mean. Arbitrary discrimination based on race is particularly abhorrent when manifest in a courtroom, a forum established by the government for the resolution of disputes through "quiet rationality." See ante, at 16. But not every opprobrious and inequitable act is a constitutional violation. The Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause prohibits only actions for which the Government can be held responsible. The Government is not responsible for everything that occurs in a courtroom. The Government is not responsible for a peremptory challenge by a private litigant. I respectfully dissent.
 
By Justice Scalia
 We have now added to the duties of already-submerged state and Federal trial courts the obligation to assure that race is not included among the other factors (sex, age, religion, political views, economic status) used by private parties in exercising their peremptory challenges. . . . Thus, yet another complexity is added to an increasingly Byzantine system of justice that devotes more and more of its energy to sideshows and less and less to the merits of the case. Judging by the number of Batson claims that have made their way even as far as this Court under the pre-Powers regime, it is a certainty that the amount of judges' and lawyers' time devoted to implementing today's newly discovered law of the land will be enormous. That time will be diverted from other matters, and the overall system of justice will certainly suffer.

HEADLINE: C.I.A. Report on Japan Economy Creates Furor at Institute

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, June 4

 BODY:
A draft report on the Japanese economy prepared for the Central Intelligence Agency, describing the Japan as an "immoral, manipulative and controlling culture," has shaken the Rochester Institute of Technology and has led its president to suspend ties with the agency.
"I think the institution is more important than that tie," M. Richard Rose, the president of the private 13,000-student institute, said last week. 
 Mr. Rose said the R.I.T. Research Corporation, a profit-making entity of the institute that prepared the report and promotes its work, has contracts with the agency worth $1.9 million this year. Mr. Rose recently finished a four-month sabbatical working as a consultant for the agency at its headquarters in Langley, Va.
It was while he was there that the report became public. In response to the resulting controversy, Mr. Rose plans to provide an explanation and announce on Thursday, at a meeting with faculty and students, whether he will stay as president.
 
Panel to Study C.I.A. Ties
 Mr. Rose said last week that he had severed ties between the institute and the agency until at least the fall, when a panel he commissioned will investigate the relationship. The panel will also examine the research conducted on the agency's behalf, including the report on Japan.
The report, which Mr. Rose has described as embarrassing, examines Japan's economic strength. Its disclosure comes as the Japanese are being solicited for funds to expand programs at the institute. The report, which is one of a series commissioned by the agency, maintains that Japan seeks to dominate the world through its economic power.
A small group of students and faculty members has been pushing for Mr. Rose's resignation since it was disclosed in April that he was using his sabbatical to help the intelligence agency develope educational and training strategies. They maintain that his ties to the agency threaten academic freedom, because the nature of much its work is secret.
The protest led to little more than counter-demonstrations on Mr. Rose's behalf until May 24 when The Democrat and Chronicle newspaper here published an article about the report, which is titled "Japan 2000." The report, prepared by Mr. Rose's executive assistant, Andrew Dougherty, included a preface under Mr. Rose's name but was written by Mr. Dougherty.
Mr. Dougherty, the institute's liaison to the intelligence agency, took responsibility for the draft, and released a revised edition that omitted some of the more inflammatory language.
Joan B. Stone, a professor of mathematics who is chairwoman of the institute's faculty council, said, "The 'Japan 2000' report made it clear to people what the difficulty is with secrecy and not having open critique." Professor Stone said she wanted to hear from Mr. Rose on Thursday before taking a position on whether he should remain president.
Mr. Rose, who returned to Rochester a week before his sabbatical was due to end on June 1, said that he had done nothing improper by working for the agency and that the institute had never kept secret its contracts with the agency.

HEADLINE: School Districts Reeling In Weakened Economy

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CENTRAL FALLS, R.I., May 30

 BODY:
After years of stretching meager budgets, the Central Falls School Department this school year pinched the last penny it could.
The district, chronically poor because of a limited tax base, had trimmed expenses by using textbooks so long they were falling apart, by turning basements into classrooms and by purchasing $300 used cars. 
 Despite the cost-cutting, the school system of 2,700 students had to get $1 million in emergency state aid this year, and in March it did something no other school system in the United States had ever done: It asked the state to take it over, a request Rhode Island officials are expected to approve in the next few weeks.
 
Control Within Districts
 American communities cherish a centuries-old tradition of ruling their own school districts. Except for heeding certain requirements for educating disadvantaged students, and accepting supplementary funds from state or Federal sources, they have staunchly resisted outside interference in school affairs.
"There is a certain amount of fear over the loss of local control with a state takeover," acknowledged Maureen Chevrette, the school superintendent. "But without the takeover, we couldn't open next year."
As goes Central Falls, so may go many of the nation's school districts because of the current recession and the inability to raise taxes -- compounded in some instances by fiscal mismanagement. From Massachusetts to California, growing numbers of school systems required emergency state aid to finance the closing days of this school year, and many more will need assistance to reopen their doors next fall.
In Ohio, 49 of the state's 612 school systems needed emergency aid this year, and state officials expect the number to at least double next year. California reports 25 school systems with severe budget problems, up from 7 last year.
In some cases, school districts have tapped cash reserves, spending on daily operations money that had been intended for long-term projects like building programs.
"This is clearly the toughest situation for school districts since World War II," said Thomas A. Shannon, executive director of the National School Boards Association. "The system is out of harmony with the economic realities."
Reasons abound for the fiscal calamity. School systems have been squeezed by laws that limit how much taxes can be increased in a single year. Schools have also hurt themselves through fiscal mismanagement. That was what produced the bankruptcy filing this spring of the Richmond, Calif., Unified School District, according to a scathing report issued Monday by a grand jury investigating the district's failure.
But the biggest factor affecting school districts may well be the current recession. Although the 1981 and 1974 recessions hurt schools, this one has been close to catastrophic, according to education officials in several states.
Thirty-eight states have budget deficits because of sharply diminished revenue from a variety of taxes this fiscal year, which have forced Draconian school budget cuts. And in the hardest-hit areas, like the Northeastern states, the recession has reduced property values, upon which local school taxes are based.
The fiscal fallout has had ripple effects well beyond the classroom. Moody's Investor Service, an organization that rates the creditworthiness of corporations and governments, recently downgraded the credit ratings of four California districts, including Richmond, making it more difficult for these systems to borrow money or issue bonds. Several states have also initiated efforts to merge school systems to save money and improve academic programs.
 
Recession's Impact on District
 Central Falls, a working-class community of 17,637 residents about 5 miles northeast of Providence, is emblematic of the grim fiscal climate for public schools. At the start of this school year, Central Falls school officials said they realized they were fighting a losing battle, despite getting $1 million in state aid to supplement an $11.5 million budget -- already reduced from $13.5 million.
Largely because of the recession, state aid to Rhode Island school systems was cut by $33 million for the 1992 fiscal year beginning July 1. In Central Falls, efforts to make up for that loss by generating other types of revenue have been difficult.
A state law prohibits local jurisdictions from raising taxes more than 5 1/2 percent a year. Even without increases, Central Falls already levies the highest tax rate in the state -- $54.75 for every $1,000 in property value. Yet it remains the poorest of Rhode Island's 37 school systems. The town's tax base is limited and cannot be expanded because the 1.2-square-mile town is bordered by other communities on every side and cannot grow.
Moreover, James R. Martin, the school system's business manager, said, "State aid has not kept pace with the Federal and state mandated programs," like special classes for the handicapped or those who do not speak English. Rhode Island's system of reimbursing local school systems for state-mandated programs has not been amended to keep up with the cost of supporting growing numbers of pupils who need the expensive special programs, Central Falls school officials said.
Like many school systems in the country, Central Falls has had to accommodate growing numbers of handicapped and minority pupils, who represent roughly 25 percent and 44 percent respectively of the system's 2,700 students. Required programs like bilingual education and classes for children with hearing or vision impairments now account for 30 percent of the system's budget, school officials said.
The district has attracted growing numbers of poor and minority families, many of them recent immigrants from Central American counties, in part because of its reputation of accommodating youngsters with special needs. Indeed, state officials said that Central Falls's reputation as a district attuned to its residents was one reason the state responded quickly to the district's call for help.
But the pressures of educating these children, while keeping up academic offerings for most of the students, finally led the system to ask that the state take it over. The district will lose virtually all of its local control in finances and operations. Staffing, already reduced this year through employee contract buyouts and early retirements, is expected to remain about the same.
Although the cost of the takeover to the state is still undetermined, state officials said they would try to allow current programs to continue, like an entire elementary school dedicated to preschool and kindergarten pupils with learning disabilities. The state will manage the system indefinitely.
"We need all the help we can get," said Linda Colvin, an elementary school music teacher.
If demographics and a tax-rate ceiling helped hobble Central Falls, the recession has largely undone the public schools in Holyoke, Mass.
 
Cutbacks in Holyoke
 The school system has laid off teachers and reduced academic offerings, like foreign language classes, and extracurricular activities, including sports at the middle-school level. District officials worry that next year Holyoke might not have the money to comply with special education requirements and desegregation programs mandated by state and Federal law.
The district's $29 million budget is in danger of being reduced next year because the City of Holyoke does not have enough money to maintain its $24 million contribution to it. The district may even have trouble staying open for the 180-day school year next year, said George Counter, the Superintendent of Schools.
"I think it stinks," he said of the potential for more program reductions. "Nobody seems to care. They just say, 'Cut the budget.' "
Harold Raynolds Jr., the Commissioner of the Massachusetts Department of Education, said: "We really are in a kind of catastrophic situation."
But for all the external factors buffeting school budgets, financial problems sometimes simply reflect mismanagement. After the Richmond bankruptcy filing in April, a grand jury investigating the district's finances attributed much of the blame to Walter L. Marks, the former superintendent of schools, who was dismissed last December, and who has refused to comment on the situation.
The Contra Costa County grand jury reported on Monday that the district's failure was the result of "inexperience in fiscal management, inability to evaluate faulty proposals and projections presented to the board by administrators, a reluctance to refuse demands by unions and community groups and a large dose of wishful thinking."
Although the grand jury does not identify Mr. Marks by name, it said he greatly enlarged his staff and overrode cost procedures. The report said: "No legal penalties are provided for such failure, nor are there legal penalties provided for the superintendent and his associates for their mismanagement of the school system. The price is paid largely by the students of the district."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Down; Gold Prices Little Changed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed mostly lower yesterday as profit taking eroded recent gains.
Gold prices were little changed from late Monday's levels. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold fell 50 cents, closing at $362.50 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $362.00, unchanged from Monday. 
 Analysts said the dollar continued to draw support from a spate of positive economic reports in the last week. The reports, which suggest the economy may be gaining strength, have increased the chances that United States interest rates will remain stable and not be lowered to help stimulate growth.
The dollar is generally helped by higher yields, which attract foreign buyers to United States investments.
John McCarthy, chief foreign exchange dealer with Algemene Bank Nederland, said the dollar was strong enough yesterday to shake off disappointing May sales figures from the nation's auto makers.
He attributed the dollar's declines to profit taking by traders who took large positions in response to the favorable economic news. The dollar moved higher on Friday after the Government said its chief economic forecasting gauge registered a strong advance in April, and the currency rose again on Monday.
The markets were looking forward to the Labor Department's report on May employment, scheduled for release on Friday. If the report also points to an end to the recession, the dollar would be expected to climb further.
The British pound gained against the dollar Tuesday, rising to $1.7000 in New York from $1.6970 late Monday. In earlier London trading, sterling rose to $1.7035 from $1.6970.
The dollar fell to 138.85 yen in New York, from 139.15 late Monday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar fell by 0.43 yen, to a closing 138.80, and in London, it was quoted at 138.75 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's prices, were: 1.7455 German marks, down from 1.7485; 1.4920 Swiss francs, up from 1.4900; 5.9115 French francs, down from 5.9220; 1,292.75 Italian lire, down from 1,294.00, and 1.14445 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14415.
In the precious metals market, gold edged up in London to a late bid of $362.70, from $362.60 late Monday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $362.20 from $362.60. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.18 to close at $362.35.
Silver fell 1.5 cents on the Commodity Exchange, to $4.141 an ounce. Silver rose in London to a late bid of $4.20, from $4.17 late Monday.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Are Low Rates Always Good?

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
IT is an article of faith in financial markets that lower interest rates are good for the economy and higher rates are bad.
But goodness and badness depend on the financial condition of the beholder. Households, particularly retired people who are most likely to have large savings, could logically conclude that lower rates are bad and higher rates good. 
 For the country as a whole, household savings have long been greater than debts, even including home mortgages, and households have traditionally earned more interest than they pay. Since the late 1970's, when controls on interest rates were removed from bank deposits, the gap between interest receipts and interest payments has widened. By the first quarter of this year, households earned $680 billion of interest but paid only $320 billion.
The gap means that when rates fall, the decline in income is greater than the decline in savings. What's more, the discomfort from lower rates is heightened because interest rates on savings are quicker to decline than on home mortgages, credit cards and other kinds of consumer debt.
Walter Williams, head of American Business Econometrics of Ridgewood, N.J., recently calculated that by September, the four percentage point decline in short-term rates over the last two years would result in a drop of $34 billion annually in interest receipts of households. At the same time, households' interest payments will have fallen by only $4 billion a year.
"We are now in the first recession since the deregulation of interest rates in the early 1980's," Mr. Williams said, "and that has greatly changed the economy's response to changes in interest rates." With 15 percent of personal income coming from interest receipts, up from 6 percent during the 1960's, Mr. Williams contends that changes in interest income are now significant enough to make lower rates hurt the economy.
The negative effects "are not enough by themselves to push the economy into recession," Mr. Williams said. But the loss of income is enough, he said, "to make things worse" since the increases in employment that result from lower rates provide only $1 additional to the economy for every $2 that has been lost in interest income. "Fed easing of interest rates," he said, "no longer helps the economy and no longer can end the recession."
The problem facing the Fed, and part of the reason why lower rates are not producing the expected benefits, Mr. Williams said, "is due to the increased caution of banks who are not lending as aggressively as in the past."
Mr. Williams's findings, though not his conclusions, are not entirely new. A 1988 study by Richard Cantor, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, concluded that a three percentage point rise in interest rates (rates were rising at the time of his article) would supply consumers with about $15 billion of cash after tax. The extra cash would increase consumption by about $10 billion, or by a third of 1 percent.
Paul Bennett, another New York Fed economist, published a 1990 article in the summer issue of the bank's Quarterly Review about the influence of financial market changes on interest rates and monetary policy. He concluded that the changes on household cash flow identified by Mr. Cantor were "comparatively minor" relative to other effects of interest rate changes on spending.
The "other" effects are not so easy to identify, but for many economists they are the fundamental reasons why an easing of monetary policy and lower interest rates stimulate the economy and a tighter policy and higher rates restrain it.
The substitution effect, for example, holds that a rise in interest rates causes consumers and businesses to substitute high interest earning investments for spending on goods and services. Alternatively, lower interest rates stimulate the economy as investments become less attractive relative to the pleasures of consumption.
The wealth effect is another explanation for how changes in monetary policy and interest rates might affect the economy. An easing in policy and lower rates, for example, would increase the value of real estate, bonds and other investments, making businesses and consumers feel wealthier and more willing to increase their spending.
While economists search for ways to unequivocally measure the substitution and wealth effects, Fed officials in charge of monetary policy appear persuaded that the effects of changing interest rates on household interest income is small change. The trend toward lower interest rates in the last two years has been criticized as too little, too late, but it shows that the Fed believes that an easier monetary policy and lower interest rates still provide more stimulus than restraint.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Securities Are Little Changed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed and interest rates were stable in quiet trading yesterday. Barring some big surprise, market participants said activity would remain slow until Friday, when May employment figures are released.
"People seem to be positioned the way they want to be in front of the employment data," one government bond trader said. 
 Prices dipped slightly after reports from the nation's leading automobile manufacturers showed that sales in the last 10 days of May were stronger than Wall Street analysts had anticipated. But the price drop was reversed later in the session.
The reports from Detroit showed that sales reached 6.5 million vehicles at an annual rate, pushing the average for the entire month up to around 6 million units, from the anemic 5.5 million vehicles sold in April.
The gain still brings sales back only to levels of February and March, when the pace of the economic decline was accelerating.
"The numbers were a lot stronger than people were looking for, and yet the market didn't react that much," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America. "Until we get the employment data out of the way, nothing will really matter."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 97 23/32 late yesterday, up 3/32, to yield 8.33 percent, unchanged from late Monday.
Among note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 6/32, up 1/8 point, to yield 8.11 percent. And the 6 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 31/32, up 1/32, to yield 6.76 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates inched lower.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.56 percent, down a basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 2 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.69 percent.
New-issue activity accelerated in the investment-grade corporate bond market, where more than $1 billion worth of securities were priced.
The flurry had little effect on prices in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds. Traders said prices of most issues rose by 1/8 point to 1/4 point in slow trading.
Municipal bond traders said today's offering of at least $600 million worth of new New York City securities would probably carry a maximum tax-exempt yield of around 8.60 percent. At that level, demand for the issue is likely to be strong, they said.
"Yields of more than 8.50 percent on the City paper will be high enough to attract a lot of buying from investors who are not usually interested in our market," one municipal bond trader said.
Late Monday Standard & Poor's reaffirmed its A-minus rating on New York City securities.
Activity in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds was very slow, traders said. Prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged on the day.

HEADLINE: Congress Is Pressured to Retain the Space Station

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
The Bush Administration told Congress today that scuttling the space station Freedom could have serious economic and diplomatic results and could deprive the nation's youth of a major source of inspiration.
The White House message was amplified by Japan, Canada and the European Space Agency, partners in the project, whose officials warned that abandonment by the United States of the multibillion-dollar project would jeopardize future international scientific ventures. 
 The Administration even hinted that it was ready to retaliate against members of Congress who are behind the effort to kill the project, should they prevail. Adm. Richard H. Truly, head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said that if the station was eliminated, a related project in the home district of the House Appropriations Committee chairman, Jamie Whitten, Democrat of Mississippi, to build a new rocket motor "would have to be re-examined."
Mr. Bush's effort to rescue the space station, scheduled for completion by 1999 at the earliest, came a day after the committee voted to deny all of the $2 billion Mr. Bush and the space agency want for the project next year. Arguing that the money was needed for domestic programs, the panel provided just $100 million to explore less costly alternatives.
Administration officials have said they will urge Mr. Bush to veto the bill killing the station. The overall measure provides $80.9 billion for the space agency and housing, environmental and veterans programs for fiscal 1992, which starts Oct. 1.
The full House will vote on the bill on Thursday. Supporters of the space station said they would try to persuade the House to increase spending for the project to $1.9 billion. The money would come from reducing space agency programs by $1.6 billion and by cutting public housing subsidies by $250 million. The Senate has yet to write its version.
Appearing before the House Science, Space and Technology Committee, the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, acknowledged that the Administration may have to settle for less than the full $2 billion.
"We should find a way to win the vote in the House and get a substantial, I hope complete, commitment to the station," Mr. Darman said.
He added that equally damaging would be the loss of a source of inspiration to American youths.
"For them, the next big step in space is space station Freedom," Mr. Darman told the lawmakers. "Does the Congress mean to affirm the next leap forward? Or would it rather content itself with a backward glide?"
Admiral Truly warned the same committee that killing the space station would jeopardize the space agency's entire manned space effort.
Mr. Darman, Admiral Truly and John P. Boright, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, warned that if the United States stopped pursuing the space station, foreign countries would be wary of future projects.
That sentiment was echoed by officials from Canada, Japan and the European Space Agency, which plan to place $8 billion of equipment on the station and have already spent $1 billion.
So far, the United States has spent $5.6 billion on the program, Admiral Truly said. It would cost an estimated $250 million to $500 million to close down the program.

HEADLINE: Gloomier Forecast on Ad Outlays

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Recent economic data may suggest that the worst of the recession is over, but a respected advertising industry forecaster has slashed his predictions of how much advertisers will spend in the United States this year.
Ad spending in 1991 will reach $132.6 billion, up only 3.1 percent from $128.6 billion in 1990, which itself was revised downward, the forecaster, Robert J. Coen, senior vice president at McCann-Erickson U.S.A., said yesterday in New York. 
 In December, the usually optimistic Mr. Coen, who provides estimates twice a year, predicted that 1991 ad spending would total $136 billion, up 4.6 percent from his earlier forecast of $130.1 billion for 1990.
 
'Sobering' to Hear Pessimism
 "It's sort of sobering to hear him being pessimistic," said Laurie Goldberger, advertising industry analyst for Shearson Lehman Brothers. "I felt in December he was overly optimistic. His perception of the world is consistent now with mine."
Even so, Mr. Coen's forecast remains higher than many others. A study by Myers Marketing & Research, in Parsippany, N.J., predicts a scant 1.9 percent gain this year.
The prediction by Mr. Coen, who is director of forecasting for McCann-Erickson and who has been tracking ad trends since 1948, is yet another blow to an industry that has suffered through its own recession for three years in addition to the national economic downturn that began in July. Mr. Coen, who is 67 years old, is perhaps the most widely followed forecaster of advertising spending in the country.
In making his initial ad-spending forecast for 1992, however, Mr. Coen sees sunnier skies, predicting a robust rise of 8.5 percent, to $144 billion, because of the Olympics and the Presidential election.
"I see lots of reasons to be optimistic about the future," Mr. Coen told his audience of investment analysts and reporters at the University Club, "as long as we can forget the present."
Addressing current conditions, "the consensus is that things are beginning to turn around," Mr. Coen said, "but it will probably be the fourth quarter before any real confidence returns and we see any signs of a big pickup in ad spending." Any acceleration will have to struggle to overcome the "lid that was put on just about all spending plans that could be held back in December or January," he said. That was when large national marketers decided to make significant cutbacks in the face of the twin travails of the recession and the Persian Gulf war.
 
Local Newspapers Hit Hard
 The media being hit hardest by the continued sluggishness in ad spending, Mr. Coen said, are local newspapers, in both retail and classified ad linage; the national television networks; local television stations, and magazines. Among the few he identified as enjoying substantial gains are national cable television networks and nationally syndicated television programming.
Over all, Mr. Coen's forecasts national ad spending to increase at a rate more than twice that of local ad spending. Nationally, he predicted a gain of 4 percent, to $75.66 billion, while locally, the gain would be 1.9 percent, to $56.93 billion. Continuing to slow the growth on the local level is the molasses-like movement in newspaper ad spending, which accounts for 50.7 percent of total local ad spending.
Mr. Coen is more sanguine about ad spending outside the United States. His predicts that ad spending overseas this year will climb 6.1 percent, to $153.5 billion, from $144.6 billion in 1990, led by strong gains in countries like Spain, up 10 percent; the Netherlands, up 9.7 percent, and Italy, up 9.5 percent.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Decline, but Hope Is Seen

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 4

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks dropped 10 percent in May from a year earlier, but on a seasonally adjusted basis car sales alone were slightly stronger than in the previous month, leading to some hope that the automotive recession may have bottomed out.
Car sales, a barometer of economic health, are being closely watched for signs that a recovery may be under way. But statistics from a single 10-day period or just one month are often misleading, as they were in January and February when many analysts thought the bottom of the automotive downturn had been reached. Subsequent sales reports in March and April were weak, squelching the optimism. 
 The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales in May was 6 million, compared with 5.5 million in April. For the final 10 days of the month, the seasonally adjusted annual rate was 6.6 million. The rate for May 1990 was 6.7 million.
"With the exception of April and January, last month still was one of the lowest sales months in memory," said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist for Manufacturers Hanover Trust in New York. "We may have hit bottom, but we're a long way from a recovery."
Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company in New York, said the May results were "consistent with a slow, steady recovery." But he added, "It's a little early to be calling it a trend."
Sales of what are considered domestically built cars -- those made in the United States and Canada -- dropped 9.8 percent in May, to 579,406, compared with 642,304 a year earlier. Light-truck sales, which include pickups, mini-vans and utility vehicles, dropped 10.4 percent, to 338,074, from 377,281 a year ago. Combined vehicle sales were 917,480, a 10 percent drop from the 1,019,585 sold in May 1990.
During the final 10 days of the month, car sales slipped 11.6 percent, to 261,362, from 295,620 in 1990. Light-truck sales dropped 15.3 percent, to 138,436, from 163,489 a year earlier.
 
Statistical Anomaly
 In mid-May, sales of domestically built vehicles rose slightly, but analysts said the increase was a statistical anomaly resulting from unusually weak sales in the period last year.
Sales of domestically built cars dropped 11.6 percent in late May, to 261,362, compared with 295,620 last year. For the month, sales of domestically built cars dropped 9.8 percent, to 579,406, from 642,304 last year.
The General Motors Corporation's domestic car sales declined 11.2 percent, to 263,434, and light-truck sales dropped 11.7 percent, to 136,623 for the month. The Buick division was the only G.M. division to post a sales increase.
James B. Fitzpatrick, a G.M. vice president, noted that the company's sales decline in May was less steep than the 15.1 percent decline in cars and 19.9 percent decline in trucks for the first five months of the year. G.M. thinks "the present economic cycle has bottomed out" and sales will begin improving, Mr. Fitzpatrick said.
But for the last 10 days of the month, G.M.'s car sales were off 18.7 percent, to 109,058, while truck sales were off 16.8 percent, to 53,854.
Robert L. Rewey, the Ford Motor Company's vice president for sales, said, "The economic recovery anticipated on Wall Street is not yet evident on Main Street." Despite some positive economic signs, Mr. Rewey said that "underlying economic weakness will moderate any near-term sales resurgence."
For the month, Ford's domestic car sales were 142,657, down 11.9 percent. Light-truck sales for the month were 111,359, down 13.4 percent.
For the May 21-31 period, Ford's domestic car sales dropped 20.3 percent, to 56,345; light-truck sales dropped 21.4 percent, to 43,811. The Ford Taurus, Mercury Sable, Lincoln Town Car, Lincoln Continental and Ford Explorer were among the few Ford models that had higher sales.
The Chrysler Corporation's domestic car sales dropped 23 percent in May, to 61,406, while light-truck sales declined 9.3 percent, to 73,942. Of that total, 34,259 -- almost half -- were mini-vans, representing a 4 percent increase over May 1990 for that type of vehicle.
The two top Japanese auto makers in the American market, the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Honda Motor Company, each registered a smaller drop in sales than their Big Three rivals, helping them gain a bigger share of the market in May. The Nissan Motor Company's market share remained roughly the same.

HEADLINE: The Media Business;
Booksellers Cheered Up By Convention Crowds

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
Record attendance and brisk business at the convention of the American Booksellers Association lifted the mood of a publishing industry made gloomy by recession.
The association said in a statement that 35,869 people attended the four-day meeting at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, compared with 24,650 at the convention in Las Vegas, Nev., last year. 
 The attendance included 7,815 booksellers, 16,511 representatives of American publishing companies and more than 10,000 literary agents, foreign publishers and other visitors. The total exceeded pre-convention estimates by more than 10,000.
Holding the convention in New York, the center of the publishing industry, certainly contributed to its popularity.
 
New Stores Opening
 There were clear signs of the vitality of the book business despite slumping sales in the first half of this year. Laure C. Aubuchon, a vice president of Baker & Taylor Books, said 50 or 60 new stores had made inquiries about acquiring books. Baker & Taylor, with more than 160,000 books in its largest warehouse in Illinois, is one of the country's leading wholesalers.
"An incredible number of people are opening new stores," she said.
Sandor Szatman, the national accounts manager for Little, Brown & Company, said the continuing spread of "superstores" was another indication of the health of the business. Such stores usually stock more than 50,000 titles, compared with 10,000 in the average chain store. They have been opened in recent years both by independents and the big chains, like Barnes & Noble, Waldenbooks and Crown Books.
"People are looking for quality and choice," Mr. Szatman said. Reflecting this, Charles R. Cumello, president of Waldenbooks, said he hoped to expand his average store to about 20,000 titles where possible.
Although the convention went better than most people had expected, concerns persisted over the recession. "What's the issue?" asked Christopher Kerr, the sales manager of Little, Brown. "It's staying in business. People are really, really worried. The war was blamed for poor sales and now the war is over and business has not rebounded as aggressively as had been hoped."
 
'Getting Harder to Collect'
 He added that several publishers were having problems getting paid by bookstores. "It's getting harder to collect," he said.
Another contentious issue between publishers and booksellers is who pays for freight. "Free freight" has become a slogan among stores. But publishers are split, with some, like Random House and Little, Brown, declining to pay, and others, like Bantam Doubleday Dell, covering the cost of shipments.
"Freight is the bitterest single issue," said Donald B. Alper, the president of Bedford Books Inc., a company of 11 bookstores in Maine, New Hampshire and Massachusetts. "Our profit margin is small and publishers can factor the freight into the cost of the book. But the bookseller's price is set and paying for freight further erodes our profits."
Jack Hoeft, the chief operating officer of Bantam Doubleday Dell, said he thought free freight would be a stimulus to the industry. "We have free freight and I would encourage all my competition to do the same," he said.
But Mr. Kerr of Little, Brown said he did not think the company would switch its policy. He argued that those publishers that do not pay freight tended to compensate for booksellers' added costs by offering them steeper discounts off list price.
