HEADLINE: Recession Puts Summer Job Market in Doldrums, Youths Find

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
Only a few years ago employers were searching desperately for students who would fill the traditional jobs of summer -- at the beach, at amusement parks, at resort hotels.
But seasons change and so do economic cycles. And this year it's the young people who are going begging. 
 Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Federal Department of Labor Statistics, said employers' need for summer help in New York and New Jersey last year resulted in about 700,000 more jobs in June, July and August for young people from 16 to 24 years old. No figures will be available for this year until the end of the summer, but labor analysts expect the recession to shrink the summer job pool, and employers and young job-seekers say they are already seeing the effects.
"It is going to be a very tough job market for them," Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
 
More Competition
 No breakdown was available on the number of summer jobs last year in Connecticut, which is part of a different Federal statistical region. But C. Richard Ficks, a spokesman for the Connecticut Department of Labor, said young people there would also face problems finding jobs this year.
"There have been major layoffs in insurance and banking, and they were targets for young people," he said.
It is true that the baby boom has yielded to the birth dearth, as demographers would say, leaving a smaller pool of people 16 to 24 chasing the jobs that are available. But in tough economic times, it is not just young people who want the seasonal jobs.
Some adults thrown out of work because of weakness in the region's economy will take any jobs available. And retired people -- a pool of labor that employers turned to in the mid-1980's when they could not find enough teen-agers for summer jobs -- are also filling some of the seasonal slots.
At the Water's Edge Inn and Resort in Westbrook, Conn., the personnel manager, Madeleine Flaherty, said that only three years ago, local teen-agers scoffed at low-paying housekeeping jobs, and the resort was forced to hire a dishwasher from New York City, 80 miles away.
But this year she has scores of applications from high school and college students. "We can be choosier now," she said. "And a lot of the kids we had last year are coming back. They're hanging on to whatever they can get."
Ms. Flaherty said that the hourly wage for a dishwasher at the resort, which increases its staff to 130 each summer, from 90, has dropped from $7 to $6.50 since last year, and the minimum-age requirement for housekeepers has been raised from 15 to 16.
"It is incredible -- I've watched a whole cycle," she said. "Kids wouldn't take a dishwasher job five years ago, but now they come in and beg for dishwasher jobs -- and I tell them there are no dishwasher jobs. Now we have men doing the dishwashing and just one or two kids."
At the Six Flags Great Adventure theme park in Jackson, N.J., 25 percent of the 3,500 employees are adults, up from 20 percent last year.
Brian E. Simmons, a personnel supervisor at the theme park, said that nonstudent labor offers an advantage because adults do not have to wait for classes to end before they can work. "We've seen a big increase in the adult population that has taken slots," he said. "Now for the youths, there is a little bit less here."
 
Cutting Back Advertising
 Six Flags Great Adventure expects to receive 9,000 summer job applications this season, compared with 7,000 last year. And the park, the largest private summer employer in the state, has been able to do its hiring earlier than in the past: on May 20, a week before Memorial Day weekend and the unofficial kickoff of summer, 94 percent of its jobs were filled this year, compared with 88 percent a year ago.
In response to the glut of applications, Six Flags Great Adventure has cut back on its job advertising and recruitment in local schools.
"The word has gotten out in the schools that we're not hiring like we were," said Melissa J. Tanney, 17 years old, of Freehold, N.J., who works in the summer as a personnel assistant at the park. "So a lot of people probably aren't even coming in to apply."
Amy Carroll of Colt's Neck, N.J., a 19-year-old University of Miami student, recently applied for a job at the theme park after failing to find anything at several restaurants, a bakery and a video store. "It's been pretty difficult," she said. "There are usually signs up everywhere advertising for people, but this year there aren't any."
State budget cuts are also hurting young people's chances for summer jobs this year. In Connecticut, part of one of the state's most popular beaches, at Hammonasset State Park, will be closed this year because the state did not have money to hire enough lifeguards. The beach will have 18 lifeguards this year, one fewer than last year and a big drop from the 33 lifeguards employed in the mid-1980's.
"This year we have more applicants but fewer jobs for them," said Gus Constantine, water-safety program coordinator in the state's Department of Environmental Protection.
 
'Outlook Is Very Dim'
 Employment counselors at local high schools agreed that there were fewer jobs available for students than in past years. In the 1980's, students wanted jobs that were career-oriented or in fields that interested them academically. But now, counselors say, they will take whatever they can get.
"The outlook is very dim," said Iris L. Burroughs, the employment counselor at Julia Richmond High School on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. "Most of the students are trying to get into the city's job program."
New York City can employ more young people this summer because Federal money for its jobs programs increases when the unemployment rate goes up. That will mean part-time public-sector jobs for 39,500 youths in summer programs this year compared with 24,000 last year.
But a weakened employment situation also means more people seeking work. Josephine Nieves, the Commissioner of the New York City Department of Employment, said that more than 1,000 young people a day had been applying for positions.
"We're already turning people away," she said.

HEADLINE: New York Feels Pinch of Slump In U.S. Tourists

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Although foreign visitors continue to find New York City an attractive destination, a steady decline in the number of Americans coming to the city is limiting tourism's ability to help lift New York out of its economic doldrums this summer.
Reservation clerks at several Manhattan hotels say bookings have picked up since the end of the Persian Gulf war in February but are still 5 to 10 percent below the level of last summer, which was also down from the year before. 
 With the national recession, New York has become too expensive a destination for many Americans despite a decline to $134.01 in the average price of hotel rooms in the first three months of this year. The average price for rooms was $138.96 for the corresponding period in 1990.
"The group business and international tourists seem to be coming back, but not the domestic commercial business yet, because of the recession," said John A. Fox, a senior principal at Pannell Kerr Forster, the New York accounting firm that tracks hotel occupancy rates. "I think the summer will be lower than last year, but it depends on the economic recovery."
 
It's Big Business
 The number of visitors to New York City is of far greater import than whether New Yorkers can hope to get a table at a fancy restaurant at the last minute or a ticket to a hot Broadway show. Tourism in New York is big business.
The estimated 25 million tourists who came to New York City in 1989, the most recent year for which figures are available, spent about $9 billion, according to the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.
By the time that $9 billion wound its way through the local economy, causing other people to earn and spend more, the total economic impact of tourism was an estimated $12 billion. To put that in perspective, combined Wall Street salaries at their peak in the late 1980's were about $11 billion.
"It's one of the largest industries in the city," Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said of tourism. "It's extremely important."
Of the estimated 25 million tourists who come to New York City annually, domestic tourists outnumber foreign visitors four to one. So the 7 percent decline in domestic airport arrivals and the 5 percent decline in Amtrak arrivals from 1988 to 1990 -- many of whom are presumed to be domestic travelers -- have hurt New York's travel-related industries badly.
 
Softening the Blow
 The continued influx of foreign tourists is all that is softening that blow. That is especially so because although overseas visitors make up only 20 percent of the total in numbers, they account for almost 40 percent of all spending.
Lufthansa German Airlines, for example, reported that since the end of February it has seen a 20 percent increase in passengers on its flights to New York from Frankfurt, compared with the same period last year.
International arrivals at La Guardia, Kennedy International Airport and Newark International Airport, were 5 percent higher in 1990 -- at 11.3 million -- than in 1988 -- at 10.8 million.
These two sides of tourism -- the enthusiastic foreigner and the reluctant American -- were reflected in the attitudes of two sets of tourists who were visiting Manhattan recently. Several teachers from the Midwest who were in town for a national debate competition said they found New York City crowded, dirty and expensive.
 
Not the 'Cheapest Town'
 They did not intend to spend much while in New York, they said, and the advice from their hotel not to go out after 6 P.M. did little to ally their fears of crime.
New York is not "a place that people would put high on their list for a vacation," said Tom Clementi, a humanities teacher from Appleton, Wis.
"And the expense, too -- this isn't the world's cheapest town," he added.
The feeling appears to be different for foreign travelers.
Two Spanish visitors to Manhattan who had decided to stay in New York for a week after completing a business trip said they found New York inexpensive compared with their hometown of Madrid. And that seemed to outweigh any fleeting concerns about coming to personal harm.
"We've spent a lot of money," said Jose Luis Pastor, flashing a somewhat embarrassed smile.
The strength of foreign tourism is "strongly due to the favorable dollar -- more than anything else," said Kerstin Sabene, an assistant manager of public relations in Lufthansa's New York office, referring to the favorable exchange rates most foreign currencies receive in the United States. As for concerns about crime, "our German managers don't think it's a deterrent," she said.
A manager at Mamma Leone's, that mid-Manhattan bastion of pasta that draws so many visitors, reported that "foreign people are kicking back in now that the war is over." Conrad Bennett, the restaurant's director of operations, said, "It's equal to last year, though not better yet."
And Alfred J. Pettanati, the manager of the observation deck at the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan is optimistic about attracting steady business from international tour groups this summer. When he was in Berlin in March, local tour operators began telling him that their telephones were finally beginning to ring again. About 50 percent of those who buy tickets to the deck are visitors from abroad, he said.
The growing importance of foreign tourists to New York has led some to call for the city to do more to make itself hospitable and "user-friendly" to visitors from abroad.
Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University, says his research shows that the city is too expensive for most Americans and that they find many features of New York alien to their culture, preferring attractions like Disney World or the national parks instead.
Foreign visitors, by contrast, often come from large cities themselves and seem to be more tolerant of dirt and congestion and to take greater pleasure in dabbling in New York's activities, like eating, shopping and taking in cultural events.
New York City already draws about half of all Italians visiting the United States, more than 40 percent of all Spaniards visiting this country and more than a third of all French visitors, Convention and Visitors Bureau figures show.
 
'Enormous' Potential
 Mr. Moss will urge in a forthcoming study on tourism that New York make itself easier for foreign visitors to consume, by making information more readily available in foreign languages, making it easier to change currencies and putting together special shopping or cultural tour packages, like baseball or golfing excursions for enthusiasts from Japan.
"The potential is enormous," said Mr. Moss.
The president of the Convention and Visitors Bureau, Marshall E. Murdaugh, could not agree more. Because it now receives a portion of the recently increased hotel tax, the bureau has been able to increase its sales force, open a Washington office and hire sales representatives in Tokyo, Frankfurt and London.
The fruits of that expansion can already be seen. New conventions booked through April of this year are expected to bring 186,980 delegates to the city in future years, compared with 89,945 delegates who were booked during that same period last year for future visits, Mr. Murdaugh said. While that will not have any impact on this summer's business, it is certainly good news for the future.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Shearson Gives Itself a Face Lift

BYLINE: Kurt Eichenwald

 BODY:
ALMOST a year after it became a wholly owned subsidiary of the American Express Company, Shearson Lehman Brothers is prettying itself up.
The brokerage house -- the nation's second largest, after Merrill Lynch -- is negotiating deals to shrink its exposure to potential loan losses, Wall Street executives said yesterday. The moves are intended in large part to reassure the bond market, upon which Shearson depends for billions of dollars in financing, that the firm is moving toward better financial health. 
 The effort mainly involves moving troubled assets off of Shearson's balance sheet and on to those of sister companies within American Express or to outside parties, through sales.
In the deals being considered, Shearson would unload at least $3.3 billion of its exposure. An additional deal, in a more preliminary stage, would remove $500 million in capital the firm has at risk.
The deals under consideration include transferring the firm's Balcor real estate subsidiary into a newly created American Express subsidiary, selling the firm's British mortgage portfolio, selling a mortgage company owned by the brokerage and possibly transferring a huge bridge loan to Prime Computer Inc. off of Shearson's books -- even though Prime's interest payments are current.
The various moves to improve the firm's capital base come as Shearson is trying to reduce its borrowing costs. On Monday, the firm registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission to issue $1 billion in debt for general operations.
Shearson executives said yesterday that the new borrowings would be used, in part, to replace some outstanding debt issued when the market was skittish about the firm's credit exposure. As a result, executives expect a drop in the interest rate the firm pays on its debts.
In recent weeks, executives with Shearson and American Express said action would have to be taken to shore up the capital base of the firm. It has been struggling to deal with a number of troubles brought on by investments made in the 1980's.
For American Express shareholders, those statements raised the specter that new stock could be issued by the company to raise money for a capital injection into Shearson -- which would dilute the shares of current stockholders. But analysts said yesterday that the actions taken by Shearson to deal with its credit problems decreased the chance that American Express would have to turn to the equity markets.
"If they are able to remove this possible overhang to their capital, it just makes it that much less likely that American Express will have to recapitalize Shearson," said Guy Moszkowski, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
Indeed, senior Shearson executives said yesterday that they thought the moves to reduce the exposure of the firm would solve its capital problems. "I don't think it's necessary," Howard Clark Jr., Shearson's chairman and chief executive, said of a possible capital injection by American Express.
The reduction of the firm's capital exposure, company executives and other industry officials said, would be accomplished through a series of complex transations.transactions.
For example, the firm's troubled Balcor real estate subsidiary would be transferred at book value to a new American Express subsidiary to be established for the sole purpose of holding it.
The transfer would have no effect on American Express's balance sheet, since it would be a deal between two subsidiaries. But it would remove Balcor from Shearson's balance sheet.
Shearson executives also said yesterday that the firm was seeking a buyer for its mortgage-banking unit, the Shearson Lehman Mortgage Corporation. The unit, based in Irvine, Calif., services about $18 billion in mortgages, and its sale is expected to remove about $1 billion in credit exposure from the firm's balance sheet. While there have been some expressions of interest, it could not be immediately determined which what companies were considering the purchase of were looking at the mortgage unit.
 At the same time, Shearson is seeking a buyr for the British mortgage portfolio of its Boston Company subsidiary. Mr. Clark said yesterday that the firm had found "interested parties who would pay at least what we have in the books," taking an additional $800 million in exposure off the balance sheet.
Although some Wall Street executives and analysts said they expected the firm to transfer to American Express some of the Boston Company's troubled loans -- including one to Donald J. Trump -- Mr. Clark said sufficient reserves had already been set aside to cover the unit's potential problem loans. "What the Boston Company has in loans is going to stay at the Boston Company," he said. "We feel that the reserves are adequate."

HEADLINE: Iraqi Plea on Exports Rejected at OPEC Talks

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VIENNA, June 4

 BODY:
OPEC today rejected a request by Iraq for a letter addressed to the United Nations asking for an end to sanctions barring Iraqi oil exports.
The request was made by the Iraqi Oil Minister in what turned out to be the shortest meeting in more than a decade of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. 
 At the one-day meeting, the group decided to retain the current overall production ceiling for its 13 members at the current level of 22.3 million barrels a day, an outcome that was widely expected by the oil industry.
The Iraqi plea for help with the United Nations was firmly rejected by the Arab oil-producing countries in the Persian Gulf. The Saudi Oil Minister, Hisham Nazer, told his Iraqi counterpart, Ussama Abdul Razzaq, that four countries present at the meeting, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar, had fought a war against Iraq to expel its troops from Kuwait. Mr. Nazer said these countries were not about to plead with the United Nations to lift sanctions that resulted from the Iraqi aggression, according to several Arab delegates here.
 
Demand Will Be Met
 OPEC officials said the quick decision to freeze the present level of production, which is estimated at above the ceiling, averaging a daily output of 22.8 million barrels a day, is enough to match anticipated demand for OPEC oil in the third quarter.
The OPEC ministers agreed to meet again in September to review the supply and demand balance for world oil markets.
That meeting could accomplish little more, however, since both Iraq and Kuwait have been out of the oil-exporting business altogether since Aug. 2, when Iraq invaded Kuwait. Because of heavy damage done to the Kuwaiti oil industry and sanctions imposed on Iraq during the Persian Gulf crisis, neither country can export oil for at least another six months, OPEC officials estimate.
This would allow Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, and the United Arab Emirates to continue to pump as much oil as they can to make up for the shortage from Iraq and Kuwait and reap additional benefits from surpassing their normal quotas.
In its communique today, OPEC reaffirmed, however, that it still regards $21 as the ideal price for oil, even though the current price for OPEC crudes hovers near $17.
The average price of a basket of crude oil monitored by the group stood at $17.68 last week. The price often quoted in the United States, for a premium light sweet grade of crude, is several dollars higher.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange today, crude oil futures settled 11 cents to 15 cents lower, with the July contract at $21.02 a barrel.
The organization's Secretary General, Dr. Subroto, who was elected to a new three-year term, said prices would be rising gradually throughout the year as demand for oil increases, which is what he anticipated. Also, Venezuela's oil minister, Celestino Armas, was elected the new president.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Celestino Armas, Venezuela's Minister of Energy and Mines, at the OPEC ministerial meeting yesterday, during which he was elected president of the group. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Industrial Nations Agree To Push for Trade Accord

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 4

 BODY:
The industrial world's finance and trade ministers have resolved to give stalled trade talks a big push forward this summer as they agreed today to try to complete the four-and-a-half-year round of negotiations late this year.
At the annual meeting of ministers of the 24-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, American, European and Japanese officials said they would seek to make substantial progress this summer in narrowing differences in numerous trade areas, including financial services and subsidies to farmers. 
 At today's meeting, American and European Community officials were not clashing angrily, as they often had in the past, over their differences on how much to slash trade-distorting aid to farmers. Instead, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, and Frans Andriessen, the community's commissioner for external affairs, vowed to step up negotiations in the belief that the plan of the community to change its farm subsidy program could help bridge its differences with Washington.
In the hope of rescuing the talks, the ministers are seeking to put the clashes about the farm aid behind them, but they still acknowledge that it will be difficult to reach an overall agreement. "We have a very narrow time frame and we have to finish the round successfully by the end of this year," Mr. Andriessen said.
Also today, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady urged other industrial nations to increase their growth to help end the economic slowdown in the West and create a favorable economic climate that would spur the reconstruction of Eastern Europe and the Middle East.
After having called for lower interest rates at a Group of Seven meeting in Washington in April, Mr. Brady said he was happy that several European nations, including Britain and Italy, had recently lowered their rates. But he indicated, in a more conciliatory tone than in April, that there was room for further rate cuts, although German officials again said today that they would not lower rates because of their inflation concerns.
Officials here said that the decision by several European countries to lower rates and the sense that the West's economic slowdown was ending had helped temper Mr. Brady's remarks on interest rates. In addition, European officials said that Washington was showing greater understanding that Germany, whose powerful central bank has kept rates high, was in a far different position from the United States since Germany was enjoying strong growth and its inflation was rising.
Nonetheless, Mr. Brady repeatedly suggested that nations that had high interest rates had adopted a defensive strategy that provided little impetus or inspiration for Eastern Europe and the third world. "You cannot produce something that will excite the world with some backward, negative philosphy," he said. "We have to do that with a positive, energy-laden, hopeful philosophy, a strategy of how that's going to be done, and that's growth."
Mr. Andriessen, the community's top trade official, said he regretted that the trade talks, known as the Uruguay Round because they began in that country, had focused so much on agriculture. The talks collapsed last December in Brussels when the community, which said it would reduce subsidies to farmers by 30 percent, refused to move closer to Washington's demand that it cut domestic support to farmers by 75 percent and export subsidies by 90 percent.
Mr. Andriessen said that in exchange for any concession the community made on agriculture, it wanted new rules for trade in financial services and intellectual property as well as new rules for resolving trade disputes.
 
July 31 Goal Urged
 In a speech today to the O.E.C.D. ministers, Mrs. Hills said that by July 31 the 108 nations negotiating in the Uruguay Round should seek to agree to the range of annual reductions in farm subsidies and the base period for which the reductions would begin. She also called for a framework text to liberalize trade in services.
The one area where tensions remained high today involved tied-aid credits, whereby the industrial countries give aid to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union while requiring that the money be used to buy goods from the donor country. Washington is pushing to prohibit such tied aid, which the Eastern Europeans complain is unfair to them because it makes it harder for them to sell goods to each other or the Soviet Union.
But several officials interviewed said Italy, France and several other European nations were opposing such a ban, and that this was blocking an agreement at the meeting.

HEADLINE: U.S. May Ease Rules Affecting Foreign Stocks

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed to make it easier for foreign companies to raise money in the United States by exempting them from many Federal securities regulations. The companies instead would need to comply only with the securities rules of their home countries.
The proposed changes, which have widespread support at the commission and are expected to be adopted by the end of the year, mark the third regulatory move by the agency in the last two weeks to attract more trading to the major American markets as global investing increases. 
 "These proposals represent a major step in the evolution of the U.S. securities regulatory system to adapt to the realities of an international marketplace," said Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the S.E.C.
Commission officials said today that the proposed changes would give Americans holding foreign stock the same opportunities as foreign-based shareholders of the same company when the company offered new stock or was in the midst of a takeover contest.
Reducing the barriers would thus allow for greater shareholder activity, they said, and enable foreign businesses to more easily raise capital by selling stock in the United States.
Mr. Breeden said that in 1990 there were more than 600 mergers and takeovers abroad, most of which had some American stockholders who "were excluded from participation in such transactions due to the costs of complying with the full U.S. regulatory scheme."
He said the proposals were intended to make it less burdensome for foreign companies to extend stock offerings to shareholders in the United States.
The S.E.C. currently requires foreign companies to comply with the American regulations on disclosure, timing and accounting, as well as those of the home country. But officials believe those regulations have generally discouraged foreign companies with American stockholders from including them in new offerings and takeover contests.
For instance, during the 1989 attempt by Minorco, the Luxembourg-controlled South African mining giant to take over Consolidated Gold Fields of Britain, Minorco said it would not make its offer available to American shareholders in large part because it said it was too expensive to comply with the Williams Act. The overall bid ultimately failed, however, after it was blocked by a Federal judge who said it would have been in violation of antitrust laws.
The agency estimated that in 1990 Americans holding foreign stocks, which generally trade on the major exchanges in the form of American depository receipts, were excluded from more than 85 offerings.
Since the S.E.C. was established during the Depression, the foundation of American securities laws has been a requirement for disclosure, based on the idea that investors can make their own decisions once they have adequate information. But many other countries require far less disclosure, and companies based in those countries have faced the choice of either making the additional disclosures or being limited in their ability to sell securities to the American public.
Still, largely through American depository receipts, many such companies have been able to attract American shareholders. By allowing those American shareholders to participate in takeovers, the S.E.C.'s proposal could make A.D.R.'s more popular, and thus make it easier for the companies to raise capital in the American market without complying with American disclosure rules.
Some securities scholars said the proposed changes were part of an evolution that would lead to a substantial reduction in the disclosure requirements for American companies.
"These developments ultimately will mean the watering down of the domestic requirements," said James D. Cox, a professor of securities law at Duke University. "You can't live long in as politically attuned an environment as the S.E.C. and impose lighter requirements on a company from Japan than one from Peoria."
The changes proposed today follow two moves late last month aimed at building the nation's securities business in the face of global competition.
On May 20 the agency gave the New York Stock Exchange permission to extend its hours in an attempt to capture growing amounts of institutional trading that have moved abroad. And last week the commission adopted a rule that permits Canadian companies to submit Canadian disclosure documents and prospectuses to the S.E.C. and avoid the higher costs of making different filings under United States requirements.
Today's proposal would exempt foreign companies that have up to 10 percent of their stock held in the United States from the disclosure requirements and time periods for keeping the offers open under the Williams Act. The exemptions would apply to situations in which the foreign companies issue new securities or rights to purchase securities or offer to buy or exchange stock in a foreign company as part of a takeover contest.
The foreign company would instead be required to submit to the S.E.C. any prospectuses and other documents involving the transaction that it filed in its own country. Unlike domestic filings, the foreign submissions would not be reviewed for compliance by the S.E.C. but would be available for public inspection.
A British company making a tender offer for the shares of another British company, for example, could extend the offer to the target company's American stockholders by simply furnishing to the S.E.C. and the stockholders the same documents it files with British authorities.
With the changes proposed today, securities experts said the S.E.C. was reacting in large part to the integration of the economies of 12 nations in Europe next year.
"The S.E.C. is in many respects between a rock and a hard place," said Ronald J. Gilson, a professor of corporate law and securities regulation at Stanford University. "It is in an awkward role as it tries to protect investors at the same time that it is trying to assure that they have the same opportunities as their foreign counterparts."
Mr. Breeden acknowledged that the changes "involve a trade-off," waiving certain investor protections for greater access to foreign markets. But he added that "the practical reality is that such protections would not be available to U.S. shareholders, and U.S. shareholders would not be able to even participate in most of these transactions under any set of regulatory protections."
 
Anti-Fraud Provisions Intact
 The changes would not exempt the foreign companies from the anti-fraud provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, which have been interpreted to prohibit insider trading.
At a hearing today to disclose the proposed rule changes, Edward H. Fleischman, a commissioner at the agency who formerly worked as a securities lawyer on Wall Street, raised the question of whether foreign companies had actually avoided offerings in the United States to avert lawsuits from shareholders.
Mr. Fleischman was assured by Linda C. Quinn, director of the S.E.C.'s division of corporate finance, that "the rights and liabilities of the foreign companies are the same as if they were in the United States."
The proposals to waive the American requirements would be limited to instances where the American shareholders represent 10 percent or less of the total ownership. In the case of an offer to exchange stock -- a common way of structuring takeovers and raising money by foreign companies -- the proposed waivers would apply only to an offering in which the total value of American stockholdings does not exceed $5 million.

HEADLINE: Shunning Bush Alternative, House Set to Pass Rights Bill

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
The House of Representatives tonight defeated President Bush's civil rights bill and set the stage for approval of the Democratic leadership's version, a measure Mr. Bush calls "a quota bill."
The Bush proposal was defeated, largely on party lines, by a vote of 266 to 162. Only 19 Republicans abandoned their President while just 16 Democrats voted with him. 
 Tonight's margin offered no certain guidance on the strength of support that the Democratic leadership's bill would find on Wednesday. Some representatives who voted for the Bush bill tonight have said they would turn around and vote for the leadership's bill Wednesday.
But their total is not expected to approach the 33 representatives who did that last year, voting first for the Administration proposal and then for the civil rights bill.
Earlier today, Speaker Thomas S. Foley said he did not believe the support for the leadership's bill would reach the two-thirds majority that would be needed to override Mr. Bush's threatened veto. That would be 290 votes if the full House voted. Last year's similar bill got 273 votes.
Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the Republican minority leader, said tonight that Mr. Bush's bill stressed "fairness over quotas, conciliation over litigation, unity over divisiveness." But Representative Don Edwards, the California Democrat who heads the Judiciary Subcommittee on Civil and Constitutional Rights, said that bill would make it "very easy for an employer to justify discriminatory practices."
Before that debate, the House swept aside another substitute for the Democartic leadership measure by a vote of 277 to 152.
That alternative was termed "the pure bill" by one backer, Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado, because it included none of the compromises the leadership made in the hope of getting a two-thirds majority for its plan.
 
Changes in Court Rulings
 In particular, she and others urged support for their substitute because it did not include any limit on the damages that could be won by women in sex discrimination suits. The leadership's bill limits punitive damages; the Bush bill bars punitive damages altogether.
That is one of many differences among the competing proposals. All would undo some Supreme Court decisions of 1989 and make it easier to sue and collect damages in job discrimination cases, but the Bush bill would make the smallest changes.
Much of today's debate was devoted not to Mr. Bush's proposal but to whether the Democratic leadership's bill would lead to quotas in hiring and promotion.
Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, said it would because "the bill's presumption of guilt and high hurdle of proof will force employers to hire by the numbers." If the bill passed, he said, employers would stop using the term "equal opportunity employer" but prefer "statistically proportonal employer."
 
Putting Intent on the Record
 Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, the majority leader, insisted the bill not only did not promote quotas but "clearly and unequivocally bans all forms of quotas." He said Republicans were speading concerns about quotas so that people laid off in a "Republican recession" would blame blacks or women for their troubles. "Black or white, you get the same pink slip in a Republican recession," he said.
Then he and Representative Jack Brooks, the Texas Democrat who heads the House Judiciary Committee, engaged in a scripted question-and-answer routine intended to establish a political point: that their bill was anti-quota and the President's bill was not, because Mr. Bush's lacked any specific provision declaring quotas unlawful and theirs did.
They also tried to make an important legislative point. "Some have claimed that the quota langauge would forbid quotas in terms of hiring unqualified persons, but would not forbid them with respect to hiring qualified workers," Mr. Gephardt said in their colloquy. "Is this distinction valid?" he asked.
Mr. Brooks read this reply: "The distinction is not valid. The language forbids quotas' being applied to any employment situation -- whether it would involve qualified or unqualified persons. That is why the bill clearly states that quotas are forbidden 'regardless of whether such persons meet necessary qualifications to perform the job.' The adverb 'regardless' is purposely used to eliminate any distinction between setting quotas as between qualified and unqualified workers, or as between different qualified employees."
The full language of bill that includes that passage says, "The term 'quota' means a fixed number or percentage of persons of a particular race, color, religion, sex or national origin which must be attained, or which cannot be exceeded, regardless of whether such persons meet necessary qualifications to perform the job."
The Bush Administration has charged that the Democrats' anti-quota language would in fact legitimize quotas in which employees who barely met job qualifications would be preferred because of race or sex over more-qualified employees.
The colloquy today was intended to establish a legislative history that could be considered by courts on how the measure should be construed if it became law.
 
A Senate Rights Package
 In the Senate, meanwhile, nine moderate Republicans introduced a package of bills intended as a compromise between the Administration and the civil rights groups backing the Democratic bill. Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, said he knew Mr. Bush wanted a bill enacted. Asked if he thought one was desired by the White House staff, with whom long and fruitless negotiations were held over the bill Mr. Bush vetoed last year, he replied "I don't know the answer; you'd better ask them."
He said the angry debate accompanying the bill was bad for the country. "Civil rights should not be fodder for partisan cannons," he said. "If there is an issue where political consultants should get lost," he said, "this is it."
One of his colleagues, Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, said the bills were "an effort to make clear to the American public that some Republicans are interested in using their electoral margins to improve race relations and not the reverse."
The Danforth package of bills is generally closer to the Democratic proposal than to the White House measure. But when it comes to providing damages for victims of sex or religious discrimination, Mr. Danforth's measures would not allow any punitive damages, as the Democrats' would. But the measure would allow compensatory damages, as Mr. Bush's would not.
Mr. Danforth said that when civil rights legislation comes before the Senate, the support of moderate Republicans will be necessary to pass it in veto-proof strength, or to enable Mr. Bush to have his veto sustained. Therefore, he said, he and his allies were an important swing group.

HEADLINE: CABINET RESIGNS IN ALBANIA STRIKE

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
Bowing to the pressure of a general strike and renewed street demonstrations, the Communist Cabinet of Albania resigned today.
The departing Prime Minister, Fatos Nano, said a nonpartisan caretaker cabinet would be appointed to prepare for new elections. The leader of the opposition Democratic Party, Sali Berisha, hailed the action as "a very important step toward real democracy." 
 Mr. Berisha's minority party, which refused to join a coalition with the Communists last month, agreed to support what Mr. Nano called a "government of national salvation."
In effect, today's action represents the end of more than 46 years of Communist rule. President Ramiz Alia, who had been head of the Communist Party since 1985, is to continue as head of state, but in assuming the presidency after elections in March, he quit his party posts.
 
Nonpolitical Caretakers Seen
 Kastriot Islami, President of Parliament, emerged from consultations with opposition leaders to say an interim government would be made up of people who had withdrawn from political parties. He said Mr. Alia would choose a new prime minister and was expected to schedule elections roughly 12 months from now.
Opposition leaders said they expected the voting to take place sooner.
The recently formed Union of Free and Independent Trade Unions, which mobilized half of Albania's 700,000 workers to join in a national strike 20 days ago, said it would recommend going back to work as soon as a nonpartisan government was formed. Their strike demands had included a 50 percent wage increase, better conditions for working women and an assignment of blame for the violent suppression of an anti-Communist demonstration in the northern city of Shkoder on April 2.
About 50,000 Albanians rallied in support of the strikers in the capital, Tirana, last Wednesday, and 6,000 defied police charges and water cannon there on Monday.
The Communists had gained the two-thirds majority required to control Parliament in elections on March 31, which foreign observers judged to be a reasonably accurate reflection of voter sentiment. But their seeming strength was undermined by the severe losses they suffered in almost all of Albania's cities and by a widening split between reformers and hard-liners.
The Communists, with more than 100,000 members still the strongest political group in the country, have scheduled a national congress for Monday. They are expected to disavow some but not all of their Marxist-Leninist tenets at that time.
Albania, a country of 3.5 million people, has been swept by political and economic turbulence ever since the Communist Party began a cautious democratization program 13 months ago under President Alia.
That program lifted the lid from a caldron of problems in a country deliberately sealed off from most of the world by Mr. Alia's predecessor, Enver Hoxha, for four decades. Last spring and summer, strikes broke out in Shkoder and Kavaje, and demonstrators were killed by policemen. Thousands of citizens sought to escape the country. The gross national product fell 10 percent. Unemployment surpassed 14 percent.
In December, university students organized anti-Communist protests in Tirana, and with swelling numbers of demonstrators paralyzing the life of the capital, Mr. Alia agreed to permit the establishment of independent political parties.

HEADLINE: BUSH NOMINATES A TOP DEMOCRAT AS SOVIET ENVOY

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
President Bush named Robert S. Strauss, a close friend, Democratic doyen and master of the political and business deal, as Ambassador to Moscow today, moving to cement his ties to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and foster business contacts at a pivotal moment in Soviet-American relations.
The announcement came as the United States and the Soviet Union were completing plans for a summit meeting in Moscow, probably late in June. 
 Mr. Bush telephoned Prime Minister John Major of Britain today to say he would no longer object if Mr. Gorbachev were invited to London to meet with the leaders of seven industrial democracies after their annual conference, which is to be held in mid-July. Mr. Gorbachev is expected to present the seven leaders with a request for Western financial aid.
 
Bush Seen as Eager
 The announcement of the Strauss appointment, which was made by Mr. Bush in a hastily arranged appearance in the White House Rose Garden and stunned diplomatic ranks here, signaled the President's personal stake in relations with Mr. Gorbachev and his eagerness to "do business" with Moscow, officials said.
It was also an attempt to find a bridge to Democratic lawmakers at a time when Mr. Bush is moving to extend new financial aid to Moscow, the officials continued.
Mr. Bush hoped that naming a hard-boiled capitalist as Ambassador would help draw Soviet-American relations into a more predictable phase, in which business deals and economic issues are becoming as important as the military and diplomatic dimensions of the superpower relationship, the officials said.
 
A Rare Non-Career Appointment
 The 72-year-old Mr. Strauss, whose nomination was made final only this morning, after Mr. Bush received the assent of Mr. Gorbachev, would be only the second envoy to Moscow since World War II who was not a career diplomat or a high-ranking military officer.
In 1979, another time when the United States hoped to foster business ties to Moscow, President Jimmy Carter named Thomas J. Watson Jr., the former chairman of I.B.M., as Ambassador to the Kremlin. The invasion of Afghanistan that December soured those efforts.
In picking Mr. Strauss to replace Ambassador Jack F. Matlock Jr., who is retiring, Mr. Bush passed over the diplomat initially favored by the State Department, Edward P. Djerejian, now Ambassador to Syria.
Officials said Mr. Bush wanted to break the long string of professionals with limited political connections who served in Moscow during the tense years of the cold war and choose a consummate insider who can act in a personal way as the United States's link to the Soviet Union during much warmer times in the relationship.
"When Gorbachev talks to Strauss, he'll be talking to Bush," one official said.
Mr. Bush made it clear that Mr. Strauss's personal connections and experience in politics outweighed his lack of experience in Soviet relations.
"I frankly can think of nobody, no one more qualified or more talented, to bring to this representation what we need: contacts with high officials, a knowledge of America, a guarantee that two ships -- big ships, important ships -- won't pass in the night for lack of understanding," the President said.
At a brief, almost jocular news conference given by three Texas comrades, Mr. Bush, Mr. Strauss and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Mr. Baker said the selection was "a big plus" for "the emerging and continually, positively forward-moving relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union."
Reflecting the swiftness of the appointment, Mr. Strauss said, "I have no statement to make other than a week ago, if anyone had told me I would standing here, I would have thought they were crazy."
Noting that he was a member of the opposition party, he added: "I certainly will come out as a Democrat. And in the meantime, I'll do my damnedest, Mr. President, to represent this nation as you and the Secretary would want me to."
But critics of Mr. Strauss seized on his political background and connections with international business as a Washington lawyer to question the appointment at a time when there is concern here about Soviet policy toward the Baltic republics.
"This is the wrong appointment at the wrong time," said John P. Cregan, President of the U.S. Business and Industrial Council, a conservative group. "Now more than ever, we need someone who is well-versed in U.S.-Soviet relations and instead we've got a guy who is well versed in the art of the deal."
Although Mr. Strauss has long been an important figure in the Democratic Party, and the White House was counting on that to help weather future squalls over its Soviet policy, it remains to be seen how helpful he will be in this respect. His primary function will be to serve as liaison to the Kremlin and as an adviser to the President and to American businesses interested in dealing with the Soviet Union, not as a lobbyist for Administration policy on Capitol Hill.
Mr. Strauss, a former Democratic Party chairman and a man with decades of deep involvement in Presidential campaigns, will be in the unfamiliar and perhaps uncomfortable position of sitting out the 1992 election -- thousands of miles from the political action and silenced by a pledge to promote Bush Administration policy.
The selection of Mr. Strauss, a longtime friend of both Mr. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, came as the United States and the Soviet Union moved rapidly on a broad array of issues.
 
Bush's Soviet Agenda
 These issues will play an important role in shaping Soviet-American relations. Each of them is dependent on decisions that Mr. Bush will be making in the coming days and weeks.
Officials said Mr. Bush was poised to recommend the extension of $1.5 billion in agricultural credits to Moscow, but was awaiting a legally required bureaucratic ruling that the Soviets are capable of repaying the loans.
He was also preparing to send to Congress before the end of the month a trade agreement he and Mr. Gorbachev signed last year, which would give the Soviet Union the best available tariff rates, known as most-favored-nation status.
Mr. Strauss said today that he had turned Mr. Bush "down flat" a week ago when offered the Moscow post, but that Mr. Baker had approached him again -- five times -- and Mr. Bush "really, really squeezed me" to take the job.
A senior Administration official said that last Wednesday, the President telephoned Mr. Baker from Air Force One while he was flying to Colorado Springs to deliver a commencement speech to the Air Force Academy and asked him to talk to Mr. Strauss again.
The Secretary of State met with Mr. Strauss over lunch in his private dining room that day and offered the ambassadorship to Mr. Strauss, who was "flattered and intrigued" but did not jump at it.
 
'95 Percent Ego'
 On Saturday, while Mr. Baker was returning from a trip overseas, Mr. Bush called him to say that Mr. Strauss had finally accepted. "It was 95 percent ego and 5 percent patriotism, I guess," Mr. Strauss said today.
The next day, Sunday, Mr. Baker called the Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, and asked him to get formal assent to the appointment on a "fast-track" basis.
Mr. Bessmertnykh called Mr. Baker this morning to say that he had spoken with Mr. Gorbachev and that the Soviet leader was "very enthusiastic" about the idea, the senior official said.
"The President," the official added, "wants to send one of his best friends, a Democrat, and someone who is known as a can-do businessman as a signal to the reformers in the Soviet Union of where we want to go in this relationship."
The President was calculating, the official said, that American businessmen would feel comfortable calling Mr. Strauss and getting his advice on offers of joint ventures and other investments in the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: For 700 Students, French Cuisine 101

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
MOST of the 11 New York City high school students dining at L'Ecole restaurant yesterday had never eaten in a French restaurant before, and until three months ago, they had certainly never cooked a French meal.
But since February, they have been part of a new program that has initiated 700 home economics students into the mysteries and near-surgical skills of French cooking. And they were reaping their rewards, only partly in the form of escalopes of codfish and pommes dauphine prepared for them by a kitchen supervised by a former chef to Charles de Gaulle and a former chef at Le Cirque. 
 Under a Board of Education program organized by Richard Grausman, a cookbook author, at 12 high schools, students who have never prepared anything more elaborate than hamburgers and rice and beans were taught to cook poached salmon, crepes, chicken piccata, profiteroles and tricolor pasta made from scratch.
They have been trained in the proper handling of the knife and the omelet pan and in measurement, cleanliness and order. They can talk about presentation and garnishing, frontiers that are new for some home economics classes.
"You curl your fingers when you chop," said Egbert Gibbs, an 18-year-old senior at Prospect Heights High School in Brooklyn who said he until the program began, he had been most comfortable helping his Trinidadian mother make curried goat. "That way the knife can't cut you."
The students have also learned that there are different worlds and different tastes beyond the mean streets where many of them grew up, though a visitor probably could not have detected that, observing the poise with which the six girls and five boys handled L'Ecole.
"I never tried French cooking," said Aisha Sanjurjo, an 18-year-old senior at Adlai Stevenson High School in the Bronx. "I'm Puerto Rican and I eat Puerto Rican food -- rice and beans, chicken and a lot of pork. French food is a lighter meal for me."
Miss Sanjurjo and Mr. Gibbs were the top winners in a competition that was the icing on the program, a contest in which they were judged on their ability to chop, slice and dice, make an omelet and prepare dishes like crepes sucrees filled with creme patissiere and topped with sauce au chocolat.
Mr. Gibbs, whom one cook described as having particulartly deft hands, won a full $12,750 scholarship for a six-month course at the French Culinary Institute on lower Broadway which operates L'Ecole. And Miss Sanjurjo, along with her teacher, Christina Lyles, won an all-expenses-paid weeklong trip to Le Cordon Bleu Cooking School in Paris.
Mr. Grausman said he conceived the program as a reaction to a food-industry convention at which manufacturers were envisioning microwave ovens for the car and cookless kitchens. He wondered if home economics classes might be willing "to upgrade their instruction" and challenge students. He disregarded warnings from friends that he ought to try his program in more affluent areas with more sophisticated palates.
"I figured if I could do it here I could it anywhere," he said. "People said, 'These New York kids won't know the difference between one dish and another.' But instead of an apple pie, they made an apple tart and just the appearance of that makes them feel they've been able to accomplish something their friends never have."
Remarking on the skill of the students, Dorothy Cann, the institute's president, said: "What we saw in the kitchen was discipline, maturity, purpose and seriousness. Cuisine is a very civilizing thing."
Still, Alair Sailhac, a former chef at Le Cirque and one of the judges, said the students had a long way to go to develop the speed, organization, economy of motion and grace under pressure that distinguishes a restaurant chef from a fine home cook.
"If you are too slow, you cannot be a chef," he said.
To start the program, Mr. Grausman held a one-day training session for home economics teachers to lessen the intimidation some of them felt about haute cuisine. They used his book "At Home With French Classics" (Workman, 1989) as their textbook, but he conceded that in the coming school year the teachers would need regular Saturday classes.
The program's teachers said that even if their students never became chefs, they have learned how to meet deadlines, to handle delicate equipment and to understand a foreign menu. The students agreed.
"They taught us the basic knowledge," said Harrison Okine, a 20-year-old junior at Stevenson who finished third in the competition. "So when you step out, you step out with confidence."

HEADLINE: Broadway Attendance Is Off, But Happy Face Is Still On

BYLINE: By ELEANOR BLAU

 BODY:
Broadway ended its 1990-91 season with a decline of nearly 6 percent in ticket sales and 9 percent in attendance but with statements that looked on the bright side.
"We find it remarkable that the season was as strong as it was in the context of the economy," Harvey Sabinson, executive director of the League of American Theaters and Producers, said yesterday. 
 "The seasons fluctuate," Mr. Sabinson said. "This business is cyclical. We had fewer productions so there were fewer work weeks. But we felt that with the new productions that opened, the types of stars and directors and playwrights, it was a very representative season."
Figures made public by the league yesterday showed that ticket sales through May 31 had declined to $267 million from a record $283 million last season -- or, in the league's way of characterizing it, "the second highest total in Broadway history."
Reporting that attendance declined to 7.36 million from 8.03 million, the league noted that attendance over the previous five seasons ranged from 6.56 million to 8.14 million. Variety, the show business weekly, reported in its June 3 issue that attendance was over 10.6 million in 1980-81. But that was Broadway's best season ever, said George Wachtel, the league's director of research, adding that its worst was 1973-74, when attendance was 5.4 million.
Anyway, he said, this season not only suffered from the Persian Gulf war and the recession but also was one week shorter than last season, which had 53 weeks because of the vagaries of the calendar.
The total number of playing weeks for all productions this season was 970, compared with 1,061 last year. And there were 28 new productions, down from 30 last year and 35 the year before. Of the 10 this year that were musicals, 3 were revivals, while only 1 of the 13 plays was a revival.
Broadway tours throughout North America had ticket sales of $449 million, a 22 percent increase from the $367 million in 1989-90.

HEADLINE: Get the Right Grip on Foreign Aid

 BODY:
Can there be a stable and just new world order in the wake of the cold war? Not unless social conditions and economic prospects improve markedly in the third world, where most of the planet's people live. That will take money, but not in unthinkable amounts. What is needed is a sharp shift in priorities, among donor and recipient countries alike.
Major givers like Japan, Germany and the World Bank press for sensible changes. But there's little sign of that spirit in Washington, where Congress is now considering the new foreign aid budget. It and the Bush Administration act oblivious to the momentous changes that have swept the world. 
 People everywhere now recognize private investment as the main engine of development. Policies that merely clear away bureaucratic obstacles to enterprise can accomplish miracles, especially if accompanied by modest investments in health, education and infrastructure.
In an impressively researched new report, the United Nations Development Program estimates that it would take only about $20 billion a year to eliminate serious malnutrition and provide universal primary education, primary health care, family planning and safe water by the year 2000.
About $50 billion could be found within third world countries themselves, mainly by reducing excessive military spending. The developed world, meanwhile, could match that contribution simply by living up to its promises.
If each donor met the internationally endorsed target of 0.7 percent of gross national product, development aid would rise by $50 billion a year. Industrial countries now contribute an average of 0.32 percent of G.N.P.; the U.S. contributes only 0.15 percent, or $7.5 billion.
But even if outsiders greatly increase their assistance, it will be wasted if beneficiary countries keep spending excessively on arms. In recent years, Iraq has spent more than seven times as much on its military as on education and health combined. Pakistan spends three times as much on arms as on education and health. Syria has three times as many soldiers as teachers. By welcome contrast, Ghana spends five times as much on education and health as on its military.
Military spending is a politically sensitive issue anywhere. Former colonies see their militaries as emblems and defenders of sovereignty. And in many poor nations, the army is a pillar of politics. Yet sovereignty and stability would both be better served if arms money could be reclaimed.
Some leading donors have now proposed linking development aid to curbs on military spending. Germany would condition aid on that basis. Japan speaks of withholding aid from countries that spend too much on arms. The Development Committee, which advises the World Bank, and the U.N. Development Program also propose linkage.
Meanwhile, Washington still favors security spending for a handful of allies. There's far more interest in preserving sacred arms ratios between Israel and Egypt and between Greece and Turkey than in addressing the needs of the billion-plus poor people of the third world. A new world cannot be built by playing old politics with foreign aid.

HEADLINE: A Political Pro for Moscow

 BODY:
President Bush's nomination of Robert Strauss as U.S. Ambassador in Moscow is an inspired choice. By turning to a formidable Texas Democrat, Mr. Bush gives bipartisan resonance to U.S. diplomacy at a critical moment in Soviet-American relations.
Mr. Strauss is a superb negotiator with sensitive political radar. Those talents could be extremely useful as the Administration seeks to reconcile sensitive differences with Moscow over nuclear arms and economic aid. 
 If Mr. Bush's choice is unconventional, so are the opportunities. The world will be the winner if a historic rivalry yields to collaboration, beginning with a successful summit meeting this summer. And by conditioning economic aid to fundamental reforms, Washington can crucially assist the stable transformation of a failed Soviet economy and floundering authoritarian system.
Mr. Strauss has shown his bargaining skills as chairman of the Democratic National Committee and as Jimmy Carter's Special Trade Representative. He has close personal ties with his fellow Texans George Bush and Secretary of State James Baker, assuring him direct access and more than compensating for his lack of extensive knowledge of Soviet affairs. As a successful capitalist bred in Dallas, he may even have some useful advice for the Soviets on how market economies operate.
Since establishing relations with the Soviet Union in 1933, Washington has usually chosen career diplomats like the highly skilled incumbent, Jack Matlock, for the Moscow post. But as a graduate of hardball Texas politics, Mr. Strauss seems just as well suited to judge the struggle for power in Mikhail Gorbachev's Moscow. At 72, Mr. Straussnow has a chance to help make as well as witness history.

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
Retaking Tompkins Square

 BODY:
Thanks to strong action by the Dinkins administration, Tompkins Square Park in New York City's East Village may once again be a park. It hasn't been that for many years, not since drug dealers, self-styled anarchists and the homeless took it over and turned it into a dangerous encampment that scared away neighborhood residents.
The Koch administration failed to reclaim the park, and until now so had Mayor David Dinkins's City Hall. Finally, yet another disturbance meant that even the patient Mr. Dinkins had had enough. The park was cleared and closed on Monday for renovation. 
 It is not a perfect solution. The $2.3 million renovation is a costly excuse to close the park, especially during a recession. Moreover, problems are likely to return when it reopens a year hence. It might have been wiser to clear but not close the park, and then impose and firmly enforce a curfew.
But mayoral aides insist that dramatic action was required to change destructive patterns in the park, and perhaps it was. In any case, the move gives neighborhood residents a chance for calm. And it gives all New Yorkers a chance to reflect on why decisive action is so rare that it takes several years, two administrations and the extreme action of barricading a public park to save it.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
A Not-So-New Order

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
The "new world order" projected by President Bush to grow out of the Persian Gulf war is looked upon by third-world spokesmen with skepticism, suspicion and doubt that it will really bring anything new to their relations with the developed world.
 That's a conclusion that seemed warranted after an international conference sponsored here by the International Press Service Council on Information and Communication.
 
 Most participants either represented or seemed to be influenced by the views of third-world nations. And that's where more than 80 percent of the world's population lives, as pointed out by Kofi N. Awoonor, Ghana's United Nations representative.
 What, ideally, would a new world order be like? asked Benjamin Mkapa, Tanzania's Minister of Information, in a panel discussion. In his view, it would "herald more equal political, economic and cultural relations between states. It would promote a greater access to and sharing of productive technology [and] provide for more evenhanded competition. And it would open opportunities for all states and peoples, not just the developed ones, to express and enjoy a greater cultural freedom."
 Neither he nor other speakers expressed much hope for such a revolution in international relations. Crown Prince Hassan of Jordan, in the keynote speech, added the further requirement that "a new agenda for the next century" should go beyond traditional concerns to "the survival issues -- global warming, the loss of species, reversing deforestation, the question of future water supplies for a planet of 10 billion."
 In a speech read by Hasan abu Nimah, Jordan's envoy to Italy, the Crown Prince said "that using oil as an environmental weapon is something that desperate warmongers are quite willing to do," as shown by the gulf war. "If the oil wars have begun," he added, "the water wars may not be far behind -- and then conflicts stemming from the consequences of soil loss, forest loss, high global temperatures and rising sea levels."
In the Crown Prince's view, however, "the United States seems to have virtually given up all claims to international leadership on these issues." It was generally accepted by the conferees that the U.S. now was the world's only superpower -- hence the necessary leader in a changing world.
 One Western voice, that of George Gerbner of the Annenberg School of Communications at the University of Pennsylvania, cited television as an obstacle to a truly new order. Its enormous power and reach, he said, were controlled by "a handful of global conglomerates with something to sell"; and its daily content left the world "drench[ed] . . . in expertly choreographed brutality."
 TV, according to Professor Gerbner, teaches that violence, like the gulf war, is an effective solution to problems. He said it also encouraged support for anything that enhanced people's sense of security in what they saw as a "mean world." Hence the worldwide "tidal wave of television" produced support for political decisions leading to wars, from populations conditioned to believe that violence could improve their security.
 Mr. Mkapa also thought it "not implausible that if a new world order emerges" from the gulf war and the collapse of Communism, "it will be based on respect for the force of might rather than the force of argument."
 For one thing, he said, the U.N. has been remarkably firm in pursuing a military course against Iraq, possibly signaling more such collective action in the future. For another, third-world nations can no longer play off one superpower against another. Now there is no rival to temper the power of the one remaining superpower.
 In Mr. Mkapa's view, moreover, "even the most vainglorious and irredentist of third-world leaders cannot but have been shocked and unnerved by the awesome destruction poured over Iraq by the war machines of the coalition forces" -- mostly those of the industrial world.
 These developments, he said, might mean less instability and adventurism in the third world; but they would tend also "to work for increased dominance" by the developed nations rather than for "more respectful, more naturally beneficial relations."
 In the U.S. too, the conference was told, though there's much hope for a new world order, widespread questions also exist. That conflict will be detailed in another article.

HEADLINE: Education Cannot Become Casualty of New York's Budget Ax

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The School Administrators Association of New York State is deeply concerned about the budget crisis. The impact is devastating to our schools and the programs offered to our children. Notwithstanding, another, more serious issue is now emerging. In an attempt to balance the budget, the Regents Scholarship Program has been suspended.
The Regents Scholarship Program, with its $250 award, is not about money, but about rewarding achievement and encouraging high standards. Even to allow the program to become part of the economic political debate demonstrates a lack of understanding by our elected leaders relative to the only symbolic statewide recognition of excellence. 
 There exists between the generations a covenant that cannot and must not be broken.
We call upon the State Legislature and upon Gov. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to restore the Regents Scholarship Program immediately so that those students in the class of 1991 will not be deprived of the chance to be recognized for their exceptional academic achievement.
 
ROBERT J. DRENNEN
President, School
Administrators of New York State
Albany, May 13, 1991
