HEADLINE: Strife Cripples Yugoslavia's Big Tourist Industry

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SPLIT, Yugoslavia

 BODY:
The boutiques beneath the soaring arches of this city's Roman palace stood deserted on a brisk spring afternoon, their jewelery and folk art gathering dust. The hotels were all but empty. Those in the tourism business here concede that the 1991 season is the worst in their memory.
"Last summer, there were many people here; now, there is nobody," said Jadranka Durdov, a 25-year-old saleswoman. "It's obvious the political situation has scared people, and I can understand why." 
 Up and down the picturesque Adriatic coast, the story is much the same for what has been one of Yugoslavia's leading industries. Visitors from Europe and the United States are staying away, apparently frightened by this nation's ethnic violence. Local tourism agents estimate that this year they are seeing only 10 percent as many visitors as last year.
 
Destination for Westerners
 With tourism booming in Eastern Europe since the fall of Communist governments, Yugoslavia had expected business to improve. For the last decade, Yugoslavia has carved out a singular niche among Eastern European nations. While Bulgaria, Romania and even Hungary catered largely to visitors from other Communist countries, Yugoslavia successfully marketed itself as a cheap, sunny destination for Westerners.
The collapse of the nation's tourism, a $2.7 billion business last year, is one of the worst economic consequences of the conflicts that threaten to tear this country apart. Ljubica Milojevic, chief of the research department at the Tourism Association of Yugoslavia, said that bookings nationwide were off 60 to 80 percent from last year.
Tourism has been one of Yugoslavia's leading sources of Western currencies, she said, employing 400,000 and accounting for about 3 percent of gross national product. More than 9 million foreigners visited Yugoslavia in 1990, about 40 percent from Germany.
In better times, Split, a city of 280,000, was one of the nation's chief attractions. Its walled old city, built by the Roman Emperor Diocletian in the years 300 to 304, is one of the best-preserved Roman ruins in Europe. Local legend has it that the emperor settled here because of the waters, the beautiful women and the absence of earthquakes.
 
Near Empty Restaurant
 But on a recent Saturday evening in Split, the Adrijana Restaurant, known for its seafood, served its first and only customers at 10 P.M. They were foreign journalists covering Yugoslavia's latest crisis.
On the sidewalk out front, several people lurked in the shadows, approaching anyone who could possibly be a tourist with their forlorn, multi-lingual pleas: "Room? Zimmer? Camara? Sobe?"
At the Bellevue Hotel nearby, Vjenceslav Perkov, a manager there, lamented the lack of traffic. "Yugoslavia is a beautiful country with the most beautiful sea in the world," he said. "This political situation has had a terrible influence on tourism. If events do not calm down, many hotels here will have to close down."
Yugoslavia's tourism has long added to the disputes among the nation's six republics. More than 80 percent of tourist dollars and Deutsche marks are spent in Split, Dubrovnik and other coastal communities in the republic of Croatia. The republics have bickered for years over how much the federal Government should invest in projects like constructing new roads to the seashore, which some argue would mainly benefit Croatia.
 
Serbians Block Road
 Recently, the tourist business has become a target for Croatia's restive Serbian minority. Last year, Serbs challenging the newly elected nationalist government in Croatia blocked the main road from Western Europe to the coast, causing a sharp decline in late-season bookings. About half of the coast's tourists come from Germany, and the main auto route crosses the republic's Serbian areas.
This year, tourism prospects dimmed when Yugoslav Army tanks rolled through the streets of Belgrade in February to quell rioting. Croatian officials said that events this spring then destroyed their last hopes of salvaging the season.
Rebel Serbs seized the Plitvice national park in Croatia, whose water falls and forests form the backdrop for many of the country's tourism posters. When paramilitary policemen stormed the park on Easter Sunday, a bus filled with Italian tourists was caught in the crossfire. Their quick-witted driver ordered passengers to crouch on the floor, averting any injuries.
The violence has intensified. First, clashes between Serbs and Croatians left at least 18 dead. Then, an anti-Army protest in Split turned into a riot that led to the fatal shooting of a 19-year old conscript.
 
Airlift on Standby
 Even before these troubles, travel agents in Split had received little more than cancellations and unusual requests. Some Belgian tourists said they would come to the region only with a guarantee that if ethnic strife broke out, they would immediately be airlifted out. A plane was reserved, but not needed.
Ana Manzoni, director of the foreign travel division at Dalmacijaturist, a worker-owned agency with annual revenues of $150 million, said she foresaw layoffs if business did not pick up.
"The damage has already been done," she said, after hearing Prime Minister Ante Markovic address reporters at the nation's annual tourism convention. "At best, we may end up with 40 percent of last year, which was not a good year. It is really a disaster."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Yugoslav tourist agents say that foreign tourism in Yugoslavia is down sharply this year because of the nation's ethnic unrest. Towns like Piran, above, in the country's beautiful coastal region, have long attracted foreign visitors and made tourism a $2.7 billion business last year. (Raoul Fornezza)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on Optimism About Improved Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened yesterday on optimism over improvement in the United States economy.
Earl Johnson, vice president for the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, said economic reports and remarks by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, led to some firming. Mr. Greenspan said the economy seemed to be stabilizing. 
 But traders remained cautious in advance of the May unemployment report, to be issued tomorrow. The report will contain the latest evidence of the economy's health.
A stronger United States economy would tend to bolster the dollar's value because it implies that domestic interest rates will stabilize or rise, which makes dollar-denominated investments worth more.
 
Rises Against Yen
 Jeff Mondschein, manager of foreign exchange for the Continential Illinois Bank and Trust Company, said some of the demand for dollars was constrained as traders cashed in on the currency's strength.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 139.17 Japanese yen, up from 138.80 yen at Tuesday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 139.20 yen. It was quoted at 139.30 yen at closing in New York, up from 138.85 the day before.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.6945, from $1.7035 late Tuesday. At closing in New York, it cost $1.6935 to buy one pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.7000.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.7490 German marks, up from 1.7455; 1.4960 Swiss francs, up from 1.4920; 5.9220 French francs, up from 5.9115; 1,294.50 Italian lire, up from 1,292.75, and 1.14555 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14445.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.7480 German marks, up from 1.7385; 1.4955 Swiss francs, up from 1.4870; 5.9175 French francs, up from 5.9105; 1.9685 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9633; 1,293.75 Italian lire, up from 1,292.00, and 1.1454 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1445.
Gold for current delivery gained 10 cents on the New York Commodity Exchange to close at $362.60 a troy ounce. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late price of $362.20, up 20 cents.
Earlier, gold rose in London to a late bid of $362.75 a troy ounce, up from $362.70 late Tuesday. In Zurich,gold fell to a closing bid of $362 an ounce, from $362.20 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 41 cents an ounce to close at $361.94.
Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid of $4.16 a troy ounce, from $4.20 late Tuesday. In New York, silver for current delivery gained 2.6 cents to close at $4.167 a troy ounce on the Comex.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Greenspan Sees Growth; Bonds Drop

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Remarks by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, sent a chill through the credit markets yesterday, where prices of Treasury securities fell and interest rates rose.
Attending an international monetary conference in Japan, Mr. Greenspan told reporters that the economy seemed to be bottoming out in the second quarter, and that as a result of rapid inventory liquidation, a stronger-than-expected recovery was increasingly likely. 
 Mr. Greenspan also said recent reports suggested that inflation in the United States would be at a lower level coming out of the recession than when it began. For the most part, however, this comment was lost on the bond market.
 
'Market Sure Took It Badly'
 "Greenspan didn't say anything radical," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "It shouldn't be much news that the recession is coming to an end. But the market sure took it badly."
Some analysts and traders said Mr. Greenspan's remarks on the employment rate eliminated virtually any possibility that the Fed might ease its monetary policy again any time soon.
The Fed chairman said that while the unemployment rate might show a further rise, turns in the labor markets would lag developments in the overall economy.
"I don't see how the employment number can help us now," a government bond trader said.
Mr. Greenspan made his remarks in the context of recent statistics that suggest the economy may have troughed. But some analysts said they remained unconvinced.
"The improvement that has been made is from such low levels that it is hard to label it a recovery," said Alan Leslie, chief economist at the Discount Corporation. "To my mind, that does not make a recovery until we see it for a longer period of time."
Mr. Greenspan's remarks had little effect on bond prices in Tokyo. The slide began when trading shifted to London and became more pronounced once American dealers reached their desks.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 97 5/32, down more than half a point, to yield 8.38 percent, up from 8.33 percent late Tuesday.
Among notes, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 26/32, down 3/8, to yield 8.17 percent. The 7 5/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 5/32, down 1/4 point, to yield 7.83 percent. And the 6 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 29/32, down 2/32, to yield 6.80 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose modestly. By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.60 percent, up four basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 5.70 percent.
 
New York City's Offering
 In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, a negotiated sale of $675 million worth of tax-exempt and taxable securities for the City of New York was well received by investors.
The maximum yield on the tax-exempt portion of the offering was 8.55 percent on bonds maturing in 2020. The rate was slightly lower what had been expected.
Officials at Goldman, Sachs & Company, the firm that acted as lead manager for the underwriting, said that as of late yesterday, all but 25 percent of the New York City issue had been sold.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Southwestern Bell offered a total of $400 million worth of new securities in a two-part offering through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs.
Three-year notes maturing on June 1, 1994, made up half the offering. The 7.70 percent notes were priced at $99.90 to yield 7.736 percent, 50 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 percent three-year notes at the time of pricing.
The remaining $200 million of the issue consisted of 8.30 percent five-year notes. The notes were priced at $99.85 to yield 8.336 percent, 50 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 5/8 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
Both parts of the issue are noncallable for life. All securities are rated AA-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, prices of most issues dipped by about 1/4 point, traders said.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said prices of most widely quoted issues fell by 1/8 point to 1/4 point in slow trading.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gasoline Off More Than 2 To Lowest Level Since War

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gasoline futures plunged more than 2 cents a gallon yesterday to their lowest level since the Persian Gulf war, dragging down the rest of the energy market.
The sharp drop was taken as a sign that the nation's refineries were producing more gasoline than needed, considering the bite that the recession has taken out of demand. 
 But experts said motorists should not expect any sudden relief at the gas pump, where prices have risen during 12 of the last 13 weeks. The energy futures market is volatile and does not necessarily foretell the direction of retail prices, they said.
Unleaded gasoline for delivery in July settled at 64.12 cents a gallon, down 2.13 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Gasoline for next-month delivery had not closed that low since Feb. 26, when the settlement price was 63.95 cents, two days after American-led forces began the ground war with Iraq.
If gasoline falls an additional 4 cents, "I think we'd have some relief at the pump," said Rita Beale, a petroleum products analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. "If we were to stay the same, pump prices would probably stay flat. It might inch down a little bit. There's a lag effect, meaning as prices go down on the screen, it takes a longer time for prices to go down at the pump."
Yesterday's drop in gasoline prices followed Tuesday night's report by the American Petroleum Institute, which showed sharp increases in the nation's supply of oil and petroleum products last week. It also came in the wake of Tuesday's meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Vienna, where oil ministers decided to maintain current production quotas.
Concerns that OPEC might cut production or come up with some unexpected move had kept prices propped up for about two or three weeks.
The combination of the petroleum institute report and the OPEC meeting "gave the market the momentum and the reason to sell off," said Victor Yu, an oil broker at Refco Inc.
Crude oil for delivery in July settled at $20.47, down 55 cents. Home heating oil for July settled at 54.28 cents a gallon, down 1.71 cents.
Traders said the market had been focused on gasoline for weeks, as the nation's supply shrank this spring. Refiners apparently all moved to erase the shortfall at once, said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J.
Then, the sharp rise in the gasoline supply for the week after Memorial Day "confirmed earlier fears of a weak driving season," Mr. Yu said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
U.S. Grants 3 Airlines Routes to Soviet Union

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
The Transportation Department yesterday selected two established airlines and a new one to serve the Soviet Union from New York and Chicago.
The awards would mean a large increase in service between North America and the Soviet Union, which are now served by Pan American World Airways Inc. and Aeroflot, the state-owned Soviet carrier. 
The department gave authority for Trans World Airlines to provide service between New York and Moscow beginning this year and next, with two more round trips being added in 1992-93.
The department also authorized American Airlines to provide service between Chicago and Moscow beginning in 1992-93.
The new carrier, Baltia Air Lines Inc., which has had no experience in flying, also received approval to provide service from New York to Leningrad, as well as between New York and Riga, Latvia. From there, Baltia would provide service to Kiev, Minsk, and Tbilisi. Both services would start this year and next.
In granting the authority to Baltia, Patrick V. Murphy, a Deputy Assistant Secretary, reversed the decision of a Federal administrative law judge, Robert Barton, in Washington.
Judge Barton found in February that the time was not ripe to allow a fledgling carrier to begin service "in a risky developmental market characterized by political and economic turmoil."
He added that Baltia had "no operating experience, no name recognition and no marketing organization."
Instead, the judge had chosen American Trans Air, a leading charter airline that has long served the Soviet Union, to fly from Philadelphia to Riga three times a week.
Mr. Murphy said yesterday that he had reversed Judge Barton's decision, since Baltia had proposed a high level of service for the markets.
He added that Baltia's proposal to serve Leningrad was far superior to that of T.W.A.
The Transportation Department also gave Pan American World Airways Inc. authority to provide service that had been authorized previously to Moscow and Leningrad.
Yesterday's actions were based on a June 1990 aviation agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union, which expanded opportunities for the carriers of the countries.

HEADLINE: Budget Impasse Forces Legislature Into a Special Session in Hartford

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 5

 BODY:
With no state budget and no immediate hope of passing one, legislative leaders adjourned their regular session tonight and called themselves back immediately into special session to try to break the fiscal stalemate.
The lawmakers' decision to declare a special session themselves, while not unprecedented, was a break with the tradition that has allowed governors that privilege. It provided further evidence of the distancing -- if not outright alienation -- that has developed between the General Assembly and Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. 
 Mr. Weicker, a third-party Governor with no allies in either the House or Senate, vetoed the legislature's budget Friday night, in effect forcing the special session. The Govermor, who had proposed a sweeping budget overhaul and income-tax plan in February, said in his veto message that the legislature's budget, which avoided the income tax through a huge increase in sales and business taxes, would hurt the economy and punish the poor.
 
Governor Calls for Action
 In his brief remarks to the joint House and Senate after the adjournment, Mr. Weicker said he believed that the battles of the regular session were best left behind and forgotten.
"You've had your votes, I've had my veto," he said. "The public now deserves their budget. See you in the morning."
A final budget is supposed to be in place when Connecticut's fiscal year begins July 1. With a preliminary budget of $8.6 billion, the state faces a revenue shortage of $2.7 billion, caused mainly by declines in sales-tax and corporate-tax revenues.
Legislative historians and veterans in the Capitol say that to their knowledge, Connecticut has never failed to pass a budget in time to start its fiscal year -- unlike some other states, including New York.

HEADLINE: Voters End Tradition of 98 Years In Sending Democrat to Congress

DATELINE: BOSTON, June 5

 BODY:
For almost a century, voters in the hills of western Massachusetts have defied this state's Democratic tradition and sent a Republican to Washington to represent them in Congress.
But this year, despite campaign appearances by President Bush and his wife, Barbara, and by the newly elected Republican Governor, William F. Weld, voters in the 1st Congressional District have had a change of heart. 
 In a special election held Tuesday that some saw as a referendum on the conservative fiscal policies of the state's new Republican administration, John Olver, a liberal Democrat, squeezed out Steven Pierce, a conservative Republican, by a margin of two percentage points. Analysts said the campaign turned on issues of abortion, crime and taxes.
 
An Emblematic Switch?
 Mr. Olver, a state senator and former chemistry professor, will now become the first Democrat to hold the western Massachusetts seat in 98 years, after three long-serving Republican congressmen. His victory, which fills the vacancy created by the death of the state's only Republican representative, Silvio O. Conte, makes the state's entire delegation Democratic. Mr. Conte died in February after serving 32 years in Congress.
A liberal Republican, Mr. Conte had tremendous cross-party appeal in the independent-minded district, where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans 3-to-1. But recent moves by Governor Weld have discouraged voters in the district, one of the poorest in the state.
Mr. Weld, the first Republican Governor in almost two decades, has supported large cuts in funding for social services and higher education and major reductions in money that the state gives to cities and towns to support education and some municipal services. Those policies have come as a staggering blow to the district, where some towns have unemployment levels as high as 14 percent.
In the voting, Mr. Olver won 70,022 votes, or 50 percent, and Mr. Pierce had 68,052, or 48 percent. Three independent candidates won the remaining votes.
"Steve Pierce is very much in the Reagan mold, and that is not where the district is," George Bachrach, a lawyer and former State Senator, said of the result. "John Olver might be too far to the left for them, but Steve Pierce is too far to the right."
During his campaign, Mr. Pierce tried to portray his Democratic opponent as the kind of tax-and-spend liberal who helped drag the state into fiscal turmoil. He also said Mr. Olver was soft on crime.
Mr. Olver's campaign was aided by the National Abortion Rights Action League, which spent heavily on television and radio advertisements criticizing Mr. Pierce's long-standing opposition to abortion-rights measures.
In the final days of the campaign, Mr. Pierce tried to ease his stance, objecting to a recent United States Supreme Court decision that upheld a Federal ban on abortion counseling at health clinics that receive Federal money. But that move, analysts and political watchers here say, came too late.

HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
New Midsize Stock Index: Will It Fly?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
DOES America really need a new stock index in addition to the Standard & Poor's 500, the Dow Jones industrial average, the Wilshire 5,000, the Russell 2,000 and countless others?
Standard & Poor's, a McGraw-Hill subsidiary, is betting that the answer is yes. Yesterday, it introduced the S.& P. Mid-Cap 400, which is supposed to do for smaller companies what the S.& P. 500 does for larger ones. The companies in it are supposed to be bigger than the small ones, but smaller than the large ones. 
 If it succeeds, the new index will turn into a profit center for S.& P., as money managers and the futures and options exchanges pay royalties on investment products tied to the index. If it fails, as many indexes have, Standard & Poor's will lose the initial investment involved in creating the index -- put by Elliott Shurgin, S.& P.'s vice president for index products, in the "low six figures" -- and the cost of maintaining it.
 The introduction yesterday produced few surprises, showing that in most recent years, stocks with middle-sized market capitalization have tended to perform somewhere between the large stocks and the small ones.
For most of the last decade, large stocks performed better, but this year the situation has turned around. Through the end of May, the S.& P. 500, which is usually viewed as being representative of large stocks, was up 19.8 percent, including reinvested dividends. The new Mid-Cap 400 was up 27.9 percent, and the Russell 2,000, the leading index of small stocks, was up 35.6 percent.
This has stirred speculation that a new era of high-performing small stocks has begun and may increase the chances of the 400-stock index gaining acceptance.
The need for a new index, if there is one, is related to the failings of the S.& P. 500 as a proxy for the stock market. Although it includes 500 stocks, the index is dominated by the largest companies and reflects their performance, because it is weighted by market capitalization.
For many years, ending in the summer of 1983, the small stocks tended to outperform their larger brethren. As a result, most money managers, owning at least some smaller stocks, outperformed the S.& P. 500 and loved to be compared with it. But for the next seven years, smaller stocks tended to be laggards, and most money managers did not do as well as the index.
There are indexes of small-capitalization stocks, most notably the Russell 2,000, but futures contracts on them never caught on, in part because many such stocks are so illiquid that is is difficult for institutions to trade them.
The stocks in the new S.& P. index were chosen in part for their liquidity, with companies dropped if most of their shares were not publicly held or if there was not sufficient volume.
In addition, a number of financial and utility stocks that would otherwise qualify were eliminated. Even so, the index ends up with a representation of about 17.5 percent utility stocks and 15.5 percent financial stocks, in contrast to 15.5 percent utilities and 8 percent financials in the S.& P. 500.
That is a bit unfortunate, said Richard Bernstein, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. "Most Mid-Cap managers tend to be growth oriented," he said, noting that such managers would normally not have many utilities. But he still thinks the index will succeed, because he sees a large need for it.
Standard & Poor's hopes the 400 index will catch on to the extent that money managers put together index funds based on it. If they do, S.& P. will get a small royalty on the funds. But the real money would come from licensing the index to the futures and options exchanges and from selling data on the index performance. S.& P. hopes there will be contracts traded on the index, but that is not certain.
Even if they do begin trading, such contracts could fail for lack of interest. Contracts on the S.& P. 500 have been big successes, and options on the S.& P. 100, a subset of the larger index, have also done well. But most others have not.
Any new contract must overcome a chicken-and-egg problem. Money managers will buy and sell the contract only if there is sufficient trading volume to provide liquidity. But that volume will arrive only if the managers use it.
If it does succeed, an "inclusion premium" might come into play: Any stock that is put in the index could then be bought by index-fund managers and therefore tend to rise more than a similar stock not included in the index.
The new Mid-Cap 400 index shows just how difficult it can be to put together a new index. Because the S.& P. considers factors other than capitalization, there are some anomalies. For example, the 400 companies have market values that range from $203 million for American Waste Services Inc. to $5.2 billion, for the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, popularly known as Freddie Mac.
The S.&tP. 500, usually considered a large stock index, has 13 companies that are smaller than the smallest one in the new Mid-Cap index. And Freddie Mac would rank No. 130 in the S.& P. 500 if it were included.

HEADLINE: Review/Music;
Once a Cult, Early Music Approaches Mainstream

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, June 5

 BODY:
In 1981, when the Boston Early Music Festival opened its doors, early music was still early. It appealed to a fervent but confined cult of devotees of the Baroque and before, especially before. The stereotype was of earnest young men in rimless glasses and earnest young women in long dresses playing lutes and recorders and acting like highbrow folkies.
 As anyone who pays the most cursory attention to classical music knows by now, all that has radically changed. The cult isn't quite yet the mainstream, but it's getting there, faster than the old mainstream would like to see from an uppity tributary. Public interest in the concerts and especially the recordings of early music has grown enormously, and early music itself isn't so early anymore. "Historically informed" performances have plunged deep into the 19th century, affecting the way even the most hidebound modern-instrument orchestras must do business. 
 For the spread of this movement in the United States, the biannual Boston event can take a good deal of credit. So its 10th anniversary, at the festival that began Saturday and continues through this Sunday, is worthy of more than passing attention.
 Actually, it is both a festival and an exhibition, with more than 100 stalls and rooms given over to the artisans and business people who service the movement, from instrument makers to record companies to artists' representatives. In addition, the Early Music Association, the movement's support group, is holding its annual meeting here this week.
 Boston may lead the American early-music movement, but it still looks to England for inspiration. As in 1989, the Boston festival's two big conducting stars this year are Roger Norrington, who has dominated the opening days, and Andrew Parrott, who will bring things to a close with performances of the Mozart Mass in C minor and other choral works Saturday night and Sunday afternoon.
Mr. Norrington's most overt contribution was a concert on Tuesday night in the Tremont Temple Baptist Church, which lies right off the Boston Common and used to call itself "the pulpit of America." Like most of the halls this festival employs, it is antiquated, un-air-conditioned and quite wonderful acoustically and visually. The Tremont Temple's main hall resembles a reduced version of classic central European concert halls like the pre-World War II Gewandhaus in Leipzig and the Musikvereinsaal in Vienna.
 Entitled "Haydn in London, Mozart in Vienna," the concert was basically (and refreshingly, in this year of Mozartean overkill) devoted to Haydn's late works composed for the English -- the Symphonies No. 96 ("Miracle") and 92 ("Oxford") and an aria from the opera "La Fedelta Premiata."
 Mr. Norrington came to fame as an original-instruments conductor with a weekend round of Haydn concerts and lectures several years ago in London, but oddly he hasn't yet released any Haydn symphony recordings. This is odd because of all composers, Haydn might seem the most suited to Mr. Norrington's gifts of buoyant rhythmic elasticity, phrasing subtlety and all-purpose wit. With the Boston Early Music Festival Orchestra (an all-star assemblage containing many New Yorkers) playing as well as any large-scale original-instruments band has managed in this country, the performances were delicious. Lorraine Hunt, whose movement up from mezzo-soprano to soprano does not yet mean confidently secure, blooming high notes, was the otherwise appealing soloist.
 Mozart did creep into this occasion, however, in the charming form of 11 dances, most composed for the Viennese Carnivals between 1788 and 1791, the year of his death. This is irresistibly winning music, especially when heard with the silvery flutes, wispy strings and woodsy horns of an original-instruments band. Mr. Norrington presided over the affair like some latter-day Johann Strauss Jr., whose own waltzes Mozart's minuets and contradances directly preceded.
 But the bonus of this concert was eight dancers in period dress and wigs re-creating the social dances this music was meant to accompany. This was more Norringtoniana, in that the English dancers were part of the Early Dance Project, which is run by Kay Lawrence, who is also married to the conductor.
 Earlier in the day, she had given a preview of the evening's dance entertainment with a program of her own, running through some of the Mozart numbers (choreographed by Alison Pooley) and providing demonstrations of court dancing back to the Renaissance. It was all as historically informed as one might wish and lovely in the timeless abstract, as well.
 The other highlight of Tuesday's offerings, and a reaffirmation of the staying power of truly early early music, also came from England. Fretwork is a viol ensemble that appeared late in the afternoon at the Tsai Performance Center of Boston University. The program was built around what seems to be the new cult favorite of early music, a sort of Pachelbel Canon by way of Arvo Part for neo-Elizabethan intellectuals (there are already four compact-disk recordings).
 That is John Dowland's "Lachrimae, or Seaven Teares," a sequence of seven mournful pavans for groaning, sighing viols and virtuoso lute accompaniment composed in 1604. This is grand, consoling music, and Fretwork chose to intersperse the doleful mood with more cheerful music by Dowland and his contemporary William Byrd. Paul O'Dette, perhaps the world's leading lutanist, played both the lute continuo part in the "Lachrimae" and several solos, as well.
 Partly for reasons of cost and partly to assuage complaints on the home front, the Boston festival gives a forum to all levels of local early-music groups. Most of these, along with often worthy but less well-known out-of-towners, are sequestered into a "Concurrent Events" category, and can sometimes yield deeply pleasurable results. A late-night, hourlong concert on Monday at the First and Second Church by Gwendolyn Toth's Artek Ensemble from New York, featuring music by Ortiz, Storace, Frescobaldi, Rosenmuller and Bach, proved as competent and imaginative as many of the offerings on the main schedule.
 But sometimes appeasing local feelings can backfire. The concert performances of Mozart's "Nozze di Figaro" by the Boston-based Banchetto Musicale, to judge from the first two acts on Monday evening, were a case in point. The performance at Jordan Hall was freighted with bits of acting that got in the way of the singing more than they compensated for the lack of a proper staging.
 The singing at its best was plausible, with nice work from Miss Hunt, Patrice Michaels Bedi, Matthew Lau and Frank Kelley. But some of the others were distinctly underpowered, and the performance as a whole seemed redundant at a time when Mozart operas with original instruments are no longer exotic. Worse, the conducting lacked any distinctive musical point. Martin Pearlman led a rough and workaday realization of the score, with vocal ornaments applied intermittently and stiffly.
 But any festival, especially in grim economic times, must be judged as a whole, not on the basis of its occasional failings. The Boston Early Music Festival would seem, after a two-day exposure, to be fulfilling its mandate to measure the movement's growth, fan the early-music flames and to offer its audiences musical sustenance of uncommon excellence.

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
The ------ Word

 BODY:
The Cute Alphabet is filling up fast. "R" has fallen, as in "the 'R' word," the nervous euphemism for recession heard at the American Booksellers Association's convention in New York this week. Last week President Bush swept up the "Q" word, applying it to supposed quotas in employment.
A locution that probably was invented to protect innocent young ears from the "F" word is metastasizing, like the dread disease that some people still describe as the "C" word. Republicans sprinkled the 1988 campaign liberally with the "L" word, and an analyst worried about the dread "E" word, referring to the supposed Republican lock on the Electoral College. 
 "B" has been taken, as in the overused word "brilliant." So have "D" as in "death," "M" as in "meltdown," "T" as in "taxes," "V" as in "vision" and "W" as in the women's vote. That leaves only A, G, H, I, J, K, N, O, P, S, U and XYZ, at least according to this quick inventory.
The ------ Word usage prompts two objections. One concerns clarity. Consider Bush Administration use of "Q." This month it refers to quotas. Last month, The Times reported, officials were "so worried that American troops may get bogged down in Iraq that they refer to the 'Q' word. The 'Q' stands for 'quagmire.' " The other objection to all this initializing, which was not objectionable initially, is repetition. Even cliches were once fresh. But overuse makes eyes glaze and invites another alphabetarian usage, the one cartoonists spell ZZZZZ.

HEADLINE: Sue the Doctor? There's a Better Way

BYLINE: By Pete V. Domenici and C. Everett Koop; Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico is ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee. C. Everett Koop was Surgeon General.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Under America's medical malpractice system, everyone pays grossly inflated health care bills. President Bush has offered sound remedies for the problem, but more fundamental change is required. Instead, we want to overhaul the system by removing virtually all malpractice claims from courts and resolving them in binding arbitration.
Medical liability insurance was the fastest growing part of patients' bills in the 1980's, increasing by more than 18 percent annually from 1982 through 1988. Today, every $100 paid to a doctor includes $11 for such insurance. In Chicago, neurosurgeons and obstetricians are charged more than $150,000 in premiums, and, like their colleagues elsewhere, pass the costs along to patients. 
 To protect themselves against potential malpractice suits, physicians order countless unnecessary tests and perform valueless procedures so that they might tell a jury they tried to provide the best care possible.
By many accounts, unnecessary care constitutes 20 percent to 25 percent of the nation's health expenditures.
The cost of premiums and outrageously high jury awards have forced physicians in high-risk specialties to quit their practices. The number of obstetricians in non-metropolitan areas fell by 20 percent between 1984 and 1989, denying many pregnant women the services they need.
President Bush, in a bill sent to Congress, is encouraging states to place limits on court awards for non-economic damages such as pain and suffering and to set up a mediation system for resolving disputes. Non-complying states would find their Federal Medicare and Medicaid aid reduced.
If insurance costs are reduced and defensive medicine is curtailed, health care costs can come down and more of the 34 million uninsured Americans will be able to gain access to health care.
We think far-reaching changes, proposed in legislation to be submitted to the Senate today, are necessary.
First, participants in all Federal health programs must resolve medical injury claims in binding arbitration instead of in court. These participants include beneficiaries of Medicare, Medicaid, Federal employees' health plans, and public health and veterans' programs. Second, employees of all companies that get a tax break by offering health plans must resolve medical liability disputes in binding arbitration as well.
This legislation would take about 80 percent of all medical injury claims out of court. (It would not apply to the uninsured and self-employed.)
Mr. Bush wants the following worthy restrictions imposed on state courts: a $250,000 cap on awards for non-economic damages; reduced awards if the injured person is compensated by other insurance coverage, and periodic payments, rather than lump sums, for awards intended to compensate a person for anticipated losses. We think these limits should apply in binding arbitration, bypassing the courts entirely.
Under today's litigation system, 15 out of 16 people victimized by a doctor are never compensated.
Sixty percent of the cost of malpractice insurance pays lawyers' fees and administrative costs, leaving 40 percent for patients. Even worse, patients wait years for compensation. In Michigan, court litigation takes nearly three years; voluntary arbitration, about half that time.
The Senate bill would encourage Federal and state governments, medical societies and other organizations to develop guidelines that arbitrators could use to define standards of medical treatment.
Under mandatory nationwide arbitration, patients and physicians would get more consistent, more expert, more reasonable and more timely decisions. This would not only be good for health care, but also the money Americans save from reduced health care bills could be used to benefit the economy.

HEADLINE: Profession of Rabbi Still Doesn't Lure Cream of the Candidates

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It was gratifying to read your upbeat article "More and More Young Jews Are Picking Careers as Rabbis" (front page, May 24). The phenomenon of many young people who have numerous career options selecting the rabbinate fills us with hope. 
 We have come a long way since the days when Jewish "ministers" (properly ordained rabbis settled in the New World only after 1840) were paid in firewood or tobacco. The various rabbinical organizations can take much credit for raising the prestige of the rabbinical profession, improving salaries and assuring medical and health benefits and pensions.
But that is only one side of the story. While some entry salaries are competitive with other professions, ultimate expectations cannot match incomes earned in medicine, law or business. Only a handful of rabbis approach the $200,000 salary package you mention, and most rabbis are hard pressed to make ends meet, educate children in yeshivas and universities, and enjoy a modicum of pleasure.
Moreover, job satisfaction is notoriously low in the clergy in general as the demands are great, with rabbis on call 24 hours daily, seven days a week. Stress takes a heavy toll of rabbis and their families, and many abandon their chosen profession.
The current recession has had a deleterious impact as well. We see more and more rabbis in economic difficulty because congregations are pinched and as a result are curtailing services and even closing their doors or merging with other synagogues. We at the New York Board of Rabbis are receiving 10 times as many calls as in the past from colleagues seeking help in finding positions or part-time chaplaincies to supplement inadequate incomes. Clearly, the American rabbinate is a more secure and stable profession than before. But it still has a long way to go to attract the cream of our men and women.
 
(Rabbi) MYRON M. FENSTER, (Rabbi) GILBERT S. ROSENTHAL
New York, May 28, 1991
 
The writers are, respectively, president and executive vice president of the New York Board of Rabbis.

HEADLINE: We're All Better Off for Reagan's Tax Reforms

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Richer Rich, Poorer Poor and a Fatter Green Book" (The Week in Review, May 26) reports on statistics compiled by the House Ways and Means Committee that show the rich getting richer and poor getting poorer since 1977. The Republican complaints that the numbers distort reality may be right to a small degree, in that the numbers magnify reality. But the phenomenon is exactly what one should have expected from the Reagan tax reforms. It is a good thing, too, for the most part. 
 Marginal tax rates that had been threatening confiscation of higher incomes have been sharply reduced. Incentives to earn and report higher incomes were sharply increased, with the result that the higher incomes shouldered a bigger tax burden.
The poor haven't really become poorer. A 20-year-old with a job in 1981 is now 30 years old and much better off. The numbers indicate that a working 20-year-old today is in about the same position as a working 20-year-old a decade ago. Of course, there are now 17 million more jobs, and working 20-year-olds are much, much better off than jobless 20-year-olds a decade ago. The economy is one-third bigger now because of the Reagan reforms, and everyone is better off than if the economy were one-third smaller.
One should not expect a dynamic system of entrepreneurial capitalism to produce income equality. A tax system designed to maximize economic growth will distribute rewards according to experience, effort and risk taking.
The one problem resulting from the Reagan tax reforms is that real per capita incomes have lagged in the lower income classes during the last decade because the reforms favored labor over capital. That is, in the last decade, labor income-tax rates were cut and labor incomes protected against inflation by indexation. This is why so many jobs were created. Taxes on capital formation increased in 1987, though, as the capital gains tax was raised to 28 percent from 20 percent. Also, investment income has not been protected against inflation.
If capital growth had kept pace with labor growth, real incomes would have risen in the lower income classes. The quickest way to increase the real incomes of the lower income classes would be to eliminate the tax on capital gains, which would encourage capital formation faster than new jobs are supplied.
Republicans cannot argue that the rich now pay more taxes than they did in 1980 and at the same time complain when Democrats point out that the incomes of the rich have risen faster than the poor. Likewise, Democrats can't continue to deny that the higher incomes of the rich mean the rich are carrying a larger tax burden.
 
JUDE WANNISKI
Morristown, N.J., May 29, 1991
 
The writer is a political and economic consultant.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: We're All Better Off for Reagan's Tax Reforms;
Business Helps Schools

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your May 22 front-page article on educators' complaints that business tax breaks are hurting schools distorts the contributions corporate taxes make to state and local government activities, including education. 
 Corporate taxes have increased dramatically in the last decade. Total corporate taxes rose 60 percent while profits rose 19 percent. For example, business taxes increased in New York State by $1.4 billion, or 76 percent, and in the State of Washington by $632 million, or 169 percent.
Property tax abatements are an effective incentive offered by states and communities to encourage business development and expansion. New business in a community brings added corporate income taxes and new jobs, which add to individual income tax, sales and property tax receipts. A growing business base increases the value of real estate and brings in new support services, further adding to tax revenues.
Communities without a growing business segment face stagnation, a lack of jobs for their citizens and a contracting tax base. One result is a declining school system, and everyone loses.
 
RICHARD W. RAHN
Vice President, Chief Economist, U.S. Chamber of Commerce
Washington, May 28, 1991

HEADLINE: Street Scene in Prague: Drugs and Money

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The New Prague Spring" (Editorial Notebook, May 13), Jack Rosenthal describes scenes in Prague and Bratislava, an area to which I have traveled recently, focusing on the economic optimism of Czechoslovaks since the fall of the Communists in 1989. He mentions that a darker side of capitalism has also evolved, and that crime and pornography have increased in Czechoslovakia. The rising crime rate can be partly attributed to increasing drug consumption and addiction. The latest entrepreneurs are the drug dealers. 
 The relaxation of travel restrictions since the Soviet departure from Eastern Europe has allowed Latin American drug dealers to operate freely. They have arrived without difficulty in President Vaclav Havel's free and democratic state, where they have found a new market to conquer and exploit.
The dealers do not face much difficulty smuggling the drugs into Czechoslovakia or finding buyers for their goods. The growing drug trade is extremely profitable for the dealers, but their wealth cannot be exported since the Czechoslovak crown is not convertible and is almost worthless outside the country. Thus the only difficulty faced by the dealers is changing their millions of crowns to hard currency.
A street scene in Prague: A young couple waits outside a currency exchange office. A tourist is about to enter the office when the couple offers the traveler a more favorable rate of exchange for hard currency. The tourist finds the exchange rate offered by the couple more favorable than the official rate.
Drug dealers exchange currency throughout Eastern Europe in this manner. By offering a slightly higher exchange rate to tourists, they can readily exchange crowns, Polish zlotys or Russian rubles for hard currency. Their operatives are often attractive women or young people who need money for one heartbreaking reason or another. Many visitors unwittingly assist the drug traders by exchanging their hard currency for the Eastern European currencies.
Everyone is pleased: the tourist gets more crowns to the dollar; the addict gets drugs; the dealer changes crowns to hard currency, and Eastern Europe's drug trade continues to thrive.
 
MICHAEL N. DIMAURO
Shelton, Conn., May 24, 1991
 
The writer heads Au Pair International.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
President Is Quitting At Santa Fe Railway

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
Two years after his promotion to president and chief operating officer of the railway unit of the Sante Fe Pacific Corporation, Michael R. Haverty said yesterday that he planned to resign and "pursue new challenges."
Santa Fe's corporate staff of more than 400 was reduced to fewer than 100 late last year after the company transferred ownership of its real estate and energy operations to shareholders, with railroad staff taking over most functions. 
 Burton M. Strauss Jr., railroad analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers, said Mr. Haverty's decision resulted from that change and not from any clash with Robert D. Krebs, Santa Fe's chairman and chief executive.
"They have gone from a major conglomerate to a railroad company with a minerals division that they expect to spin off," Mr. Strauss said.
In a statement, Mr. Haverty, 46 years old, cited an "increasing amount of overlap" between his work and that of Mr. Krebs, 49. The company said Mr. Krebs, who in a statement complimented Mr. Haverty's work, would add the duties of the railroad president to his current job.
Born in Atchison, Kan., Mr. Haverty climbed the executive ladder at Santa Fe first as a trainmaster in Santa Barbara, Calif., and then in bigger jobs in Emporia, Kan., Temple, Tex., and Chicago. He obtained an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago in 1981. His total earnings last year exceeded $500,000.
Mr. Haverty completed a 20 percent cut in the railroad's employees to 14,300 at the end of March, from 17,800 a year earlier, enabling the company to pare expenses further than the recession crimped revenue.
Santa Fe Pacific, based in Chicago, spun off its energy unit, Santa Fe Energy Resources, and its real estate operation, Catellus Development Corporation, to its stockholders last Dec. 4. In addition to the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway, which has 11,266 miles of track spanning 13 states in the West and Midwest, the parent company owns two pipelines operating in the same regions and a minerals company.

HEADLINE: Curtis Brewer, 65, Lawyer Known For Work on Rights of the Disabled

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
Curtis Brewer, a lawyer who was a quadriplegic for much of his life and who founded Untapped Resources, a nonprofit legal-services agency for the handicapped, died yesterday at Tisch Hospital in the New York University Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.
Mr. Brewer was stricken with a viral infection of the spine in 1955, when he was 30 years old, and was left paralyzed from the neck down. He died of complications from stomach surgery necessitated by a progressive weakening of his lungs that stemmed from the initial paralysis, his family said. 
 From his wheelchair Mr. Brewer fought for the rights of handicapped people. In 1964, he started Untapped Resources, for which he served as executive director and general counsel, to study the effects of social and economic conditions on the disabled.
Discovering that many of the disabled were unaware of their rights or prevented by bureaucratic red tape and other barriers from receiving services and benefits to which they were entitled, he set out to help them through legal action.
He graduated from Brooklyn Law School in 1974 with a grade-point average of 3.5 and was admitted to the New York State bar without an examination, which would have been difficult for him to take because of his disability.
He was an early campaigner for easier access for the handicapped. Unable to get his wheelchair into Carnegie Hall some years ago to attend a performance by his friend Itzhak Perlman, the violinist, who himself uses crutches, Mr. Brewer began a campaign to secure wheelchair access to public auditoriums. A lift was subsequently installed on the Seventh Avenue side of Carnegie Hall, and when it was remodeled in the mid-1980's, elevators were put in for the first time.
He is survived by his wife, the former Bettie Foster, a New York University administrator; a son, Scott, of Washington, a law clerk to Justice Thurgood Marshall of the United States Supreme Court; two daughters from a previous marriage, Zakia Al-Ghuiyy, director of a geriatric treatment center in Atlanta, and Geraldine Hailstolk, a family therapist in Maryland; two brothers, Garland, of Medford, Mass., and Raymond, of Boston; a sister, Jean, of Roxbury, Mass., and four granddaughters.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Curtis Brewer (The New York Times, 1974)

HEADLINE: Taxpayer Ire Not Evident in New Jersey's Primary

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVANSpecial to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 5

 BODY:
New Jersey's two major parties got through Tuesday's primary elections without rebuke from an angry electorate that many political leaders had feared was bent on making changes.
 Only two incumbent legislators, both Democrats, were denied nominations for new terms. But the losses by Senator Thomas H. Paterniti of Edison and Assemblyman George J. Otlowski of Perth Amboy were ascribed to local issues and not to broad voter unrest over taxes. 
Party leaders today were already turning their attention toward the November election, with Republican leaders saying they intended to make it a referendum on Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax program.
 
Incompetence vs. Credibility
 Jeffrey T. Michaels, executive director of the Republican State Committee, said, "Voters will have an opportunity to pass judgment on the incompetence of the Florio Democrats and the largest tax increase in the history of New Jersey."
 But Steve DeMicco, executive director of the State Democratic Committee, said his party was not afraid to talk about taxes, especially property taxes, which the increased state revenue is intended to hold in check while increasing aid to local school districts.
 "The issue in November will be credibility," Mr. DeMicco said. "And that goes to whether the voters really believe Republicans will repeal the tax program in the middle of a national recession."
 Senator Paterniti and Assemblyman Otlowski ran into political problems because of their service as mayors, not as members of the Legislature. Mr. Paterniti stepped down this year after a year as mayor of Edison Township, during which he proposed raising local property taxes to resolve a long-standing budget problem. His spot on the ballot as a Senate candidate was won by Harry S. Pozycki, a Metuchen lawyer and former municipal official.
 
8 Incumbents Retire
 Mr. Otlowski, an Assemblyman for 18 years, was mayor of Perth Amboy from 1976 until last year, when he resigned in the face of a petition drive aimed at recalling him from office. Opposition to Mr. Otlowski by the city's growing Hispanic population prompted Democratic Party leaders to ask him not to run again for the Assembly, and then to deny him the party line on the ballot in Tuesday's election when he refused to step aside.
 Jay Zisnewski of Perth Amboy, a lawyer and political newcomer, won the Assembly nomination with party backing.
 The Democratic Party will also lose eight incumbents -- four Senators and four Assembly members -- to retirement. They decided not to run for re-election after the recent realignment of election districts in the wake of the 1990 census.
 Only one Republican member of the Assembly decided against seeking a new term. Another was denied party support and is running for the Senate as an independent in November.
 A handful of other incumbents survived strong challenges in Tuesday's election. In Mercer County, two Democratic Assemblymen, Gerard S. Naples and John S. Watson, won nominations over the strong opposition of G. Dallas Dixon of Trenton, a former Mercer County Democratic chairman, who criticized the incumbents for their support of Mr. Florio's tax program.
 In one of the most closely watched contests, William L. Gormley, a Republican Senator from Margate, won a new nomination against a strong challenge by Domenic F. Cappella, the Ventnor City Administrator, by capturing 56 percent of the vote.
 Mr. Gormley, a moderate and the only Republican Senator to support Mr. Florio's bill banning assault rifles, became the target of conservative Republicans who helped finance his opponent's campaign.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A Better Feeling On Trade Talks

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE tension between the United States and the European Community over trade, especially in agriculture, was eased by this week's meeting in Paris of financial and trade officials of the wealthy countries that make up the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. But a lot of tough bargaining is ahead if the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations, under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, is to be brought to a successful conclusion.
Interviewed by telephone at the end of the Paris talks, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said, "The outcome was positive, the atmospherics were better -- there was a much better feeling in the air." Indeed, the meeting's communique declared, "The Uruguay Round has the highest priority on the international economic agenda." It said success in the talks, which started in 1986 in Uruguay, remained crucial to continued growth of the world economy, and it called for "a substantial and comprehensive conclusion as early as possible, preferably before the end of the year." 
 To achieve that goal, the ministers recognized that "political decisions to overcome major existing differences are needed by all participants without delay." A key player in that political process will be France's new Prime Minister, Edith Cresson, who is regarded as even tougher on trade issues than her predecessor, Michel Rocard. Mrs. Hills, for example, said Mrs. Cresson was "more protectionist" than her predecessor and said it was "very difficult" to guess how flexible she would be in trying to avert a failure of the Uruguay Round.
The United States is not weakening its own drive for opening up trade in agriculture. It is striving to get rid of export subsidies, barriers to farm imports and internal subsidies linked to trade protection. The Europeans, for their part, say the United States has a good way to go in getting rid of its own barriers.
Little or no progress has been made on agricultural reform. The Paris communique noted that agriculture supports had increased in 1990, after declining in 1988 and 1989, and cost taxpayers $300 billion last year.
"Unless policies are improved," the ministers said, "the budgetary and economic costs, as well as trade tensions, are likely to rise and the economic progress of countries dependent on agricultural exports are likely to be seriously affected, including developing countries."
Such language is encouraging. But more than recognition of the problem is needed, Mrs. Hills said. "You need an action plan," she said. "And the bad news is that quota restrictions remain in some areas, and agriculture is still a fortress." She also stressed the importance of opening world trade in services, manufacturing, intellectual property and investment. The total volume of world trade, she said, is now $4 trillion, of which only about two-thirds is open.
She expects a "bumpy road," a "sawtooth pattern," "two steps forward, one backward." Her overall assessment of the talks in Paris was: "We made constructive progress, and have a lot more work to do. It's important for countries to translate their very good words into action."
The other big issue in Paris was how to deal with Mikhail S. Gorbachev's pitch for much greater economic aid from the West. The general view of the Western ministers was that until Mr. Gorbachev and his aides fixed on a single plan for rebuilding the Soviet economy, there would be no aid package.
One American official, speaking off the record, said: "There is not enough money in the West to finance a non-plan. Until they decide what they are doing, it would be pouring money down the proverbial rat hole."
Countries differ on the aid issue, depending, as one minister put it, "on their proximity to the Soviet Union." Thus, the United States is less willing than Germany to work on an aid package. With the United States deep in deficit and Germany preoccupied with the big bills related to unification, talk of negotiating an aid package for the Soviet Union looks premature.
The meeting of ministers in Paris reaffirmed their view that "fundamental reform" was the only answer to the structural problems of the Soviet economy, and urged the Soviet Union and its republics to introduce the "broad range of macro and microeconomic reforms necessary to move to a market economy."
In friendly fashin, they told Mr. Gorbachev that "policy dialogue, technical assistance and humanitarian aid can support Soviet reform," and that "whenever appropriate, existing multilateral institutions should be used to channel assistance" to the Soviet Union.
Mr. Gorbachev does not need to attend the London meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations next month to hear that. Nevertheless, it appears that he will be invited and will go, for whatever good the West can do him as he struggles to save his sinking economy.

HEADLINE: Pakistan Asks Talks on Atom Spread

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAHORE, Pakistan, June 6

 BODY:
Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, intent on asserting civilian government control over strategic policies in a country long dominated by the military, asked the United States, the Soviet Union and China today to sponsor urgent talks on nuclear nonproliferation in South Asia, where both Pakistan and India have the ability to make nuclear weapons.
Speaking to high-ranking military officers at Pakistan's National Defense College in Rawalpindi, Mr. Sharif, who has been in power for barely eight months, said a regional conference on nuclear weapons should be held "as quickly as possible." 
 A team of Pakistani Foreign Ministry officials will be in Washington next week to discuss this and other issues with the Bush Administration and members of Congress. Mr. Sharif said the team would not be begging for American aid.
Fears about Pakistan's nuclear program have led Washington to ban all military aid to Islamabad and new economic aid. India, which set off a nuclear explosion in 1974 and has never agreed to inspections, has escaped United States sanctions, to the distress of Pakistanis, who believe that they are being victimized unfairly.
 
India's Program Cited

"The fact is that India exploded a nuclear device in 1974," Mr. Sharif said in his speech. "It has a number of nuclear enrichment and reprocessing facilties outside the framework of International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards. It is also reported to have unsafeguarded plutonium sufficient for producing over 100 Hiroshima-sized bombs. We cannot, therefore, ignore India's fast growing nuclear program and jeopardize our national security."
In a breakfast meeting with three American reporters in Lahore today, Mr. Sharif left the impression that he had been prepared nonetheless to agree to International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards without waiting for India, but that "pressures at home" were one reason that this step could not be taken.
Officials and diplomats interpreted this as a veto by the military, which controls Pakistan's nuclear program. But Mr. Sharif asserted that he made the decisions.
"It is the Government of Pakistan and its Foreign Ministry that make policies," Mr. Sharif said when asked about differences of opinion between civilian and military power centers. "The army follows."
"In two or three months you will not ask these questions, I hope," he added. He described the choice of today's venue for his nuclear policy speech as "very significant."
Pakistan is awash in rumors about military opposition to Mr. Sharif. He and the army Chief of Staff, Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg, first clashed over Pakistani policy during the Persian Gulf war. Mr. Sharif broadly backed Saudi Arabia and the United States, and General Beg talked about "strategic defiance" and an independent policy line.
 
New Inquiry Into Zia's Death
 Recently, Mr. Sharif ordered a new investigation into the mysterious crash that killed President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq in August 1988. The military investigation, he told reporters today, "was not getting anywhere."
Last week, when an army ammunition depot blew up in Nowshera, in the North West Frontier Province, Mr. Sharif publicly chided the military for having learned nothing from an earlier, more destructive blast near Rawalpindi four years ago.
Today, Mr. Sharif praised General Beg for his part in insuring a peaceful and democratic change in government after President Ghulam Ishaq Khan dismissed the Government of Benazir Bhutto in August 1990, but he went on to say that the army chief would step down when his term ends in two months.
Since 1974, Pakistan has made a number of proposals on limiting nuclear development in this region. The Islamabad Government is on record as saying it would agree to safeguards and sign the nuclear nonproliferation treaty if and when India did. But India has always insisted that it would not join such international agreements until they were signed by all nuclear nations. India fears the nuclear intentions of China, which has not signed, just as Pakistan fears those of India.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Silver Hits an 8-Month High On Hope of Strong Demand

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver soared to an eight-month high yesterday amid speculative buying prompted in part by an industry report that demand for the metal was exceeding production.
Gold futures also rose and oil futures were mixed. 
 Silver futures settled 24.7 cents to 26.9 cents higher on the Commodity Exchange in New York, with the contract for delivery in June at $4.414 an ounce, the highest daily settlement for a near-term silver contract since Oct. 9.
Silver's surge followed a leap of more than 12 cents on May 28. Some analysts said the moves confirmed the market's recovery from the 17-year low of $3.505 an ounce reached in February.
"The recent lows below $3.60 will prove to be the bottom for quite a long period of time," said William O'Neill, senior futures strategist at Merrill Lynch Futures.
But he would not rule out a retreat to $4, the price around which silver had hovered for three months.
 
Demand Exceeding Supply
 Speculative interest in silver has been gradually building, a reflection of rising hopes for an economic recovery. The catalyst for yesterday's move may have been the Silver Institute's 1991 survey, which said industrial demand exceeded silver production last year for the first time since 1978.
The report, released Wednesday, projected that 1991 demand would exceed new supplies by 32 million ounces.
"Certainly, the Silver Institute figures were a constructive influence," said Stephen Platt, metals analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. But Mr. Platt and Mr. O'Neill said the rally was already in the making before the report came out.
Oil prices fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange but gasoline staged a modest afternoon rally on perceptions of strong summer demand.
Light sweet crude oil was 4 cents to 16 cents lower, with July at $20.33 a barrel; heating oil was 0.08 cent to 0.57 cent lower, with July at 54.2 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.06 cent to 0.32 cent higher, with July at 64.44 cents a gallon, and natural gas was 0.8 cent to 3.4 cents lower, with July at $1.297 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher After Jobless-Claims Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly higher in quiet trading yesterday, helped by an improvement in United States unemployment.
Gold prices advanced worldwide. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $365.10 an ounce, up $2.50 from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank said gold rose $2.05 an ounce, to a late bid of $364.25. 
 Analysts said the dollar advanced following a Labor Department report that the number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits fell for the third straight week in May, the first such streak in more than a year.
The decline suggested the recession might be ending and gave traders reason to believe the Government's jobless report for the full month of May, due today, might be better than expected.
"The consensus is for the best number of the year," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the financial advisory firm IDEA, referring to the non-farm payroll component of the report.
Economists expect non-farm payrolls to post a decline of about 70,000, the smallest so far this year, which could push the dollar higher.
The dollar held to a relatively narrow trading range throughout the session. But Mr. Chandler noted thatthe United States currency hit a high for the year against the Swiss franc, a move some traders view as a precursor to a similar advance against the German mark in the coming days.
 
Dollar Up in Tokyo
 In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 139.25 Japanese yen, from 139.17 yen on Wednesday. Later in London, it fell to 139.15 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 139.28 yen, down from 139.30 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.6865, from $1.6945 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.6870 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.6935.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.7535 German marks, up from 1.7490; 1.5040 Swiss francs, up from 1.4960; 5.9400 French francs, up from 5.9220; 1,299.75 Italian lire, up from 1,294.50, and 1.1465 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1456.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $364.25 a troy ounce, up from $362.75 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $364, up from $362. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose 95 cents, to $362.89.

HEADLINE: Plan for Boat People Cheers Hong Kong

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG, June 6

 BODY:
When the boat people from Vietnam started pouring in again in recent months, the prospects for resolving a problem that had haunted this territory for years seemed grim. But a more accommodating attitude by the United States has now given Hong Kong hope that it will not always be burdened by unwanted refugees.
The United States Government agreed on Wednesday to back the "non-voluntary" return of boat people to special camps in Vietnam, as long as the camps were managed by an international organization like the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. That was a breakthrough because the United States has always opposed forcible repatriation of the boat people. 
 Partly because of the United States view, Vietnamese refugees in Hong Kong normally have not been sent back to Vietnam against their will. The number of refugees is rising daily, and many have no realistic hope of resettlement in the West. Many people in Hong Kong favor forcing the boat people to go home just as illegal immigrants in China are forced to go back.
American officials still say the proposal does not violate their position, mainly because they contend the centers in Vietnam, as envisioned, would be distinct from the Vietnam Government. Nonetheless, the new backing could mean that Hong Kong's more than 50,000 asylum seekers, who are unlikely to be given refugee status, could be returned to Vietnam.
 
'A Positive Step'

"We welcome this as a positive step toward resolving this very difficult problem we've faced for 16 years," said Clinton E. Leeks, refugee coordinator for the Hong Kong government. "It's not a solution in itself, but it is a step toward achieving one."
The proposal, jointly sponsored by the United States, Britain and Hong Kong, must be presented to the Vietnam Government, and it is not clear what the reaction will be. Vietnam has consistently maintained that it will not accept Vietnamese people who are returned against their will. But it has also hinted it might be responsive to the idea of being host to internationally run camps, a refugee official said.
So far this year, 9,345 Vietnamese have sailed illegally into Hong Kong, nearly a third more than the number that arrived in all of last year. In May, 5,116 Vietnamese escaped to Hong Kong, and so far 748 new asylum seekers have arrived in June. At that rate, this year may see more than 20,000 Vietnamese fleeing to Hong Kong.
All asylum seekers arriving here are taken to camps where they are interviewed and screened for refugee status. The process is long, and in the meantime the Hong Kong government spends millions of dollars housing, feeding and caring for them. More than 58,000 Vietnamese -- fewer than 7,000 of whom have been accepted as legitimate political refugees -- now live in crowded, makeshift, often squalid camps.
 
Extent of Force Is Unclear
 But the majority of escapees from Vietnam appear not to be eluding persecution, but simply to be searching for a better life, say refugee officials from Hong Kong and the United States. But they have refused to go back under the existing voluntary repatriation scheme, and that suggests they will resist the new proposal.
"Why would they go back to a holding center in Vietnam instead of being detained in Hong Kong?" Kingsley H. Y. Sit, a Hong Kong legislator, said.
Officials always speak of "voluntary" or "non-voluntary" repatriation, and it is unclear to what extent force will now be used. One official said it remained to be discussed whether the Vietnamese people would be dragged onto planes or boats to go home.
One reason for the inflow cited by refugee officials is a proposal by Representative Robert K. Dornan, a California Republican. He suggested in a letter to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in mid-March that Vietnamese refugees be resettled in Kuwait to help rebuild the country.
Although American officials immediately rejected the suggestion, Mr. Dornan's plan was carried over Vietnamese-language Voice of America, and the prospects of being resettled in Kuwait spread like fire through Vietnam.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Fall on Strong Jobs Report

DATELINE: KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell again yesterday and interest rates moved higher as dealers sold notes and bonds after a report from the Labor Department suggested that May employment data scheduled to be released today might be stronger than had been anticipated.
Figures from the Labor Department showed that initial unemployment claims in the week that ended May 25 fell by 6,000, to 439,000, from the previous week's mark of 445,000. It was the third straight weekly decline. Most economists had expected the number to be unchanged. 
 But the big surprise to bond traders was the very large declines in the number of people the Labor Department said were receiving unemployment benefits.
The drop "makes some economists believe that the employment numbers will show strength rather than weakness," one government bond trader said. Strong employment figures are an indication that the economy might be regaining vigor, raising the prospects for inflation. Higher inflation erodes the value of fixed-income securities, prompting bondholders to sell.
 
Weakness Still Seen
 Nevertheless, most Wall Street economists were forecasting that today's labor report would show that conditions deteriorated further in May, with non-farm payroll employment declining by anywhere from 75,000 to 100,000 jobs and the unemployment rate rising to 6.8 percent from the 6.6 percent rate recorded for April.
Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montague Economics, pointed out that the claims data released yesterday were for a period after that covered by today's Labor Department's employment survey, which generally takes place during the first two weeks of each month.
Still, yesterday's report "has to change the confidence you may have had in your forecast," he said.
In addition to the initial claims figures, reports yesterday that sales were strong last month at major retail department store chains reinforced growing concern among credit market participants that economic recovery was coming sooner and would be more vigorous than had been expected.
"The bond market won't improve until it sees how weak the recovery really is," Mr. Fabbri said. "It will take a few months of data at least showing that the recovery is weak and inflation is not going to shoot up before long-term interest rates can improve. But I believe that is going to happen."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 96 25/32 late yesterday, down 11/32, to yield 8.42 percent, up from 8.38 percent late Wednesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 17/32, down 9/32, to yield 8.21 percent. And the 6 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 26/32, down 3/32, to yield 6.85 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were little changed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.54 percent late yesterday, down a basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 5.69 percent.
 
Slow Trading in Corporates
 In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, market participants said that prices of most issues dipped by about 1/8 point in lethargic trading.
Activity was equally slow in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds. Prices of most widely quoted issues fell by about 1/2 point, dealers said.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week ended May 27.
The declines were in line with expectations, and the report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.
