HEADLINE: Hanging On in Textile Country

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EDEN, N.C., May 31

 BODY:
Economists and free trade proponents have generally assumed that when a domestic industry shrinks, workers will do what they must to survive: pack up and seek suitable work elsewhere in a process akin to natural selection in the capitalist system.
Here in Eden, where a local blanket factory is struggling to compete with less expensive imports in a slumping economy, the mill, owned by Fieldcrest Cannon Inc., has repeatedly furloughed John M. Biggs and given only four hours of work over the last five weeks to his wife, Alma Jean. But the Biggses are not budging. 
 In fact, they're digging in. They have planted an extra row of corn, an extra row of beets and three extra rows of beans in their garden this spring to save money at the grocery store. The vegetable garden is one way the Biggses hope to avoid having to leave this small town in northwestern North Carolina near the Virginia border, where they and three of their parents have lived their entire lives.
The Bush Administration's campaign to loosen trade restrictions on a range of services and products from investment banking to blankets threatens to open American borders to a flood of imports from low-cost foreign manufacturers. That means that the Biggses may lose their livelihood. Congress has cleared the way for the Administration to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico and to try to finish an international round of trade talks that is likely to accelerate sharply the growth of textile imports.
The effort to lower or eliminate tariffs and other import restrictions is designed to spur exports in the United States and elsewhere. But that could lead to job losses here and in other factory towns. That has happened before. Yet the uncertainty in Eden is the latest example of the human toll of free trade.
Thousands of workers lost their jobs in the steel towns of Ohio and Pennsylvania in the 80's, as well as the auto and factory cities of the Midwest. Many swarmed to the Sun Belt a decade ago when the Texas oil boom offered jobs and a fresh start.
But thousands of others were left behind because they did not want to pack up and move. When the consumer electronics, telecommunications equipment and textile industries moved from the Midwest, New York and New England to the South in the 1950's and 1960's, many families left behind in small, dying towns could not afford to move to more prosperous places, said Robert B. Reich, a professor of political economy at Harvard University.
"Moving from a high-unemployment area to a low-unemployment area, selling an old home and buying a new one has plagued relocations for generations as the American economy has undergone changes," Mr. Reich said.
To economists, further growth in textile and apparel imports -- and the corresponding loss of jobs -- may be good. By some estimates, import restrictions force the average American household to spend as much as $200 extra each year for clothing and textile products like rugs and blankets.
"It's a real question -- should consumers be subsidizing someone's unwillingness to move?" asked Alfred J. Field, an associate professor of economics at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
 
A Mobile Society
 The South, and North Carolina especially, is often heralded as a mobile work environment where workers can easily move to jobs in urban areas and still maintain their way of life in country towns not far away.
Commuting might be difficult for the Biggses because 12-hour shifts are common in the textile and apparel industries during seasonal surges in demand. The Biggses are concerned that they may be forced to leave Eden, population 15,000, to seek new jobs in Greensboro, a city of 184,000 an hour's drive to the south.
Mrs. Biggs is alarmed at the prospect of leaving her home. She has taken only two trips in her life: to Florida 25 years ago and to the Grand Ole Opry in Nashville a few years ago.
"I don't really care for driving in heavy traffic," she said. "And if you talk about moving to a big city, you've got drugs -- not to say we've not got drugs here -- and you've got crime."
Moving to Greensboro would also mean a substantial financial setback for the Biggs family, which paid $38,000 last year for a four-bedroom house with a large lawn. The price was a bargain, Mrs. Biggs explained, because it also included living room furniture, a refrigerator, a stove, a microwave oven and even a full set of china.
 
Housing Market Slumps
 Mrs. Biggs said that with young people leaving Eden for jobs elsewhere and with few people moving into town, the family's current home might not be salable. The median price of a home in Greensboro is $78,500, twice as much as in Eden, according to the Census Bureau. The median rent in Greensboro is $358; $229 in Eden.
Outside the textile industry, jobs are few and far between in Eden. A local brewery has halved its employment. The furniture factories in nearby towns pay a little more than half the $8.07 hourly wage that Mrs. Biggs now earns. One of the last family restaurants on the back roads of Eden had a fire late last year and has not reopened. That leaves minimum-wage jobs mostly in the fast-food franchise restaurants that line the four-lane highway that has increasingly become Eden's Main Street.
Sometimes communities can create new jobs by persuading new industries to set up local factories that require similar skills to the dying textile and apparel plants, said Carol A. Conway, the deputy director of the Southern Growth Policies Board, based in Durham, N.C., a joint research program supported by state governments in the Southeast.
Yet many employers in North Carolina, including in Eden, have been hostile to high-paying industries that may hire away the low-wage labor they need to remain competitive, said William P. Meade, a consultant in Chapel Hill who advises companies that are expanding existing operations in North Carolina.
 
Automation Not Enough
 The automation of textile and apparel factories is eliminating many jobs but it may still not be enough to counter the advantage of foreign countries paying workers as little as a dollar a day. The blanket mill that employs Mr. and Mrs. Biggs and both her parents was built a decade ago to replace a mill next door that used obsolete equipment and employed twice as many people. The mill declined to comment for this article.
The fairly automated textile industry, which relies extensively on American-made synthetic fibers, is so nearly competitive in world markets that the United States trade deficit in textiles has narrowed in the last several years as the dollar has weakened, making American exports cheaper overseas.
Economists say the apparel industry has a so-called absolute disadvantage because it has higher costs than its foreign competitors. This need not prevent an industry from thriving. But the true cost of producing textiles and apparel is measured by economists in terms of what could have been produced by the same workers and other resources if they were used in other industries. The forgone production is greater in the United States than in other countries.
"In a less extreme form, it's like trying to grow coffee in the United States -- it can be done, but it's difficult," said William R. Cline, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
 
What Children Plan
 What remains unclear is whether Mrs. Biggs's children will avoid their parents' predicament. Laura Biggs, 23, took a six-week medical training course after her graduation from high school. She now lives at home and works as a nurse's assistant at a local nursing home.
Jeffrey L. Biggs, 16, just finished the 10th grade. His favorite subject was industrial shop. Asked what he wanted to do after graduation from high school, he replied, "Maybe custom-paint cars."
When prodded by his mother, Jeffrey allowed unenthusiastically that he might go to college for two years.
Finding work outside Eden is an unattractive but likely step, he added. But any job will have to be within an hour's or an hour and a half's drive of Eden, he said, adding, "I'd like to live somewhere I don't have to plan trips home."

HEADLINE: Businesses Plan a Slim 3% Rise in Spending

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
Businesses in the United States plan to increase their investment spending by just 3 percent this year, the smallest rise in five years, the Government reported today.
Analysts said the recession, in trimming consumer demand, had reduced available cash as well as any immediate need for new plants and equipment. 
 The Commerce Department said that a survey conducted in April and May found businesses planning to spend $540.1 billion for expansion and modernization, up from a record $524.2 billion in 1990.
Many analysts had expected capital spending to slow this year because of the recession.
The Commerce Department said its survey showed that capital spending rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter after increasing six-tenths of 1 percent in the previous three months. It is expected to rise 1.7 percent in the second quarter, 1.8 percent in the third and five-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth.
As the effects of the recession fade, plant and equipment spending "will show pretty good growth in 1992," said Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, a Lexington, Mass., forecasting organization.
Still, any increase this year would help stimulate the economy. In addition, spending to replace aging plants and equipment and expand operations helps to increase productivity, an important factor in view of increasingly strong competition from abroad. Productivity is defined as output per hours worked.
Productivity is also considered vital to improving the nation's standard of living without increasing inflation. Productivity rose just three-tenths of 1 percent at an annual rate in the first quarter of 1991, well below the average growth of 1.6 percent a year between 1982 and 1989.
Capital investment has risen during each of the last four years, although growth slowed to just 4.5 percent in 1990 as the economy began its downturn.
Spending had surged by 10.4 percent in 1989 and 9.5 percent in 1988 after rebounding by 3.1 percent in 1987 from a decline of 4.1 percent in 1986.
Before adjusting for inflation, the survey projected a 2.7 percent rise in business investment, to $547.2 billion, after gains of 5 percent in 1990 and 11.4 percent a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Britain Is Proposing to Invite Gorbachev to London Talks

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, June 6

 BODY:
British officials proposed today that the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, be invited to London next month to meet with the leaders of the world's seven major industrial democracies, immediately after their mid-summer economic summit.
As the host of the summit, the British Prime Minister, John Major, sent a letter to other members of the Group of Seven nations, asking for their permission to invite Mr. Gorbachev, who has been pressing to come to London to plead for more Western economic support for his domestic reform package. 
 But in Bonn, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, jumped the gun, telling a session of the German Parliament that Mr. Gorbachev would be in London to meet with Western leaders.
"I welcome the fact that Gorbachev will attend the world economic summit," Mr. Kohl said. German officials later acknowledged that an official invitation had not yet been sent to the Soviet leader, but said they expected one within the next day or two.
Mr. Kohl has been urging that Mr. Gorbachev be invited to London during the Group of Seven meeting, although he said he was not asking that the Soviet leader take part in the summit meeting itself.
 
Not to Be Part of Summit
 That was also the basis for Mr. Major's proposal today. "We will be asking Mr. Gorbachev to come immediately after the summit, and not during the summit itself," said a spokesman at 10 Downing Street. "It is not going to be the G8. It will still be the G7."
Britain will tender the official invitation on behalf of the Group of Seven, after it receives affirmative replies from the other nations.
The announcements in London and Bonn appeared to end nearly two weeks of hestitation and uncertainty about whether Mr. Gorbachev would get a chance to plead for Western help before the leaders of the United States, Britain, Germany, Italy, France, Canada and Japan, when they meet in London from July 15 to 17.
Pressure to invite Mr. Gorbachev had come mainly from the Continent, where France, Germany and Italy have made insistent public appeals that he should be invited to London at the time of the conference, although not necessarily as a participant.
European officials said it was symbolically important that the West demonstrate support for Mr. Gorbachev's attempt to bring economic and democratic reform to the Soviet Union.
The United States and Britain have been more wary, in part out of concern that Western nations will be unable to come up with the huge amount of aid Mr. Gorbachev will need to bail out the battered Soviet economy.
 
Bush Softens Position
 But President Bush softened his position in recent days, and he told Mr. Major by telephone this week that the United States would not object if Mr. Gorbachev were invited to London.
On Wednesday, in Oslo, Mr. Gorbachev repeated his plea for Western help to keep his economic reforms alive, warning that unless perestrokia surives, the world will lose its best chance yet for peace.
British officials said the logistics of the meeting between the summit participants and Mr. Gorbachev were yet to be sorted out.
In his speech, Mr. Kohl expressed reservations about just how much the West could do for Mr. Gorbachev. "We are not in a position to finance a bottomless barrel," he said, adding that Moscow "needs help to help itself."
"The rebuilding of the Soviet Union must be decided there," he said.
 
Aid to Be Tied to Reforms
 In London, British officials said there was an emerging consensus among the Group of Seven that any significant financial aid should be granted in stages and tied to the Soviet Union's progress in adopting a market economy. The assistance should also be given to the private sector and not to the Soviet Government, they added.
"I don't think anyone has the desire to put money in on a state-to-state level, with the possibile exception of Germany," said a top aide to Mr. Major.
In Copenhagen today, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d stepped up the Bush Administration's efforts to dampen Soviet expectations about how much economic aid they might get.
In particular, Mr. Baker for the first time publicly signaled that the United States would not support any of the current suggestions for a "grand bargain," under which the West would make a large, long-term commitment of financial aid to the Soviet Union in return for firm commitments from Moscow to move to a free-market democracy.
"The Soviets," Mr. Baker told his NATO allies, "must start with self-help. If they do, we will support them. Indeed, we are developing a package of supportive measures, which we hope we can coordinate with you and others. But I don't honestly think we can catalyze Soviet reform through a big bang approach. Our effort is more likely to be a step by step process -- certainly one with a grand goal -- but ever a realistic and workable approach."
The Japanese have taken one of the toughest positions among the Group of Seven toward the Soviets' appeals for aid, arguing like many in the United States and Britain that it would unwise to consider large-scale aid before Moscow has put basic reforms into place.
"Japan wants to see reform implemented, not a promise of reform," said an official with the Japanese Foreign Ministry in Tokyo. "There have been many promises in the past."
The Japanese have also been leery about the meeting with Mr. Gorbachev, although officials say they will go along with the consensus of the Group of Seven.
"We are afraid that Mr. Gorbachev will expect some kind of gift package when he comes to London, but this expectation will not be realized," the official said. "We're not shutting the door, but we're concerned about what he thinks he can get."
Japan's hard line toward the Soviet Union is a result in part of a territorial dispute over four groups of islands off the northern tip of Hokkaido, which the Soviets occupied in the waning days of World War II. Japan says the islands must be returned before it can consider boosting trade, investment or aid.

Mr. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, arrived yesterday in Stockholm from Oslo, where Mr. Gorbachev had delivered his long-delayed Nobel Peace Prize address. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Sales in May Up for Many Big Retailers

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Many of the nation's biggest retailers reported yesterday that sales in May had improved sharply from the same month a year earlier. While sales were helped by good weather, some analysts see the gains as another indication that the recession may be ending.
Thirteen of 20 top retail companies said that in the four weeks ended June 1, same-store sales -- results at stores that have been in business for at least a year -- rose. The more favorable weather helped sell summer clothes, air-conditioners and garden equipment. 
 Among the gainers were Wal-Mart Stores, with a same-store rise of 13 percent over the year before; the K Mart Corporation, which was up 8.5 percent, and the Limited, up 10 percent. The Gap, reported a 15 percent gain in same-store sales, and Charming Shoppes rose 30 percent.
 
Declines at Sears and Penney
 But Sears, Roebuck & Company and J. C. Penney reported lower sales for the second consecutive month, both in total and same-store sales. Sears said total sales at its merchandising group fell four-tenths of 1 percent, to $2.49 billion, and that same-store sales fell 1.3 percent. Total sales for 17 weeks were down 1.8 percent, to $10.1 billion. Penney said its overall sales dropped 1.2 percent, to $1.01 billion, while same-store sales fell 2.5 percent. Penney's four-month sales fell 3.1 percent, to $4.2 billion.
But over all, "sales were up very nicely in May," said Edward F. Johnson, director of the Johnson Redbook Service of Lynch, Jones & Ryan in New York. "Our computation for total sales is that the May average gain of reporting companies was up 14 percent against a year-to-date gain of 11.5 percent."
He said the same-store average in May was up 6.5 percent from the period a year earlier, against a yearlong gain of 2.8 percent. "It's obvious that while warmer weather helped, the consumer is feeling better about things, which may mean that the recession is waning."
 
Apparel Chains Up in Month
 As a group, the apparel shop chains showed the best total-sales results for the month. The Gap reported a 33 percent jump, to $165 million; the Limited was up 22 percent, to $440 million; Charming Shoppes, which operates Fashion Bug stores, had a 38 percent sales gain, to $94.2 million; Merry-Go-Round Stores was up 28 percent, to $50.1 million; Edison Brothers Stores, whose chains include Jeans West, had a 20.8 percent rise, to $101.2 million, and the Melville Corporation, which owns Marshall's and the Thom McAn shoe stores, had 19.7 percent higher sales, at $697.8 million.
"There are certainly some positive signs in the economy, but I would prefer to see at least two more months of good figures," said Jeffrey S. Stein, retail analyst at McDonald & Company Securities in Cleveland.
The big change in the ranks of the largest retailers continued in May for the fourth straight month, as Wal-Mart widened its lead over its two largest competitors, Sears and K Mart. Wal-Mart recorded a 38 percent rise in total May sales, to $3.5 billion, and 37 percent higher sales in the year to date, to $12.7 billion. K Mart also continued its recent thrust with a 12.5 percent gain in total sales in May, to $12.5 billion, and a 9.5 percent advance in year-to-date sales to $10.4 billion.
Sears's merchandising sales again fell under those of the other two companies by dollars. Nonetheless, Edward A. Brennan, the chairman of Sears, said that the company was encouraged by double-digit gains in apparel, home computers, air-conditioners and lawn mowers, although furniture and appliances were depressed.
Ann Taylor Stores, which reported its monthly results for the first time since it went public, said its May sales were 11.8 percent higher, at $37.3 million, but its same-store sales were down six-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: A Japanese-Style 'Old Boy' Network

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 6

 BODY:
When Japan's banks and securities houses began battling several years ago to break into each other's business, policy makers at the formidable Finance Ministry were deadlocked over what to do. It finally took an even greater power to break the stalemate: the "Old Boys."
Occasionally, an issue arises in this seemingly harmonious society that lifts the facade of orderliness and illuminates both the intensity of the business rivalries and the real lines of power for resolving disputes. The five-year tug-of-war over financial deregulation has done just that. 
 It is particularly interesting to observe this process at the Finance Ministry, which is widely seen as the most powerful arm of the Government. The ministry combines what in the United States would be all the bank regulatory agencies, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Internal Revenue Service, the Office of Management and Budget and a few lesser agencies.
The Old Boys, who are widely referred to, even by themselves, by this English phrase and often in shorthand as "O.B.'s," are dozens of retired senior Finance Ministry officials who form a club-like elite. At the top of the heap are the former vice ministers, the highest career post. They might hold the job for only a year or two but then move on to lucrative jobs in industry and O.B. status, from which they continue to hold sway over policy and personnel moves at the ministry. (The finance minister's post is a political appointment and thus the former ministers generally do not continue to have as much say over financial policy.)
The momentous battle between the banks and securities houses over eliminating the barriers in Japan's version of the Glass-Steagall Act, the United States law that separates commercial banking from investment banking, is no ordinary struggle. Put simply, commercial banks want to get into the highly protected securities business, and the securities brokers want to keep them out.
The banks, which enjoy a decidedly higher status in Japan as the partners of industry, had prevailed initially by offering to build "firewalls" between their banking and securities operations to protect against conflicts of interest and other abuses.
At the ministry, the securities and banking bureaus usually reflect the thinking of the industries they regulate. The bureaus thus found themselves at odds over how to lower the barriers separating the businesses. So a small group of O.B's quietly decided how to break the impasse. There were no weekend hunting trips, no intensive lobbying efforts.
Instead, the Old Boys merely passed the word to the bureaucrats through advisory panels on which they sat that the securites industry should give up only a little to Japan's huge banking institutions.
The result: Perhaps in 1993, banks will get modest powers to engage in the securities business. Through separate subsidiaries they will be allowed to do bond underwriting. They will be shut out of the more lucrative equity underwriting and brokerage operations, however. The banks will be able to deal in some new kinds of securities and private placements, but they will have very limited ability to trade securities.
In return, securities houses will be permitted to trade foreign currencies and to engage in some kinds of trust banking.
"The banks were too optimistic; they thought it would go too easily," said Hiroshi Tanimura, 75 years old, a pleasant man who as an O.B. occupies a large corner office at the Finance Ministry.
"They thought they could build the firewalls rather easily," he added in an interview, breaking into one of his broad smiles. "But I thought that would be rather difficult."
Although he insisted that he had been essentially neutral, Mr. Tanimura did hint that it had been sort of fun taking the banks down a few pegs.
"The banks were in a sort of go-go mood," he explained. "They don't need a strong cheerleader. So the Old Boys' voices are not so strong on their side." Coming from such an influential person, the importance of such hints is not lost on Japan's policy makers.
Besides Mr. Tanimura, the ruling O.B.'s in this case were Minoru Nagaoka, 67, and Michio Takeuchi, 70, collectively known as "N.T.T." (Mr. Takeuchi and Mr. Nagaoka declined to be interviewed.)
 
The 'Godfathers'
 "Really, those three are not known just as O.B.'s, but as godfathers," explained Yukio Noguchi, a former bureaucrat who is now a professor at Hitotsubashi University and an expert on financial policy. "We call them 'Don.' It's very difficult to explain this process, though, because it's all informal."
He added: "They are all former vice ministers, but not all vice ministers can be godfathers. It is hard to explain how they obtain this."
The affiliations of these three give some indication of where their interests lie. Mr. Nagaoka is currently the president of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, a friend to the securities industry. Mr. Takeuchi and Mr. Tanimura are former presidents of the exchange and currently head Government-affiliated research centers connected to the securities markets. They deny favoring either side, of course, but their innate conservatism has worked to the unmistakable advantage of the securities houses, whose aim is to preserve much of the status quo and stanch competition from the banks.
Perhaps the surest sign of the power of these three Old Boys is the fact that they deny having any. If a Japanese official is asked to explain how the Old Boys do it, the answer is usually a shrug of the shoulders. But that informality lends the Old Boys even more influence, because they are not constrained by any transparent process that could be examined and criticized.
The Old Boys "have to be seen as independent of the political world, as politically neutral," Mr. Noguchi explained. "There is a real fear within the ministry that personnel decisions will be influenced by politicians. And the bureaucrats respect the Old Boys' judgment as intelligent and objective."
In fact, that is what most acknowledge in their candid moments to be the real source of the power of the O.B.'s -- their ability to influence personnel decisions. The process of determining promotions and work assignments is one of the most opaque and secretive at the Finance Ministry. Those decisions cannot be questioned and affect a bureaucrat's entire career.
Privately, several bureaucrats acknowledged that some of the more powerful Old Boys had been consulted on these assignments. Thus, no bureaucrat is willing to ignore the Old Boys' advice and risk angering them.
 
Extended Impact
 The issue now is that any changes in Article 65, as the law separating banking and the securities businesses is known, will have a bigger impact on the international realm than most of the matters on which the Old Boys are usually consulted. Permitting Japan's banks into the securities markets could make them more competitive in garnering the business of Japan's largest industrial corporations; the securities houses fear that greater competition at home could shrink their profits and make it tougher for them to build their businesses globally.
The clash over Article 65 has raged in the dim hallways of the rundown Finance Ministry building here for nearly six years. Advisory panels of outside experts, including many of the O.B.'s, have met to hammer out compromises. But in the end, accoding to many of those involved in the process, the Old Boys were able to tip the balance slightly in favor of less change.
"Yes, I would have to say that behind the scenes the Old Boys have influenced this to some degree," said Shoichi Royama, an economics professor at Osaka University and chairman of a Finance Ministry advisory panel making recommendations on financial deregulation. "The current bureaucrats always pay their respects to the Old Boys, although that does not mean the Old Boys dominate them."
The Old Boys are consulted on a range of policy questions, of which the battle over Article 65 is just the most visible. For instance, Mr. Noguchi said that in the recent battle over raising taxes on land holdings, several Old Boys had weighed in by trying to shift the power to collect property taxes to the central Government rather than local governments.
 
Sneer and Fear
 The single greatest threat to the Old Boys and the bureaucrats in the Finance Ministry are the politicians. The politicians are the only independent force that can influence bureaucratic debates, an enormous threat to the Finance Ministry. The bureaucrats both sneer at and fear the politicians.
That concern was evident recently when Tetsuo Kondo, a former bureaucrat and now a senior member of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, publicly suggested that the consumer was being forgotten in the debate on financial deregulation. Finance Ministry officials did little to hide their resentment of this intrusion into their field, all but ignoring the substance of Mr. Kondo's remarks.
But Mr. Tanimura made it clear that, as powerful as Mr. Kondo might be, there was still a higher power to be reckoned with in Japan.
"Yes, he's an Old Boy," Mr. Tanimura said, "but not as much an Old Boy as me!"

HEADLINE: Dow Drops by 10.51 to Close Below 3,000

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices gave way yesterday for the second straight day, as trading turned sluggish. Investors appeared increasingly worried that the stock market could be losing ground. Concern also grew that bond market yields, already very strong, could soon begin pulling money out of stocks and into bonds.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which lost 22.58 on Wednesday, lost 10.51 points yesterday to close at 2,994.86 -- the first time the blue-chip index had moved below the 3,000 mark since May 29. 
 Big Board trading slid to 168.3 million shares, from 186.6 million the day before. Declines led advances, 870 to 673. Birinyi Associates said that five heavy waves of program selling, some of them around 2:19 P.M., clipped 13 points off the Dow. More than a hour of yesterday's activity, the research house said, was program trading.
"The stock market's struggling," said Peter Canelo, chief investment strategist for County NatWest Securities, "and obviously bonds are the key. Bonds are pushing up to the 8.4 percent yield level."
Peter DaPuzzo, co-director of worldwide equities at Lehman Brothers, expressed concern over what he called "the new leadership in cyclicals and transportation stocks."
"Many people," Mr. DaPuzzo argued, "doubt that these cyclicals -- the smokestack stocks -- can truly lead us much higher on the Dow. Furthermore, when the rails lead the transportation index, as they're doing now, that's a concern because it usually foreshadows a decline."
While the Dow transportation index edged lower yesterday, Conrail moved ahead 3/8, to 57 3/4; Santa Fe Pacific gained 1/4, to 9 5/8; Union Pacific tacked on 3/4, to 89 3/4, and Burlington Northern ended unchanged at 33 3/8. By contrast, Delta Air Lines dropped 1 3/8, to 73 1/8; UAL 1 5/8, to 154, and AMR, parent of American Airlines, lost 1, to 65 7/8.
Other leading market indexes also weakened, including the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, and the Nasdaq and American Stock Exchange measures.
Wall Street, though, seemed divided on how far along the nation's economic recovery might be.
"There's a lot of apprehension," Mr. DaPuzzo said, "that the recovery is not so clear as people thought it'd be."
Noting that Wall Street was worried about bond yields climbing, Mr. Canelo argued that the latest economic signposts suggested that "the recession is probably over."
 
Difference in Yields
 Speaking of bonds, Mr. Canelo argued that the difference between a stock dividend yield of 3.2 percent and a bond yield of 8.4 percent was "not quite at the point where it would take money away from stocks." He added that he would not become worried until the spread widened to 5.5 percentage points or more.
That would presuppose bond yields of 8 3/4 "and if we were to get to 8 3/4," he said, "it'd be a very serious restraint -- and halt the bull market."
Among yesterday's movers, Time Warner, which slid 6 1/4 on Wednesday, plunged 11 1/4, to 99 1/2, with 1.5 million shares changing hands. The company announced plans to sell stock to shareholders at a discount, split the stock and possibly buy back preferred stock. Traders thought the plan could dilute the value of the stock.
Paramount Communications, the film company, jumped 4 1/4, to 45, with 1.6 million shares changing hands on rumors that Kohlberg, Kravis & Roberts, the Wall Street leveraged buyout firm, would team with David Geffen, the entertainment executive, to bid for Paramount. Mr. Geffen denied any involvement with Kohlberg, Kravis and people close to Kohlberg, Kravis also denied the rumor.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

COMPANIES
Time Warner said it would offer shareholders 34.5 million new shares for $63 to $105 a share. Time Warner's stock plunged for the second straight day, closing at $99.50, down $11.25, or 10 percent, on the news. On Thursday, it fell $6.25 in anticipation of the offering, which would dilute existing shares. [D1.]
The two biggest airlines posted traffic gains for May. American and United's rises were the first significant advance since the Persian Gulf war. But analysts and travel agents attributed some of the recovery to promotional ticket sales and said the big question was whether there would be a future downturn. [D1.] 
 The S.E.C. penalized Laidlaw Holdings' former chairman and chief executive for misappropriating more than $1.1 million from accounts of clients of the brokerage and asset management firm. Walter L. Twiste accepted the findings without admitting or denying guilt and agreed to be barred from the securities industry. [D4.]
Kraft General Foods confirmed that it planned to drop fat-percentage claims from some products, including cottage cheese. [D5.]
America West Airlines said that it had suspended payments to holders of leases on its planes to conserve cash. The airline said it did not expect to interrupt its flights. [D4.]
 
THE ECONOMY
Many of the nation's biggest retailers reported sales rises in May over May 1990. While sales were helped by good weather, some analysts see the gains as another indication that the recession may be ending. Among the gainers were Wal-Mart, K Mart, the Limited and the Gap. Sears, Roebuck and J. C. Penney were down. [D1.]
As Congress moves toward freer trade, some workers fear job losses but are not moving to where they might find new jobs. One family on furlough from a blanket factory in Eden, N.C., is trying to cope financially by planting a larger vegetable garden. [D1.]
More business will be provided for minority-owned companies to manage assets taken over from failed savings associations, L. William Seidman, chairman of Resolution Trust, pledged. [D2.]
American businesses plan to increase spending for expansion and modernization to $540.1 billion this year, a scant 3 percent over last year's record outlays, the Commerce Department said. [D2.]
A high-speed national data "highway" is to be developed from Internet, a national computer network. Originally used for scientifc research, it will now include commercial use. [D3.]
Bridgeport, Conn., will seek Federal bankruptcy court protection, Moody's Investors Service said. The rating service suspended the city's bond rating. [B2.]
 
MARKETS
The Dow Jones industrial average fell below the 3,000 mark, losing 10.51 points to close at 2,994.86 in sluggish trading. [D6.]
Prices of Treasury securities continued falling and interest rates moving higher, as dealers sold notes and bonds after a stronger-than-expected report on May employment data. [D12.]
The dollar rose in quiet trading, helped by the jobs report. Gold prices advanced. [D13.] Silver futures soared to an eight-month high, with the June contract at $4.414 an ounce on the Comex. [D13.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
Trade tensions were eased between the United States and Europe by this week's meeting in Paris of officials of the O.E.C.D. But tough bargaining lies ahead if the Uruguay Round of trade talks is to succeed. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Reebok, which has seen sales of its Pump basketball shoes leap to the four-million mark in 18 months, is winning accolades from athletes and Wall Street analysts alike. Market Place. [D6.]
Chrysler is betting that horse racing will pay off. Its Triple Crown Challenge combines national advertising and promotions with dealer incentive contests, showroom displays and other special events. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENT;
Harvard President Urges Social Commitment

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 6

 BODY:
In his final address after 20 years as president of Harvard University, Derek C. Bok delivered a pointed rebuke today to the country's leaders who "stand by idly" in the face of rising poverty, crime and homelessness.
Charging that "an eerie indifference hangs over the land," Mr. Bok said, "Instead of a popular outcry to end the urban violence, the poverty, the homelessness, the hunger of children, the loudest clamor we hear from the public today is 'no new taxes.' " 
 Mr. Bok, who will step down at the end of this month, spoke in Harvard Yard this afternoon after the university's 340th commencement exercises. Seated on the dais near him was Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts, a Republican who has pushed through a series of severe budget cuts to make good on a campaign pledge of no new taxes.
Mr. Weld has been widely criticized for cutting back on spending for education and social services.
 
Adorned in Top Hat
 A graduate of the Harvard class of 1966 who was celebrating his 25th reunion today, Mr. Weld was dressed in a top hat, morning coat and striped pants, befitting his status as chief marshal of his Harvard reunion class.
A descendant of one of the founders of Harvard in 1636, Mr. Weld looked on attentively as Mr. Bok decried what he said was a loss of sense of purpose by American universities over the past two decades. Where universities long believed they existed to train the nation's leaders and develop its science, Mr. Bok said, there is now "a buzzing confusion of complaints."
Universities are under attack by the public and the government for rising tuitions, for their financial aid practices, for affirmative action programs and for expanding beyond a traditional curriculum of Western studies, Mr. Bok said.
Mr. Bok told an audience of more than 20,000 students, family members, professors and alumni that the criticism of universities should instead be that their "research on school reform, poverty, crime and many other social afflictions lags far behind the urgency of these problems for our society."
Harvard and other universities must redefine their "social mission," Mr. Bok said. This is especially true, he said, at a time when "education for humane citizenship is a stunted enterprise, and preparation for teaching and most of the other helping professions suffers from benign neglect."
Mr. Bok shared the platform this afternoon with the former Soviet foreign minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who delivered a short speech calling for a global ban on nuclear weapons tests. Mr. Shevardnadze, who was awarded an honorary degree by Harvard today, said he had become concerned that with the euphoria over the ending of the cold war, "we have become too complacent about the danger of nuclear catastrophe."
At a press conference later, Mr. Shevardnadze said he welcomed President Bush's decision to let Mr. Gorbachev attend a meeting of the Group of Seven Industrialized Nations in London in July to appeal for Western aid to help the ailing Soviet economy. But he said he did not expect any substantive decisions there on Western aid.
Instead, Mr. Shevardnadze said, the Soviet Union must work harder to reform its own economy to make it more attractive for foreign investment.
Mr. Shevardnadze said he was "green with envy" as he listened to a report on fund raising by Harvard alumni this afternoon, particularly that the 25th reunion class alone had contributed more than $5 million this year.
Among the other honorary degree recipients were the novelist Andrei Sinyavsky, a Russian dissident; the cellist Yo-Yo Ma; the architecture critic Ada Louise Huxtable, and Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund.
Harvard awarded 1,550 undergraduate degrees and 3,646 graduate degrees.
 
School of Visual Arts
In T-shirts and sneakers, in glittering dresses -- in just about anything but cap and gown -- the 500 graduates of the School of Visual Arts went through the school's 41st commencement exercises yesterday at Avery Fisher Hall.
A school tradition dictates mufti or evening wear as the fashion for commencement. A slide show of all the graduates, some dressed in even odder outfits, is also shown before the ceremony.
The speaker at the commencement was the actor Eli Wallach.

Mr. Shevardnadze, in a speech to the graduates, called for a global test ban on nuclear weapons. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A Bull Market for Fraud Emerges in Hard Times

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
In New Jersey this spring, thousands of people signed up for high-paying jobs rebuilding Kuwait. Many of the jobs did not exist. But hefty application fees did.
In Connecticut, hucksters appealed to the public to donate money to buy water filters for troops growing thirsty and sick in the Saudi Arabian desert. 
 Around the nation, law-enforcement officials say, this is a banner year for con artists who have exploited anxieties about recession and war to separate an unwary public from its money. In times of economic uncertainty, they say, the public is more susceptible to ploys that promise quick fortunes or instant relief to their worries.
"Right now it is a prime market for swindlers," said James Allen Fox, a professor of criminal justice at Northeastern University in Boston. "When times are good there are many ways to strike it rich legitimately. When the times go sour, people from the shady side come out and offer opportunities."
 
Postal Service Tracks Fraud
 One of the few government agencies that keeps statistics on consumer fraud, the United States Postal Inspection Service, which investigates mail frauds, says it has investigated 1,659 cases in the first eight months of this fiscal year, up from 1,299 for all of the fiscal year 1987, when the agency began keeping track.
Law-enforcement officials in many states say they have seen a sharp rise in complaints about false promises of jobs or access to credit cards or loans.
In New Jersey, officials said they were struck with a wave of complaints this spring about offers of high-paying jobs in Kuwait from companies that advertised in local newspapers. Many of the companies, they say, had no connection with construction projects.
Patricia A. Royer, director of the state's Division of Consumer Affairs, said several charged $19.95 or $29.95 for the telephone numbers of government offices offering free information.
Another company took no money, exacting a toll only in promises it could not keep. Ms. Royer said Omne Maintenance Engineers in Union, N.J., took 4,000 applications for jobs in Kuwait that it said would pay up to $57.50 an hour. On one day alone more than 1,000 job hunters lined up outside the company's offices.
"The prospect of lucrative employment rebuilding Kuwait seemed like a dream come true," Ms. Royer said. "It was the talk of union halls. People took days off to apply and made plans to quit their jobs."
The company, she said, apparently planned to use the names of the electricians, carpenters and plumbers it gathered to start an employment service that would approach construction companies and offer them lists of workers. The company signed a consent order agreeing to send postcards to the applicants saying that it had no contracts for work in Kuwait. Omne was also fined $3,500.
 
Water Filters for Soldiers
 In Connecticut, the Department of Consumer Protection reported that consumer fraud complaints rose to more than 3,000 in the first five months of 1991 from about 2,000 in the first five months of 1990.
The department is investigating complaints about phone pitches describing troops sick from bad water in Saudi Arabia and offering to send soldiers a $49.95 water purifier in exchange for a $10 contribution.
A spokesman for the New York Attorney General, Robert Abrams, said his office estimated that consumer fraud complaints had risen more than 50 percent since last summer. The spokesman, Edward Barbini, said that in one case, a Manhattan company advertised that loans and grants were available to people who had bad credit ratings if they telephoned (900) USA-LOAN.
 
Alchemic Fraud
 Callers "only got the list of Federal agencies that offer housing loans and project grants," he said. "Perhaps the biggest surprise was that the calls cost each consumer $50 or more."
Many cases being investigated by the Postal Inspection Service involve imaginative get-rich quick schemes, said Paul Griffo, a spokesman for the service. For example, a California company offered to sell consumers tons of dirt from an abandoned gold mine in the Nevada hills for $16,000. The company promised that a new technology could extract gold ore that had been left behind by miners of the Comstock Lode in 1876.
But the mine never produced any gold, said Kacy McClelland, the postal inspector who investigated the case. The ads did not mention that the Comstock Lode was actually a famous silver strike. The president of the company, Murray Brooks of Westminster, Calif., was arrested in March and charged with mail and securities fraud.

HEADLINE: No Needy Mother, Just a Con Artist, Brooklyn Police Say

BYLINE: By CRAIG WOLFF

 BODY:
From house to house the woman went with a heart-wrenching tale. Her little boy, 7-year-old Joey Lupa, had died of leukemia and there was no money for a proper burial. She cried and shared her sorrows with the people who came to the doors. "Would you give, please?" she asked. And people all over Brooklyn and Queens did, donating at least $25,000 -- money now locked in a police evidence room.
Yesterday, Rose Pannizzo was arrested and charged with scheming to defraud, grand larceny and criminal impersonation, the police said. 
 There is no 7-year-old named Joey Lupa who died of leukemia, said Sgt. Tadgh McNamee, supervisor of the Community Policing Unit at the 63d Precinct. There is only a woman who over the last two and a half months did a despicable thing, he said. She traveled from her home in East New York to tap the hearts and wallets of her good neighbors in the Mill Basin, Marine Park, Bay Ridge, Canarsie and Bensonhurst sections of Brooklyn and Howard Beach, Queens, he said.
The officer who arrested her, Gregory Bacalles, had heard about Ms. Pannizzo from residents who said, "Isn't it a shame about that little Joey Lupa boy?" said Sgt. McNamee. The officer, eager to demonstrate the Police Department's community spirit, sought out the woman, called Rose by residents along his beat in Bergen Beach.
He wanted to ask if the police could help. But compassion turned to suspicion when residents gave different accounts of where she lived.
When she was arrested at 71st Street and Avenue W in Bergen Beach, Ms. Pannizzo was carrying a stenographer's notebook with 297 entries listing addresses and contributions ranging from $10 to $100.
The police found her 1982 Lincoln Continental parked nearby. In the front seat were ledgers listing an additional 1,014 cash donations and a few checks, including some from churches.
Ms. Pannizzo admitted the crime, Sergeant McNamee said, saying she needed the money for her unemployed husband and several children, which could not be immediately confirmed.
Asked how she swayed so many people, the sergeant said: "She has the gift of gab. She's been at the station house for two hours and she already has all the officers buying her candy and soda. They feel sorry for her."
